column2: LEAD: Chris Davila scored two of his three touchdowns in the fourth quarter as Midwood rallied yesterday to beat South Shore, 20-19, in a game that broke a first-place tie in the Public School Athletic League's Brooklyn A Division I. Midwood's record is now 7-1, and it has a berth in the playoffs that start in two weeks.

LEAD: Bing Quon Chu, a businessman and leader of Chinese-American organizations, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Booth Memorial Hospital in Flushing, Queens. He was 65 years old and a resident of Flushing.
LEAD: A map of Chicago on Sept. 27 misidentified a road south of Congress Parkway; it is Balbo Drive, not Balboa Drive.

LEAD: ''TOUCH water and you touch everything'' in the West, John Gunther wrote in ''Inside USA'' in 1947. And the engineers of the United States Bureau of Reclamation did not just touch the West's great rivers, they transformed them, turning dry and dusty wastelands into a modern-day Mesopotamia.
LEAD: SONGS don't have to be number one on the charts to be hits in Wisconsin, as Gov.

LEAD: The engagement of Dr. Jacqueline Anne Leavitt to Lieut. Scott Latham Stafford, U.S.N., has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Carlton Leavitt of Washington and York Beach, Me., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Jim Stafford of Seattle and the late Alice Stafford.
LEAD: Imagine that someday the Mets and the Yankees really do play a Subway World Series. Could the Series actually be decided by Randy Velarde?
LEAD: NAVIGATING the winding roads of Litchfield County without the aid of a map, Francine Scherer zeroes in on farms tucked snugly in the hills and invisible from the main road.

LEAD: IT happened incrementally, and for a long time few realized the magnitude and import of what was going on. But over the last quarter-century and especially in the last decade, the American metropolis has been transformed into something new and different. Suburbs, once dependent on the central city, have metamorphosed into vast, glittering, independent ''outer cities'' that rival and often surpass the traditional big-city downtowns as centers of economic power and vitality.
LEAD: HE was guardian of the Bolshevik Revolution, defender of its faith, a disciple whose oratory enthralled the masses.

LEAD: AS the sun sets over the Hudson River a few blocks away, a woman walks her dog down a cobblestone street. Outside his brownstone, a man beats a rug with a broom. It is 1987, but the setting is turn of the century, for history has left its mark on the Far West Village.
LEAD: FOX'S DREAM By Tejima. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: Philomel Books. $13.95. (Ages 3 and up)

LEAD: Kirkland Graham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome J. Graham Jr. of New Vernon, N.J., was married there yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King to Timothy Frederick DeLaney, a son of Robert J. DeLaney of New York and the late Irene Dolbear DeLaney. Msgr. John F. Corr officiated. The bride, a graduate of the Kent Place School and Lafayette College, is a researcher in the news archives department of NBC News.

LEAD: IT WAS A SUNNY afternoon in Los Angeles, and the researchers at Alan Kay's computer lab were outside on the playground, shrieking their way through recess. Inside, in the art room of a rather down-at-the-heels elementary school in West Hollywood, a group of local technologists - people from the University of California at Los Angeles, the Rand Corporation, the International Business Machines Corporation, Pacific Telesis, the Times Mirror Company - were gathered around Formica-topped tables to hear Kay talk.

LEAD: SOMETIME next year, probably in the summer, condominiums at a new waterfront development called Jonathan's Landing are to go on sale. To find them, prospective buyers will drive along a new road on a sliver of landfill that juts into Gravesend Bay on the South Brooklyn shore.

LEAD: NOW that Halloween is over, most Americans look forward to only one more use for the abundant pumpkin crop: in the Thanksgiving pie. That is a pity, because this estimable member of the squash family has a multitude of other delicious uses.
LEAD: WHEN THE FAT MAN SINGS By William Murray. 216 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $14.95.

LEAD: A total of $1.4 million for housing for the homeless has been awarded to three nonprofit organizations in Westchester and will be used to help create apartments for 26 families and a communal house for five individuals. The money came from the New York State Homeless Housing Assistance Program, which gave $20 million for 24 projects across the state.

LEAD: In his article ''Homosexuals and the Churches'' (Oct. 11), Edward Tivnan writes that ''research seems now to indicate [ that ] one has no choice in being homosexual.'' The premise is an astonishingly broad one and cannot be allowed to pass unconsidered.
LEAD: National pride was ample and undisguised last month when Susumu Tonegawa became the first Japanese to win the Nobel Prize in medicine.
LEAD: THE Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles, host to vivacious movie stars and ambitious politicians in a glittering era now gone, prepared its last rites.

LEAD: LAST August, when the weather was hot and stocks were high, Edward M. Kerschner, an investment strategist at PaineWebber Inc., felt that something was wrong. With the precision of a seismograph, Mr. Kerschner's indictors showed the stock market was headed for a fall. To his clients, he issued a warning: ''Stocks are now unattractive for the first time since 1984.

LEAD: ''A LOT of parents don't know what to tell their kids about using alcohol, except to 'be responsible,' '' said Deirdre M. Breen, a community-education specialist with the Westchester chapter of the National Council on Alcoholism and Other Drug Addictions. ''They believe that they are good kids, and then cross their fingers when they go out to a party.

LEAD: Saying that he would ''much rather be here talking about arms control or the stock market crash,'' Senator Albert Gore Jr. volunteered at a state convention in Miami yesterday that he had occasionally smoked marijuana as a student and as a soldier in Vietnam.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Reid Heminway of Middlebury, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Molly Lewis Heminway to Charles Edward Keeble Moseley, the son of Mrs. Richard Curtis Miles of New York and Greenwich, Conn., and the late Charles Guy Moseley.

LEAD: For more than a decade, friends and police investigators say, Joel B. Steinberg physically and emotionally abused his lover, Hedda Nussbaum. And in that time, they say, a woman who once was an intelligent and effective editor and author seemed to lose all self-respect and become unable to extricate or defend herself.
LEAD: High on a plateau of the west bank of the Schuylkill, overlooking Fairmount Park and the city beyond, stands a butter-colored mansion.

LEAD: THE appearance of such desirable crop traits as disease resistance was once a very gradual process, governed by the laws of natural selection and aided, perhaps, by tedious selective breeding by farmers. Now agricultural scientists are doing in the laboratory in a matter of days or weeks, what once took years.

LEAD: SOMETIMES it is the winners who proclaim, ''Wait till next year.'' Certainly that was the underlying gleeful tone of New York State Democratic leaders last week as they savored upset victories in important city and county elections and declared that the results boded well for Democrats nationally in the 1988 elections.

LEAD: PAUL VOLCKER'S TELEPHONE keeps ringing. The callers ask for his advice or sound him out on how much damage has been done. Even out on the street, Volcker can't escape his questioners. At 6 feet, 8 inches, he is hard to miss. So people stop him to ask, ''Are we going to be all right?'' or to say, ''We need you back in Washington.
LEAD: ''This is a country where people think 2 percent inflation is already too high.''

LEAD: IT CAME to my attention recently that October had once again been designated by sex-education groups as National Family Sexuality Education Month. Not knowing quite how to mark the occasion or whether businesses would be closed, I stayed put and gave it a little thought: What should the young learn about sex that they do not already know?
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Wendy Sue Levine, the daughter of Jane N. Levine of Clifton, N.J., and Dr. Frank L. Levine of Saddle Brook, N.J., was married last evening to Jonathan L. Mechanic, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Mayer Mechanic of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi David Panitz and his son, Rabbi Michael Panitz, officiated at the Park Lane Hotel in New

LEAD: SEVEN YEARS AGO I ATTENDED a concert by the late blues giant Muddy Waters that forever changed my assumption that rock music made by musicians over 50 could only look foolish. Mr. Waters, then 66, looked every day of his age. But when he barked out such bump-and-grind blues classics as ''I'm Your Hoochie Coochie Man'' and ''Got My Mojo Working,'' the singer-guitarist exuded a gruff charisma that was commandingly ferocious.

LEAD: IN the past, day care has been perceived by critics as service for people outside of mainstream family life - ''people with problems,'' professionals in the field say. When nuclear families were intact and most mothers could stay home, day care, it was thought, met the needs of only a few.

LEAD: Consumers don't seem too worried about the general state of the economy, to judge from the first indicators of their sentiments since the stock market collapse. Polls produced mixed, somewhat puzzling responses, but none of them seemed to portend a widespread movement to swear off spending. A similar reading emerged from the sales indicators.

LEAD: In light of tougher positions by Iran and Iraq on how to end their war, the chances for an American-led initiative to impose a global arms embargo against Iran seem increasingly bleak, according to White House and State Department officials.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: THE YEAR WITHOUT MICHAEL By Susan Beth Pfeffer. 164 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $13.95. (Ages 12 and up)
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IT'S the time of year when I start feeling sorry for the man from United Parcel Service. Almost daily he has to lug an armload of coffee-table sized photography books, still warm from the presses, into my apartment. It's getting close to Christmas, which means (to book publishers, at least) that it is a grand time for luxurious, eye-catching books.

LEAD: Ursula Meese said it was no worse than her husband's writing that ''Ursula and I send our best regards'' without consulting her first. But some legal experts saw it differently. What the wife of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d had written to a Federal judge last June - without, she said, consulting Mr.

LEAD: WHETHER it's the nature of the job or of the people who fill it, a United States Attorney is typically on the quiet side. Because Rudolph W. Giuliani is not, the Federal prosecutor's office in Manhattan is probably more in the public mind than ever before. Mr. Giuliani's own image has been well-exposed, too, which should not hurt if he decides, as is widely speculated, to seek the Republican nomination for the

LEAD: Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, the 51-year-old army general who yesterday became Tunisia's second President since it won independence from France in 1956, started out to become an electronics engineer.
LEAD: Q. I have a lot of oil stains on my asphalt driveway. What should I use on these stains before I apply a sealer?

LEAD: The complete account of how and why President Reagan surprised many in the Senate and the Administration nine days ago by choosing for the Supreme Court a little-known 41-year-old judge championed by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is not yet known.

LEAD: NOT SO MANY years have passed since arithmetic teachers faced up to the grim prospect of classrooms full of cheap electronic calculators, enabling students to sidestep the painstaking memorization of multiplication tables. What would happen, educators wondered, when these students went on to try the rigors of calculus?
LEAD: In this city loud with the blare of car horns, the cries of hawkers and the late-night bang of construction, there is a new sound: the talk of politics.
LEAD: The owner of the Sands Hotel and Casino has announced that it will build a second casino hotel here, saying the 1990's will bring ''exploding'' growth in Atlantic City.

LEAD: Closings in the week ended Oct. 24 MANHATTAN East Midtown $200,000 150 East 56th Street 1-bedroom. 1-bath, 880-sq.-ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, hardwood floors; common charge $649, taxes $2,853 (Broker:

LEAD: At St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Middlebury, Vt., Sarah Clifford, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas R. Clifford of Cornwall, Vt., was married yesterday to Ledlie Irwin Laughlin 3d, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Laughlin Jr. of New York and South Woodstock, Vt. The ceremony was performed by the Rev.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Cromwell Starring Richard Harris and Alec Guinness. Directed and written by Ken Hughes. 1970. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 139 minutes. $69.95. This is a large-scale movie that a critic called ''shapeless'' in 1970 when it came to theater screens. It is a truncated biography of Oliver Cromwell, who is portrayed as a last, if not only, angry man by Richard

LEAD: ARGENTINA is a lot more than Buenos Aires, its cosmopolitan capital. Its million square miles stretch from the Tropic of Capricorn almost to the Antarctic, and from the Atlantic deep into the Andes. The two-hour air journey from Buenos Aires to Salta, where the mountains meet the tropics, is a voyage into a different geography, climate and culture.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Workers have begun installing tiny tunnels on a street to protect migrating salamanders from cars.

LEAD: BEFORE World War II, Berlin ranked among the great cities of the world, and many images from that time are familiar to us: the grandeur of Unter den Linden, the cosmopolitan elegance of the Hotel Adlon, the brimming activity of Potsdamer Platz and Alexanderplatz. But these places were destroyed, surviving today only in photographs that scarcely represent their grand subjects.

LEAD: I am writing to comment on the article ''Decline in Students at Medical Schools'' that appeared Oct. 4. As a board-certified family practice physician of 25 years, I have seen the changes occurring in medicine that are deterring the best students of the best colleges from choosing medicine as a lifelong profession.

LEAD: THE PINCE-NEZ AND THE PUSH broom mustache have a lot to do with the visceral response of the audience to Len Cariou's entrance, in ''Teddy and Alice.'' The generous sprinklings of ''Bully!'' through the dialogue don't hurt, either.

LEAD: AS ITS TITLE MAKES CLEAR, and the film itself makes even clearer, ''Gaby - A True Story'' is about a real woman and her real travails. Gabriela Brimmer was born with cerebral palsy, and without command of any muscles except those in her left foot. That foot became her only means of communication: she could spell out words by pointing her big toe at an alphabet board.

LEAD: IF one polled the bridge cognoscenti and asked them to identify the best player of all time the result would be in doubt. But there is no doubt at all that B. Jay Becker, who died last month at his home in Flushing, Queens, at age 83 would be on every short list.

LEAD: Olivia Bell Mason and Christopher John Beukers, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Beukers of Stony Brook, L.I., and Longborough, England, plan to marry next month, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Mason of Palm Beach, Fla., have announced.

LEAD: At the Beth El Synagogue Center in New Rochelle, N.Y., Melissa Epstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Epstein of Yonkers, was married last evening to Dr. Elliot Regenbogen, the son of of Helen Regenbogen of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Irving Regenbogen. Rabbi Melvin Serner officiated.

LEAD: For most of the three centuries that people have inhabited this marshy island in the middle of Chesapeake Bay, daily life has been governed by tide, wind, season, isolation and the Methodist church.
LEAD: Leslie P. Kamen and Dr. Donald L. Siegel were married last evening at the Copacabana in New York by Rabbi Stanley A. Dreyfus.

LEAD: THE COMMON RESPONSE TO the question of what architects can do to solve the crisis of affordable housing for middle- and lower-income people is: not much. Architects really do not have the power to alleviate this problem on their own, the reasoning goes, and significant solutions will have to wait for the time when the Government decides to spend some money.
LEAD: IT WAS like a family celebration.

LEAD: THE ARK IN THE ATTIC An Alphabet Adventure. By Eileen Doolittle. Photographs by Starr Ockenga. Painted backgrounds by Eileen Doolittle. Unpaged. Boston: A Floyd Yearout Book/David R. Godine. $18.95. (All ages) THE Z WAS ZAPPED By Chris Van Allsburg. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company.
LEAD: Senior Soviet officials said today that high-level attention would be required to resolve remaining technical differences in a treaty to eliminate intermediate range missiles.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-29
LEAD: AN ARTIFICIAL WILDERNESS Essays on 20th-Century Literature. By Sven Birkerts. 430 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $20.95.

LEAD: The defendant before Federal Judge R. Allan Edgar was the son of a Congressman, so pleas for leniency from influential quarters could be expected. But the Judge still must have been startled by a letter from Ursula Meese urging ''very favorable consideration'' for Joe Duncan, who stood convicted of tax fraud.

LEAD: House Speaker Jim Wright turned down a request by Nicaraguan officials to serve as an intermediary in cease-fire talks between the Sandinista Government and Nicaraguan rebels, diplomatic officials said today.
LEAD: ''I have today asked President Reagan not to forward my nomination to the Supreme Court.'' - Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg. [ 1:6. ]

LEAD: THE Arias plan for peace in Central America registered an accomplishment last week that had eluded the United States Government in nearly seven years of political and clandestine military conflict with Nicaragua. The Sandinista Government was placed on the defensive and obliged to accept indirect negotiations with the contra rebels.

LEAD: Govan A. Mbeki, who was confined in a South African prison 23 years ago for talk of taking arms against the system that ordered his imprisonment, was released last week. Mr. Mbeki, a longtime leader of the outlawed African National Congress and a close associate of Nelson R. Mandela, is now 77 years old and in ill health.

LEAD: IF many in the West found Mikhail S. Gorbachev's keenly anticipated speech on Monday timorous in its reappraisal of the Soviet past, it also contained suggestions of flexibility in the Soviet future - suggestions that will further complicate the problems of Western policy makers who wish to exploit new opportunities while maintaining a healthy skepticism.
LEAD: 17 KINGS AND 42 ELEPHANTS By Margaret Mahy. Illustrated by Patricia MacCarthy. Unpaged. New York: Dial Books for Young Readers. $10.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

LEAD: The marriage of Melissa I. Althoff, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Althoff of Maytown, Pa., to Jonathan A. Schein took place last evening at the Carlyle Hotel in New York. Rabbi Joel Goor performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Barbara R. Herman of Westport, Conn., and Gerald D. Schein of New

LEAD: ALAIN PROST MUSCLED THE TITANIUM SHIFT into sixth gear, dialed up the 1,200-horsepower turbo booster and flung his iridescent red-and-white Formula One race car past the Estoril grandstands at 180 miles per hour, faster than an F-15 jet fighter on takeoff. Prost, twice the world champion, was waging a record-breaking duel with Gerhard Berger in the dramatic closing minutes of the 70-lap 1987 Portuguese Grand Prix, one of 16 races in the Formula One Grand Prix championship, the World

LEAD: Fay Chiang's father summarized his life in 10 minutes shortly before he died of cancer in 1974. Only then did the daughter learn that he had started working in this country at the age of 10 in a laundry.
LEAD: Exploring this low island in the mouth of Africa's largest harbor, a black American visitor mused, ''This island almost belongs more to America than to Africa.''
LEAD: Federal prosecutors have rested their case after presenting more than 100 witnesses, 360 taped conversations and 1,000 exhibits in a trial focusing on the Genovese crime family.

LEAD: To the Editor: I recently had my passport wallet stolen from my jacket on a night train from Cologne to Stuttgart. What ensued might interest your readers. I reported my loss to the Stuttgart railway police about 6:30 A.M.: my passport, first-class German rail pass (with six days' validity remaining) and cash.

LEAD: The Vermont chapter of the Nature Conservancy is stepping up efforts to protect the state's endangered common loons, having acquired one nesting site recently and hoping to purchase another one soon.

LEAD: Ellen DaCosta Harris, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Harris of Winnetka, Ill., and Henry E. Knoblock 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Knoblock Jr. of Duxbury, Mass., were married last evening at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Cambridge, Mass., by the Rev. Gerald P. Cohen.

LEAD: Susan S. Fiske, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Fiske Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to P. Russell Williams Jr., a son of Mrs. Eugene Stringham of Newtown, Conn., and Peter R. Williams of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Anne Kimball performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme,

LEAD: THE ECONOMY Gross National Product III Q'87 II Q'87 Year Ago Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in billions $3,831.2 $3,795.3 $3,683.3 Real G.N.P. Growth Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in percent 3.8 2.5 2.4 Corporate After-Tax Profits II Q'87 I Q'87 Year Ago In billions, annual rate $134.5 $136.6 $138.0

LEAD: CINCINNATI, Nov. 7 - When residents and merchants in this city's Hyde Park neighborhood decided that a small piece of roadside parkland known as the Mudhole needed a better image, they set out to dress it up with a piece of public sculpture.

LEAD: Karen Straw killed her husband, but in September a Queens jury acquitted her of murder after hearing defense evidence that she was a battered wife. Soon, a Manhattan jury is to begin to hear testimony in the trial of Robert Chambers for the murder of Jennifer Levin in Central Park. Mr. Chambers claims Ms.

LEAD: They have been ridiculed, laughed at and branded losers, but yesterday, the long blue line of Columbia Lions was given a respectful round of applause as the players trudged quietly from the field to the locker room after the game. The Lions, though, did not acknowledge the fans. Some, like Matt Sodl, the senior defensive end, were crying.

LEAD: THE YELLOW UMBRELLA By Henrik Drescher. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: Bradbury Press. $9.95. (Ages 2 to 5) RAINBOW RHINO By Peter Sis. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95. (Ages 3 to 5)

LEAD: AT THE TRIAL, Shyamala Rajender had to endure what she calls ''a pack of lies'' hurled at her by the University of Minnesota, where she used to teach chemistry. ''They said I was not a good teacher, that I was not a good researcher, that I didn't compare with any of the bright stars in the department,'' she recalled, the anger barely veiled in her voice after more than a decade of grievance procedures and litigation that finally forced the university to grant her tenure.
LEAD: CONDEMNED TO REPETITION The United States and Nicaragua. By Robert A. Pastor. Illustrated. 392 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $24.95.
LEAD: SOME SOUL TO KEEP By J. California Cooper. 211 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $14.95.

LEAD: UNTIL the stock market plunge three weeks ago, banks and stock brokers consumed Manhattan office space like hungry boys at a Sunday morning buffet. But now they are running scared, seeking to slim down.
LEAD: The former mistress of a neo-Nazi gang leader has told a jury her lover confided to her that his gang planned the killing of a Denver radio talk show host.
LEAD: A Federal judge has rejected an heiress's bid for the property of a fundamentalist church that the woman had forced into bankruptcy through a lawsuit.

LEAD: I laughed until I had tears in my eyes when I read Russell Baker's column ''Computer Fallout'' (Sunday Observer, Oct. 11). The word processor reigns supreme in my house, and many's the time that writing a brief paragraph stretches into two hours of painstaking adding, deleting and. . . .
LEAD: THE GREAT TRIUMVIRATE Webster, Clay, and Calhoun. By Merrill D. Peterson. Illustrated. 573 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $27.95

LEAD: IF Pete Malinverni were slightly more explicit about the melodies he plays on the piano, he might be accused of being a cocktail pianist. But the melodies in his improvisations are elusive, and his running, single-note lines sometimes have a Count Basie touch or a suggestion of Willard Robison's down-home reminiscences.
LEAD: DEMOCRACY, ITALIAN STYLE By Joseph LaPalombara. 308 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $25.

LEAD: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV gave a politician's speech last week on the troublesome topic of his country's history. It did not play very well in the West, where many expected a historian's speech, but it was probably not intended to. It was a speech for domestic consumption, crafted for a society with a willful reverence for its version of the past.

LEAD: RULES FOR EAGLE WATCHERS Ever since the Shepaug Eagle Observation area was set up in 1985, bird lovers in the state have been swarming to the site and unwittingly disturbing the eagles' privacy. This year, however, the Department of Environmental Protection has set up some regulations to protect wintering bald eagles from the overwhelming number of visitors.
LEAD: DINING out in Wilton presents a challenge, and the paucity of restaurant choices is usually blamed on the town's prohibition of liquor sales in public places.
LEAD: More than 200 people, concerned about dwindling bank services in East Harlem, met yesterday to assess the impact of the problem on the predominantly black and Hispanic community.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: BLACK SWAN. By Christopher Hope. Illustrated by Gillian Barlow. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) This moving, lyrical novel, the author's fourth, is set in South Africa in 1965. Its hero, 17-year-old Lucky, is an idiot savant who lives with his adoptive grandmother in a black township. The boy is able to mimic perfectly the voices and manners of movie and radio personalities, but defies all outside attempts to pull him out of his dream world.

LEAD: PLANS are taking shape for new headquarters for the American Medical Association west of Michigan Avenue and north of the Loop, signaling the long-awaited, full-scale redevelopment of the River North district into a mixed-use adjunct to the rapidly expanding downtown.

LEAD: Senator William Alden Smith may not have known that a ship's ''bow'' is different from a ship's ''head,'' but William F. Buckley Jr. apparently does not know that a ship's bulkheads are different from a ship's watertight doors.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: SINCE 1981, the Federal minimum wage has been frozen at $3.35 an hour, which translates to an annual income of less than $7,000. Fearing inflation and opposing Government encroachment on the marketplace, the Reagan Administration has been dead set against increasing the figure.

LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d has told Congressional budget negotiators that he is ready to discuss a substantive package of tax increases but that in return he wants a commitment from Democrats on how much domestic spending they are willing to cut, participants in the talks said today.
LEAD: Eric Ball, playing in place of injured Gaston Green, rushed for 128 yards and three touchdowns today as U.C.L.A. routed Oregon State, 52-17, in a Pacific-10 Conference game.

LEAD: At Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., Nancy Ellen Garfinkel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Garfinkel of Plainview, L.I., was married last evening to Martin Scott Eller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Eller of Morganville, N.J. Rabbi Gilbert Klaperman officiated.
LEAD: SENATE

LEAD: THE BOOK OF ADAM TO MOSES By Lore Segal. Illustrated by Leonard Baskin. 115 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95. (All ages) ADAM AND EVE The Bible Story. Adapted and illustrated by Warwick Hutton. Unpaged. New York: Margaret K. McElderry Books. $13.95. (All ages)
LEAD: For the last week, Haitians have been witnessing the unfolding of a campaign of terror apparently intended to disrupt elections and preserve the old order of the Duvalier family dictatorship.
LEAD: Forty-five years ago, right after the destruction of this village 15 miles west of Prague, great homage was paid to its martyred people.
LEAD: Rent-Stabilized in a Hotel

LEAD: William B. Beam, a retired executive vice president of the American Express International Banking Corporation, died of kidney failure Tuesday at Baylor Hospital in Dallas. He was 62 years old and lived in Dallas and Swiftwater, Pa. Until 1985, he also lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Where were all those insouciant, club-crazed Angelenos last year, when several hundred other people were beginning their march of over 3,000 miles across the United States in the cause of peace?

LEAD: Todd Santos became the National Collegiate Athletic Association career passing leader in Division I-A today, but his San Diego State team lost to Brigham Young, 38-21, in a Western Athletic Conference game.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: DURING registration at Dartmouth College, students can pick up forms, course material and a sex-education packet containing a condom, a dental dam for oral sex, and an explicit pamphlet explaining how to have safer sex in the era of AIDS. When they go to the library they can also get a condom when they check out a book.
LEAD: LEGISLATION to protect tenants has recently been a source of controversy in Garden City.
LEAD: Unesco's General Conference voted overwhelmingly today to elect Federico Mayor Zaragoza, a former Spanish Education Minister, as its next Director General.

LEAD: THEY ARE the children of the children of the 60's, growing up in an age when much of what seemed outrageous then is commonplace. Yet in many ways, today's teen-agers are having to sort through an ambiguous and contested legacy. The sexual revolution in America bequeathed them a social code that is explicit yet no longer liberated, and an atmosphere in which adolescents are scrutinized more publicly than ever before, yet given little guidance by the adults they must answer to.

LEAD: Officials of the Komsomol, the 40-million member youth arm of the Soviet Communist Party, have drafted a proposal to assert control over independent political groups that have sprung up in answer to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's call for a measure of democracy.

LEAD: AN ACTOR By Brooke Goffstein. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: A Charlotte Zolotow Book/ Harper & Row. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 8) AN ACTOR'S LIFE FOR ME! By Lillian Gish. As told to Selma G. Lanes. Illustrated by Patricia Henderson Lincoln. 80 pp. New York: Viking Kestrel. $14.95.

LEAD: The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Karl P. Donfried of Amherst, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Erika Donfried, to Alan Edward Untereiner, the son of Dr. Wayne Whitlock Untereiner of Rancho California, Calif., and the late Ann Yeomans Abbott. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: WHEN Robert F. Wagner Jr. was a young New York City Councilman at Large he suggested, only half jokingly, that a fire alarm be set off at 110 Livingston Street, the turn-of-the-century building in downtown Brooklyn that houses the city's Board of Education. The offices would be emptied and the doors locked, and the school bureaucrats should never be allowed to return.

LEAD: After the successive failures of two nominations to fill the vacancy on the Supreme Court, the White House and the Justice Department must again search for a nominee whose ideological credentials can satisfy Republican conservatives and still permit confirmation in a Democratic-controlled Senate.
LEAD: MAURICE SENDAK ON children: ''I have none.

LEAD: The Green Mountain Club will make its first major land purchase along the Long Trail, thanks to a $120,000 state grant awarded this week. The purchase of three miles of trail in Lowell also will be made with a $120,000 loan from the Vermont chapter of the Nature Conservancy. About 35 miles of the 265-mile trail is up for sale, jeopardizing the continuity and integrity of the foot path.

LEAD: Sherry is an 8-year-old for whom it is an achievement to sit upright, strapped into her wheelchair. She has profound mental and physical disabilities. She cannot feed or dress herself. She cannot talk. She cannot walk.

LEAD: Year after year the selection of baseball's most valuable players is an almost arbitrary choice between two players equally worthy of the award - one seemingly deserving on the basis of statistical achievement, the other for leadership of a pennant winning ball club. Why not establish a new annual award to honor the ''Slugger of the Year'' in each league?

LEAD: TO FIND THE PFEFFER-muhle, just follow Bach's disapproving gaze. Standing on his sooty granite pedestal by the side of Leipzig's old St. Thomas Church, where he used to direct the choir, he glowers at a wooden door across the way from which, in the evening, come muffled bursts of laughter.

LEAD: THE waiting for OS/2 is almost over. The International Business Machines Corporation announced here on Tuesday that the first version of OS/2, the advanced operating system for the more powerful members of its personal computer family, will be in the stores Dec. 4.

LEAD: White House officials and Congressional leaders have worked out the basic elements of a compromise over arms control issues that until now had placed the two sides on a collision course, Administration and Congressional officials disclosed today.

LEAD: THERE is a war going on here. It is an intercommunal war between Israelis and Palestinians. In Lebanon a similar war between ethnic communities has resulted in the destruction of buildings and whole cities, which makes it easy to detect. But in Israel the Government and its security force are strong, the lid is more tightly sealed, and so, day to day, the war is harder to see.
LEAD: PRINTMAKING IN FRANCE

LEAD: Jamie Fiske, whose parents drew wide attention in 1982 with public appeals for organ donors, turns 6 years old on Thanksgiving Day, which doctors consider an important milestone in the girl's recovery from a liver transplant operation five years ago.

LEAD: IT was, in some respects, a New York City subway shooting with similarities to the Goetz case. But it has a different ending. Like Bernhard H. Goetz, James Grimes, a subway token clerk in Brooklyn, carried an unlicensed pistol because he said he had been mugged before. And like Mr. Goetz, Mr. Grimes fired the weapon at four men he said were trying to rob him.
LEAD: Q. I have a lot of oil stains on my asphalt driveway. What should I use on these stains before I apply a sealer?

LEAD: ''I WAS really very pleasantly surprised,'' said Mikhail Baryshnikov, after members of the American Ballet Theater danced the parts of fashion models at a show of Mr. Baryshnikov's signature body- and dancewear collection.
LEAD: A front-page picture caption last Sunday about budget negotiations between Congress and the White House incorrectly stated the place of the meeting. It was at the Capitol.

LEAD: AMERICANS are paying too much for their financial services. But America's commercial banks are willing, and able, to help lower prices by hundreds of millions of dollars by increasing competition. The missing ingredient is Congressional authority to give banks the capability to move into new markets that will strengthen our banking system.

LEAD: A wiretap has been discovered on a Harvard University law professor's telephone, and the professor said today that the surveillance might have led to public disclosure of his misgivings about Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, who ended his bid for Supreme Court today.

LEAD: If you have access to a computer and want to find the latest mortgage data in 36 areas around the country without scurrying from bank to bank or making a lot of phone calls, you might consider a new service offered by HSH Associates of Riverdale, N.J.
LEAD: THE woods are filled with clubs for discount travel.

LEAD: Britain and other Commonwealth nations are offering military and economic assistance to Mozambique to protect railways, ports and other development projects against attack by South African-backed guerillas.
LEAD: Have the slumping Rangers, weary of having sand kicked in their faces, decided to get even instead of getting mad?

LEAD: Yet another hotel is under construction in northern New Jersey, the 300-room Hilton at Short Hills, and it is scheduled for completion early next year. The hotel is at 41 John F. Kennedy Parkway, directly across from the Short Hills Mall about 12 miles west of Newark International Airport, and near both the New Jersey Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway.

LEAD: Attackers threw bombs and sprayed gunfire at members of an opposition party who were meeting today, killing one person and wounding more than a dozen, the police and witnesses said.
LEAD: An article on Nov. 1 about a cruise from Helsinki to Leningrad gave an incorrect telephone number for Cosmos International Tours; it is 800-556-5305.
LEAD: Bergen Catholic, which had been unbeaten and unscored upon in nine games since Thanksgiving Day last year, saw both streaks end yesterday in Ridgewood.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: THE GEORGIA O'KEEFFE CENTENNIAL exhibition at the National Gallery of Art is an attempt to allow the work of one of America's best- known artists to speak for itself. The 10 galleries devoted to 120 of her works offer no meditations on the artist's glamour and theatricality, on her love affairs with Alfred Stieglitz and the Southwest, or on her particular blend of sensuality and abruptness, exhibitionism and reclusiveness.

LEAD: The Knicks have been hoping to shake up professional basketball a bit this season. Faced with the prospect of relentless defensive pressure and a motion-oriented offense, their opponents were supposed to be wary of an evening that could result in frustration.
LEAD: Noboru Takeshita, Japan's new Prime Minister, urged the Reagan Administration and Congress today to move quickly to reduce the United States budget deficit.
LEAD: The Government of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has rejected an appeal by The Star against the shutdown of the popular English-language daily on Oct. 28.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Elmont (2-5) upset New Hyde Park (5-2) by 10-6 in a Nassau County Conference III game yesterday. With six minutes remaining, a running back, John Michel, scored the winning touchdown on a 12-yard run. For the Spartans, the conference champions the past three years, the victory is the highlight of their most dismal season in several years.

LEAD: Carolyn Pharr Vinson and Stephen Alfred Bou, lawyers in Washington, were married at the Washington Cathedral yesterday by the Rev. Henry Harris, associate rector of All Saints Episcopal Church in Chevy Chase, Md.

LEAD: IN CHAMBERS Chamber music comes in many sizes and sounds, and those who like to sample a little of everything can go from big to small this week when two of the major professional Long Island-based groups take to the stage. Today, the New York Virtuosi Chamber Symphony, under Kenneth Klein's baton, transports its audience from Brookville to the Mediterranean when it performs ''In the Gardens of Spain and Italy.
LEAD: MOST openings go through cycles of rise and decline whose duration cannot be concretely predicted, but the Marshall Gambit accelerates the process to roller-coaster speed.

Hoyt of New York, was married yesterday in Sierra Madre, Calif., to Charles Colville Steidel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Steidel of Scottsdale, Ariz. The Rev. Michael A. LEAD: At St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Bloomfield, N.J., Ellen Teresa O'Boyle, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David J. O'Boyle of Glen Ridge, N.J., was married yesterday to William C. McCahill Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. McCahill of Huntington, L.I. Msgr. Vincent P. Coburn performed the ceremony.

LEAD: DESPITE the tumult on Wall Street, the Axe Castle in Tarrytown is not under seige. In the Great Hall, beneath its beautiful rose window, the research department is quietly at work. And it is business as usual in the formal ballroom below, now used by the Axe computer department. The 18th-century Oak Room, unchanged since it was brought intact from a Paris mansion, is being readied for a meeting.

LEAD: Two 13-year-old boys who had a brief argument with a man in an abandoned car in a Brooklyn lot Thursday night returned moments later with a container of gasoline and set the car on fire, fatally burning him, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: TALKING TO STRANGE MEN. By Ruth Rendell. (Pantheon, $16.95.) ''They are just like schoolboys,'' observes Mungo Cameron's father as he watches a televised report on a spy trial. ''Like so many schoolchildren playing games.'' But what this staid English doctor doesn't know is that the youngest of his children, teen-aged Mungo, is busily proving the truth - and the dangerous consequences - of that statement.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: HISTORIC Hudson Valley, the new name of the historic preservation group better known to county residents as Sleepy Hollow Restorations, celebrated its expanding role last week with a festive dinner dance in Manhattan. But it promised that Westchester's historic sites will not be ignored as the organization sets out on its mission to encourage tourism throughout the region.

LEAD: As he considers candidates to succeed Mario Merola as interim Bronx District Attorney, Governor Cuomo is confronted with a politically sensitive decision.

LEAD: NEW HAMPSHIRE'S Fish and Game Department is planning a moose season - the state's first since 1901 - for next year, and it appears as if the event will take place on schedule.

LEAD: HICKSVILLE is Long Island's middle ground. Similarly, Wickers, a restaurant in a Hicksville shopping center, is close to the center of Long Island's restaurant spectrum. It's not a fancy place offering haute cuisine at haute prices, nor is it a fast-food spot with a tab to match. Wickers is the kind of place that most Long

LEAD: SOUTH KOREANS are enjoying a novel sensation: being courted by politicians eager for their votes. As campaigning accelerates for next month's election, their first chance in 16 years to vote directly for a president, hundreds of thousands of Koreans are turning out at the candidates' rallies.

LEAD: BLANCHE DuBOIS is one of the most extraordinary creations of a playwright's art, and it is gratifying to report that Ellen Barry is offering an enlightening, lucid view of this most cherishable role.

LEAD: John F. English, a national, state and Long Island Democratic leader for many years, died yesterday of liver cancer at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 61 years old and lived in Muttontown, L.I., and on Fire Island.

LEAD: Interception returns of 85 yards by Ralph Rios for one touchdown and 18 by Mark Mullen for another carried Fordham to a 45-26 victory over Pace yesterday at Finnerty Field in Pleasantville, N.Y., to give the Rams their first championship in the three-year-old Liberty Conference.

LEAD: Warren J. Schlitz of Shaker Heights, Ohio, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Constance Ann Schlitz, to Worth Daniels MacMurray, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank G. MacMurray of McLean and Madison, Va. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: SOME 60 minority-group members with professional baseball ties are meeting in Irving, Tex., this weekend to promote hiring of black and Hispanic persons in the major leagues. The group, calling itself The Baseball Network, was organized by Frank Robinson, Willie Stargell, Ray Burris and a former scout, Ben Moore.

LEAD: Cynthia Ruffner Hart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alden S. Hart of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., was married yesterday at the Congregational Church in Short Hills, N.J., to Dr. William Harland Montgomery 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Montgomery Jr. of Mendham, N.J. The Rev. Gregory Schmidt officiated.

LEAD: IT was perhaps predictable that the members of the generation of the 60's and 70's would come to regret some of their youthful indulgences when they traded in their tie-dyed T-shirts and stashes of marijuana for gray suits and chardonnay. But the Douglas H. Ginsburg episode has shown that generational bygones cannot be entirely forgotten.

LEAD: New Haven's policy of excluding children with AIDS from public school classes has come under attack from the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union, which says it will use every legal remedy available to halt the practice.

LEAD: The police seized a 400-pound bear after learning that customers at a private club were being encouraged to pay $5 to wrestle with the bear. The police intervened Thursday night at Ms. Kitty's after Toby, a defanged brown bear, had wrestled his first match, officials said. No one was hurt. The bear's owner, Burlie Webb of Hot Springs, Ark., was charged with one count of illegal exhibition of a wild or exotic animal.

LEAD: PIERRE-MARIE DOUTRELANT DIED earlier this year while jogging in the Bois de Boulogne, in Paris. He was 46 years old, left a wife and a couple of kids, and may have been the best wine journalist of our time.

LEAD: The earthquake in Southern California last month was smaller than first estimated, but it also showed that faults hidden by a fold in the earth's crust may make the city more quake-prone than once believed.

Marie Lawrence of Bohemia, the 24-year-old mother of Christopher, a 3-month-old, is to appear in court tomorrow morning as Long Island's first non-garbage-sorting offender. Mrs. Lawrence failed to separate her recyclables.
LEAD: A COMMON QUESTION among many women, I'm told, is ''Where are all the single men?''

LEAD: In the mid-19th century, when the slaughter of the California gray whale was in full swing, whalers called them ''devil fish.'' Like monsters sent straight from hell, the 40-ton creatures would charge straight down the muzzle of a harpoon gun and, even mortally wounded from harpoons, defend their young until their last breath, holing many a stout whaling boat with their huge bodies.

LEAD: In the good old days when sports were sports, the czars were czars. Watching the World Series with his chin on the box-seat rail, as Kenesaw Mountain Landis did. Running the National Football League from his suburban Philadelphia home, as Bert Bell did. Setting the 24-second clock, as Maurice Podoloff did.

LEAD: THE murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr., for which jury selection continued in Manhattan last week, had all the makings of an old-fashioned, straightforward, good-versus-evil courtroom drama.
LEAD: Dwayne Downing returned an interception 38 yards for a touchdown and Blair Thomas ran 58 yards for another score today as Penn State defeated Maryland for the 23d consecutive season, 21-16.

LEAD: BOTH ends of the New York Philharmonic's Friday night concert at Avery Fisher Hall brought us to the edge of the sea. But we were shown it from very different sides. People share equal billing in Britten's ''Peter Grimes'' (we heard the Passacaglia and the four ''Sea Interludes''). Debussy's ''La Mer'' rises beyond human passions and depicts the sea itself.
LEAD: I KNEW that becoming single midway through my life would change my economic and social status, but I was not prepared for the root-deep shake-up it would be to my gender identification.

LEAD: Fieldston came from behind yesterday to snap Brunswick's winning streak and capture the Southern Division title of the Fairchester League with a 24-13 victory. Fieldston meets Hopkins-Grammar next Saturday for the championship.

LEAD: ON Oct. 12, Salomon Brothers Inc. announced plans to discontinue its municipal bond department and dismiss 12 percent of its work force. News that the company with the largest share of the business was pulling out of the ''muni'' business was the hottest topic - until Oct. 19 when the stock market made history.

LEAD: Small-orchestra concerts at the beginning and the end of this week catch the critic's eye. Monday night the Jupiter Symphony, directed by Jens Nygaard, plays one of its expected programs of the unexpected at Alice Tully Hall. Strauss's Horn Concerto will show up, the Bach Double Concerto, here in its oboe-violin version, also out-of-the-way pieces by Dvorak, Tchaikovsky and Weber.

LEAD: ALARMED BY THE present perturbation of the economy, many circumspect audiophiles have postponed planned purchases. To be sure, the more passionate music lovers usually manage to persuade themselves that buying stereo equipment falls into the same budgetary bracket as rent and groceries. But some who have toyed with the notion of revamping their entire sound system are now more likely to think in terms of selective updating -changing only those components that have clearly outlived their allotted span.

LEAD: Craig Heyward, impressive in Pitt's homecoming loss to unbeaten Syracuse a week ago, staged a personal homecoming today, running for 175 yards and his eighth touchdown of the season as the Panthers beat Rutgers, 17-0.

LEAD: THE Chicago Bears, leading the Central Division with a 6-1 record, are favored to win their game against the 3-3-1 Packers in Green Bay today, but, win or lose, one cherished Chicago record is likely to fall.

LEAD: An article Oct. 11 about a forum involving several possible candidates for New York City schools chancellor incorrectly described one of the participants, Dr. Peter Negroni. Dr. Negroni had previously stepped down as Superintendent of Community School District 12 in the Bronx.

LEAD: Chaminade, getting a safety to go with its four touchdowns, defeated Cardinal Spellman, 29-28, yesterday in a quarterfinal game of the Catholic High Schools Athletic League playoffs.
LEAD: The Pretoria Government said today that the release of Govan A. Mbeki Thursday was a ''trial run'' for the release of the jailed African National Congress leader, Nelson R. Mandela.

LEAD: John Francis English, a national, state and Long Island Democratic leader for many years, died Saturday of liver cancer at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 61 years old and lived in Muttontown, L.I., and in Kismet on Fire Island.

LEAD: Lyssa Ann Raichelson, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Raichelson of West Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to Steven Scott Girden, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Girden of Stamford, Conn. Rabbis Norman Patz and Alex J. Goldman officiated at the Headquarters Plaza Hotel in Morristown, N.J.
LEAD: The Palestinian guerrilla group led by Abu Nidal announced here today that one of its units had seized a French-registered boat with eight people aboard off the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip.

LEAD: Last March, when the evangelist Oral Roberts said that God might ''call me home'' if he did not reach a lofty fund-raising goal, Jerry Collins wrote him a check for $1.3 million. LEAD: Throughout the West the wails are heard: Eliminating medium-range missiles from Europe will soon lay pitilessly bare the West's weakness in conventional forces. That's baloney. The man is Ronald Harwood, the writer whose credits include ''The Dresser,'' both play and film, and, more recently, the HBO movie ''Mandela.

LEAD: Q.What would happen if a thermonuclear bomb exploded on the surface of the Moon? Could a large number of explosions alter the orbit of the Moon and affect our tides? LEAD: Kenneth Tyler, the fine-art printer, remembers that a mere 30 years ago prints in this country were small, timidly black and white and mainly collected by book lovers. Now they are large, bold and done by first-rank artists, thanks in part to Mr. Tyler himself. Thinking big and in glorious color, he has worked with such talents as Robert Motherwell, Frank Stella, Roy Lichtenstein and David Hockney to extend their vivid imagery into the graphic arts.

Mr. Lehder, who is 38 years old, is charged in a 1981 indictment with smuggling 3.3 tons of cocaine from Colombia to Normans Cay in the Bahamas and then to Georgia and northern Florida in 1979 and 1980.

LEAD: SQUEAKY, wobbly stairs aren't just a nuisance. They can be hazardous if trouble spots are allowed to worsen. Squeaks are caused by stair parts rubbing against each other. You can silence many staircase noises merely by applying powdered graphite or some other dry lubricant to reduce the friction. But stair parts shouldn't move at all, and while lubricating them may mask the symptoms, it is not a cure for the disease.

IF you see only one werewolf movie this year, you might as well make it ''Howling III,'' Philippe Mora's not-altogether straight-faced howler on behalf of lycanthropes' liberation. Among other things, the Australian-made movie suggests there's nothing inherently evil about being a werewolf that a little human understanding wouldn't cure. Mr. Mora and his associates are blunt about it: this anti-werewolf hysteria must stop. In the meantime, they're free to exploit it with a good deal of earnest levity. ''Howling III'' involves a tribe of indigenously Australian (marsupial) lycanthropes, a defecting Russian ballerina named Olga, who is herself a werewolf, and Beckmeyer, a hardworking, civil libertarian Australian professor, who has espoused the werewolf cause.

LEAD: Jeannie Longo of France, who holds more than 10 world records in cycling, had never tested positive in drug tests in nine years of competition until traces of ephedrine were found in her system after she won a 3-kilometer race in September at Colorado Springs. LEAD: ''ART of the Fantastic: Latin America, 1920-1987,'' at the Queens Museum, is an effective and, at times, impressive exhibition, even though it is not a consistently good one. LEAD: Seven of the nine House Democrats on the Congressional Iran-contra committees will attach a separate statement to the panels' report next week taking issue with the report's conclusion that the White House was fully cooperative with the Congressional inquiry.

LEAD: Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, broke a bone in his face and suffered a cut over his eye when he slipped Thursday on his icy driveway in McLean, Va., a spokesman said. Mr. Lugar was treated at the Bethesda Naval Hospital and was released but will have to return next Wednesday to have the facial bone set, the spokesman, Andy Fisher, said.

LEAD: Farmingdale (7-1) ended the regular season on strong note yesterday with a 24-0 victory against the Massapequa Chiefs (6-2).

LEAD: Bob Knight called Joan Mellen last January, tracking her down at Temple University after reading her review for The St. Petersburg Times of John Feinstein's book, ''A Season on the Brink.'' No formalities, no introductory pleasantries: he just wanted to let her know that he thought she understood what he was about, the motives behind how he coached, how hard it was to make people learn.

LEAD: >''IT was the closest thing to a ? circus you've ever seen at a public meeting,'' said Walter D. Johnston, Acting Chairman of the Westchester Rent Guidelines Board, which granted rent increases this month of 3 percent on one-year leases and 5 percent on three-year leases.

LEAD: On many National Hockey League teams, the fourth line is the professional assignment of either last resort or initial opportunity. Whichever, it can often be a lonely way station at the end of the bench and just a short hop from the minors.
LEAD: Contrary to the article on Long Island street festivals [ ''Success Spoils Annual Street Fairs, Oct. 25 ] , the annual Oyster Festival is neither spoiled nor unmanageable.

LEAD: Despite the loss in the second quarter of the team's leading rusher, Byram Hills defeated Ardsley yesterday, 10-0. The victory was Byram Hills's ninth without a loss and the sixth shutout of a season in which the Bobcats led Section 1 by allowing only 20 points.

LEAD: IN a recent interview, Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, suggested that program trading was a major cause of the Oct. 19 crash in stock prices. ''It's very hard not to rail at the index futures markets - I don't think these techniques add much to the sum of human endeavor,'' he said.
LEAD: The duel of the frozen chickens is among the claims on file at the Insurance Library Association of Boston.

LEAD: Recently, Edward Witten returned to his alma mater (Brandeis), where he received an honorary degree. Many on campus were surprised to discover that Witten, the enfant terrible of physics, was a history major as an undergraduate.

LEAD: THE marketing director of one division of a major food company in White Plains logs 24,000 miles a year visiting company production facilities. An oil broker in Purchase, operating in international markets, estimates he travels 66,000 miles a year in airplanes.

LEAD: WHEN partners in Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue, a law firm, began looking for new offices after 60 years in the same downtown Cleveland location, they never seriously considered a site outside the city's center.

LEAD: SANTA CLAUS has come to other towns in shiny convertibles, in helicopters that land on country-club lawns and at railroad stations, but Woodbridge Center's St. Nick will arrive this year on a new carrousel that will become a permanent attraction.
LEAD: Police officers are not required to preserve breath samples for drunken driving suspects who may want to challenge the validity of Breathalyzer tests later, New York's highest court has ruled.

LEAD: The engagement of Marie-Elaine La Roche, a managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, to Dr. Peter Richard Donovan, an exploration geologist with the United Nations Development Program in New York, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Andre La Roche of Cresskill, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be.

LEAD: At The Temple in Atlanta, Patricia Hill Hertz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jennings Hertz Jr. of Atlanta, was married last evening to Douglas Foster Reid, a son of Mrs. Thomas R. Reid of St. Clair Shores, Mich., and the late Mr. Reid. Rabbi Alvin Sugarman performed the ceremony.

LEAD: DUSTY KAY COULDN'T EVEN produce an ashtray. ''I don't have a thing left here except this can of Hawaiian Punch,'' the television producer said with a scowl, surveying his large, virtually barren corner office for a place to discard his cigarette. He found only packing cartons.

LEAD: Soviet textbooks should spend less time dwelling on poverty and urban crime in the United States, and the Russians want publishers of American textbooks to present a more balanced discussion of Lenin, a leader of a joint textbook study project says.

LEAD: Prof. Edward Witten's new constructions may tie in to earlier, undisputed, findings. In 1982, a team of researchers, led by Alain Aspect, found that it is possible for particles to communicate instantaneously over great distances. This violates a long-held theory that nothing travels faster than light.
LEAD: WOMEN AND LOVE A Cultural Revolution in Progress. By Shere Hite. 922 pp. New York: Alfred A Knopf. $24.95.

LEAD: IMAGINE volunteering to be a surgeon, a pilot or a train engineer. Imagine if every man could spend some of his time doing what he aspired to do as a boy. Just by offering. Just for the fun of it. I do. I'm a volunteer firefighter.

LEAD: A study by Planned Parenthood projects a rapid increase in live births, maternal deaths and self-induced abortions worldwide if the Reagan Administration proceeds with a planned cutoff of funds for the group's international division.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: JUST ABOUT ANYTHING OUTRAGEOUS could happen when a renowned punk ballerina and a provocateur of the art world collaborate. But when Karole Armitage and David Salle convene at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival for a four-day engagement beginning Wednesday to display their latest endeavors - ''The Tarnished Angels'' and ''The Elizabethan Phrasing of the Late Albert Ayler'' - they'll tackle, instead, the somewhat immaculate tradition of ballet with what appears to be reverence.
LEAD: BECAUSE they confront AIDS daily in their jobs, 700 New Jerseyans gathered here recently for an official update on the state's No. 1 health concern.

LEAD: Mary Elis Voyatzis, an assistant professor of classics at the University of Arizona, was married yesterday in Tucson, Ariz., to Frederick Frelinghuysen, a management consultant. The Rev. James Tavlarides performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Church of St. Demetrios, assisted by the Rev. Paul W.
LEAD: Luciano Pavarotti will give two master classes at the Juilliard School, Thursday from 2 to 6 P.M. and next Sunday from 3 to 5:30 P.M. He will work with singers presently studying at the school.

LEAD: At St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Blauvelt, N.Y., RoseMary Dugan, a daughter of Mrs. Richard D. Dugan of Orangeburg, N.Y., and East Hampton, L.I., and the late Dr. Dugan, was married yesterday to Kenneth Richard Stevens, a son of Mrs. H. John Stevens of New City, N.Y., and the late Mr. Stevens.
LEAD: YOUNG MAN WITH A HORN Starring Kirk Douglas (in photo), Lauren Bacall, Doris Day. Directed by Michael Curtiz. Warner Home Video. 112 minutes. $19.98.
LEAD: The American Foreign Service is in trouble. Experienced diplomats, unsure about their futures, are casting about, sending out resumes in search of late-in-life careers.

LEAD: TERRORISM, since it burst anew on the international scene in the early 1970's, particularly in the Middle East, has spawned a small army of researchers and specialists, including government officials, political scientists, journalists, psychologists, and others, trying to understand its causes and the best ways of putting a stop to it.

LEAD: HOFSTRA UNIVERSITY, adding to its reputation as the leading academic conference center on Long Island, will assemble 150 scholars, politicians, historians and journalists this week for what is believed to be the first major re-examination of the Presidency of Richard M. Nixon.

LEAD: Dissatisfied With Broker Question: Earlier this year, we used a mortgage brokerage firm to get a loan. Our broker told us that it would take about eight weeks to obtain a mortgage. The agent who started our work became ill and a replacement took over. He was incompetent and as a result four months later we had no mortgage.

LEAD: Judge Anthony M. Kennedy, President Reagan's latest nominee to the Supreme Court, spent at least $65,332 as a part-time lobbyist from 1963 to 1975, when he was named to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, state records show.

LEAD: THE release earlier this month of Govan A. Mbeki, the black leader imprisoned for 24 years, has already changed the chemistry of South African politics and opened a new debate about the prospect of black unity against the Pretoria Government's divide-and-conquer tactics.

LEAD: With a sharp contemporary twist, the town-house project of Katonah Close takes its architectural cue from Victorian homes built in nearby Katonah, N.Y., around the turn of the century. But the unit prices of $325,000 to $375,000 are thoroughly modern - and a bit daunting to some prospective buyers.

LEAD: The hotel was one of Bangkok's most glittering; the buffet tables were heaped with the great cuisines of Asia. But Abdul Sattar Edhi, in his worn, homespun jacket, chose only a bowl of soup and a piece of flat bread known as naan.

Rappaport, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, were married last evening at Temple Gates of Zion in Valley Stream, L.I. Rabbi Harold Halpern performed the ceremony. LEAD: Acting on a 14-year-old request from a West German court, the Argentine authorities have arrested a man they identified as Josef Franz Leo Schwammberger, an accused Nazi war criminal, at a ranch in the province of Cordoba.
LEAD: Two sheriff's deputies were shot to death at their headquarters while they were booking a drunk driving suspect today, and a man was later arrested with the officers' car.

LEAD: HIS statistical status will provide little solace to the Cincinnati Reds, who squandered their chance to win a division title, but Eric Davis attained a remarkable level of run production efficiency this year.

LEAD: FOR anyone suffering from exhaustion from trying to pull the weeds out of the Garden, take two spoonfuls of Mets and Giants history and relax. Chances are that the Knicks and the Rangers will get even worse before they get better.
LEAD: Kuwait and Morocco became the latest Arab nations to resume full diplomatic relations with Egypt today. Iraq and the United Arab Emirates took similar steps this week.

LEAD: SENATOR BOB DOLE, Republican of Kansas, last week became the last of the people who have said they are running for President to make his race official. Mr. Dole's aim is to wrest the Republican nomination from Vice President Bush, and his message was carefully chosen to highlight the frontrunner's vulnerabilities as a man of privilege and as a second-in-command.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Eve Gordon, a daughter of Dr. Mary McDougall Gordon of Saratoga, Calif., and Richard Bennett Gordon of Arlington, Va., to Todd Waring, a son of Douglas Waring of Ballston Spa, N.Y., and the late Gretchen Schoonmaker Waring.
LEAD: WANTED: Investors. Must be willing to pony up $1.4 billion for a company that will collect no money for at least six years but will, all the while, stuff billions into a hole in the ground.
LEAD: A Brooklyn man was shot and killed in his family's restaurant late Friday in an incident that the police said might have been mob-related.
LEAD: A Bronx man has been charged with child abuse after hospital officials said his 4-month-old son had suffered brain damage caused by a severe shaking.
LEAD: After 14 years of quiet exile, the king of Afghanistan, Mohammad Zahir Shah, has emerged as a key figure in efforts to negotiate a Soviet withdrawal from his country.

LEAD: CHRISTMAS, LIKE MANY LESSER OCCASIONS at our house and sometimes no occasion, was marked with chocolate-dipped coffee beans and cats' tongues from Altman & Kuhne, a Fifth Avenue candy shop. Dolls came from grandmothers and books from my mother, but it was my father who brought home those chocolates in European-looking packages: the coffee beans for the adults - in theory at least - and the cats' tongues, finger-length spatulas of bittersweet, for me and my sister.
LEAD: Mayor Koch is a man of many opinions, some of which have to do with municipal affairs.

LEAD: Proposed state regulations that would require businesses and homeowners to post warnings of pesticide sprayings are being challenged by a coalition of restaurant owners, farmers and the pest-control industry.
LEAD: The talent in college basketball has become fairly evenly distributed in recent years, primarily among two dozen or so of the nation's strongest programs.

LEAD: THE lawn should be as short as possible for winter to eliminate the chances of disease, especially snow mold; if the grass was not cut before storing the mower, set the cutting blade at 1 1/2-inches or a bit lower, if possible, and mow one more time; if a few leaves remain, they will be chopped up by the blades and can remain as mulch, but rake off thick layers of leaf mulch.

LEAD: TERRY CREACH and Stephen Koester explored the choreographic possibilities of male movement in an energetic and invigorating program Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. If one could sometimes question the uses to which their energy was put, one had no doubts about these dancers' abilities.
LEAD: The Sunday racing card at Suffolk Downs was canceled because of the snowfall last week, but a regular schedule will resume on Monday, officials said.

LEAD: EVERY November, when the calendar insists it's fall but it begins to feel like winter in Washington, D.C., my husband and I start to think about our annual week or two of guaranteed sunshine on the Pacific coast of Mexico.

LEAD: Yes, there is a Mafia, an organized crime network largely made up of Italian-American mobsters. But Americans haven't yet learned to stop stigmatizing all Italian-Americans because of it. The positive development is that at last - after years of subterranean murmurings - the subject, and the prejudice, can be openly confronted.

LEAD: THE problem is elementary, but deucedly difficult. The 56 short stories and four novels that Sir Arthur Conan Doyle wrote about Sherlock Holmes exist on paper - 11,000 pages' worth. Many Baker Street Irregulars and other admirers of the great detective would like to see the works available in an electronic data base.

LEAD: STARTING off today's generous offering of concert opportunities is Philharmonia Virtuosi's ''Bach's Lunch'' series, with a 2 P.M. recital at Concordia College in Bronxville (or come at 12:30 and have an informal luncheon beforehand). Two glowing Quintets make up the program: Paul Peabody, the concertmaster, and four more of the group's principal string players line up for Schubert's C Major and the guest pianist, Stephanie Brown, joins in for the Brahms F Minor (693-5595).

LEAD: Carl Miller, a tall, white-haired man in his mid-50's, often spends weekends driving through the countrysides of New York, Connecticut or New Jersey. Unlike other weekend drivers, Mr. Miller is not on a pleasure trip. He is tree hunting.

LEAD: Two explosions ripped through a chemical plant near here today, touching off massive fires that burned out of control all afternoon and left at least three people dead and more than 30 injured, the authorities said.

LEAD: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Englewood, N.J., Robin Drake Cameron, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Cameron of Englewood, was married yesterday to Richard Spencer Steen, a son of Mrs. George Voutsas of Carmel, Calif., and the late Dr. Sigvart J. Steen. The Rev. Jack M. McKelvey performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Sartre's Irrational Cheer A philosopher turned novelist, Iris Murdoch is in a good position to appreciate irrational appeals. This is from her ''Sartre: Romantic Rationalist'' (Viking).

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Armstrong Webster of Glen Ridge, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Anne Elizabeth Webster, to Charles David Leight, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold C. Leight of Denver. The couple plan to marry in April.

LEAD: WOODMERE can now boast one of the best new restaurants to open on Long Island in recent years. The food at La Petite Maison Russe harks back to the old Franco-Russian alliance, when Russian Czars imported French chefs. This small storefront restaurant has reversed those roles. The chefs are Russian.

LEAD: William F. Buckley Jr. was reported to have said that his descent to the Titanic as a guest of the French expedition would be done to ''give himself something new and different to write about'' (''Down to the Great Ship,'' Oct 18). So be it! But his article addresses the unique philosophical problems attending this discovery/salvage affair only perfunctorily.

LEAD: A headline in a listing of Trans-Panama cruises on Nov. 1 misidentified the cruise line that operates the Bermuda Star; it is the Bermuda Star Line.

LEAD: Vermont's Republican Party, the colossus of state politics for more than a century but struggling in recent years, is planning for a political comeback by recasting its image in a new, more liberal light.

LEAD: FOUR years ago, when Dr. Philip Wiedel, a surgeon at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York, began to plan for retirement, he and his wife, Monique, decided that they would eventually take up permanent residence in their country home in the southeast corner of Danbury.

LEAD: THERE IS NO END TO IT; EVERYBODY wants to get into the act. If it's not sex, drugs and rock-and-roll, then clearly there's too much violence. Politicians, moralists and other interested parties have always wanted to regulate television. Pecksniffs love to testify at hearings. What's different now, however, is that the impulse to regulate television entertainment is being extended to television news.

LEAD: When music followers talk about the good old days of instrumental performance, it is never quite clear what they mean. In general, this is intended as a reference to the Romantic school and its progeny, but what was that? After all, there are those who grew out of this 19th-century tradition with a taste for frank emotionalism and textual liberty-taking, and there also are those who favor removed, intellectualized interpretations.

Mr. and Mrs. John Wiley of Columbus, Ohio, have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Sernau of White Plains.

Just before you reach a major intersection, where the H-1 freeway meets a cross-island trunk route, you get your first glimpse.

LEAD: THE LOST LANGUAGE OF CRANES, by David Leavitt. (Bantam, $8.95.) Philip's parents don't know that their son is a homosexual, but he doesn't know that his father is also gay. Last year, our reviewer, Phillip Lopate, found the author's preoccupation with sexual orientation ''obsessively repetitious'' but said that the novel ''lingers in the mind, greater than the sum of its problematic parts.
LEAD: TO hear them talk, one would think that Congress and the White House are worried about the crash of the stock market, the fall of the dollar, and the United States budget and trade deficits.

LEAD: Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, has formally invited Mikhail S. Gorbachev to address a joint session of Congress while the Soviet leader is in Washington next month for the planned summit meeting with President Reagan, a spokesman for Mr. Byrd said today.

LEAD: ON Friday the United Nations Postal Administration will issue a six-stamp set with the theme ''Immunize Every Child.'' The release publicizes efforts of the World Health Organization (W.H.O) and the United Nations Children's Fund (Unicef) to immunize children by 1990 against the six major communicable diseases: diptheria, measles, poliomyelitis, tetanus, tuberculosis and whooping cough.

LEAD: A marine convicted of espionage has convinced Government counterintelligence agents that there was no extensive spy ring in the security detachment at the American Embassy in Moscow and that no Soviet agents were admitted to the embassy, military officials say.

LEAD: The Superintendent of the State Police, Col. Clinton L. Pagano, has issued a special bulletin to troopers advising them that the state's experimental ''no-flunk'' motor-vehicle inspection program in northern counties does not mean they should be lax in enforcing safety regulations.

LEAD: JACOB'S LADDER. By John A. Williams. (Thunder's Mouth Press, $13.95.) If John A. Williams had simply written a political thriller set in West Africa in the 1960's, then ''Jacob's Ladder'' might have emerged as a well-written genre novel featuring a number of sensitive evocations of landscape and mood.

LEAD: As 22 state Baptist groups ended their annual conventions, there were hints that moderate Baptists were mastering political organization in their battles with orthodoxy in the nation's largest Protestant denomination.

LEAD: I'VE added a new activity to my morning routine. I call it the key hunt. After years of feeling that daily searching for my keys is an intrusion, I have given in and officially made room for hunting in between bathing and breakfast. Now I have a full seven minutes of detective work before I begin to panic.

LEAD: AFTER the police fired on anti-Government protesters here last week, the leading opposition party in Bangladesh scheduled a prayer service for three slain partisans. But its leader was unable to attend. Sheik Hasina Wajed, the Awami League's head, is a woman, and Moslem tradition dictates that women be barred from ceremonies for the dead.
LEAD: Two leftist guerrillas linked to the 1983 slaying of a United States military adviser have been ordered released under an amnesty program that is part of the Central American peace plan.

LEAD: Don Juan's a hero with a hundred faces: For some he's mostly Mozart, or Moliere. He shows up in a hundred different places, He's profligate, Byronic, debonair. He goes to Hell, so heavy his disgrace is, In ''Man and Superman'' we see him there - A daring Shavian variant on the pattern; So after that let's send him to Manhattan.

LEAD: Roger Lewis, a former Assistant Secretary of the Air Force, chairman of the General Dynamics Corporation and the first president of Amtrak, died Thursday at his home in Washington. He was 75 years old. Mr. Lewis' career, which began in 1934 in the sheet metal shop of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, took him over the next 40 years to top jobs in aviation, aerospace, military contracting, railroading and the Federal

LEAD: TURKEY may be the star of the Thanksgiving table, but vegetables play an effectual supporting role. And since this holiday is the celebration of the harvest, I like to serve a selection. I bake whole acorn squashes in the oven, not cutting them open until after they are cooked. Then I slice them in half, scoop out the seeds and add a little butter, salt and pepper.
LEAD: Rotnei Anderson, a fullback, rushed for 118 yards, and Oklahoma made two late drives for a 17-13 victory over Missouri in a Big Eight Conference game.

LEAD: Only 24 hours after the Nicaraguan Government offered a cease-fire proposal to the contras, President Reagan accused the Sandinistas today of dragging their feet as they put into effect the Central American peace agreement.
LEAD: Reading Frank Wolkenberg's article ''Out of a Darkness'' (Oct. 11) was a remarkable experience for me. I felt he was describing my life.

LEAD: RUBY BRAFF objects to being called a jazz musician. He is, he says, an entertainer with a horn. He once made an album called ''Adoration of the Melody,'' and that is the way he approaches his music.
LEAD: A map on Nov. 1 with an article about a museum in Vermillion, S.D., reversed the labels for two neighboring states; they were Iowa and Minnesota.
