The show, remaining through March, marks the 40th anniversary of the Shelburne Museum, the repository Mrs.
LEAD: Breast cancer may become an increasingly serious problem for women as those of the baby boom generation grow older, Federal health researchers report.

LEAD: TO an American raised to revere the bald eagle, the notion of eating a national symbol might sound less than appetizing. But in Barbados, the self-proclaimed land of the flying fish, the emblem that adorns all the tourist brochures turns up at lunch, dinner and even breakfast, steamed, sauteed, deep-fried and every which way but blackened.

LEAD: The Oyster Creek Nuclear Power Plant, which was shut down by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission two months ago because of safety violations, will resume normal operations in about two weeks, according to officials at the plant.

LEAD: DESPITE GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''NO-STAR'' policy at the New York City Ballet, the company produced many stars during his 35 years as benevolent dictator. The last male artist on whom Balanchine created major roles is Ib Andersen, who, almost five years after Balanchine's death, has come into his prime - with little fanfare.

LEAD: Before he went to South Africa in 1983 to see for himself what life under apartheid was like, Sir Richard Attenborough was a self-described ''well-intentioned liberal,'' the sort who protests by not buying South African oranges. His heart was in the right place.

LEAD: THE clamor for state tax cuts, which echoed loudly through the State Capitol in late summer and early fall, has quieted in recent weeks after the plunge in the world stock markets and the resulting increased caution about the future pace of consumer spending in Connecticut and the nation.

LEAD: The flowers were bought, sold and fastened to lapels long before the Michigan State Spartans took the field for their historic afternoon. Lorenzo White's record-setting runs for the roses merely made them appropriate.

LEAD: The City University of New York will be hard-pressed to meet proposed Federal goals to reduce student loan default rates at many of its colleges, according to the university's director of financial aid.

LEAD: THIS HAS BEEN AN AUTUMN OF extraordinary revivals. Martha Graham's ''Celebration'' received its first New York performances in 50 years during the Graham company's recent season.

LEAD: Alexandra West Rollins, a consultant to the State Department on public administration and the arts, was married at Grace Episcopal Church in New York yesterday to Gordon Allen Upton, a financial-services consultant. The Rev. Harold E. Barrett performed the ceremony.

LEAD: FOLLOWING are excerpts from a panel discussion on ''New Economic Forces,'' held during the Columbus Day weekend by the Sag Harbor Initiative. The quotations were compiled by Blake Hanson.

LEAD: Paul Schullery's history of American fly fishing, like the sport itself, is not for everyone. Primarily, it's for those who think that ''fly fishing is the best thing there is.'' It might also interest nonangling history buffs, who will be amazed to discover that fly fishing has given rise to as many competing schools of thought as the Weimar Republic.

LEAD: Dr. Beth Karen Scharfman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Melvin A. Scharfman of Great Neck, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. Uri R. Shabto, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Avtalion Shabto of New York. Rabbis Mordecai Waxman and David Lincoln officiated at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

LEAD: There will be dozens of free agentssigned in baseball, just like last year, and they'll sign with the same team they played for this year, except for one major player, Jack Morris. George is fed up with his second-banana status, and he'll make Jack an offer he can't refuse. JEFF MARINER
LEAD: Jeff Burger passed for 217 yards and 2 touchdowns today as Auburn thrwarted Georgia, 27-11.

LEAD: It's How You Play the Game Screaming and clapping, the home-team crowd was going wild in the balcony overlooking the college's tiny gymnasium. The entire student body was on its feet. (Actually, they had to be, since there weren't any seats.) But euphoria was rampant, for it was the opening home basketball game and their team was winning, as in scoring more points than the opponent, a feat most students had only dreamed about.

LEAD: Testing to help curb the AIDS epidemic can be either voluntary or compulsory, but that's a choice only in theory. A compulsory program would drive underground the intravenous drug abusers and gay men who most need to be reached. No wonder public health officials overwhelmingly prefer voluntary tests.

LEAD: ON THE STREETS OF NEW York, it pays to look up and look down, and not always for the reasons you might think. Some of the city's most colorful restaurants, shops, clubs and galleries are tucked away in basements or perched in second floors, where lower rents enable entrepreneurs to be more than usually inventive about whatever it is they purvey.

LEAD: Businesses in Atlanta could earn nearly $60 million from the Democratic National Convention next summer, and even more if the party's Presidential nomination has not been decided by the time delegates arrive July 18.

LEAD: FROM time to time in recent years, it has been the fashion to talk of the depersonalization of dancers in the face of rapidly rising technical demands. Some of that talk has been of the Joffrey Ballet, but the present company is filled with performers in whom expressive personality and technical expertise are merged.
LEAD: THE stock market took a tremendous tumble on Oct. 19, but in the publishing industry, at least, no one was prepared to jump.

LEAD: LAUREL VLOCK knew Bridgeport needed its own commercial television station after a 1978 survey showed that a majority of the city's elementary schoolchildren thought the mayor of Bridgeport was Edward Koch.
LEAD: I HAVE decided to embrace, provisionally, advice to go on living as much as possible as I did before. So yesterday at the supermarket I bought loin lamb chops.

LEAD: LET THE FRENCH roll out their bell skirts, pouf sleeves and stiff hoops. Italy's arsenal of seduction is formed of gentler stuff. This year, Milan's fashion leaders, a handful of shrewd nonconformists, demonstrated pointedly that sex appeal can be a subtle thing.

LEAD: FATSO: Football When Men Were Really Men. By Arthur J. Donovan Jr. and Bob Drury. (Morrow, $15.95.) Reading Arthur Donovan's account of what it was like playing pro football in the 1950's is as close as most of us will ever get to sitting around a big-league locker room, opening a few cool ones and listening to the big guys talk about the legendary wars and warriors of the good old days, before million-dollar contracts, before the Super Bowl, when there was still at least one player (Chuck Bednarik) who played both ways, offense and defense, for 60 full minutes per game.

LEAD: A North Brunswick man ordered customers out of a post office at gunpoint and held his former wife hostage there for about eight hours today before releasing her and surrendering, according to the police. The police said no one was injured. The incident began shortly after noon when the man, Daniel Alfrey, 38 years old, apparently angry that his former wife had a boyfriend, walked into the post office, the authorities said.

LEAD: This classic French country dish sits proudly on my kitchen counter, ready to be served (Food: ''After Quiche,'' by Patricia Wells, Oct. 4). Now I read that this brilliant marriage of the flavors of beef, red wine and herbs has become a culinary has-been.

LEAD: Evenings on the Town New Plays Nov. 16 - The Circle Repertory Theater, a leading Off Broadway showcase for new American plays, will present six short new works by playwrights including Lanford Wilson and Terrence McNally at a benefit for the company at the Equitable Center, 787 Seventh Avenue near 51st Street.

LEAD: THE true exorcism of ghosts occurs when they are gradually absorbed into the lives of the living. All last year I was writing dialogues with my father, Gregory Bateson, who died in 1980, an ironic activity because he also wrote dialogues -called by him ''metalogues'' - between a father and daughter, dialogues that were largely but not entirely fictional.
LEAD: A bomb hidden in a box of chocolates blew up in the American University Hospital in West Beirut today, killing 7 people and wounding 31, the police said.

LEAD: In an effort to keep drivers with excessive traffic violations off the road, the state of Maryland is considering storing photographs of drivers in a computer to prevent people from getting several licenses.

LEAD: To the Editor: Your article on ''Vienna's Love of the Trolley'' (Travel, Aug. 23) reminded me of my own experience. First of all it was very amusing to see official signs along the Ringstrasse track saying ''Warum so schnell'' (Why so fast). At one point we were tooling along at a very comfortable speed when coming around the corner on a narrow street we were stopped by a small car parked halfway across the tracks.

LEAD: THE GARDENS BETWEEN THE entrances to the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery and the Museum of African Art are now the colors of late fall, dark reds and yellows and evergreen. When I revisited those newest additions to the Smithsonian Institution, the long queues of the opening weeks had disappeared. There seemed to be no crowds, and yet there were hundreds of people.

LEAD: The Nicaraguan Government has agreed to accept a four-member team of American mediators as part of its effort to reach a cease-fire with United States-backed contra guerrillas, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today.
LEAD: Notre Dame is on a mission to win the national college football championship, but may never get the chance to fulfill it.
LEAD: At the Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington, Mary Martha Keeley was married yesterday to Richard William Beckler in a ceremony performed by the Rev. Peter Ryan.

LEAD: CLEARLY a boom is underway on the Venezuelan island of Margarita, 24 miles off the mainland and half an hour by plane from Caracas. As soon as you alight, you hear the humming, buzzing and slamming of construction work, and you see high-rise buildings that seem to have shot up overnight on near-desert terrain.

LEAD: WITH the continuing turmoil in the stock market, Treasury securities have taken on new allure. The biggest attraction is their safety - Treasuries are backed by the full faith and credit of the United States. But demand for the securities, especially those with maturities of six months or less, has become so strong that it has depressed yields.
LEAD: SOVIET SUMMITRY:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Katherine Ashton, a daughter of Mrs. and Mrs. Robert W. Ashton of New York, was married at Trinity Episcopal Church in New York yesterday to Brian David Young, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Young of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Robert Cowperthwaite performed the ceremony.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: An interview with the author Mary Helen Washington on Oct. 4 incorrectly identified her college affiliation. She graduated from Notre Dame College of Ohio, Cleveland.
LEAD: MISS AMERICA, 1945 Bess Myerson's Own Story. By Susan Dworkin. Illustrated. 229 pp. New York: Newmarket Press. $18.95.

LEAD: Kathryn Louise Law, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Teets Law Jr. of Tenafly, N.J., was married there yesterday to David Wayne Hoyle, a son of the late Rev. and Mrs. Wayne Edmond Hoyle of Excelsior, Minn. The Rev. John Croneberger performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Atonement.
LEAD: A report last Sunday on the engagement of Ruth Hefren Kennedy and Robert Sloan Bowers incorrectly identified the future bride's parents.

LEAD: IT IS SOMETIME AFTER MIDNIGHT IN THE Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on West 44th Street. In this pleasantly faded monument of Manhattan gentility, with its red leather banquettes and oak-paneled walls, the gaze of the late-night audience is fastened on a dark-haired sliver of a woman tautly poised beside a piano.
LEAD: MANY homeowners who have taken out mortgages think their only obligations to the lender are to make timely payments on the loan and to pay taxes and insurance premiums. Not so.
LEAD: WHEN a performance of the Philharmonia Virtuosi Chamber Orchestra in April 1985 turned into a rollicking rendition of Broadway-style tunes, few in the Westchester audience were surprised.
LEAD: Q. We have a large bluestone patio about 10 years old, and some of the cement between the flags is coming out of the joints. Can you tell us how to handle this problem?

LEAD: Yale's quarterback and captain, Kelly Ryan, had his most productive game of the season today as the Elis easily defeated Princeton, 34-19. This victory, Yale's sixth in a row, set up a grand finale for the Ivy League championship: Harvard against Yale at the Yale Bowl on Saturday.

LEAD: Suspense spreads over varied locales in this week films - a desolate Los Angeles police station, a small-town Texas bar, a high-rise Manhattan publishing office, a ski resort in St. Moritz and a London theater.

LEAD: Aberdeen $170,000 125 Van Brackle Road 3-bedroom, 2 bath, 12-year-old ranch; family room, 2 patios; taxes $2,395. Livingston $575,000 5 Bushkill Drive 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 28-year-old ranch; deck, C/A, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $7,013.

LEAD: A group of small sailboats bobbed in the water near the Wavertree at the South Street Seaport. The mild and sunny weather yesterday should continue through today, with a high temperature in the upper 50's. (The New York Times/Jim Wilson)

LEAD: The centerpiece of next month's superpower summit meeting is to be the signing of a treaty eliminating intermediate-range nuclear forces. The public and Congressional debate about ratifying the treaty will greatly influence future arms control efforts and our relations with Europe and the Soviet Union.

LEAD: The airstrips used to supply Nicaraguan guerrillas are still operating in Honduras, but continued Government support for the rebels is no longer certain, according to Honduran political analysts and several diplomats here.
LEAD: Rudolf Nureyev, the ballet star who defected from the Soviet Union 26 years ago, returned home for the first time today under an unusual two-day visa that will allow him to see his ill mother.
LEAD: YEARS ago, women's chess was generally stodgy, lacking aggression and combinational fireworks, but that's not true any more.

LEAD: East Islip $230,000 11 Meadow Farm Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old split level; den, solarium, fully carpeted, country setting; taxes $4,200. Kings Park $189,000 43 Juniper Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; den, new kitchen, finished basement, oak floors, 0.5 acre; taxes $5,400.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Congdon of Nantucket, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Anne Chapin Congdon, to Whitney Adams Gifford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Gifford Jr. of Perrysburg, Ohio, and Nantucket. Miss Congdon, a graduate of Connecticut College, is the Estee Lauder representative at the Higbee Company in Cleveland.
LEAD: COWS roam fields next to the international airport.

LEAD: Trailing Boston College by 17-0 early in the second quarter today, the undefeated Syracuse football team gave its fans, its coaches and the Sugar Bowl officials something to worry about. But not for long.
LEAD: Shere Hite has retained the literary agent Irving Lazar to auction the paperback rights to her book ''Women and Love,'' which has come under increasing attack by academic specialists.
LEAD: To the Editor: Having spent a week in Yugoslavia this summer, I am surprised by Nick Yapp's ''Lost Among the Carnivores in Yugoslavia, a Vegetarian's Beef'' (Travel, Sept. 20).
LEAD: LIFE, A USER'S MANUAL By Georges Perec. Translated by David Bellos. 581 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $24.95.

LEAD: IN 1868, the Vincentian Order of the Roman Catholic Church founded a parish and college on Brooklyn farmland and named it after St. John the Baptist. The order built a school and a priests' residence and an immense Romanesque church, with a nave 10 stories high and seating for 1,200.
LEAD: Q. We have a large bluestone patio about 10 years old, and some of the cement between the flags is coming out of the joints. Can you tell us how to handle this problem?
LEAD: Julius Gabris, one of four Roman Catholic bishops in Czechoslovakia, has died, the official Czechoslovak press agency reported Friday. He was 74 years old.

LEAD: Lauren Jane Karassik, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Karassik of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, was married last evening to Stephen Lawrence Weiss, a son of Arthur Weiss and Helene Rothstein, both of New York. Rabbi Marc Gelman performed the ceremony at the Pine Hollow Country Club in East Norwich, L
LEAD: The questionnaire [ ''In Doctor's Office, on Trial for AIDS,'' Opinion Page, Sept. 27 ] was ''disquieting.''

LEAD: PAUL H. SMUCKER WAS worried when he looked down the table during a board of director's meeting of his little country company some years back. To be sure, he knew everyone there. Seated around him were Willard E. Smucker, his father; Welker J. Smucker, his uncle; Aunt Winna Smucker; Aunt Wilma Smucker, and her husband, Harold

LEAD: THE radar detector business is not for the timid. Makers of the little black boxes, which alert drivers to the presence of police radar and help them avoid speeding tickets, have come under fire from traffic safety organizations, politicians and police. Their technological adversaries, the makers of police radar equipment, consistently find new ways to circumvent detectors.

LEAD: The protracted struggle over the Museum of the American Indian now comes down to a confrontation between Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Senator Daniel Inouye of Hawaii. Senator Moynihan leads forces that would put the museum in the old U.S. Custom House in Lower Manhattan. Senator Inouye argues for transfer to the Smithsonian Institution in

LEAD: K. C. Cole's informative essay on the latest developments in mathematical physics left out only an explanation of why physicists believe that the new and remarkable theory of strings is, as they call it, the theory of everything. The history of science demonstrates that all progressive research programs not only explain the anomalies left unaccounted for by existing theories, but also reinterpret the domain of observable facts in the application of new conceptual models.

LEAD: To the Editor: I enjoyed ''What's Doing in Frankfurt'' (Travel, Oct. 18). I do regret, though, that the article failed to mention two sites that I consider main attractions. The first is the zoo, with about 6,000 animals. It is one of the first zoos to attempt natural habitats, a children's zoo and a large house for watching nocturnal animals.
LEAD: Judge Anthony M. Kennedy could slightly shift the balance of the Supreme Court on criminal law and perhaps some civil rights issues, a review of several of his decisions suggests.
LEAD: Chuck Hartlieb hit Marv Cook with a 28-yard touchdown pass with six seconds remaining to give Iowa a 29-27 victory over Ohio State in a Big Ten Conference game today.
LEAD: FORTY-TWO YEARS after Pvt.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Perry R. Mandel of Glen Cove, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Susan Elizabeth Mandel, to Dr. Bennett Jay Kashdan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kashdan of Fort Lee, N.J. A February wedding is planned.

LEAD: Kevin Maguire of the Sabres hitting the ice after taking check from the North Stars' Brian MacLellan during first period of game friday night in Buffalo. The North Stars won 5-4, on a goal by Brain Bellows in the third period. (AP)

LEAD: ''Home Remedies,'' an article about indoor pollutants on Sept. 27 in The Good Health Magazine, part 2 of The Times Magazine, misidentified a harmful substance released in excessive amounts by malfunctioning gas appliances. It is carbon monoxide.

LEAD: THE WAY PEOPLE TALKED about One Liberty Place when plans for this skyscraper were announced a few years ago, you would have thought that this was not a new building but some sort of nuclear weapon. One Liberty Place would be the ruination of Philadelphia, cried the project's opponents, the sign that this somewhat genteel city had sold out to real-estate developers and become just like anyplace else.
LEAD: IT'S Jersey Justice on trial again - or so it seems to Jim Fisher, author of ''The Lindbergh Case'' (Rutgers University Press, New Brunswick, $22.95).

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 GARDEN OF SHADOWS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The beginnings of the evil that beset the Dollanganger family in four previously published novels. 2 1 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon.

LEAD: THERE have been, heaven only knows, mountains of words devoted to family problems, to the stresses and strains that threaten the tight weave of the domestic fabric. There have also been wise tomes issued on the effect of television as an isolating agent that can destroy togetherness in the home. But none of them have touched upon the particular matter that comes between man and wife in our otherwise serene situation.
LEAD: Officials at the Sing Sing Correctional Facility, the maximum-security prison in Ossining, are helping inmates make their getaway - by teaching them driving skills.

LEAD: Roses in December The Story of Jean Donovan. A film by Ana Carrigan and Bernard Stone. Narrated by John Houseman. First Run Features. 55 minutes. $29.95. While serving as a lay missionary in El Salvador in 1980, Jean Donovan and three close friends, the Maryknoll Sisters Maura Clarke and Ita Ford and the Ursuline Sister Dorothy Kazel, were murdered by the Government's security forces.

LEAD: To the Editor: I traveled extensively in Yugoslavia, visiting the country more than 10 times since the early 70's. Although, I must agree with the author that Yugoslavs are carnivorous, as much as Americans and most of the other Europeans, what struck me the most is the abundance of fruit, vegetables, cheese, yogurts and seafood along the Adriatic coast.
LEAD: In reply to the ''Population Bomb'' article: I suggest we first think of all the land improperly used because we grow tobacco. Some of the food we grow is converted into alcohol.

LEAD: SELECTED POEMS 1956-1986. By Anne Stevenson. 149 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. Paper, $9.95. TWO HORSE WAGON GOING BY By Christopher Middleton. 143 pp. New York: Carcanet. Paper, $8.50.

LEAD: NO sooner do I finish complaining about the limitations of auto-focusing cameras than one camera maker makes me eat my words. Specifically, I recently groused that auto-focusing sensors always aim dead center in the middle of the picture. This forces picture takers either to frame their subjects accordingly, or to use the pesky ''focus hold'' feature (if the camera provides it).
LEAD: This small New England town struggled with despair after learning that a 9-year-old boy had been shot to death and one of his friends was accused of murder.

LEAD: Abbie Hoffman filed suit in Federal court here Thursday to force election officials to count his absentee ballot in the town of New Hope, which could decide the community's deadlocked borough council race.

LEAD: Barbara Klaus's ''Therapy at the Diner'' [ Long Island Sound, Oct. 25 ] attempts to malign the diner, an institution that students of American culture, artists and photographers have recognized as a most significant expression of the American way of life. So much so that the Smithsonian has gone to great length to locate an early classic version to be shipped to

LEAD: This letter is in response to the Oct. 25 Opinion Page article ''The Population Bomb Is Still Ticking.'' I agree with Diana Gerhardt's assessment that Long Island is overcrowded; we do have too much garbage, too much population and too many shopping centers being built. Our traffic situation is deplorable during midday and the rush hours try the patience of many.

LEAD: THE Sag Harbor Village Board has proposed a law that would require certain businesses in the village that play recorded music or feature live entertainment to obtain a license. But the measure has been called unconstitutional by lawyers, racially motivated by minority business owners and an example of overzealous government regulation by business leaders.

LEAD: EXCEPT FOR THE SPINDLY HIGH heels no Christmas shopper would wear, and the lack of a black mink coat, Gale Jarvis could be any of the frantic young upscale parents nervously pondering the goods at F.A.O. Schwarz, racing from one department to another, ferreting out what's hot and what's not. But instead of just reading the price tags, Gale Jarvis is changing them.
LEAD: Poland has announced that average consumer prices will rise by 40 percent in 1988.

LEAD: WHEN the speed limit on some highways returned to 65 miles an hour earlier this year, manufacturers of radar detectors were more than a little concerned. After all, while commercial radar detectors had been around for 20 years, their business came to life only in 1974, when the highway speed limit was cut to 55 m.p.h.

LEAD: IT has become a familiar ritual among National Football League owners seeking a better stadium deal at home, the grand tour of cities seeking an N.F.L. franchise. It was just such a mission that took Bill Bidwill, the owner of the St. Louis Cardinals, to Baltimore, which has been clamoring for a team ever since the Colts' midnight departure for

LEAD: Ever since reading Edwin Abbott's Victorian science-fiction classic ''Flatland'' during my college days, I've held that modern man's belief in science and his faith in religion were not contradictory mindsets. I'm even more convinced after reading K. C. Cole's article ''A Theory of Everything'' (Oct.

LEAD: EVEN after five years of economic expansion, there are reports of hunger in America, among farmers in Kansas, elderly people in the Ozarks and homeless people in big cities from Houston to New York. But no one knows how many Americans are hungry, and attempts to estimate their number are highly controversial.

LEAD: FRANCE'S oldest pet cemetery, one of the most lavish in the world, faced an uncertain future two months ago in Asnieres, outside of Paris. The owner had locked its gate on an island in the Seine and was threatening to plow up the land and sell it to apartment builders.
LEAD: Q. We have a large bluestone patio about 10 years old, and some of the cement between the flags is coming out of the joints. Can you tell us how to handle this problem?

LEAD: A shortage of beechnuts and acorns, food of choice of New Hampshire's black bears, is driving the bruins to ruin apple orchards and cornfields in territory more populated than their usual mountain terrain.

LEAD: Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, one of the Senate's most outspoken conservatives, said Friday he might be interested in the Republican vice presidential nomination if the job could be tailored to his liking.

LEAD: ''Ye Olde Safer Sex Shoppe'' has opened at Stanford University, offering information and products aimed at slowing the spread of AIDS. The shop, which is actually just a table where condoms and other items are sold, is sponsored by an AIDS education project with approval from administrators and student groups.

LEAD: LYING amid bridges at Manhattan's northern tip, Inwood is connected to the rest of the island by Broadway and two subway lines, to Washington Heights often by a hyphen, and to several Caribbean islands by a stream of packages that leaves the post office on Vermilyea Avenue from the neighborhood's large Hispanic community.

LEAD: Deputy Secretary of State John C. Whitehead has announced that an American-style institute of management training will be established soon as a joint United States-Hungarian venture.

LEAD: A Song by Love and Rockets proclaimed ''No New Tale To Tell'' in the group's concert Thursday night atthe Beacon Theater, and truer self-descriptions were rarely sung.

LEAD: At the Inwood (L.I.) Country Club last evening, Joanne Lori Blum, the daughter of Gary L. Blum of Manhattan and Harriet E. Blum of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married to Glenn Warren Bayer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Bayer of Lawrence, L.I. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The relationship between President Reagan and Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, has deteriorated so badly that it is complicating efforts to arrange compromises on domestic and foreign policy, officials in the White House and on Capitol Hill say.

LEAD: GERICAULT'S ''Raft of the Medusa'' dominated the Paris Salon of 1819 but as the first work of art to deal with a topical outrage (the abandonment of shipwreck survivors) it nonplussed its viewers as much as it fascinated them. This huge canvas, the artist's magnum opus, remains an oddity, being considered more than reportage but somehow less than high art.

LEAD: IT WAS LIKE HALLOWEEN. PEOPLE WERE knocking pigs and chickens out of the way and stirring skeins of yarn with a long stick.'' Laura Pearson talks animatedly about the days when her handmade sweaters were dyed in a cauldron over an outdoor fire. Now only a handful of her designs for Tijuca, her New York knitwear company, are produced under comparably rugged conditions.

LEAD: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan, Carolyn Gisele Logan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis D. Logan of New York, was married yesterday to Christopher Foy Rupp, a son of Cynthia Foy Rupp of Palm Beach, Fla., and New York, and the late Albert G. Rupp. The Rev. Jane Henderson performed the ceremony.
LEAD: In my opinion the Oct. 25 article ''Garbage Is Issue in Two Races'' was unfair in its treatment of Ben Zwirn, Democratic candidate for supervisor of Town of North Hempstead.

LEAD: A GLIMPSE OF THE BEDSIDE READING OF President Corazon C. Aquino only deepens the riddle presented by this most unusual and misunderstood leader. On a low table, beside her bed with its flowered coverlet, in her cool and quiet house surrounded by sandbagged bunkers, light reading is notably absent.

Especially since Mr. Leeds is a man who hasn't a clue about the numbers on his license plate, his safe-deposit box or his Social

LEAD: A STUDY disclosed that most women dislike their bodies. It reported, however, that men tend to see themselves as just about perfect. This startled me at first. Then I laughed. Then I thought about it.

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York, Jill Nisbet Gilbert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy H. Gilbert of Lake Forest, Ill., was married yesterday to James Callahan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Callahan of Norwalk, Conn. The Rev. Victor J. Sivore performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A 22-year-old man charged with breaking windows and painting swastikas on the walls of a Jewish meat market may have been involved in other vandalism acts against Jewish-owned businesses, the police say.

LEAD: EARLY PAINE Clive Phillpot, director of the library at the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan, will give a talk about one of his countrymen - Thomas Paine - at the New Rochelle Public Library, 8 P.M. Tuesday. An emigre from England himself, albeit two centuries later, Mr. Phillpot will explore Paine's early life in Thetford, Alford and Lewes, which is seldom discussed.
LEAD: A Federal judge has rejected defense motions for acquittal of four defendants accused of killing Alan Berg, the host of a radio talk show, and closing arguments are scheduled Monday.
LEAD: Attorneys for New Jersey and New York City negotiated by telephone today in an effort to settle out of court the dispute about trash that washed up on New Jersey beaches over the summer.

LEAD: AN URCHIN IN THE STORM: Essays About Books and Ideas. By Stephen Jay Gould. (Norton, $18.95.) This collection of reviews is a perfect volume for fans of Stephen Jay Gould. For everyone else serious about writing or thinking, ''An Urchin in the Storm'' is nearly a perfect study in method. Mr. Gould, a paleontologist with a bent for the subtleties in arguments about nature and nurture and the intricacies of evolutionary theory, teaches at Harvard.

LEAD: Dr. Jennifer Suzanne Hock and Dr. Bruce Brod, who are residents at the Rhode Island Hospital in Providence, plan to be married in March.

LEAD: THE THEATER HAS A THOUSAND and one ways of doublecrossing the people who work in it, and woe betide the actor or writer or composer or designer who doesn't keep a cautious eye on his exposed left flank. The theater doesn't mean to trip up any of its attractive inhabitants, of course. It's just that in an activity so collaborative it's very easy to get some of the signals mixed.

LEAD: The trade deficit shrank in September, with the value of the nation's imports exceeding that of exports by $14.1 billion, down $1.6 billion from August. The September number was at the low end of what had been expected and financial markets were pleased, especially when traders recalled that the ''October massacre'' began with the release of the August number on Oct.

LEAD: Two weeks before Haiti is supposed to have its first presidential election in 30 years, the place designated as national election headquarters is still filled with carpenters and the racket of hammers and power saws.
LEAD: WHEN Mario DiCecco, a violinist, founded the Waterbury Symphony 50 years ago, a great brass section was at hand. Musicians moonlighted in the mills for income.

Peekskill, N.Y. $236,000 8 Avenue A, Quarry Acres 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, walk to station, 2-car garage; taxes $3,411.
LEAD: To the Editor: Having left Vietnam in 1975, my heart is still poignant with memories from Dalat, the city briefly mentioned in ''Vietnam for Visitors'' (Travel, Sept. 13).

LEAD: English Colleges Question:I am interested in attending the summer school sessions offered by Oxford or Cambridge University in England. Where can I get information on classes and arrangements? - P. E., Woodside, Queens Answer:There are several sources to approach - aside from writing to individual colleges in both cities.
LEAD: SPREAD A LITTLE HAPPINESS The First Hundred Years of the British Musical. By Sheridan Morley. Illustrated. 224 pp. New York: Thames and Hudson. $29.95.

LEAD: I have just learned that because of the huge expense of carting Town of Oyster Bay garbage to Ohio, Wisconsin and perhaps farther west as time goes on, our taxes will be increased by 47 percent. Why do those in charge not consider a moratorium on closing landfills, giving the towns an opportunity to build proper recycling and resource recovery plants?

LEAD: Susan Wagner tentatively won the Staten Island division of the Public School Athletic League's A Conference yesterday and took its first step toward repeating as league champion. The eligiblity of one of its players is in question, and the league expects to make an announcement tomorrow that could mean Wagner would forfeit all its games.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: FEW stock groups have as many handicaps to discourage investors as the savings and loan industry. Accounting rules are quirky. Regulatory burdens are onerous. And a number of the group's bolder players are hip-deep in loans that may not be repaid. If that were not enough, well-run savings units, selling at historically low valuations compared with their book values and earnings, are plentiful - more plentiful, in fact, than bargain hunters bidding for their stock.

LEAD: Covert Action Curb The Congressional Iran-contra committees' report will recommend new rules for reporting covert operations, Congressional officials say. Page 20. Role for Afghan King After 14 years of exile, the Afghan King is being mentioned as a possible key figure in a pact to end the Soviet presence in his country.
LEAD: ''TAISHU ENGEKI'' IN JAPANESE means theater for the masses. Some people call it working-class Kabuki, and that's exactly what it is.

LEAD: Almost a decade ago, New York City officials proposed a series of waste-to-energy incinerators. The first was to be built in the Brooklyn Navy Yard by 1984. Today, construction has yet to begin, delayed by strident community opposition, a lawsuit and changing environmental regulations.

LEAD: AS he stepped to the meeting table, President Hafez al-Assad of Syria stumbled into the seat reserved for his rival Baath Party comrade and now bitterest of enemies, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

LEAD: Bobby Humphery and JoJo Townsell were chosen by the Jets in the 1983 National Football League draft. Full of vim, vigor and ambition, they figured, as most rookies do, that their talents were exactly what the Jets had ordered.

LEAD: The New York City Ballet returns to the New York State Theater on Tuesday for its 87th season in the city. The highlights of this first week of the new winter season include two revivals and performances by a new member of City Ballet and several newly promoted dancers. A centerpiece of the opening-night gala benefit for the company is ''The Concert,'' that goofy but poetic evocation of concertgoing choreographed by Jerome Robbins and last performed by the company in 1984.

LEAD: Louise March, a founder of the Rochester Folk Art Guild, a nonprofit artisan's collective farm in Middlesex, N.Y., died of a heart attack yesterday at the Soldiers and Sailors Hospital in Penn Yan, N.Y. She was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan and Middlesex.

LEAD: ONE OF THE MOST POWERFUL works of art to have been produced in Britain during this century is the ''Hieratic Head of Ezra Pound'' by the very young French sculptor Henri Gaudier-Brzeska. Carved in 1914, and now the centerpiece of ''British Modernist Art: 1905-1930'' at the Hirschl & Adler Galleries, 21 East 70th Street, it stands for a key moment in the history of the cosmopolitan London that was to be dispersed and demoralized by the outbreak of World War I in

LEAD: BRITTEN'S operas - ''The Turn of the Screw'' among them - test small opera companies but also reward the virtuous among them. The orchestra parts are finely made, and their original touches speak most clearly through equally fine chamber groups. Britten's words demand the same kind of clarity; they are meant to be heard and understood at close quarters.
LEAD: The faculty of Colby College in Waterville, Me.,has voted to ban the Central Intelligence Agency from recruiting students on its campus. The student government opposes such a ban.

LEAD: The engagement of Elisa Margaret Gribin and Michael Jay Litchman has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel D. Gribin of Kings Point, L.I. Mr. Litchman is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry M. Litchman of Providence, R.I. A summer wedding is planned.

Garret D. Dorsey, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Elliot Burk officiated at the First Unitarian Church in Pittsburgh.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration and school superintendents from large cities have issued a guide to combat the problems that lead more than 3,700 teen-agers to drop out of high school every day.

LEAD: THE 25TH OF DECEMBER WAS THE DAY on which I was born, but that's not the only thing I have against it. Personally, I never believed in Mr. Claus. At least I have no recollection whatsoever of any traumatic moment of disillusionment with the myth. When his name was finally scrubbed from the tedious list of people to whom I ought to be grateful and, worse, to whom I was compelled to write, I think I was relieved to be free of yet another part of that general collusion between children and parents by which all parties strive to keep alive the wilting hope that the young are guileless.

LEAD: These are stressful times not only for the Rangers, who as a group have been somewhat cowed by a seven-game losing streak, but also for Marcel Dionne, who because of injuries to his younger teammates is playing about twice as much as he'd like to.
LEAD: A radio personality who pays for his own air time has publicly acknowledged white supremacist beliefs and renamed his weekly radio talk show ''Aryan Nations Hour.''

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Leonard S. Danzig of Little Silver, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Phoebe Danzig, to Reed Graham Schneider, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin H. Schneider of New York and Sharon, Conn. The couple plan to marry Dec. 19.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: FOR more than a hundred years, the United States has done virtually what it pleased in Central America. And for six years the conflict between the Reagan Administration and the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua has lurched and sputtered inconclusively. But last week, Reagan policy makers watched events accelerate sharply and sought to keep them from getting out of their control.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.
LEAD: IN WHAT is the largest public-relations campaign the Kean administration has ever started on behalf of public schools, New Jersey is trying to increase the role parents play in education.

LEAD: INSTALLING hanging cabinets against a framed wall is a task that many do-it-yourselfers view with trepidation. Not only must the cabinet's horizontal surfaces be level and its vertical surfaces plumb, but also, for strength, at least some of the fasteners must penetrate the studs that make up the core of the wall.
LEAD: EDUCATING children about AIDS is a race against time, according to Linda Cocian, supervisor of nursing and child care for this city's schools.

LEAD: LEAVE it to the gutsy Boston Post Road Stage Company to come up with a play that is intended to stir things up. For openers - indeed, in its first explosive scene - ''Split Second'' by Dennis McIntyre presents a harrowing confrontation, rife with racism, and then winds up raising provoking moral and legal issues.
LEAD: After two centuries two small Massachusetts towns are still vying for the title ''birthplace of the American Navy.''

LEAD: LIKE most Americans, I own an advanced state-of-the-art weapons system. Mine is a 1 1/2-ton missile propelled by a finely tuned, highly sophisticated, computer-controlled power plant that, with the slightest touch of the controls, is capable of generating forces several hundreds of times the force that I, alone, a normal mortal, unassisted, can produce.

LEAD: THEY MIGHT NOT THINK of themselves quite this way, but they constitute a distinctive group - Murray Perahia, Radu Lupu, Richard Goode, Peter Serkin, Krystian Zimerman, Andras Schiff, among them - prominent pianists who are altering the traditional image of the keyboard virtuoso.

LEAD: AT the crossroads between the fast-food getaway and a formal dining experience is the neighborhood family-style restaurant, the place for an informal meal away from home, hearth and kitchen stove. Every town needs at least one, a place where children are welcome and you can drop by for a hamburger or a steak and feel comfortable wearing jeans.

LEAD: I enjoyed reading Roberta Hershenson's article on Scarsdale's historic Wayside Cottage and the Varian family who occupied it from 1763 to 1853. [ ''In Scarsdale, a Dig Reveals the Past,'' Oct. 25 ] Your reporter did not mention the following interesting tidbits. The Wayside Cottage was at one time a Drover's Inn during the Revolutionary period.

LEAD: At the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue, Carla Renee Friedman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philmore H. Friedman of Jericho and Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married last night to Robert Karen, a son of Mrs. Murry Schulman of Hollis Hills, Queens, and the late Joseph Karen. Rabbi Louis Bernstein performed the ceremony.

LEAD: NO ONE KNOWS HOW MANY PEO-ple visit the renowned Christmas windows at Lord & Taylor on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. ''We've tried to count,'' says Kenneth B. Schliemann, a divisional vice president for the retailer, who serves as creative director for the Christmas windows. ''But it's tough to discern who's watching and who's simply passing by.

LEAD: I AM a good girl. Too good. I've always knuckled under the nearest available authority. I did what my parents told me to do, then my teachers, then my employers, lawyer and doctors. LEAD: SINCE Oct. 19 traders, regulators and the investing public have been searching for an explanation for the stock market plunge. Perhaps we will never understand exactly why this ''correction'' was so violent and why it took place when it did. Nevertheless, the usual suspects have been rounded up. High on the list of the accused are stock index futures ''program traders.

LEAD: AFTER a long day in heavy traffic, it is easy for a bus driver's nerves to frazzle, and learning to deal with stress and not take it out on overbearing passengers takes training, say NJ Transit officials.

LEAD: If the pilots of the Northwest Airlines jetliner that crashed in Detroit in August forgot a key step needed for a safe takeoff, as almost all safety experts agree, why did the plane's automatic warning system fail to sound the alarm?

LEAD: Senator Jesse Helms, decrying what he called ''the anatomy of a smear,'' said Friday that the Justice Department had cleared him of accusations that he or a member of his staff leaked classified information to officials of Chile's authoritarian Government.

LEAD: ''I'm well, I'm happy, I'm excited to be here.'' - Rudolf Nureyev, in Moscow. [ 4:1. ]

LEAD: ARTIE SHAUGHNESSY has been infected with the American dream of making it big in show business. In John Guare's surreal tragicomedy, ''The House of Blue Leaves,'' the only impediment's to Artie's rise to songwriting fame are Bananas, his insane wife; Ronnie, his AWOL son, and -well, that's just the beginning.

LEAD: THERE are women whose taste and bearing project the sort of easy self-assuredness that guarantees they will never look out of style. Such a woman is Eleanor Graham, who, in the time we have observed her, has yet to look anything but terrific.

LEAD: In many respects, the football game today against Columbia is one that Cornell would probably like to forget. The Big Red turned the ball over six times, fumbled two kickoffs, had numerous penalties and let some obvious scoring opportunities slip away.

LEAD: Larry Heinemann was not looking for much more than a free meal, some conversation and perhaps a cocktail or two. Instead, Mr. Heinemann, a Chicagoan, emerged from the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre Hotel last week as the surprise winner of the National Book Award for fiction.

LEAD: A dispatch from Philadelphia Oct. 25 about the restoration of a former department store misidentified the leader of a campaign to save the building and misstated her age. The woman, Eleanor Gesensway, is 51 years old.

LEAD: THANKS to an extensive Federal project, mariners will soon be able to ply the waters off North Jersey with less anxiety.

LEAD: AMONG the many advances in military aviation in the 1930's was a tower to train paratroopers patented by Comdr. James H. Strong in 1936. He licensed one such six-chute tower for a Chicago amusement park. But for the 1939-1940 World's Fair in New York, Commander Strong developed a 250-foot high version with 12 parachutes.
LEAD: BLACK and white in almost infinite variations is the key to Gloria Sachs's spring collection.

LEAD: THE Irish Republican Army rarely second guesses itself about the violent attacks that have claimed hundreds of lives in Northern Ireland in the last 17 years. But after one of its bombs killed 11 people at a memorial service for veterans in Enniskillen last Sunday, the outlawed organization issued its second apology in five years.
LEAD: THERE was none of the usual suspense or drama to President Reagan's announcement on Wednesday that Judge Anthony M. Kennedy was his latest choice for the Supreme Court.

LEAD: When Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad seeks to justify an unprecedented recent wave of arrests without trial, the closing of newspapers and the banning of public gatherings, he warns of the danger of rising animosity between the Malay people who gave this country its name and the Chinese who have been living among them for generations.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The movement to draft Governor Cuomo of New York for President got a push today from an unlikely source: former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., a Republican candidate for President.

LEAD: I am impressed by Edward Witten's accomplishments. However, I think he misses the point when he says: ''One lesson you can learn is don't make mistakes.'' The history of science is fraught with mistakes, made, in some cases, by eminent scientists, including Newton and Einstein. It is from these mistakes, in most cases, that we learn.

LEAD: AT THE METROPOLITAN Museum of Art's Hudson River School exhibition, there's a wonderful bit of diplomacy-cum-criticism among the annotations on the walls. A painter named Jasper Cropsey, one placard says, ''tended to model his work on that of his colleagues, using their compositions and techniques as catalysts for change in his own style.
LEAD: ONE of the Joffrey Ballet's many virtues is an ability to entertain, which it does through the most serious of artistic enterprises - a repertory that includes the great ballets of all time.

LEAD: ''I THINK every new teacher should have a mentor,'' said Linda Prince, a first-year science teacher at Syosset High School. ''In the beginning there are so many questions, and with a mentor you can ask for help without feeling like you're imposing.''

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Theodore H. Lunine of Philadelphia of the engagement of their daughter Janet Lunine to Jonathan Barzilay, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Barzilay of New York. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: A fierce debate over the environmental safety and economic wisdom of garbage-burning incinerators has begun as scores of communities around the nation move toward spending billions on their construction.

LEAD: Old-timers still tell tales about Hugh Taylor Birch, who at the turn of the century collected three miles of of isolated beachfront property when land was cheap and settlers were few and far between.

LEAD: WHEN MY SON DECIDED several years ago to turn his back on a budding career as a rock saxophonist and become a lawyer, the first question I, who had practiced law for three decades, asked myself was: ''Where have I gone wrong?'' He was accustomed to a profession in which every amplified blast of his horn, every adroit bit of body language on stage, was greeted by an adoring audience with hoots of pleasure and shouts for more.

LEAD: Jeff Wiley and Gordie Lockbaum led unbeaten Holy Cross, the No. 1 team in Division I-AA, to a 40-7 rout of William & Mary today.

LEAD: BORIS N. YELTSIN seemed the quintessential new Soviet man, a chest-thumping advocate of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's openness and restructuring and an irrepressible critic of past party failures and hidebound ideology.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William K. Zinke of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Catherine Duryee Zinke to Samuel W. Ach, the son of Sarah C. Ach of Cincinnati and the late Roger W. Ach. A spring wedding is planned.

LEAD: ON FEB. 15, THIS MAGAZINE published my article ''Crack Murder,'' the story of a veteran homicide detective, Albert E. Cachie, and his investigation of the killing of a Brooklyn crack dealer, James Baker. Baker had been found dead in the passenger seat of his Mercedes with a bullet wound in his chest and four others from another gun in his head and neck.

LEAD: IT is not just in the United States that people worry about who is going to pay for social security. Throughout the industrialized world, because of the baby boom's huge presence and low fertility rates, the classic demographic pyramid is narrowing at the base and swelling at the top. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development projects that in its 24 member nations the proportion of the population aged 65 and over will rise from 12 percent now to 22 percent in 2040.

LEAD: LIKE the giant Christmas tree that adorns the plaza at Rockefeller Center each holiday season, the Radio City Music Hall's ''Magnificent Christmas Spectacular,'' is one of the most visible and popular symbols of cultural continuity in a city where almost everything else seems subject to jarring change.

LEAD: Prof. and Mrs. Ward S. Curran of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Andrea Jannett Curran to Brian Cullinan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur D. Cullinan of North Conway, N.H.

LEAD: Linden's star running back, Kelvin Johnson, scored on a 27-yard run with three minutes left in the game to lift his team to a 19-13 victory over Westfield yesterday at Linden. It was the eighth success for unbeaten Linden, a strong contender for the North Jersey Section 2, Group IV championship in the playoffs.

LEAD: WHILE residents in other Connecticut communities lock horns over such social problems as where to construct prisons, put garbage dumps and build low-income housing, here in the tiny western town of Sherman, they argue about Tiffany lamps.

LEAD: Vice President Bush won a key ''straw poll'' today, turning back a strong challenge from Pat Robertson, the former television preacher who twice embarrassed Mr. Bush in highly visible party votes in the last year.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 25 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: IT was a matter of 1 point, but the difference between the champion and runner-up is always greater than the margin of the final score. To a certain extent, making up that difference is why Rony Seikaly returned to Syracuse this season, when the Orangemen will attempt to win the national championship that slipped away last spring.

LEAD: To the Editor: In regard to MacDonald Harris's article on Giverny (Aug. 30), my husband and I also traveled there in May; however, we had an experience of which readers of the Travel section should take notice.

LEAD: FOR Bianca Jagger, the year 1979 was portentous. That was the year she divorced the rock star Mick Jagger and the Somoza dictatorship was overthrown by Sandinista revolutionaries in her native Nicaragua.

LEAD: WHILE NEW YORK CITY is always a source of education and fun for kids, during the holiday season it becomes a wonderland. The weather is often fine in December, so it could be the perfect month for you and your children to explore and rediscover New York City while savoring a enchanting time of year.
LEAD: On a chilly Saturday night last month, 17-year-old Wendell Heard defied his parents' warnings and went to Celebrity Hall, a go-go dance club here.

LEAD: HUNDREDS of mourners, many weeping, stood in line late last week to pay respects to 6-year-old Elizabeth Steinberg, the Greenwich Village girl who died Nov. 5 after what the police said was a brutal beating by her adoptive parents.
LEAD: BOBBY, or Scooncat, as he prefers to be known, lives in a high-tech room, into which the world keeps intruding in mostly disagreeable forms.

LEAD: FOR ALL OF MY FRIENDS WHO HAVE been living out of town for too long, who have been promising each other a splurge on the ultimate, go-for-broke weekend in ''the City'' and asking me for suggestions: here is my Christmas present to you all. (And maybe a couple of ideas for the friends who are here every day.) LEAD: FOURTEEN years after American troops withdrew from Vietnam, a state commission continues to struggle with one of the most controversial results of the war. The Vietnam Herbicides Information Commission was established by legislation in 1982 for what was to have been a five-year program. Last July, the commission was reappointed under new legislation for three years to finish its work.

LEAD: The 15-week-old Government of Prime Minister Giovanni Goria resigned today after the small Liberal Party withdrew from the governing coalition in a dispute over measures to reduce the huge budget deficit.
