LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: Rudolf Nureyev, the dancer who defected more than 26 years ago, in Moscow. He was given a visa to see his ailing mother. Page 4. (Reuters)

LEAD: TRY NOT TO MISS THE current exhibition at the New York Public Library, ''William Wordsworth and the Age of English Romanticism.'' It would be worth making the effort to see it for the sake of the Turners alone, or for the work of any one of half a dozen of the other artists on view.

LEAD: The article on Edward Witten and string theory excited the mystic in me. As Malcolm W. Browne pointed out in the accompanying box, ''Mathematics and Magic,'' the 16th-century cabalists postulated that the world was created by an outpouring of divine emanations, 10 in number, called the Sefirot. The ''vibrations'' of these realms are accessible to the human senses only in their lowest manifestations.

LEAD: Once a conspirator, twice a fool. New York's King George (Steinbrenner) will pursue and sign Jack Morris, especially since an arbitrator will determine Morris's salary next year regardless of what uniform he dons. JEFFREY KANTOWITZ Fair Lawn, N.J.

LEAD: Last April, Luz Ortiz and her daughter were about to become a sad statistic: another New York City family shattered by domestic violence. Mother and child had been beating and abusing each other, leading finally to the teen-ager's placement outside the home.

LEAD: THERE are more than three dozen Caribbean islands, stretching across a body of water one-third the size of the United States. The choice presents a perennial problem: which island suits you best.
LEAD: THE PEARLKILLERS Four Novellas. By Rachel Ingalls. 215 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $15.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: RACHEL JACKSON, accompanying Andrew when he took control of Pensacola in 1821, prayed to be delivered from the ''vast, howling wilderness'' of the Florida panhandle. Shortly after the Civil War, residents of Florida's peninsula seriously considered ridding their state of a nuisance by ceding its entire western arm to Alabama for a million dollars.
LEAD: CAPTAIN VINEGAR'S COMMISSION By Philip Glazebrook. 333 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95.
LEAD: WE WAITED A WHILE for things to settle.
LEAD: I MADE a surprise landing on Planet of the Fit. It was a surprise for me because I was unaware of this alien region, only a short drive away, orbiting a remote hemisphere in a nearby mall.
LEAD: Troy Aikman ran for a touchdown and passed for another in a 17-point third quarter today as U.C.L.A. erupted for a 47-14 victory over Washington to remain unbeaten in the Pacific-10 Conference.

LEAD: Bobby McFerrin: Spontaneous Inventions Directed by Bud Schaetzle. 1986. HBO/Cannon Video. 48 minutes. $29.95. Bobby McFerrin's array of vocal techniques - hums, clicks, hisses, glottal stops, chest thumps - enables him to mimic a cappella an entire jazz ensemble. In each tune he seems to find a new way to accompany himself.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Fishman of Bala Cynwyd, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jane Leslie Fishman to Efraim Grinberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gedalio Grinberg of New York. A March wedding is planned.
LEAD: LAST April, 7-year-old Michele Snow of Riverside, Calif., was struck in the head by a heavy metal object. She died three days later.

LEAD: From the shadow of an abstract sculpture titled ''Song of the Vowels,'' a group of students and teachers raised their voices in song the other night to Thomas Pynchon and his mammoth novel, ''Gravity's Rainbow.''

LEAD: ACCOUNTING, an industry whose expansion has mirrored that of Long Island's economy, continues to see a growing demand for its services. But leaders in the field now fear that recent criticism of mistakes in the industry, as well as the increasing workloads brought on by the new tax law, will hinder their efforts to find enough qualified young recruits.
LEAD: Edith Wiens

LEAD: Heidi Gretchen Regina Solomon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Solomon of Media, Pa., was married yesterday to Peter Robert Barnett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Barnett of Hobart, Australia. Rabbi Mayer Selekman performed the ceremony at Temple Sholom in Broomall, Pa. The bride is director of sales promotion at the American Society of Chartered Life Underwriters and Chartered Financial Consultants in Bryn Mawr, Pa.
LEAD: NASA to Get Disney Center

LEAD: VALUE OF CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS (Residential in millions of dollars) Sept. 87 Sept. 86 Change New York 476.4 439.8 8% New Jersey 324.9 352.7 -8% Connecticut 198.1 228.6 -13% (Source: F.W. Dodge Division, McGraw-Hill Information Systems) *2*MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages)
LEAD: THE Newark Legal and Communications Center, a $73.8 million project to provide downtown office space for law firms, is finally becoming a reality.

LEAD: HANUKKAH IS ABOUT THE MIRACLE of a little clay lamp - the kind of primordial object, commonplace enough, that has turned up by the score in archeological digs in the old lands surrounding the Mediterranean. It happened once that a lamp of this character - a simple jar hung with a wick - contained only enough oil to last a single day.

LEAD: FOR more than 30 years, highway departments have been selling us the same old bill of goods: ''building more highways to ease congestion.'' After spending billions upon billions and paving over countless acres of valuable land, congestion is worse than ever. None of the state transportation department's proposals will ease the jams for long.

LEAD: Don Nelson, who traded 11 seasons of coaching the Milwaukee Bucks for part ownership in the Golden State Warriors, would never recognize the starting lineup his successor, Del Harris, has put together.

LEAD: An appellate judge has temporarily barred the New York City Department of Correction from transferring inmates to a former troop barge, but the agency will continue to seek to use the barge as a jail, an agency spokeswoman said yesterday.
LEAD: Debra Lynn Wolf and Mark Akulin Koenig were married yesterday at their home in New Rochelle, N.Y., by Rabbi Sandy Bogin.

LEAD: THE TERM ''CROSSOVER'' MIGHT SEEM AL-most synonymous with ''music'' in this age of fusion, eclecticism and cross-cultural borrowings. Everybody mixes genres these days, as old traditions crumble and new ones arise. But the most controversial and prominent form of crossover of late has been the incursion of opera singers into the linked worlds of the Broadway musical and the pre-rock popular song.

LEAD: The report by the Congressional Iran-contra committees will recommend new rules for covert operations that go further than the changes announced earlier this year by President Reagan, according to Congressional officials.
LEAD: Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov fought sharply on the terrain of a disputed ending before agreeing to a draw in Game 13 of their world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, Friday.

LEAD: Most anywhere in Manhattan, a 180-unit condominium project would likely climb 30 or 40 stories high. But not in Battery Park City. A few days ago, construction crews began excavating a one-acre foundation for a building that will rise only nine stories - in accordance with design guidelines established by the Battery Park City
LEAD: The Interior Department should indefinitely suspend plans to lease tracts in the Georges Bank off the New England coast for oil and gas drilling, a House subcommittee recommended Monday.
LEAD: No. I sincerely do not think free agents will be signed in baseball.

LEAD: Former Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland is no longer an ex-convict. Mr. Mandel was governor when he was convicted in 1977 of taking $380,000 in bribes in return for influencing racetrack legislation. He served 19 months in jail, paid a $40,000 fine, resigned his office and was disbarred. Last week, a Federal district judge in Baltimore overturned the convictions of Mr.

LEAD: VACATION sweepstakes to Tahiti. Robert Goulet at the mall. Ticket giveaways. These are hardly the techniques used to promote Broadway blockbusters. But Spokane and Tulsa are a long way from Times Square, and when Pace Theatrical Group Inc. takes such touring productions as ''South Pacific,'' starring Mr.

LEAD: Immediately before this week's anti-Government riots, President H. M. Ershad dropped in on some of his constituents. Among the stops was the Ninth Division headquarters of the Bangladesh Army, where he announced financing for a new mosque.
LEAD: BRIDGE administrators have argued about processes of selection for almost as long as biologists, and like them continue to disagree.

LEAD: Taking its cue from the success of programs like ''Sesame Street,'' the Kaiser Permanente Medical Care Program - a national health-care plan - has developed a theatrical troupe that travels nationwide to teach elementary-school children about health and safety.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Bloch of New York and Southbury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Bloch, to Lawrence Alan Jeydel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Jeydel of Fair Haven, N.J. A March wedding is planned.

LEAD: THERE'S no such thing as a good time for an injury, but Gary Stevens, the jockey, seems to find particularly bad ones. In 1985, he suffered broken ribs in a spill three weeks before the Breeders' Cup and missed those races. Then yesterday, Stevens suffered a broken ankle in an accident at the starting gate before the fourth race at Santa Anita, and will miss the Breeders' Cup races at Hollywood Park Saturday.
LEAD: The gazetteer accompanying an article on Turtle Bay on Nov. 1 omitted the name of a New York City Council member who serves the neighborhood. She is Carol Greitzer.

LEAD: ON those rare powder-gray days, or if the cornflower sky becomes too monotonous, many Acapulco vacationers turn away from pools and chaises to their second favorite pastime: shopping. An impressive part of the population of this tropical resort, estimated at nearly one million, is involved in the production, promotion or sale of handcrafts.
LEAD: New York City gained 37,000 units of housing between 1984 and 1987, according to city officials.

LEAD: A Travel Advisory report in the Travel section today about Dublin's 1,000th birthday lists an incorrect address for the Irish Tourist Board. The correct address is 757 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017.

LEAD: IN a practice that has angered advocates for people with AIDS, some Connecticut funeral homes are charging up to $500 extra to handle the bodies of AIDS patients, while others are turning the bodies away.

LEAD: AS part of his commitment to help developers produce more affordable housing, Mayor Koch set up the Office of Housing Coordination 18 months ago to expedite projects through New York's complicated regulatory system.
LEAD: LATE in life, Fred P. C. Chao has developed a new career, one that looks a little like taking sand to the beach.

LEAD: Four people were killed and four others were seriously injured early yesterday morning when a car lost control and crashed into a Consolidated Edison work site on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in upper Manhattan, the police said.

LEAD: Tin Men Starring Richard Dreyfuss, Danny DeVito and Barbara Hershey. Written and directed by Barry Levinson. 1987. Touchstone Home Video. 112 minutes. $89.95. Just as certain foods are relished by the Chinese more for their texture than their flavor, so must ''Tin Men'' be savored for its very special texture rather than for its plot.
LEAD: THE WORD THEY USE IS ''SCARY.''

LEAD: President Reagan said today that he expected an agreement on a budget compromise next week as Congressional and White House negotiators considered a three-month delay in Federal pay increases, cost-of-living increases for Social Security and other Federal benefit programs.

LEAD: GHOST'S HOUR, SPOOK'S HOUR By Eve Bunting. Illustrated by Donald Carrick. Unpaged. New York: Clarion Books/ Ticknor & Fields. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9) I WON'T GO TO BED! By Harriet Ziefert. Illustrated by Andrea Baruffi. Unpaged. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $10.95. (Ages 4 to 8)
LEAD: Sexual Privacy
LEAD: Pieter Nicolaas Menten, the Netherlands' most notorious Nazi war criminal, died here today in a nursing home, according to Dutch television. He was 88 years old and no cause of death was given.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William A. Colt of Sharon, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Cathy Ann Colt to Dr. Roger James Pomerantz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Pomerantz of Scarsdale, N.Y. The wedding is planned for next month.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: When the day is clear or the moon is bright, the traveler descending on Bangkok from the air can see right through one of Thailand's disguises.
LEAD: Amid signs of increasing turmoil within his Presidential campaign, Bob Dole plans to announce a virtual top-to-bottom shake-up of his organization next week.
LEAD: The Devils allowed five straight power-play goals to the Detroit Red Wings this afternoon and suffered their first loss of the season at home, 6-4.
LEAD: AFTER nearly two years of scandals, and more than a year of talk about reform, New York City's government is now likely to approve public financing of municipal election campaigns.

LEAD: It's a good week for New York bands with international tastes. Saqqara Dogs, a trio that performs Monday and Tuesday at Dance Theater Workshop (219 West 19th Street), keep the world on a guitar string. Their songs, mostly instrumentals, are built on repeating riffs that might come from Africa, the Middle East or the Bronx; the spiky, danceable tunes mix exotic instruments - especially dumbek (drum) and mbira (thumb piano) - with Western electronics, for sparse, minimal funk.

LEAD: Lebanese police officials inspecting site of bombing yesterday at the American University Hospital in West Beirut. The bomb, which was hidden in a box of chocolates, killed 7 people and wounded 31. Page 3. (Reuters)

LEAD: PACKAGE tours are a good way to cut costs and save time arranging a vacation in the sun. In addition to air fare and hotel accommodations, most include Federal departure tax and airport transfers. Some, known as all-inclusive packages, include meals, drinks, recreational activities, taxes and tips.

LEAD: Senator Robert Dole is a formidable candidate for President: sensible, knowing in the ways of Washington, a conservative who has no time for the fantasies of Reaganomics. He has shed the meanness of the past, showing us instead a man with compassion for the dependent and rejected in society.

LEAD: Ellen O'Neill Beach, a daughter of Victoria Gorcoff Beach of Schenectady, N.Y., and John Arthur Beach of Albany and Syracuse, was married yesterday to George Mares. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marin Mares of Bucharest, Rumania.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: JOE MANTEGNA REVELS IN shady characters: slimy gamblers, cutthroat salesmen, lecherous dentists, mercurial mobsters and Hollywood hucksters. He plays the type of men who snarl, ''You say I acted atrociously? Yes I did. I do it for a living.'' Even his less raffish roles are rarely saintly - a New York actor impersonating an ex-con, an ambitious attorney who ''wants to be Senator after he's President.

LEAD: A PLAN to allow liberal-arts graduates who are not education majors to teach in Connecticut schools has attracted attention from hundreds of people interested in changing careers to teaching. But it has also split educators.

LEAD: Ever since the Wall Street plunge demonstrated the financial world's interdependency, Asian opinion leaders have been viewing the U.S. with the same condescension as the brisk Lilliputians saw big Lemuel Gulliver: an amiable, clumsy giant whose profligacy is awful but whose strength could still prove useful.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mary Beth Whitehead, who says her marriage fell apart in the course of the landmark Baby M custody case, has started two new lives. As Mrs. Whitehead was divorced from her husband, Richard, last week, her lawyers disclosed that she plans ''very soon'' to wed Dean Gould, the father of a baby Mrs. Whitehead expects in the spring.

LEAD: THOMAS Sobol was inaugurated last month as New York State's 11th Commissioner of Education, the chief executive officer of the Board of Regents. In this post, Mr. Sobol, a 55-year-old former superintendent of schools in Scarsdale, bears the responsibility for guiding probably the most diverse network of local school systems in the country at a time when the quality of public education has become a major political issue.
LEAD: A half-season after the Super Bowl, the Giants will finally begin to take the measure of the slick wide receivers they drafted this year.

LEAD: In the flag-draped sanctuary of St. Agnes Church here, before a two-foot portrait of the late singer Kate Smith, the Rev. Albert Salmon, looked out on the 700 people who had come to pay to the woman who gave voice to American patriotism.

LEAD: To the Editor: In a Practical Traveler column on July 5 by Dennis Hevesi about adventure trips for the disabled, there was brief mention of the Blue Spruce Lodge in Trout Creek, Mont. I sent for a brochure and decided to make the trip. It turned out to be the greatest vacation of my life.

LEAD: THE entry on getting around by cycle in Bermuda in the 1988 edition of a well-known guidebook includes the following sentences about motorized bicycles, or mopeds: ''If you've never ridden before, don't worry. You'll have as much time as you need to practice in an open area before hitting the road.
LEAD: THE ARABIAN NIGHTMARE By Robert Irwin. Illustrated. 282 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

LEAD: A GENERATION of consciousness-raising makes Kurt Weill's ''Lost in the Stars'' seem ponderous today. Racial hostility's broad themes are too powerful and pervasive to need simple restatement anymore, making this musical version of ''Cry the Beloved Country'' an all too black-and-white rendering of recent social history.

LEAD: KALEIDOSCOPE. By Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) In her 21st novel, Danielle Steel continues her forays into the life styles of the rich and heartsick. This time, readers are led to war-torn Europe, where they witness the burgeoning friendship of two Americans, Sam Walker and Arthur Patterson, as well as the heady love affair between Sam and Solange Bertrand, an exquisite Frenchwoman.

LEAD: At the Swedish Seamen's Church in New York, Nancy Ann Olson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin R. Olson of Glenview, Ill., was married yesterday to Dan Hofstadter, the son of the late Felice Swados Hofstadter and the late Richard Hofstadter of New York. The Rev. Jan Madestam, a Lutheran minister and the pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: I identified with Frank Wolkenberg's feelings of relief. That is what I felt when our son was recently diagnosed as having Attention Deficit Disorder. We received a brief explanation from his psychologist and advice from a neurologist, but Frank Wolkenberg's article was the most I have read on the subject.

LEAD: Dr. Julius Lane Wilson, first director of medical education of the American Thoracic Society, the medical section of the American Lung Association, died of an aneurysm Tuesday at his home in Tryon, N.C. He was 90 years old.
LEAD: ANGELS FEAR Towards an Epistemology of the Sacred. By Gregory Bateson and Mary Catherine Bateson. 224 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $18.95.

LEAD: It's tempting to see the Boris Yeltsin story as the end of Soviet ''new thinking'' and a slide back to the days of Stalin's purges. But caution is in order. It's fine to applaud loosening of controls and to condemn the old Soviet ways. It makes little sense, however, to draw profound conclusions about the fate of glasnost, or openness, and perestroika, or reform, on the basis of daily or even monthly events.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ''IN ENGLAND, we have three years of cut-knuckle training, but in America you just go into the studio and get on with it.''

LEAD: I FIRST CAME TO KNOW WILLIAM Gaddis at a writers' conference in the Soviet Union in 1985. I had heard that he was shy and averse to publicity, but I found that this reputation was based only on his belief that a writer's life and personality should be as little as possible associated with his work.
LEAD: LIFE is a process of choices, most people like to believe.
LEAD: LIVING HUNGRY IN AMERICA By J. Larry Brown and H. F. Pizer. Illustrated. 212 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $18.95.
LEAD: IF the third time's a charm, Joe Dudek should have quite a season with the Denver Broncos next year.

LEAD: ONE MAY OR may not feast on ham or lamb at Easter. And a goose, or some other fowl, at Christmas is fit for a flip of the coin. But the last Thursday in November without turkey is a cause for depression.

LEAD: MATCHING Fieldcrest towels, sweaters and a wedding gown filled Capt. Eleanor Alexander's hope chest. The 27-year-old Army nurse from River Vale had put off marriage until she returned from her six-month stint in Vietnam.
LEAD: THESE BLACK TIMES are getting blacker.

LEAD: The Silver Chalice With Paul Newman, Virginia Mayo, Jack Palance, Pier Angeli, Lorne Greene, E. G. Marshall, Natalie Wood. 1954. Warner Home Video. 135 minutes. $19.98. ''Introducing Paul Newman,'' the opening credits proclaim, and the Biblical-epic buff doesn't need more of a reason than that to sit through this New Testament saga.
LEAD: William Rion Bonham, comptroller for the law firm of Goldberg & Finmann, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Glen Cove (L.I.) Community Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Sea Cliff, L.I.

LEAD: I am the mother of a 9 1/2-year-old boy who has ADD with hyperactivity. After our son was diagnosed three years ago, we decided not to use medication, and our pediatrician backed us up on this. We work on teaching him appropriate behavior and self-control.
LEAD: THE LIFE OF THE PARTY Democratic Prospects in 1988 and Beyond. By Robert Kuttner. 265 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $18.95.

LEAD: I KNOW IT ISN'T FAIR TO FOLLOW CELEBRATED thinkers around waiting for them to contradict themselves. But who ever said critics were fair? Of all living composers, perhaps Pierre Boulez has put the most stock in logical argument. Even his famous polemics in behalf of his own works, though transparent propaganda of an elevated sort, have always had an air of indisputable rationality about them.
LEAD: A group of Rochester hospitals has decided to let the amount of money they are paid for their services be determined in part by the quality of care.

LEAD: Tennis Lendl and Jarryd in Final: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia and fifth-seeded Anders Jarryd won their semifinal matches yesterday in the $375,000 Benson and Hedges championships at Wembley, England. Lendl eliminated Henri Leconte of France by 6-4, 7-6 and Jarryd defeated unseeded Jacob Hlasek of Switzerland by 7-6, 6-1.

LEAD: YOUTH SCENE Despite their peers' obvious preoccupation with pop music, some teen-agers are still interested in the classics. Just how well this interest is translated into achievement should become apparent today, when two youth orchestras and winners of the Great Neck Symphony's Young Musicians Competition take to the stage.

LEAD: For a bigwig in the major leagues of sports, an empty warehouse might seem like a bush way to buy into the Manhattan real estate game. But John McMullen figures he can take the 60-year-old building on the northeast corner of Hubert and West Streets, whip it into shape by next November and charge about $25 a square foot to downtown companies that need back-office space.

LEAD: NEWARK'S Central Ward is a collection of fragments: institutions that have stayed put and grown while most fled, shiny new suburban-style housing built for homeowners, the darker remains of the city of the poor and much cleared land.

LEAD: IF the Valley Stream residents on and near South Cottage Street get their way, operations at Inflight Newspapers Inc., which supplies the two major New York airports and their airlines with newspapers and magazines, will stop between 11 P.M. and 7 A.M.
LEAD: Hopkins, the defending champions in the Fairchester League, retained its title with a 31-18 victory over the Southern Division winner, Fieldston.

LEAD: The military contracting industry, which was riding high only several years ago as the Reagan Administration pursued the largest arms buildup in American peacetime history, is now heading into what may be its most difficult and competitive era.

LEAD: An enormous glowing blue arc in the distant universe, observed earlier this year and thought to be one of the largest objects yet detected in the cosmos, turns out to be an optical illusion caused by the light-bending effects of gravity, astronomers reported yesterday.

LEAD: Lenin lies in his tomb on Red Square, and Stalin is interred at the Kremlin Wall. LEAD: President Reagan, who rode into office as the nemesis of Big Government, now rides around Washington as the defender of an indefensible cause: elevating the Veterans Administration to a cabinet-level department. Yet that seems likely; bipartisan majorities in Congress appear ready to roll.

LEAD: It has been close to a decade since the first oversized tennis racquets came onto the market, and two decades since Jimmy Connors played with his first steel racquet. Now comes another oddity: a racquet that its manufacturer, Wilson Sporting Goods Company of River Grove, Ill., says will set a new standard.

LEAD: Soviet officials are scheduled to come to the United States next week to inspect an installation in Utah intended to dispose of chemical weapons. The idea is to demonstrate the technology for getting rid of chemical weapons if a treaty banning them is signed. But the Washington press corps may want to think twice before trying to cover this inspection.

LEAD: Lawyers for New Jersey and New York City worked down to the wire today to avoid going to court to settle their dispute over garbage that fouled the state's beaches in the summer.

LEAD: ''BREAKING THE CODE,'' the new London import at the Neil Simon Theater, is yet another English drama about a sensitive genius whose homosexuality leads to his crucifixion by the hypocritical establishment. But if Hugh Whitemore's flawed, discursive play shares many of the symptoms of its well-worn genre, it finally pulls away from the sentimentality of ''Another Country'' and ''Prick Up Your Ears'' and all the recent rest.
LEAD: The comments and questions from the audience about last week's public repudiation of Boris N. Yeltsin by the Communist Party bristled with anger and disillusionment.

The traffic turned out to be Air Force fighter planes flying over the Pentagon as part of the ceremonies saluting Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger on his last day in office.

LEAD: Helen Hallet Kennedy, a civic leader in Bedford, N.Y., died Sunday at her daughter's home in Bedford after a brief illness. She was 80 years old.

LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today proposed a 3.6 percent reduction in long-distance rates. It said the plan was contingent on the Government's reducing the access charges it must pay to local telephone companies by that amount.

LEAD: Mountain climbers, including sons of the first two men to reach the summit of Mount Everest, plan to scale the Himalayan peak next spring in the first attempt to plant equipment there for making precise measurements of its elevation, expedition organizers announced last week.

LEAD: A majority of the members of the Economic Policy Committee of the 24-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development today called on West Germany to do more to stimulate its economy.
LEAD: To the Living Section:

LEAD: Dr. Mary Schmidt Campbell, the first to admit she was ''brazen'' in seeking the job as New York City's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, has now spent seven weeks in office, and she does not seem a bit daunted by the task. ''I am a political animal,'' she says, adding that she feels comfortable with the political system and intends to use it to help the arts, starting from the grass roots on up.

LEAD: The dollar fell sharply yesterday in selling that began on Asian and European foreign-exchange markets and carried over into New York. Business was relatively quiet in all markets, currency dealers said, but sales of dollars were persistent enough to erase the gains made by the dollar on Monday.

LEAD: Micheal Ray Richardson, the guard formerly with the Knicks and Nets, has signed a contract to play for the Albany Patroons of the Continental Basketball Association. He was banned from the National Basketball Association in 1986 for repeated drug use. . . . The Philadelphia Flyers have signed Ron Hextall, the goaltender, to a new multiyear contract.
LEAD: Although intrauterine devices became one of the most widely used types of birth control during the 1970's, their inventors were unclear about how such devices interacted with the body.

LEAD: OUR refrigerator used to develop a nervous tic at Thanskgiving and Christmas. Not because it was stuffed with food - which it was -but because my children were home from school for vacation and opened it every time they passed it.

LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday rejected a motion to throw out a lawsuit brought in 1981 by a Peruvian commodities trading company against the Hunt brothers of Texas and leading brokerage firms. The ruling means that the suit will be heard in Federal court beginning Feb. 3, 1988.
LEAD: To The Living Section:
LEAD: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday at Citicorp's regular weekly commercial paper auctions.

LEAD: Investigators focused their attention today on building what could become a multiple-murder case against Richard Angelo, the registered nurse accused of injecting fatal amounts of a muscle-paralyzing drug into one of his patients at Good Samaritan Hospital here.

LEAD: Ireene Wicker Hammer, who as ''The Singing Lady'' told fairy tales over radio and television to millions of American children, died yesterday in a nursing home in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 86 years old.

LEAD: A contract for Thomas Hearns to defend his World Boxing Council middleweight title against Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the former undisputed champion, could be completed by the end of next week, according to the Hearns camp. LEAD: Q. We recently moved into a home that had carpet in the bathroom. This carpet was held down with double-faced tape that has left a gummy residue on the floor. LEAD: A major earthquake followed by dozens of aftershocks jarred portions of Alaska Tuesday and forced hundreds of coastal residents to flee their homes. No serious injuries or damage were reported in the quakes, which began with a temblor measuring 6.9 on the Richter scale. The quake was centered in the Gulf of Alaska, about 270 miles east-southeast of Anchorage and 90 miles southwest of Cape Yakataga, between Yakutat and Cordova.
LEAD: Home building plunged in October to its lowest level in more than four years, the Government reported today.
LEAD: A 10-year restoration of Flushing Meadows Corona Park, at a cost to New York City of $80 million, is to be announced today by Mayor Koch.

LEAD: ''Magdalena,'' the only Broadway musical with a score by the Brazilian musical giant Heitor Villa-Lobos, occupies a singular niche in the annals of music-theater history. When the lavish folk operetta opened at the Ziegfeld Theater on Broadway on Sept. 20, 1948, after wildly successful engagements in Los Angeles and San Francisco, it was the most expensive show to have been produced on Broadway.

LEAD: Vice President Bush leads Senator Bob Dole of Kansas among New Hampshire voters in the race for the Republican Presidential nomination, a poll indicates.

LEAD: The Borough Presidents of Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx yesterday sued Mayor Koch and the Board of Estimate, of which they are members, to stop the Mayor's plan to build shelters for the homeless in their boroughs.

LEAD: ''Jean Renoir, the Boss'' was shown as part of the 1985 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 5, 1985. The film opens today at the Bleecker Street Cinema.

LEAD: Pressing its defense against a $1.1 billion takeover bid from Paul A. Bilzerian, the Singer Company said it had begun preliminary discussions with a number of domestic and foreign companies. Singer added that it could not give any assurance that anything would develop. Singer said it had begun talking to suitors ''as a possible alternative'' to the Florida corporate raider's $50-a-share tender offer and had been furnishing these suitors with confidential data on Singer.
LEAD: United Press International, which has reeled from crisis to crisis in its struggle to survive, announced yesterday that it was making its third change of top editors in less than a year.

LEAD: Senior contra officials say that they reject a recent Sandinista cease-fire proposal and that they will probably make a counterproposal to an intermediary for the Nicaraguan Government sometime next week.

LEAD: Dr. Samuel Engle Burr Jr., a former professor of education at the American University in Washington, died Monday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 89 years old and lived in Hightstown, N.J.

LEAD: ''WE'RE out to make hot tea hot,'' exclaimed Susan Read, effusive executive vice president and executive creative director of Lintas:New York, as she turned to the VCR to bring the new campaign for Lipton tea to the screen. It was, she promised, a big idea. In any event it was big enough to supplant Don Meredith, the one-time Dallas Cowboys quarterback who had been spokesman for the flow-through tea bags for more than a decade.
LEAD: Goldman, Sachs & Company laid off several employees yesterday in two divisions.

LEAD: The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee said today that, although he expected the confirmation process for Judge Anthony M. Kennedy to ''move pretty swiftly,'' the full Senate was unlikely to vote on his nomination to the Supreme Court until early February.

LEAD: Fifty-six passengers on a city bus in Brooklyn were injured yesterday morning when, after a collision with a car, the bus driver swerved to avoid a crowded bus stop and crashed into a storefront, the police said.

LEAD: The Westfield Symphony will give a free performance of works by Mahler and Tchaikovsky tomorrow at 2 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. The symphony, based in Westfield, N.J., and conducted by Brad Keimach, will perform Mahler's Symphony No. 4 and Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto. The soloists are Peter Winograd, violinist, and Cheryl Parrish, soprano.

LEAD: The new managers of Crazy Eddie Inc. said yesterday that they had discovered an inventory shortfall estimated at $45 million and that the consumer electronics retailer expected a ''substantial'' third-quarter loss.
LEAD: Gordie Lockbaum finished an incredible career, and Holy Cross finished its first unbeaten season since 1918 tonight.

LEAD: The Villa-Lobos Music Society will present an all Villa-Lobos concert, including several premieres, tonight at 8 o'clock in Cami Hall (165 West 57th Street). Tickets are $10. Information: 427-5103.

LEAD: The money might come from drug trafficking or insider trading or loan sharking or embezzlement. But until recently, two things about it were always true. First, no matter how ill-gotten it might be, the wrongdoer was always free to spend it on a lawyer. Second, that lawyer was always free to accept it - and keep it.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Christopher Wilmarth, a critically acclaimed sculptor whose works are on permanent display at many of the nation's best-known museums, apparently hanged himself yesterday in his studio-home in Brooklyn, the police said. He was 44 years old.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Amid the military pageantry of the farewell ceremony for Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger on Tuesday came a poignant reminder of military reality and a footnote to recent history.

LEAD: IT has never been easy to make an exhibition of Andre Derain that validates the very high regard in which he was held by those who knew him. Derain the man was clearly a man of good will, a marvel of intelligence and the best of companions in the Louvre. As a young man, he wrote some of the most vivid and amusing of all artists' letters.

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 411 money market mutual funds increased $1.54 billion, to $262.91 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 111 institutional funds were up $781.2 million, to $74.37 billion. Assets of the 207 general-purpose funds were up $294.5 million, to $79.12 billion.
LEAD: Wilf Paiement, who has not played in the minor leagues since 1974, was assigned yesterday to the Muskegon Lumberjacks of the International Hockey League by the Piitsburgh Penguins.

LEAD: As everyone knows, Miami is an odd place. It is definitely part of the United States, but it is also the capital of a misty Latin American republic called Exilia, Refugia or Nostalgia, according to choice. It lives steadily preoccupied with Cuba, some 90 miles and a world away, but Cuba can be approached from various directions.

LEAD: Three months after he left his post as White House deputy chief of staff in 1985 to become a private lobbyist, Michael K. Deaver apparently used the radio telephone on Nancy Reagan's official airplane to conduct his consulting business, witnesses at Mr. Deaver's perjury trial said today.
LEAD: A Long Island man was shot to death gangland style early yesterday in Bayside, Queens, and the police said he might have been an associate in the Colombo organized-crime family.

LEAD: As the Knicks broke out of their timeout huddle with 4 minutes 56 seconds remaining in the fourth period tonight, holding a lead of 101-93 over the Nets, Coach Rick Pitino's final words were, ''Forget the score, keep playing offense.''

LEAD: The Rev. William Huegel, left, pastor of First Baptist Church in Winchester, being comforted after fire damaged the church yesterday. With him are the Rev. L. Stanley Manierre and the Rev. Veronica Lanier of the American Baptist Churches. No injuries were reported. Part of the building was being converted into condominium apartments.

LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about a rehearsal for a concert production of Heitor Villa-Lobo's ''Magdalena'' misidentified the woman standing at left. She was Dona D. Vaughn, co-col-laborator and director of the musical.

LEAD: PUBLIC television's ''Mystery!'' series, broadcast on Channel 13 Saturdays at 9 P.M., is heading into the stretch this weekend of what has turned out to be a first-rate Dorothy L. Sayers festival. Dramatizations of three of her Lord Peter Wimsey novels have been scheduled back to back, the collection recounting, even as assorted mysteries have to be solved, Lord Peter's persistent wooing of Harriet Vane, herself an Oxford-educated writer of mystery novels.

LEAD: A Delta Air Lines jet with 112 people aboard lost power in an engine over the Pacific but landed safely after flying 400 miles on its two remaining engines with a military escort, officials said today.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. THE BALLROOM, #253 West 28th Street (244-3005) - *(Nov. 8, 1985) This restaurant-cum-cabaret is holding its fifth annual Festival of the Birds on Thanksgiving Day.
LEAD: A former Protestant city councilman who once said Roman Catholics should be burned was shot in the head and critically wounded today, the police said.

LEAD: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company has agreed to lower its rates by $8.2 million or 1.6 percent a year, Governor Cuomo's office announced today. The agreement, worked out between the utility and state officials, will mean a savings of about $1.20 a month through Oct. 1, 1989 for the typical Brooklyn Union customer, the Governor's office said.
LEAD: The $14 slacks and blue jeans are stacked high at the Starr Western Wear store here, a few blocks from the Mexican border, in preparation for the annual rush of holiday shoppers.
LEAD: Republican Congressional leaders today strongly criticized a proposal to invite Mikhail S. Gorbachev to address a joint meeting of Congress.

LEAD: Americans traveling to Mexico may not see hotel rates or air fares reduced immediately by the plunging value of the peso, but they will be able to find shopping bargains, travel agents said yesterday.

LEAD: As one of the world's largest manufacturers of consumer electronics, the Sony Corporation knows plenty about the hardware side of the music business. But it has had little experience with the recording side, which includes the delicate task of handling temperamental artists.
LEAD: The Economy

LEAD: William Anderson Sutherland, a founding partner of Sutherland, Asbill & Brennan, an Atlanta and Washington law firm, died Nov. 7 of a heart attack at his home in Washington. He was 91 years old.

LEAD: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, increasing American pressure on Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, voted unanimously today to cut off all but humanitarian aid to Panama until civilian rule is restored.
LEAD: Elizabeth Corday, the longtime executive producer of the daytime drama ''Days of Our Lives,'' died of respiratory failure Monday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center here. She was 75 years old.

LEAD: Detaining suspected truants is among the duties New York City police officers can legally carry out, the state's highest court ruled today. In a 6-1 decision written by Chief Judge Sol Wachtler, the Court of Appeals said the city's charter gives officers in New York City responsibility for guarding the ''public health'' and preventing ''the violation of all laws and ordinances in force in the city,'' Judge Wachtler wrote.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An appellate judge in Manhattan strongly rejected a bid yesterday by Joel B. Steinberg and Hedda Nussbaum to prevent the biological mother of 17-month-old Mitchell Steinberg from taking custody of him.

LEAD: The growth of large law firms and the salaries they pay is having a logical effect: in a survey of 1986 law school graduates, the National Association for Law Placement has found that 61.6 percent entered private practice, the highest percentage since the association started keeping records in 1974, when 52.2 percent went into private practice.
LEAD: Six Soviet scientists and diplomats toured a chemical weapons installation in the western Utah desert today, an event that some officials said could lead to a treaty banning the weapons.
LEAD: The Magazine Publishers of America yesterday heralded the names of the 1987 Publisher of the Year and of the group's new executive vice president/ marketing development.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will meet next week in Geneva with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, to resolve remaining differences on a missile treaty and to review the agenda for the summit meeting next month, Reagan Administration officials said today.
LEAD: Choir in the Park
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It's certainly arguable whether inviting Mikhail Gorbachev to address a joint meeting of the United States Congress is a good idea. But indisputably the confused squabble between the White House and Congressional leaders over that invitation is a shameful global embarrassment.

LEAD: The National Basketball Association and the Turner Broadcasting System have reached a two-year contract extension granting TBS exclusive national cable rights to games through the 1989-90 season for $50 million. The fee is double that of the current contract, which expires at the conclusion of the present season.

LEAD: Piedmont Airlines today became the first airline to order devices for its planes to warn against collisions. The Government has said it will require the equipment on all large airliners by 1991 or 1992.

LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission has asked the Justice Department to prosecute Donald J. Trump, the New York developer and investor, for making use of a ''parking'' agreement to facilitate an acquisition.

LEAD: An article on Oct. 25 about a program to assign police liaison officers to some New York City hospitals incorrectly described the history of the program at Bellevue Hospital Center. A liaison officer has been assigned to Bellevue for many years.
LEAD: The summit meeting is less than three weeks away and much of this city is in a bit of a dither.
LEAD: The New Jersey Highway Authority voted today to double the 25-cent tolls on the Garden State Parkway.
LEAD: Lettered high on the tall facade of Nebraska Stadium here is a noble tenet: ''Courage, generosity, fairness: These are the true awards of manly sport.''

LEAD: The cost of caring for some AIDS patients could be reduced to less than $100 a day from about $800 a day if public and private health insurance plans would pay for home care of AIDS patients, health care officials say.

LEAD: Two films from the 1930's by the French director Pierre Chenal - an adaptation of Dostoyevsky's ''Crime and Punishment,'' and ''The Man From Nowhere,'' a comedy based on Pirandello's ''Late Mathias Pascal'' - will be screened through Thursday at Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street. The actor Pierre Blanchar was featured in both films; at the 1935 Venice Film Festival, he was named best actor for his role as Raskolnikov in ''Crime and Punishment.

LEAD: For the 181 lawyers, investigators, clerks and secretaries on the staffs of the Iran-contra Congressional committees it is all over but the cleanup - a 10-month whirlwind in which strangers came together and shaped a piece of history, ''It's a once in a lifetime experience - once you do this, what could ever be as exciting again?
LEAD: A series of mandatory lectures on drinking and driving is being lined up for Minnesota Vikings players by General Manager Mike Lynn after the arrests of several players for drunken driving.

LEAD: MORE than anyone else, the nation's horse breeders should care about the medication crisis in thoroughbred racing. Instead, when they present their $10 million Breeders' Cup extravaganza at Hollywood Park tomorrow, they will be perpetuating the sport's most unsavory aspect.
LEAD: Researchers at the National Institutes of Health said today that an amino acid compound had proved in laboratory tests to be a ''very, very promising'' drug for the treatment of tumors.

LEAD: Lee Byung Chull, chairman and founder of the Samsung Group and one of the fathers of modern industrial South Korea, died of lung cancer today. He was 77 years old. Mr. Lee started his business in 1938 and rebuilt it after the Korean War into a high-technology manufacturer and South Korea's first major trading company.

LEAD: After an impasse of several months, the Canadian Government today enacted into law a measure sought by the United States that will give 10 years' patent protection to drug manufacturers marketing their products in Canada.

LEAD: HOW valid are the assumptions that underlie the relatively hopeful forecast of most American economists and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris that the United States economy will continue growing slowly next year?

LEAD: Shamrock Holdings Inc. said it planned a hostile tender offer of $12 a share, or $91.9 million, for the interest it does not already own in Wherehouse Entertainment Inc. In addition, Shamrock, based in Burbank, Calif., sued Wherehouse in a state court over the company's anti-takeover plan. Wherehouse, one of the nation's largest video, record and computer software chains, rejected an unsolicited $14.25-a-share bid from Shamrock last month.

LEAD: SCULPTURE is so abundant in New York art galleries these days that it may well qualify as the season's dominant art form. Nowhere is it more plentiful than at Metro Pictures in SoHo, where Martin Kippenberger's exhibition threatens to spill out onto the street. Mr. Kippenberger, a 34-year-old artist who lives in Cologne, West Germany, has exhibited paintings and sculpture in Europe for nearly a decade.

LEAD: The Mets have signed Larry Milbourne, a former major-league infielder, as an instructor in their minor-league system. Milbourne, who retired after the 1985 season after 11 seasons in the big leagues, including two stints with the Yankees, will be assigned specific duties later. . . . LEAD: The Eating Well column in The Living Section on Wednesday gave an incorrect figure for the amount of omega-3 fatty acids in certain fish.
LEAD: In August 1980, Wilfredo Gomez, the World Boxing Council superbantamweight champion, knocked out Derrik Holmes in five rounds in a nationally televised bout.

LEAD: When William E. Brock 3d took over as chairman of Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign two weeks ago he stressed the need for an ''open campaign.''

LEAD: The Occidental Petroleum Company, in a consortium with an Italian chemical company and a Japanese trading house, signed an agreement today with Moscow to build a petrochemical plant near the Caspian Sea that could cost as much as $6 billion.

LEAD: ''It will have an enormous effect on the floor of the House and the Senate and help us capture the votes we need to pass a compromise.'' - Representative Pat Williams, Democrat of Montana, on the prospect of automatic budget cuts. [ A1:6. ]
LEAD: The most accurate kickers in National Football League history are playing right now. And two of them are performing for New York teams.

Luckily, Miss Streisand's performance is better than that, but it's the showboating aspects of '

LEAD: The board of the Duro-Test Corporation said it had rejected a tender offer of $14 a share, or $66 million, from a partnership led by William P. Lyons, a Yale University professor, and said it was considering a sale of the company to a third party or in a leveraged buyout. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Duro-Test said it had provided information about the company to others who had expressed an interest in the light bulb manufacturer, based in North Bergen, N.J.

LEAD: WHEN a clean-cut college student turns into a werewolf, he does unspeakable things. Nothing violent, but this monster cuts classes! He starts hanging around with a frivolous crowd - oh, no! college students who like to dance! - so his jilted girlfriend confronts him in biology class. ''They don't like you, only the wolf,'' she warns.

LEAD: The Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, made no announcement today about its short-term interest rates after a meeting of its central committee. Many economists had predicted that the bank would announce a reduction today.

LEAD: At a closed-door meeting in New York this week, executives controlling several hundred billion dollars of corporate pension funds vowed to take steps to reduce the amounts they pay Wall Street brokers and investment management organizations.

LEAD: ''This kind of neurotic behavior is not usually handled in groups,'' Dr. Perry Frantzman explained. His 14 patients were in a circle. The doctor had agreed to take them on because he knew otherwise it might mean death.

LEAD: A Federal district judge has reduced to $5.3 million the $22.8 million libel judgment that the entertainer Wayne Newton won against NBC, ruling that the evidence did not support Mr. Newton's assertion that television broadcasts linking him to organized crime figures had hurt his reputation or income.

LEAD: Two pelicans waiting in a van at the Bronx Zoo yesterday before they were taken to their winter quarters indoors. It took a dozen zookeepers, some in waders and some in boats, to capture the four pelicans on the zoo's Cope Lake and bring them in for the season. (NYT/Ruby Washington)

LEAD: This was a bustling week for the antiques market in New York. Manhattan's newest and most elaborately designed antiques center - Place des Antiquaires, at 125 East 57th Street -opened to the public yesterday after many delays, and an ambitious show of period art, furnishings and decorations opened Wednesday at Didier Aaron, 32 East 67th

LEAD: The Orchestra of the 18th Century will perform at the Fine Arts Center of the State University campus at Stony Brook, L.I., tomorrow at 8 P.M. Tickets are $14 to $18. Information and directions: (516) 632-7235.

LEAD: Several hundred students gathered Tuesday at Moscow State University in an unusual expression of public concern over the Soviet hierarchy's ouster of the popular Moscow Communist Party chief, according to a participant.

LEAD: One of the great joys of Laurence Olivier's professional life was watching John Gielgud and Ralph Richardson act together onstage. Seeing those two knights in tandem was ''a dream,'' observed Lord Olivier, ''a brilliant double act'' with ''all guns blazing.'' In modern theatrical history, there have, of course, been other twinned performances of the highest caliber, though perhaps not with the astonishing symbiosis - and contrast of opposites - of these theatrical eminences.

LEAD: The British Government has made two public policy decisions this week that organizations representing AIDS-infected individuals are hailing as important and enlightened steps in dealing with the needs of AIDS-sufferers in Britain and in helping check the spread of the disease.

LEAD: LET writers of other epochs contemplate the myths of antiquity or the deaths of kings as they struggle with the fine points of existence. For American playwrights of a certain generation, ''I Love Lucy'' is a deeper commentary on the family constellation than ''Oedipus''; ''Wheel of Fortune'' says more about democracy's drift than ''Leaves of Grass.

LEAD: A Suffolk County grand jury indicted a 25-year-old nurse today on three counts of assault, and the authorities exhumed two bodies in what could become a multiple-homicide case against the nurse, Richard Angelo.

LEAD: The United States made a formal request yesterday to host the 1994 World Cup Championship. President Reagan made the bid in a meeting with Joao Havelange, president of FIFA, soccer's governing body, at the White House.

LEAD: FORESTS of Tiffany lamps cast a color-pulsing glow on Bauhaus chromed metal tables, Art Deco frosted-glass vases and vehemently Victorian carved desks. The bazaar called ''Modernism: a Century of Style and Design, 1860 to 1960,'' one of New York's youngest and liveliest antiques and decorative arts fairs, returned yesterday for its second visit to the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 66th Street.
LEAD: Cornelius Bennett wishes people would stop comparing him with Lawrence Taylor. But Kurt Sohn, who will run against Bennett on Sunday, said today there wasn't any comparison.
LEAD: McCann-Erickson, New York, has been assigned the retail media account of Columbia Pictures for the New York region. The billings are around $10 million.
LEAD: Mexico's Finance Minister appealed for confidence in the economy today as the peso fluctuated in chaotic trading after Wednesday's plunge.

LEAD: Avram Weiss, a violinist, and Joseph Seiger, a pianist, will perform works by Handel, Grieg, Bach, Kreisler, Bloch and others on Sunday at 8 P.M. in Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street). Tickets are $12, or $6 for students and the elderly. Information: 362-8719.

LEAD: A Lebanese citizen awaiting trial in the United States on charges that he took part in the June 1985 hijacking of a Jordanian airliner was also involved in the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jet the same month, Reagan Administration officials said today.
LEAD: * Atlas Corp., Princeton, N.J., a natural resources company, appointed Keith R. Hulley president of the mineral division.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it would indefinitely lay off about 1,155 of its hourly employees in January, when it will slow auto production at three of its United States plants. The cut would increase the company's list of indefinitely laid-off workers by 2.5 percent. A Lansing, Mich., plant that makes the Buick Skylark and Oldsmobile Cutlass will lay off 850 of its 4,350 workers.
LEAD: Golf

LEAD: An article yesterday about a mur-der suspect who was fatally shot in a struggle with two New York City Po-lice detectives misidentified the sus-pect and the detective who shot him. The suspect was Stephen Randol; the detective was Mark Hembury.

LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about the high level of oil imports incorrectly described the Institute for International Economics. The Washington-based group is a nonprofit research organization, financed by foundations, corporations and government.

LEAD: What the judicial authorities describe as a kidnapping-for-ransom network within the Argentine federal police force has come to light with the discovery in recent days of the bodies of three missing businessmen.
LEAD: Anson Dorrance, the head coach of both the men's and the women's varsity soccer teams at the University of North Carolina, may face an unusual decision Saturday night.
LEAD: J. Angelo made the following written statements to the Suffolk County police: FIRST STATEMENT
LEAD: Joe Nieuwendyk, a rookie, scored four goals as the Calgary Flames routed the Quebec Nordiques tonight, 9-1.

LEAD: Injured quarterbacks abound this week, many of them limited in practice or not able to make it at all. They have hurt their ankles or shoulders or knees or egos. So the backups will become major factors Sunday. And that means teams with sophisticated defenses could fool some of the inexperienced second-stringers.

LEAD: The pianist Alicia de Larrocha will perform works by Schumann, Mompou and Granados tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, one block from the intersections of Nostrand and Flatbush Avenues. Tickets are $10 to $20. Information: (718) 434-1900.

LEAD: Three days after an inconclusive Supreme Court decision on insider trading, the Securities and Exchange Commission and prominent securities lawyers today submitted a proposal to Congress to define illegal trading in securities using confidential corporation information.

LEAD: A father and daughter, strangers to each other, are united on ABC's ''20/ 20'' tonight. The father had fought in Vietnam; the daughter, in a way, was one of the war casualties. The program, on Channel 7 at 10 P.M., is touching.

LEAD: A Superior Court judge, declaring a National Collegiate Athletic Association drug-testing unconstitutional, today barred the N.C.A.A. from testing Stanford athletes for drugs, with the exception of the men's basketball and football teams, where limited testing, probably for cocaine and steroids, will be permitted.
LEAD: International A3-13 khail S. Gorbachev, to address a joint meeting of Congress when he is in Washington next month was strongly criticized by Republican Congressional leaders. Page A1

LEAD: While most members of the Iran-contra committees think their inquiry was a success, many of the lawmakers and their staff assistants say in hindsight that various aspects of the investigation should have been done differently.

LEAD: A Catholic-Jewish conference scheduled to be held here next month to explore the role of the Roman Catholic Church in Europe during the Nazi Holocaust has been indefinitely postponed at the request of Jewish leaders who are angry about recent Vatican actions.

LEAD: When Vice President Bush told reporters early this year that he had ''expressed reservations'' to the White House about the secret sale of arms to Iran, many officials in the Reagan Administration were surprised.
LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

LEAD: NEAR the end of her one-woman retrospective show at the Westbury Music Fair, Julie Andrews sings a piece of special material called ''50 Words or Less,'' by Larry Grossman and Buzz Kohaan, in which she rattles off a list of adjectives that have been applied to her. They range from ''sweet'' to ''wholesome'' to ''cold.

LEAD: STILL breathing hard after a practice last week in Norman, Okla., Charles Thompson was saying that nothing had changed in his existence as a quarterback for the football team at the University of Oklahoma.

LEAD: George Washington University turned down a request from White House officials to allow the press corps to use the university's gym as a media center for the upcoming visit of the Soviet Leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, but that doesn't mean the university would mind having some of its experts in Soviet culture be used as press sources.

LEAD: The phrase ''de rigueur'' no longer applies to clothing styles - that's clear to anyone watching the eclectic parade on any city street corner, at any downtown movie house, at any urban cocktail party. But in a small town in southern New England, the tyranny of fashion remains alive and well.

LEAD: Louisiana's Governor-elect, Buddy Roemer, faced with a four-month waiting period before he takes office and with a budget crisis that he said would empty state coffers by Inauguration Day, moved this week to try to get control over state policy and spending.

LEAD: ''GIOVANNI PISANO IN GENOA'' is a slightly smaller version of a show that took place this spring in Genoa. It brings together the recently restored marble fragments of the last two works by Giovanni Pisano, the great Gothic sculptor who had never before had an exhibition in the United States. There are around 20 works, some by Pisano's contemporaries and students.

LEAD: The immediate economic outlook hinges on confidence. Will consumers, businesses and investors continue their healthy patterns of spending and investment or will Black Monday and its aftermath frighten them into retrenchment and bring on recession, or worse?

LEAD: A SPLENDID Provencal flower has taken root in the craggy industrial terrain of TriBeCa. Called Bouley, it is the creation of the French-schooled David Bouley, who made his mark at nearby Montrachet. The three-month-old restaurant has the potential for greatness, although a wobbly kitchen prevents it from reaching its potential.

LEAD: Stocks continued their seesaw course yesterday, falling broadly amid worries that a deficit-reduction plan would not be reached. The Dow Jones industrial average, which rose nearly 17 points on Wednesday, plunged 43.77 points, or 2.26 percent, to close below 1,900.

LEAD: NOT many restaurants serve the rustic French appetizer called rillettes de canard, which is a spread made with shredded duck and spices. At six-week-old L'Ecluse, a snug French bistro on Avenue of the Americas at King Street, a ramekin of delicious rillettes (this one combines duck and pork) comes as an appetizer along with grilled garlic toast and a little green salad.

LEAD: PU YI (1906-1967), the last Manchu emperor of China, came to the Dragon Throne at the age of 2 and some months. Four years later, the prince regent, Pu Yi's father, was forced to abdicate all imperial authority to republican forces. The boy-emperor continued to stay on in lonely, unreal splendor in Beijing's Forbidden City for another decade or so.
LEAD: L. Clark Heist, who has been with the Champion International Corporation for 30 years, has been named president and chief operating officer, effective Dec. 1.
LEAD: Governor Cuomo last night criticized and refused to participate in a ''sweeping review'' of the New York City school system by the State Board of Regents.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A 1931 Bugatti 41 Royale, owned originally by the Bugatti family, was sold yesterday for $9.8 million, a record at auction for an automobile. The buyer at the Christie's sale, held at London's Royal Albert Hall, was Nicholas Harley, a British vintage-car dealer.
LEAD: Friday ONCE UPON A TIME, ETC.

LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in the month ended Nov. 13 decreased from the previous month by 44.7 million shares, or 8.8 percent, to 465.5 million.

LEAD: ''THERE is a Portuguese word, saudades, that means nostalgia for people, places and things that may never have existed,'' Andrea Marcovicci said the other day. ''In my singing, I've stretched that to mean nostalgia for a time we never lived in. My father was 63 and my mother 29 when I was born. Because he was a creature from another era, I grew up surrounded by musical influences that were not of my own time.
LEAD: The Reagan Administration and a small group of Democratic Congressmen are divided over how the United States should use its leverage to insure a free and fair election in Haiti this month.

LEAD: Several years ago, having listened hard to America's right-to-lifers, the Reagan Administration found a way to throw them a bone. The Agency for International Development would not renew its contract with Planned Parenthood unless the birth control agency pledged not to help any overseas programs that also offer abortion services.
LEAD: Godfrey Bloch, a former carpet manufacturer, died at Lenox Hill Hospital on Wednesday. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: Big Money From a Small Country

LEAD: John Martel has stalked the courtrooms of America for 28 years, compiling a record other lawyers admit places him in the upper realms of America's top corporate trial lawyers. In an era when few cases reach final trial, Mr. Martel has battled nearly 100 to conclusion, representing such major clients as the Bank of America and the Hearst
LEAD: Federal regulators pledged $1.3 billion today to resolve the difficulties of the Vernon Savings and Loan Association in Dallas, the largest such Government bailout of a savings institution.
LEAD: Thomas W. Eglin, the dean of students at the Lawrenceville School, died of a brain tumor Wednesday at his home in Lawrenceville, N.J. He was 55 years old.

LEAD: ''HONEYMOON'' was made in English, but it seems to have been designed as a cautionary tale for European audiences, a warning about hellish New York. It stars Nathalie Baye, and from the first shots of Miss Baye's trim little high-heeled legs making their way through ruffian-filled Manhattan, it's clear that this gentle
LEAD: Senator Paul Simon of Illinois found today that the problem with becoming a front-runner is that competitors start snapping at your heels.
LEAD: Fourteen years after Gen. Augusto Pinochet's military coup destroyed democracy in Chile, his reign of terror not only is continuing but has noticeably worsened in the last month.
LEAD: Egyptian Goddesses
LEAD: THE VELVET PRISON: Artists Under State Socialism. By Miklos Haraszti.

LEAD: Mayor Koch yesterday scaled back his proposal for 1,000 new apartments for middle-income New Yorkers in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx, in the hopes of winning the Board of Estimate's approval for the disputed plan.

LEAD: LUIGI COMENCINI'S ''Boy From Calabria,'' opening today at the Carnegie Screening Room, is an inoffensively sentimental Italian movie about a poor peasant boy's efforts to become a marathon runner, much to the horror of his hard-pressed father.

LEAD: The White House said today that President Reagan would put $23 billion in automatic spending cuts into effect to reduce the Federal budget deficit even if Administration and Congressional negotiators agree on alternatives before the Friday deadline.
LEAD: ''STRETCH your arm no farther than your sleeve,'' as the old French saying goes.

LEAD: The Allegis Corporation, parent corporation of United Airlines, has agreed to prepay a $700 million convertible note issued by the Boeing Company last spring when United placed an order for 36 Boeing jets. Boeing said Allegis would be required to pay the $700 million plus accrued interest of $50 million before Jan.

LEAD: New York City's bond rating was raised yesterday to its highest level since 1975, despite concerns that recent declines in stock prices and employment at securities concerns would weaken the local economy and strain the city's financial condition.

LEAD: The country's Roman Catholic bishops today threw their moral and political weight behind efforts to bring peace to Central American, in particular backing the mediation of their fellow prelate, Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo of Nicaragua.

LEAD: As transportation experts and opposition politicians pointed to possible safety lapses, the Government announced today that it would hold an inquiry into a fire that killed 30 people at London's busiest subway station.

LEAD: With 10 days remaining before the scheduled date for presidential elections in Haiti, election officials say the Government has finally begun lending its support, and concern about a possible postponement appears to be fading.

LEAD: Despite police raids and the advent of state lotteries and offtrack betting, numbers - a time-honored form of illegal gambling as easy as buying a pack of cigarettes - continues to thrive in poor neighborhoods of New York City.
LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday barred Yonkers from aiding ing commercial and residential development until the city complies with his desegregation order by planning new public housing.

LEAD: New calculations of the average amount of radiation an American is exposed to in a year have doubled the estimate. For the first time, the calculations include the effects of radon gas seeping into houses.

LEAD: ''Loyalties'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times March 21. The film opens today at the Quad Cinema.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It's now official. The Internal Revenue Service had ruled that Election Night parties, assuming they are given by a candidate's campaign committee for the candidate's campaign workers, are an ''exempt function'' under Section 527(e)(2) of the tax code.
LEAD: An 11-member jury convicted six defendants on drug charges yesterday shortly after a Federal judge, in an unusual action, removed the lone juror who had been holding out for acquittal.

LEAD: Iran said today that Iraqi warplanes had raided an unfinished nuclear power plant for the second time this week, and Iraq said it bombed three tankers in Iran's waters and shot down two enemy planes.

LEAD: An American physician's assertion that he led an international medical team treating victims of a recent radiation accident here has been challenged by American diplomats and Brazilian doctors and officials.
LEAD: Influential House committee chairmen are upset over Senate legislation that would scuttle a plan establishing two dump sites for the accumulating tons of high-level nuclear waste.

LEAD: After telling the Soviet television reporter what they knew about her country - it is part of both Europe and Asia and Moscow is its capital -the geography class at a school in the rural town of Litchfield had some questions.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury debt issues moved slightly higher yesterday in what dealers described as the slowest session of an uncommonly dull week, as market participants continued to wait for the Administration and Congress to resolve their differences over the Federal budget deficit.

LEAD: A defendant in the Howard Beach murder and assault trial admitted the day after the incident that he and two other white teen-agers beat one of three black men involved in the case, a detective testified yesterday.

LEAD: This year's General Assembly session opened on an upbeat note, with a Security Council peace initiative in the Persian Gulf and signs that the United Nations was shaking off its reputation as a hot air machine, grinding out endless resolutions that no one reads, much less acts on.

LEAD: The Communist Party U.S.A. is not likely to run candidates for President and Vice President next year to protest what it says is a ''very undemocratic electoral system'' in the United States, the party leader announced yesterday.
LEAD: The Gillette Company created two new operating units from three existing groups yesterday and said each would be led by a vice chairman.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: If an intermediate player is considering buying a bridge book, he is entitled to ask, ''How much will it tell me that I did not know before?'' The answer may be, ''Nothing, a little, quite a lot or a great deal.''

LEAD: Around the turn of the century, in a period of opulence somewhat similar to today's, it became customary for builders to include servants' quarters in middle-class houses in the growing industrial cities of the Northeast. That practice continued until the Depression, when homes and living styles started to grow simpler.

LEAD: ''SIGN O' THE TIMES,'' which opens today at the Warner and other theaters, is mostly a concert film, but it also plays like science fiction: a visit to the Prince planet, where life is strange indeed. And madly, viscerally exciting, peopled by red-hot, inexhaustible Princelings whose onstage excesses become the perfect backdrop for the star's own antics.
LEAD: Marcel Dionne was correct: The Rangers should not have assumed that they could reproduce the work ethic that brought them out of their slump just by writing it into their game plan.
LEAD: BASEBALL
LEAD: Mora's 'Communion'

LEAD: This was one night when the sneak preview took top billing over the featured attraction. What a pair of quarterfinal matches of the Virginia Slims championships lacked in intrigue, drama and excitement was more than compensated for in a doubles confrontation between the team of Steffi Graf and Gabriela Sabatini against Martina Navratilova and Pam Shriver.

LEAD: School may be the only source of stability in the lives of New York City's homeless children. Yet the city's Board of Education has lost track of several hundred school-age children in emergency hotels and shelters. No one checks up on them to make sure they go to class. Children already ''at risk'' are thus put in further jeopardy.

LEAD: The Bell & Howell Company disclosed yesterday that it was negotiating with an investor group headed by Robert M. Bass of the wealthy Texas family on a management buyout of the publishing and information services company.

LEAD: The stock market collapse and the dollar's decline created the urgent need and the opportunity for Washington to prove that tough budget issues could be resolved through bipartisan negotiation, that national interests could transcend parochial ones. Now, after a month of buck-passing, Congressional and White House leaders propose to reduce the deficit by less than the automatic cuts scheduled in the Gramm
LEAD: Will he or won't he? Will Lawrence Taylor, despite an injured hamstring, be well enough to play for the Giants Sunday against the Saints in New Orleans?

LEAD: Imported toys that resemble popular brand-name products can pose serious safety hazards, toy experts say. These toys can even find their way onto the shelves of reputable stores across the country.

LEAD: Impatient with Federal efforts to control smog, New York, New Jersey and the six New England states are starting a major effort to reduce ozone by requiring changes in gasoline sold in the region in warmer months, beginning next summer.

LEAD: The Army has awarded a $605.4 million contract to the General Dynamics Corporation for 624 M-1A1 Abrams tanks. The award, the latest installment in a four-year, fixed-price deal announced last spring, calls for delivery of the tanks by March 1990.

LEAD: In a move that could affect thousands of New York business people, including hundreds on Wall Street, New York University will reduce by nearly a fourth the part-time student body at its Graduate School of Business Administration, according to faculty members at the school.

LEAD: Installment debt can creep up at this time of year, endangering your credit rating. Credit-card companies and lenders will not extend credit to consumers in the danger zone whose payments amount to 20 percent to 30 percent of their gross income. Consumers, moreover, cannot get a mortgage if their total debt payments exceed 36 percent of their gross income.

LEAD: The New York City Department of Health has increased dramatically its projection of AIDS cases for 1991 and its official count of the cumulative number of AIDS cases in the city. Unfortunately, those revisions, while welcome, come as no surprise because they are long overdue.

LEAD: Representatives of the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers and the Actor's Equity Association have negotiated a three-year contract that will increase earnings for some actors and stage managers by more than 20 percent over the next three years.
LEAD: Marian Van Tuyl, a noted dance educator, writer and performer, died of cancer at her home in San Francisco on Nov. 10. She was 80 years old.

LEAD: ''It's a pity that stupid politics can prevent artists from performing,'' Elena Obraztsova said last week. ''Politics are politics and art is art. The two shouldn't be mixed.'' The Russian mezzo-soprano was in New York to prepare for her Carnegie Hall recital Monday night, her first appearance in the city in eight years.

LEAD: The faculties at Tulane University and Newcomb College, separate institutions for 100 years, are to merge. While Newcomb will maintain its campus and remain a school for women, the merger of the faculties will enable conflicts on tenure, promotion and other issues to be resolved.

LEAD: The score was tied, 3-3, which was acceptable to the Rangers, but instead of relaxing, they used the final two minutes to bear down and avoid the strain of an overtime session so close after Thursday night's loss in Minnesota.

LEAD: The Dresden Staatskapelle, which traces its history to 1548 and hence can claim to be the world's oldest orchestra, arrived in Carnegie Hall Thursday night for the first of three Manhattan concerts. (The two others, conducted by Colin Davis, will be Wednesday at Carnegie and Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall.) LEAD: Amfac Inc., a diversified company with operations in distribution, retailing, hotel and land development, said today that Ronald R. Sloan had been removed as its president and chief executive officer. Henry A. Walker Jr., the company's chairman, has resumed his former positions as president and chief executive officer.
LEAD: Anxiety about how much consumers will cut back spending is likely to produce unusually vigorous price cutting this Christmas selling period.

LEAD: Beaming and confident after her first night with her baby, Nicole Bridget Smigiel said yesterday that she hoped to combine college and motherhood in a new life dedicated to the child she surrendered at birth 17 months ago to Joel B. Steinberg.

LEAD: Diane Johnson and Robert Stone have been named the 1988 recipients of ''The Mildred and Harold Strauss Livings.'' Each will receive $50,000 annually for five years, for purposes of allowing them to devote their time exclusively to writing.
LEAD: The auditorium at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53d Street, has reopened after six months of renovation. The hall is now called the Bankers Trust Company Auditorium.

LEAD: The American Ballroom Theater swept into the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street,) on Tuesday night to open a two-week season. And that is reason to cheer, for the company is one of our most unusual and delightful dance groups.

LEAD: In a revised offer, British Airways said yesterday that it was willing to pay about $260 million to buy British Caledonian Airways. The new bid, which involves a swap of stock, is considerably less than the $417 million that was offered originally.
LEAD: ''A balanced package.'' - Representative Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas and Speaker of the House. [ 48:1. ]
