LEAD: N.B.A. 76ers 116, Celtics 85: Charles Barkley had 22 points and 14 rebounds as Philadelphia routed Boston last night, the Celtics' worst loss to the 76ers in 21 years. The last time Boston lost by as many as 31 points to Philadelphia was Nov. 29, 1966, when the 76ers won, 138-96. Reggie Lewis and Mark Acres, two rookies, each had 14 for the Celtics, who were playing without the injured Larry Bird.(AP)

LEAD: I was surprised and pleased to read James Atlas's article ''A Magazine Junkie'' (Guest Observer, Nov. 1). I thought I was alone in my affliction. There is a pile of Penguin classics sitting atop my coffee table, and on a bookshelf. I've even stopped buying magazines. But can I help it if every day, when I arrive home from work, my mailbox is crammed with mail-order catalogues?

LEAD: Arthur Davis ran for four touchdowns and 320 yards yesterday as South Shore of Brooklyn upset second-seeded Port Richmond, 42-12, in the quarterfinal round of the Public Schools Athletic League Division A playoffs. Port Richmond (8-0) was one of two undefeated teams in the P.S.A.L. during the regular season.

LEAD: Rudolf Serkin has canceled the recital he was to give at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 9, on the advice of his doctor, who said the 85-year-old pianist was suffering from fatigue. No replacement date has been set. Ticket refunds will be given only at the box office, before Jan. 9. Hours are 11 A.M. to 8 P.M.

LEAD: Beginning Dec. 1, owners of rent-stabilized apartments must attach a new form outlining tenant rights to all new or renewal leases.

LEAD: IN ''La Sonnambula,'' performed by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday at the New York State Theater, George Balanchine has created a dark, almost satanic version of a romantic narrative ballet, set to sweeping and melodic music by Vittorio Rieti after themes from three Bellini operas. Alain Vaes frames the action, a party attended by an unannounced Poet and a mysterious Sleepwalker, with a solid, bourgeois country home in his new set.

LEAD: Feelings of triumph and dominance are part of a long heritage of primate evolution and human social development. That Sam Toperoff should fear and hate himself because he experiences these natural feelings is a pathetic comment on the way contemporary social ideologies alienate us from ourselves. Sexual egalitarianism requires self-hatred.
LEAD: ''THE more good retail you have, the better,'' says Robert H. Rodgers, a principal in Devon Properties. ''It improves the economics.''

LEAD: Dr. Saran Jonas and Dr. Ruth H. Jonas of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Elizabeth Ann Jonas, to Dr. Thomas Eisen, a son of Dr. Herman Eisen and Dr. Natalie Aronson Eisen of Newton, Mass. A March wedding is planned.
LEAD: EVEN for this depressed Shore city, it seemed a particularly cruel blow late last September when fire destroyed 16 town houses along Wesley Lake.

LEAD: THE North Fork is as lovely in November as it is in June. Blazing autumnal color, acres of vineyards, farm stands bursting with pumpkins, squash and cauliflower, and white-frame farmhouses line the country roads leading to Rosie's Old Mill Inn on the Mattituck Inlet.
LEAD: The American Forestry Association says acid rain and other air pollution are harming the nation's forests and has called on Congress to act to strengthen controls on the pollutants.

LEAD: ON ''SATURDAY Night Live,'' the comedian Al Franken asked Bruce E. Babbitt, a Democratic Presidential candidate, ''Governor, what about the character issue?'' Babbitt: ''What about it?'' Franken: ''I'm referring to your long history of going into supermarket express lanes with more than 10 items.''
LEAD: Sir John Colville, principal private secretary to Sir Winston Churchill and two other prime ministers, has died, family death notices said today. He was 72 years old.

LEAD: SEVERAL KEY POINTS COME TO mind with the Joffrey Ballet's vibrant reconstruction of ''Le Sacre du Printemps.'' One is that this unprecedented attempt to revive Vaslav Nijinsky's lost choreography succeeds in revealing the full meaning of the ballet. Dropped shortly after its premiere in 1913, the first ''Sacre'' and its content have been difficult to visualize over the decades, difficult to comprehend.

LEAD: Soviet veterans of the war in Afghanistan have started a nationwide organization to combat official neglect of those who served in the war and to press for monuments honoring soldiers killed there, organizers of the group said today.

LEAD: THIS would be a good week to apply fertilizer to dogwood trees; rake up remaining leaves and discard them, do not compost, as a precaution for disease control; scatter acid-type fertilizer on the ground around the root zone according to rates on bag label; rain and melting snow will seep nutrients in during winter.

LEAD: Classic Tales Retold Hi-Tops Video. 90 minutes. $29.95. This is an amiable collection of a dozen animated (and in some cases abridged) familiar stories, originally produced by BFA Educational Media. The voiceover narrator credits the origin of the individual stories - ''Jack and the Beanstalk'' is English, ''The Little Match Girl'' and ''Thumbelina'' come from Hans Christian Andersen, ''Hansel and Gretel'' from the Brothers Grimm, and so on.

LEAD: Despite an injured hamstring, Lawrence Taylor of the Giants may play Sunday against the Saints here.

LEAD: Two American soldiers were injured when their Army CH-47 Chinook helicopter crashed and burned Friday in Colombia, the Pentagon said today. The helicopter's pilot reported engine failure while it was returning to its base in Panama from a refueling mission. The soldiers suffered first- and second-degree burns over about 30 percent of their bodies when the Chinook crashed near the city of Monteria, Colombia, the Pentagon said.

LEAD: IN terms of evidence, the final report issued last week by the Congressional Iran-contra committees added little to the startling public testimony last spring and summer about the secret activities of the Reagan White House. But the committees' analysis of that evidence was devastating. The report spoke of ''confusion and disarray at the highest levels of Government,'' of ''pervasive dishonesty and inordinate secrecy,'' of ''deception and disdain for the law.

LEAD: Participants in a conference on land-use issues in New York City that ended yesterday came with an array of ideas. Among all the opinions, one came closest to a consensus: neighborhoods should have a greater say in their own development.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David Arthur Oestreich of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Deborah Ann Oestreich to Jason Seth Rubin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mel Rubin of Great Neck, L.I. Ms. Oestreich is an assistant vice president in the international department at Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York.

LEAD: EACH November, turkeys, football games and early glimpses of Christmas tinsel herald the nearing of Thanksgiving. In the town of Washington, the season is also marked by the sight of bright yellow school buses traveling along the narrow roads, bringing groups of children eager to learn about the first Thanksgiving to the American Indian Archaeological Institute.

LEAD: Matt Frantz made a 26-yard field goal with 5 minutes 18 seconds remaining today to give Ohio State a 23-20 victory over error-prone Michigan that sent out dismissed Coach Earle Bruce as a winner.

LEAD: Nearly 500 of 2,530 inmates at a city jail on Rikers Island refused the noon meal yesterday on the second day of a peaceful protest against more searches and other security measures initiated last week to reduce violence at the institution, the New York City Department of Correction reported.

LEAD: The work of two Brazilian musical giants, Antonio Carlos Jobim and Heitor Villa-Lobos, will be featured in Lincoln Center concerts Monday evening. LEAD: TELETEXT INFORMA-tion services, long established in Europe, are now being carried on an increasing number of cable TV systems in this country, and American viewers can now, for the first time, buy television sets with built-in teletext decoders at virtually no added cost. Until now, consumers had to buy a separate decoder to gain access to these news and feature services, which present pages of print and graphic displays on the screen.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul T. Walker of South Salem, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Felicia Louise Walker to Jeffrey David Saferstein, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald R. Saferstein of Paramus, N.J.

LEAD: IN A NOVEMBER LOADED WITH sculpture, there are three solo shows concentrated around 57th Street that are particularly worthy of attention. All three sculptors make discrete objects. Their approaches, however, and the complex issues with which they are concerned, are very different. Each challenges prevalent ways of thinking.
LEAD: In bitter, bonechilling weather, Steven McDonald returned home today to a warm welcome from friends, family and fellow police officers.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: DWIGHT GOODEN was married to Monica C. Harris last night in Tampa, Fla., in a private ceremony attended by some 600 guests, including Gary Carter, Dave Magadan and a few other of Gooden's teammates on the Mets.
LEAD: An article on Nov. 15 about the homeless misstated the amount the county expects to spend this year on its homeless population. It is $35 million.

LEAD: One day last June, a 12-year-old boy spent two and a half hours calling and listening to sexually explicit messages on telephone pornography services. Two weeks later he sexually assaulted a 4-year-old girl.

LEAD: Some 60 animal rights protesters, many of them carrying flash cameras and grisly photographs of freshly shot deer, stalked hunters in the Yale-Myers Forest today in an effort to disrupt the start of Connecticut's annual controlled deer hunt here.

LEAD: PLEASE take your seats, students of fashion, because we are ready to discuss this week's mixed metaphor. To wit, the leather motorcycle jacket, made famous by Marlon Brando in ''The Wild One,'' that is now making the rounds in some very up-to-date company. This jacket has a well-earned tough-guy reputation, but pair it with a miniskirt or baggy trousers, and it looks positively chic.

LEAD: ''Can the Giants and the Jets still make the playoffs?'' Only if Charlie Conerly and Joe Namath assume quarterback duties for the Giants and Jets, respectively, for the remainder of the season. Otherwise, wait till next year! NICHOLAS D. DECURTIS New York

LEAD: THE IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS have made it to the dance floor.
LEAD: MANY homeowners give little thought to choosing a paintbrush. Others find the array of brushes confusing and the choice difficult.

LEAD: BARRY KIESELSTEIN-CORD RE-members being ''somewhat taken aback, even apprehensive,'' at being ushered into the private vault of an investment banker client. Assembled there in radiant profusion were some 35 pieces of jewelry he had designed. When Kieselstein-Cord expressed his astonishment, the client replied, ''Your work is part of my investment portfolio.

LEAD: Ever since he discovered that his farm well was contaminated with fertilizers, Steve Shivvers had been carrying his drinking water home in a plastic jug, filled from the tap at his family's business in this small town in southern Iowa.
LEAD: NEW HAVEN is developing into a real diner's delight. While there have always been many restaurants in town, the range, variety and quality seem to have improved over the last couple of years.
LEAD: Game 15 of the world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, ended in a draw yesterday, and with a wrangle.

LEAD: Union, regarded as perhaps the best team in the state, responded to a Linden touchdown in overtime with one of its own yesterday and won, 10-9, at Union to gain the final round of the North Jersey Section 2, Group IVplayoffs.

John Buckley, who does public relations for Jack Kemp, says, ''We have always taken Pat Robertson seriously.'' Lee Atwater, Mr.

LEAD: TUCKER ROBBINS maneuvered his four-wheel-drive vehicle over 20 miles of rough, mountainous Guatemalan terrain, where the foliage is lush and thick with cedro - a tree similar to oak whose wood is ideal for making furniture.
LEAD: Georgetown University must provide homosexual student groups with the same privileges given other campus organizations, an appeals court here has ruled.
LEAD: P. J. Feeney gained 205 yards and scored three touchdowns to lead the West Islip Lions past Connetquot, 34-15, in a semifinal of the Suffolk County Division I football playoffs yesterday.

LEAD: Dr. H. Jeremy C. Swan of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Pamela W. Swan of Long Beach, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Katherine Lucy Swan, to Dr. Geoffrey Steven Ginsburg, the son of Dr. Martin A. Ginsburg of Woodmere, L.I., and Sheila Horwitz of New York.

LEAD: Joanne Cestone, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Angelo Cestone of East Hanover, N.J., was married there yesterday to Michael Farrell McHugh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas McHugh of Brick Town, N.J. The Rev. Richard Carlson, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: Orient Express Question:Whom should we contact to learn about a trip on the Orient Express? - R. K., Lake Forest, Ill. Answer:Several trains go by the name Orient Express. One is called the Venice Simplon-Orient-Express, which is run by Orient-Express Hotels, using original, restored Orient Express cars.

LEAD: ''SAYING goodbye to Joe Gagliardi is very heavy business,'' said Sol Wachtler, the state's Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, during a recent well-attended dinner for the popular 75-year-old Larchmont jurist. But it did not seem such a serious matter to most of those present that evening.

LEAD: A badly needed housing bill, the first in seven years, blew up in the Senate last week after passing the House, 391-1. The charge of budget-busting did it. Reducing the budget deficit is Washington's primary goal at the moment, but housing, whose share of Federal spending has shrunk substantially in the last eight years, is no place to look for residual extravagance.

LEAD: NOW THAT RECORD PRICES ARE SET AL-most daily in the auction rooms, statisticians may find the idea of compiling a ''Top 10'' listing of prices irresistible; those who truly care about art will place such lists among the silliest and most misleading formulations of our time. ''Those people had to be crazy,'' posterity will say.

LEAD: MANY home buyers are still feeling shockwaves from last month's stock market collapse. Some were relying on now-devalued securities for the down payment while others lost buyers for their own homes. Now, unwilling or unable to back out of contracts for new homes, they are scurrying for quick cash to close their deals.

LEAD: THREE years ago in a modest ceremony in Manhattan, a Methodist from Texas married a Jew from Ohio. It was the second marriage for both. Both had lived and worked in the city for more than a dozen years. Both had happily stored Christmas tree balls and Hanukkah candles in the rarely opened little cabinets above their separate fridges.
LEAD: Women aspiring to political power would do best right now to pursue state, not national, office, if they want to work at the cutting edge of public policy.

LEAD: IN A cavernous warehouse and four support buildings just off the entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel here, a group of artisans and craftsmen have the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays on their minds 365 days a year, even though their work is on display for only a few hours.

LEAD: Philip Letourneau Sr. returned to his dairy farm in Derby, Vt., one evening early this month to find two trucks bearing Canadian license plates abandoned in mud in a hayfield.

LEAD: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21 (AP) - Rodney Peete passed for two fourth-quarter touchdowns today as Southern Cal upset U.C.L.A., 17-13, to earn a Rose Bowl rematch with Michigan State, a 27-13 victor over the Trojans in the season-opener.

LEAD: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., Margaret Jane Brewer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn A. Brewer Jr. of Pennington, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Alan Libbey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Libbey of Portland, Me. The Rev. Jean R. Smith officiated. The bride was until recently the director of social work services at the Community Memorial Hospital in Toms River, N.J.
LEAD: Ruben Zamora kissing the flag after return from exile. He urged Salvadorans to ''build a road to peace through dialogue.'' Page 20. (Agence France-Presse)
LEAD: THIS year, as America has celebrated the bicentennial of the Constitution, the people of Connecticut have been made aware of the significant contributions their state made in that process.
LEAD: Two women believed to be prostitutes were killed in separate incidents in New York City yesterday morning and Friday evening, the police said.

LEAD: Mrs. Charles M. Kagan of New York and Southampton, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Barbara Lynne Kagan, to Thomas Adam Kornreich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton A. Kornreich of Harrison, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla.

LEAD: The police rousted more than a dozen homeless people from their makeshift shelters and tents on Massachusetts Institute of Technology property today, arresting several when they balked at leaving in the rain, school officials said. A spokesman for the institute, Robert C. DiIorio, said people at the tent city had been warned since last month that they could not stay.
LEAD: A table on Oct. 25 comparing stock market averages misstated the percent change of the American Stock Exchange market value index from Aug. 12, 1982, to Oct. 22, 1987. It was 127 percent.

LEAD: STAN GABY of Colchester shows people those places in Connecticut where contintents collided, glaciers melted, striking rock patterns were formed and mysterious stone ruins were left. He is a professor of geosciences at Mohegan Community College in Norwich, and he wants his students, and others, to notice the geological features around them.

LEAD: Too many Westerners are accepting the idea that communism can achieve prosperity by employing a form of controlled capitalism. Buyers of this notion find few sellers, resulting in a wild run-up in the market of political optimism.

LEAD: I WATCHED the man go in circles, trying to put a million miles on his car. Indian summer had come and gone, so it was cold in New York. I stood inside, inhaling a warm bloody mary and taking note of this silliness through the window, watching him go round and round.

LEAD: THE entertainment world of Las Vegas is so far removed in spirit from Broadway that performers who have become fixtures in Nevada often arrive in New York pathetically unprepared to translate their showroom acts into theatrically coherent variety shows. One of the most painful illustrations in recent memory was provided on Thursday evening by Redd Foxx, the 64-year-old pioneer of blue humor, who arrived at the Academy Theater, 234 West 43d

LEAD: FOR most of its 15 years it attracted the top thoroughbreds in the nation to Belmont Park, but according to Gerard J. McKeon, the president of the New York Racing Association, the Marlboro Cup will be run no more. McKeon said the mile-and-a-quarter race, which was named for a cigarette, had been canceled because a new marketing team had taken over at the cigarette company, Philip Morris USA
LEAD: AFTER appointing a planning director, Huntington, L.I., faced an embarrassment. The director flunked the Civil Service test for the job.
LEAD: THE would-be New Jersey homeowner is fast becoming a prime candidate for the official list of endangered species in the Garden State.

LEAD: The White House and Congressional leaders who negotiated the $76 billion Federal budget compromise were constantly fearful of the financial markets' judgment of their agreement and would have preferred cuts in spending for Social Security to produce a bigger reduction, the President's budget director said today.

LEAD: An underwear magnate who has roundly criticized President Reagan and the Democratic Presidential candidates has decided against seeking the Democratic nomination himself because ''there is not time enough to run.''

LEAD: EVERYONE on St. Lucia seems to be a charter member of the Chamber of Commerce, led by the cabdrivers. Rarely does one meet drivers so in love with their country, so knowledgeable - and yet so willing to charge the correct fare. They will tell you about the hiking trails that wind through the interior's rain forest, about the orchids and Amazon parrots, and the volcanic range that rises to more than 3,000 feet and includes the pyramidical cones of the twin peaks called the Pitons.

LEAD: ''KEEP looking up,'' declare the bright blue and white buttons worn by members of the Hudson River Museum staff, and for two good reasons a lot of museum supporters last week were doing just that.
LEAD: For two weeks, the Nebraska fans who regularly pack Memorial Stadium with their red outerwear listed the factors that would win this year's game of the century.

LEAD: RESIDENTS of a Valley Stream neighborhood backing up onto one of the village's busiest streets are fighting the latest of many battles in which Long Island residents are trying to change zoning laws they think are distressingly antiquated.

LEAD: The marriage of Kimberly Elizabeth Balfour, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thurston Theodore Balfour of Newport News, Va., and Annapolis, Md., to Hugh Franklin Bennett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Franklin Bennett of Greenwich, Conn., took place yesterday in Newburyport, Mass. LEAD: A Time for Thanksgiving Notables at the Waldorf Nov. 23 - Paul A. Volcker is scheduled to present an award to Jimmy Carter, Henry A. Kissinger will make a presentation to Gerald R. Ford, and Patti LuPone and Robert Merrill will entertain at the 33d annual Humanitarian Awards Dinner of United Cerebral Palsy of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria.

LEAD: A review of Victoria Glendinning's ''Rebecca West: A Life'' on Oct. 18 misidentified Francis Biddle. He was a judge on the war crimes tribunal at Nuremberg. Robert H. Jackson was the United States' chief counsel for the prosecution at the trials.

LEAD: THE second-best Broadway ticket this month would put you in a 22d-floor hearing room overlooking Foley Square, where the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission has been methodically and quite rapidly casting a net over the theater district. When November began, six theaters in and around Times Square had landmark status.

LEAD: THE 15th edition of the Connecticut Walk Book, a hikers' guide for 50 years, is being published this month by the Connecticut Forest and Park Association.
LEAD: The Boston Celtics, minus Larry Bird, bounced back from their 31-point loss 24 hours earlier to the Philadelphia 76ers and defeated the Nets, 107-97, tonight at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Roger V. Pugh Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Robin Marie Pugh to William George Filmyer Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Filmyer of Philadelphia and Loveladies, N.J.

LEAD: THE baby, clad in a diaper and man-sized wingtips, carries a rattle in one hand, a briefcase in the other and a message from the Prudential Insurance Company of America: Small-business executives, the ad proclaims, should protect themselves from takeovers by heirs of deceased partners. You've come a long way, baby.

LEAD: WHETHER BEADED, shell-covered or crafted of gold, ancient, medieval and tribal jewelry have much in common with each other, as can be seen in the 40 austere yet robust selections on view at the Edward H. Merrin Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue (at 57th Street) through Dec. 24.

LEAD: For some years now Washington has been the site of a fascinating controlled experiment. The study has been seeking the answer to this question: Can the American system of government work, in the modern world, with no one in charge?

LEAD: JOHN LYDON could not believe the audience response when Public Image Ltd., his band, played Wednesday at the Beacon Theater. The sold-out house stood and watched him perform, then applauded each song warmly - but it neither joined in on choruses nor sneered back at Mr. Lydon's taunts. As Johnny Rotten, the voice of the Sex Pistols, and then as the cynical, corrosive leader of Public Image Ltd., Mr.

LEAD: VINCE: A Personal Biography of Vince Lombardi. By Michael O'Brien. (Morrow, $19.95.) For years, football fanatics and non-football fanatics have said that Vince Lombardi, the legendary head coach of the once-great Green Bay Packers, was a godsend to the sport. His motto was ''Winning isn't the most important thing; it's the only thing'' and some have proclaimed that he was the personification of success.

LEAD: Not since former Mayor John V. Lindsay abandoned his upbringing to become a Democrat in 1971 had the Democrats made such a fuss over a New York Republican. Donald J. Trump, the billionaire investor and real-estate developer, last week was asked by Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, to be the host at a major fund-raising event, the 25th annual Democratic Congressional dinner in Washington in March.

LEAD: William Safire missed a chance to deal with the grammar problem of the Donna Rice campaign. The jeans are labeled ''No Excuses''; therefore, the phrase ''No Excuses'' is synonymous with the product. Ms. Rice doesn't manufacture the product, does she? Therefore, to be accurate, the copy line should read, ''I don't make No Excuses.

LEAD: Despite strong opposition from conservative Republicans, Congress seems likely to adopt the deficit-reduction plan announced Friday by President Reagan and Congressional leaders, officials in the White House and on Capitol Hill said today.

LEAD: YOU can never understand a Swiss town unless you understand Switzerland as a whole. And a whole is something that Switzerland does not seem to be. LEAD: SCIENTISTS and scholars met recently at Clark University in Worcester, Mass., to report on what man has done to the planet. In dozens of papers, they described how the pressures of human population and industrial activity had not only changed the face of the earth but also altered its physical elements.

LEAD: THE rush to clear the musical decks before Thanksgiving is most decidedly on, with at least half a dozen attractive entries on today's concert calendar. Squeezing in half an hour ahead of most of the competition is another of the New Rochelle Library's ''Music, Wine and Cheese'' recitals, the 2:30 P.M.

LEAD: Several thousand rioting workers ransacked the city hall in the industrial city of Brasov last Sunday, driven to the streets by severe pay cuts and the prospect of a third consecutive winter of food and energy shortages.

LEAD: THIS bicentennial year of our Constitution comes at a time of sharp public debate over the appropriate role of religion in American life. There is much discussion about the meaning of the First Amendment's religion clause. Did it, as some say, merely prohibit the establishment of an official state religion, or did it erect an impenetrable wall between church and state?
LEAD: Q. The red brick floor in our sunroom is 11 years old and has become soiled. How should we clean this brick and what can we do to keep the bricks clean without painting?

LEAD: TOUGH, brutal, playful, ironic and terrific. Adjectives seem unduly passive in describing ''What the Body Does Not Remember,'' the extraordinarily innovative dance piece that concludes the ''New Work From Belgium'' series at the Kitchen.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald P. Flagel of Dayton, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter Stephanie E. Flagel to Andrew J. Serowitz, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Serowitz of Jericho, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony A. Constantine of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Allison J. Constantine, to Rick Allen Beispel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Beispel of New York. A spring wedding is planned.

LEAD: I would like to point out that there is more to fink and schmier than meets the eye. The English ''canary'' is about the equivalent of the German ''fink'' - meaning ''to sing,'' thereby breaking the rule of ethics not to tell.

LEAD: THE former President of Venezuela, Luis Herrera Campins, came to Managua recently on an important mission. As a leader in the worldwide Christian Democratic movement, he had been asked to mediate between contending factions in the Social Christian Party, which is one of many opposition groups trying to wrest power from the Sandinista Government.

LEAD: Amnesty International has charged that local provincial policemen were directly involved in the slaying or disappearance of dozens of unarmed Moslems during several days of Hindu-Moslem rioting in northern India last May.
LEAD: THE SIXTH CONTINENT Russia and the Making of Mikhail Gorbachov. By Mark Frankland. 292 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.95.

LEAD: Regarding the article ''Fairfield U. Program: 10 Years of Career Help'' [ Oct. 18 ] , I would like to call attention to the fact that Fairfield University is not the only institution in Fairfield County to offer such career counseling and related services to the general public.

LEAD: SOME of the youngest symphony players in the state and the world's oldest orchestra have Hartford performances coming up in the next couple of days as the Greater Hartford Youth Symphony plays tonight at Millard Auditorium, and the Dresden State Orchestra appears Tuesday at Bushnell Hall.

LEAD: What Sam Toperoff describes in his article ''An Ugly Feeling'' (About Men, Oct. 25) is something that I've witnessed often enough to name the Male Operational Definition of Maleness. By this, I mean that at an elemental level men define their maleness as ''triumphing over women.''

LEAD: Facing a research budget substantially smaller than they had envisioned, officials in charge of President Reagan's program to develop a ''Star Wars'' missile defense system say they are planning sharp cutbacks and delays of up to two years in key experiments and development projects.

LEAD: After months of virtual public silence on the search for a new schools chancellor, Mayor Koch has accused the New York City Board of Education of taking too long in its quest. And he put forth two candidates of his own.

LEAD: Exploiting mounting resentment over refugees and workers from third world nations, small right-wing parties have cropped up across the northern tier of Western Europe demanding the expulsion of foreigners who are said to be taking jobs from Europeans.

LEAD: THE New York City Ballet has a promising addition to its roster in Lindsay Fischer, a young American dancer who left the Dutch National Ballet to join the City Ballet as a principal dancer this season. LEAD: Gina M. Capella, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Rafael F. Capella of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla., and Michael E. Martin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Martin of San Francisco, were married yesterday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Tuxedo, N.Y. The Rev. John F. Breen performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Deborah Anne Norville, a correspondent for NBC News, plans to be married Dec. 12 to Karl G. Wellner, president of JS Products in New York.

The Jets appear to be headed for victory, but Mark Gastineau roughs Phil Simms and the Giants drive for the tying field goal. In overtime, Ken O'Brien is picked off three times.

LEAD: As he ordered Richard Angelo held without bail on assault charges, Suffolk County Judge Alfred C. Tisch suggested that the 25-year-old nurse may have ''perpetrated the largest series of mass murders in the metropolitan region, if not the nation.''
LEAD: There are just 142 days to go before the Mets' 1988 home opener at Shea Stadium, an afternoon game (1:35 P.M.) on Tuesday, April 12, against the Montreal Expos.

LEAD: DEMOCRATS on the Board of Legislators wasted little time last week in challenging County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's proposed 1988 budget, which calls for a 10.3 percent increase in spending, as being ''wasteful'' and containing ''misleading'' information.

LEAD: THE State Education Department thinks that for kindergartners, two and a half hours is not enough. The department, with a grant of $1 million, has helped 17 local school boards to start or to expand a variety of extended kindergarten programs this year beyond the two and a half hours a day that many districts offer and plans to ask the legislature for more money to start or expand such programs next school year.

LEAD: A Wren Church Is Reopened In City of London A church designed by Sir Christopher Wren that was considered a model for St. Paul's Cathedral has reopened in the City of London after a 20-year restoration.

LEAD: John Schuyler Linen , a retired New York banker, died Thursday at his home in Lake Wales, Fla. He was 93 years old.

LEAD: IN the 1940's and 50's, the area adjacent to downtown was one of the nation's largest clothing-manufacturing districts. But foreign competition and labor problems closed much of it down. Few firms survived into the 1960's and many of the solid old buildings began to decay.
LEAD: For Charles Rinaldi, an official with the National Park Service, hiking the three-mile stretch of Appalachian Trail along Saddleback Mountain's treeless summit ridge is ''a kind of euphoria.''

LEAD: THERE has probably been no more startling event this young music season than Jonathan Harvey's ''Bhakti'' at Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night. As played by the members of Parnassus under the direction of Anthony Korf, this 12-part, 50-minute work is a triumph of exuberance.
LEAD: In the Midwest, where winters can be mean, an attached garage is seen by many home buyers as a necessity, not a luxury.

LEAD: TIME and money appeared to be running out earlier this year for the Old Slave Mart Museum in Charleston, S.C., whose collection included dolls and quilts made by slaves and bills of sales for human ''property.''

LEAD: Jesse Kornbluth's article ''The Woman Who Beat the Klan'' (Nov. 1) focuses attention on the importance of civil rights at a time when the Supreme Court's balance is being called into question. The story of Beulah Mae Donald demonstrates that discrimination remains an issue and that racism continues to plague the lives of many.

LEAD: WITH the planned merger of the Hartford National Bank Corporation and Shawmut Bank Corporation of Boston approved last week by shareholders of both banks, the midsize bank has almost disappeared from the state.

LEAD: AFTER the completion of the city's first subway in 1904, Upper Broadway saw accelerated building of apartment houses, theaters and stores as the street became a sort of regional rialto. LEAD: Collette Pustay fought back tears Friday as she finished her shift at the Volkswagen plant here. Three hours earlier, she was among 2,500 employees who learned that the West German automobile maker would close the plant next year because of slumping sales.

LEAD: THREE aircraft operated by the Army Corps of Engineers were bought for use in emergencies, but when the Army Audit Agency checked, it found that ''virtually all of the flights were for routine matters and could have been accomplished with commercial aircraft.''

LEAD: A year ago, when the National Football League neared the middle of the season, the Giants were moving along smartly with a 5-2 record. After that, they won every game they played -nine in the regular season and three in the playoffs - and became the Super Bowl champions.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Alan Phillip Halpert of Livingston, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Debra Halpert, to Todd David Watson, the son of Robert E. Watson of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Ann Watson of West Orange, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez said Friday that Spain would stick to its decision to bar United States F-16 jet fighters from Spanish soil, despite strong pressure from European allies on behalf of the United States.

LEAD: Lots of families, when planning for the future, think about one day having a little place at the shore. A new conversion project in Westhampton Beach on Long Island that is under review by the Attorney General's office presents such an opportunity but on a scale many may not have imagined. Goodstein Development, a Manhattan company active in commercial and residential projects, has purchased three beachfront hotels on Dune Road and is converting them into cooperative units.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The owners' use of replacements and the counting of substitute games has raped and ruined the reputation of the N.F.L. Their arrogance is sickening. Therefore, I don't care if the Jets or the Giants make the playoffs. Nor do I care if there are playoffs or the Super Bowl. There is as much integrity in the N.F.L.
LEAD: There is a Gimpel in every human being.

LEAD: The Giants lost twice to a team (Dallas) that lost to the hapless Detroit Lions. They're going to be lucky to break even -and it serves them right for going to New Jersey. As for the other team in the Garden State - their chances are much better. I'd prefer, however, that they're passed by the only football team in New York State - the Bills.

LEAD: DAVID WARRILOW, WHO HAS made a career of interpreting the compressed poetry of Samuel Beckett's minimalist dramas, is currently assuming the challenge of a play by a Revolutionary-era Russian poet that has words enough to spare, including those of the author's invented language.

LEAD: St. Clare's, a small general hospital near the theater district of Manhattan, has had so many brushes with financial oblivion that the staff has lost count. But lately, St. Clare's has begun to thrive, and officials say it is because of AIDS.

LEAD: It seemed like a good idea last spring: Turn a floating barracks from England into instant New York City jail cells. Today, all too late, it looks like an enormous blunder.

LEAD: Paul Killiamen, Harvard '37, with Ruth Dreyfuss and Susan Edwards, before Harvard beat Yale, 14-10, for Ivy League title. LEAD: Rhoda Levesque remembers well when village workers placed a wooden cross atop a Christmas tree on the county courthouse lawn in 1958. The cross was in memory of her young husband, a local sports star who died that year in a mill accident.

LEAD: United States policy toward Panama will soon face two key tests whose outcome is certain to affect the deepening political crisis here, Panamanian political leaders and foreign diplomats say.

Are increases on these buildings limited as they are for rent-stabilized housing?
LEAD: An offensive started by Angolan Government forces last summer against American-supported rebels led by Jonas Savimbi has failed, according to American officials and independent experts.

LEAD: It took Fordham 60 minutes today to rid itself of nearly 46 years of frustration as the Rams stunned eighth-ranked Hofstra, 41-6, in a National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III playoff game.
LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration is reviewing its pilot certification rules and looking at the flight experience of airline pilots.

LEAD: THE jazz quartet that Ron Odrich leads at Charlie O's (Park Avenue at 39th Street) on Thursdays from 6 to 9 P.M., might be viewed merely as an interesting novelty group if it were not also one of the best small jazz groups playing today.
LEAD: Sarah Clayton's essay sharpened an indelible picture that has remained in my mind for many years.

LEAD: In an emotional response to two articles appearing on Oct. 25, I must write you this letter. The articles were titled ''Nassau Water Restrictions Are Here to Stay'' [ Long Island Weekly ] and ''Hempstead Opens Tap on Development,'' subtitled ''Water Curb Over, 3 Projects Planned For Mitchel Field'' [ Real Estate ] .

LEAD: THE people of Kyonggi Province, which surrounds Seoul, are said to be cultured, but also vain. In North and South Cholla Provinces, in the southwestern part of the country, they are supposed to be untrustworthy. Over in North and South Kyongsang Provinces, to the southeast, folks have a reputation for hot tempers.

LEAD: River's Edge Starring Crispin Glover, Keanu Reeves, Dennis Hopper. Directed by Tim Hunter. 1987. Embassy Home Entertainment. 99 minutes. $79.95. The first scenes of ''River's Edge'' evoke a horrifying triptych: a doomed baby doll, a tattered sex doll and a dead teen-ager. The group connected with their fates is the crux of this harrowing vision of adolescence.

LEAD: ''I had to prove myself to the staff and to myself,'' Richard Angelo was quoted as telling Suffolk County prosecutors last week as they began exhuming the bodies of patients he may have killed in the course of his duties at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip. According to the authorities, the 25-year-old registered nurse admitted injecting powerful muscle-paralyzing drugs into patients, then working frantically to revive them.

LEAD: The record has been one-sided, suggesting that what was being heralded as the next great rivalry in women's tennis is still several months away. Quite unexpectedly, Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina has given herself another opportunity to show that the record is a bit misleading, and that she is closer to Steffi Graf than many tennis fans might think.
LEAD: STAUNCH, TRUE-BLUE audiophiles commonly regard so-called one-brand systems with contemptuous disfavor. Their attitude is clearly prejudiced, but not without its reasons.

King of Chicago, to Dr. Kambiz Noruzi, a son of Sonia Noruzi of Upper Saddle River and the late Naghi Noruzi.

LEAD: A WELL DATED JUNE 21, 1887, COM-memorating Queen Victoria's jubilee as the British sovereign, is the newest addition to Heydon, an estate village in Norfolk, three hours outside of London. This tiny hamlet consists of several cottages nestled in a widow's row, a miniature post office, a 14th-century church, a park and a village green.
LEAD: Leading by 16-6 with less than 10 minutes to play, Columbia appeared today to be on the verge of beating Brown, a 26-point favorite, and ending a 40-game losing streak spanning four years.

LEAD: AGE, the weak dollar and Italian intransigence have conspired, happily, to change our travel strategy for good. Late in life, my husband and I have learned to shape the days to our new interests and lesser energies, and thereby discovered a new and even nicer Italy. We've exchanged the cities, with their rudely expensive hotels and restaurants, raucous traffic and endless ''chiuso's'' (''closed'') for the quieter pleasures of its hill towns, seductive landscapes and, above all, its piazzas.

LEAD: NORTHEAST UTILITIES, which supplies electricity and gas to most of Connecticut through its operating subsidiary, Connecticut Light and Power, recently announced that it would seek to cut its budget by 15 percent before 1990 by selling surplus property, cutting 600 jobs and eliminating unnecessary programs.

LEAD: The picture of Michael K. Deaver that is emerging at his perjury trial is one of an amiable, former small-town California public relations man who became one of the most trusted members of President Reagan's inner circle.

LEAD: THE human voice is a paradox among musical instruments, being both infinitely flexible and totally beyond our control. We cannot look at the larynx, repair it or adjust its components as we sing. It is a part of us in whose function we take no part.

Harry Sparrow, the central character, is a tough, hard-drinking American foreign correspondent.

LEAD: Landscape Closes at Lunchtime The classical British traveler goes abroad to suffer as well as to enjoy other countries. This is Cyril Connolly writing to a friend from Greece in 1963. It is quoted in ''The Norton Book of Travel,'' edited by Paul Fussell.

LEAD: Soccer North Carolina Extends Streak: Top-ranked North Carolina, extending its unbeaten streak to 48 games, easily beat third-ranked California, 4-0, yesterday in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's soccer final four at Amherst, Mass. LEAD: What was intended among state party leaders here as a kind of showcase event, the first national test of delegate strength among Republican Presidential contenders, has dissolved into an acrimonious battle over party rules that has left Michigan Republicans confused and badly divided.

LEAD: IF it takes one man, working alone, eight years to paint a railway bridge, the bridge will need repainting by the time he has completed his task. Therefore, the authorities decide, it would be more efficient to hire 1,800 men to do the project in a single day. Naturally, the structure cannot support the weight of an army of painters, and, with a loud cracking, the bridge collapses.

LEAD: Sarah Clayton's moving essay, ''What Will Happen to My Sons'' [ Opinion page, Oct. 11 ] , was in error when she referred to June 6, 1944, as the day ''when the allies began their long-awaited advance on Europe that eventually brought World War II to an end.'' Historically, this was not the case.

LEAD: To the Editor: During 11 adventurous days our family explored by car parts of Czechoslovakia and Hungary. While restrictions on the personal freedoms and economic choices of the citizenry were obvious, no limitations were placed on our very unstructured travels.

LEAD: I want to correct a misimpression created by the remarks attributed to me in the article on Republican Presidential candidate Robert Dole (''The Contradictions of Bob Dole,'' by Martin Tolchin and Jeff Gerth, Nov. 8). The remarks quoted in the article were accurate - as far as they went. What was left out were my other remarks, on Bob Dole's great strength: his ability to bring together opposing sides and mold a consensus on tough issues.

LEAD: I was struck by Sam Toperoff's need to continue to press for an answer to the disturbing question of why he ''somehow needed to make women, as a class, the defeated foes of [ his ] triumph.'' He experienced, in all its ugliness, the real nature of the power-worshiping system of male dominance (and female subordination) on which our social order is based.

LEAD: WHEN LLOYD Richards was 9 years old, in the early 1930's, his father died of diphtheria. It suggests something of the trauma of the event that Richards, a man with precise memories of childhood, can conjure up few of the details surrounding Albert Richards's passing. The elder Richards had been a strong and secure man, a follower of the black nationalist Marcus Garvey, a breadwinner who moved from Jamaica to Toronto to Detroit in search of a $5-a-day wage on which to raise his family of seven.

LEAD: IT was late on a Saturday afternoon on Sankampaeng Road in Chiang Mai, the second largest city in Thailand, famous as a center for crafts and decorative arts. The road was under construction and there was just room enough for one lane of traffic in either direction - plus the ubiquitous motorcycles that make their own rules.

LEAD: At a rally in Queens last week for a presidential candidate in South Korea, Kim Young Sam, the largest bouquet of red and yellow crysanthemums came from supporters of his chief rival in the opposition, Kim Dae Jung.
LEAD: The attorney-client privilege protects lawyers from divulging the whereabouts of their clients, an appeals court has ruled.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John L. Thomas of Exeter, N.H., of the engagement of their daughter Julia Anne Thomas to Marc V. Johnson, a son of Anne F. Ryan and C. R. Johnson Jr., both of Greenwich, Conn.

LEAD: MORE than a month after he suffered a seemingly minor strain to his left hamstring, Louis Lipps, the Pittsburgh Steeler wide receiver, has reinjured the hamstring and been placed on the injured reserve list. Lipps, who suffered the injury on Oct. 19, the first day of practice after the players' strike, thought he had recovered, but when he tried to run Tuesday he felt pain once again.
LEAD: James E. Folsom, a Democrat who served twice as Governor of Alabama, died yesterday at his home in Cullman, Ala. He was 79 years old and had been in failing health in recent years.

LEAD: SINCE OCT. 1, JOHN ACKERLY HAS BEEN CARRYING IN HIS pocket a handful of bullet casings. He says it is important for him to have these tangible reminders of the day when the Tibetan capital of Lhasa erupted in one of the bloodiest demonstrations against Chinese rule since Tibet was invaded in 1950.
LEAD: Vietnam: In the Year of the Pig Produced and directed by Emile de Antonio. MPI Home Video. 103 minutes. $39.95.

LEAD: I fail to see much humor in William Safire's column ''Goons and Ginks and Company Finks'' (On Language, Nov. 1). Perhaps Mr. Safire is not aware that Fink is also a surname - one, I might add, not always easy to live with. In the Manhattan telephone directory alone, you'll find almost 200 people listed, to say nothing of the Finck or Finke variety.

LEAD: WHEN the Country Bank opens its doors for business in the ShopRite Plaza Mall in Carmel after the first of the year, its president, Ross M. Weale, intends to have his desk on the banking floor, in full view and accessible to customers.
LEAD: With their black Harley-Davidson jackets, stubbly beards, hard-tipped boots and tattoos, the big men clomping through the gym looked more than a little out of place at the Y.M.C.A.
LEAD: MILITARY conscription, an issue that never quite goes away, and the closely related idea of having all young people devote a term of service to their country, are increasingly under discussion.
LEAD: THE Nature Conservancy's plan to sell 10.3 acres to the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory has raised concerns among some local residents.

LEAD: HUNTING season for most species of waterfowl began Friday on Long Island, and at one duck habitat, Cold Spring Pond in Southampton, sportsmen and waterfront homeowners are contesting one another's notions of how best to enjoy the public body of water. But this is to be a political battle in which the weapons are petitions and the warfront is at Town
LEAD: The Spectrum was rocking with cheers after two periods, but they turned to jeers for the Flyers tonight after Philadelphia yielded five straight goals to the Islanders in the last period.

LEAD: NO BUILDING IS STATIC; ALL OF them change over time, both in their physical reality and in our perceptions of them. And buildings take a long time to settle in, to find their natural relationship to their users and to their surroundings. Sometimes years of use can bestow a depth and a resonance to a building that had seemed thin and facile when new, and just as often those years can see initial promise turn sour.

LEAD: ''WHEN I first arrived here,'' said Bruce MacCombie, who took over as dean of Manhattan's Juilliard School last year, ''I went around to check out our electronic music department. What I found was an archaelogical dig.'' He immediately set out to bring Juilliard into the electronic music age.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Isadore Rosenfeld of Harrison, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hildi Victoria Rosenfeld, to Richard W. Silbert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Silbert of Boston and Chestnut Hill, Mass. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: I would like to have seen Michael Donald pictured as he was when he was alive -smiling, happy, full of the life that was stolen from him. MARTHA PETKAS Houston
LEAD: The marriage of Betsy Lane Osborne to James Edwin Doherty took place yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Andrew J. Mullins officiated.

LEAD: IT is no wonder that the mysteries and the fantasies that encompassed childlike exploration and intense eroticism - in short, the wonderment of the world of Jorge Luis Borges - should inspire a so-called avant-garde troupe, for Borges's word puzzles, perceptions, paradoxes and plotlessness are not the stuff of conventional theater.

LEAD: KAL 007: THE COVER-UP. By David E. Pearson. (Summit, $19.95.) At least six books have now been produced on the shootdown of Korean Air Lines 007 by a Russian fighter. None, including this one, has satisfactorily explained why the airliner strayed deep into Soviet airspace. David E. Pearson has, however, made a significant contribution to the controversy over the incident.

LEAD: St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Susan Shay Morrill, a daughter of DeWitt Crawford Morrill of Darien and the late Jane Ball Morrill, to Clay Carter Wommack, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Forrest Sinclaire Wommack of Suffolk, Va. The Rev. Walter H.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The six Democratic Presidential candidates jockeyed for position at the New Hampshire Democratic convention today, heating up a cold autumn afternoon with tough talk about the Reagan Administration, the Federal budget and the importance of this state's primary.

LEAD: SHAKESPEARE WALLAH Starring Shashi Kapoor and Felicity Kendal (both in photo). Produced by Ismail Merchant. Directed by James Ivory. Written by Ruth Prawer Jhabvala and James Ivory. 1965. Embassy Home Entertainment. 120 minutes. $39.95.

LEAD: Marina Kellen Gundlach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen M. Kellen of New York, and John French 3d, a son of Mrs. Frank H. Teagle Jr. of Woodstock, Vt., and the late Mr. French Jr. of New York, were married yesterday.

LEAD: Amy Cifrino and William Anthony Rooney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis C. Rooney Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., plan to marry in April, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. James P. Cifrino of Cohasset, Mass., have announced.
LEAD: Harvard and Yale played to a 0-0 tie in soccer today and the result gave the unbeaten Crimson the Ivy League championship for the first time since 1970.

LEAD: IT was the tone of ''Sons and Lovers,'' not the subject matter, that came as a shock when the novel was published in 1913. The directness of the writing established the erotic hold the mother and the son had on each other. People were amazed, but 10 minutes after the book had been published everyone who could read said, ''Of course.
LEAD: AN IDEA first cooked up at the Campbell Soup Company complex here in 1976 is proving able to retain its zest the third time around.

LEAD: You finish THE JERICHO RUMBLE by Christopher Murphy (Walker, $16.95) and then turn back to the first page. Facing it is a Xerox copy of a ''brevet d'invention'' from the French patent office dated Feb. 12, 1965. It appears to be the real thing. (Later in the book an English translation is provided.) It is the patent of an invention that can scramble brains and destroy buildings by an ultrasound device.
LEAD: A 31-year-old man was arrested and charged with killing a woman whose decomposed body was found behind the suspect's apartment building in the Bronx yesterday, the police said.
LEAD: VLADIMIR'S CARROT Modern Drama and the Modern Imagination. By John Peter. 372 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $24.95.

LEAD: OF the things that can make a columnist happy, letters from readers are second only to paychecks. But there are times when they serve as reminders of how a simple thing like photography can be made to seem enormously complex.

LEAD: THE autumn winds bring fierce whitecaps to Haverstraw Bay. Even on the calmest days, I've yet to see another rowing shell scudding along the Hudson. On the wild days, the whitecaps transform the smooth precision of rowing to a delicate balancing act that slams spray over the bow and threatens to overturn my slender craft.

LEAD: Tessa Melvin's article, ''1917: When Women Won Right to Vote'' [ Nov. 1 ] , did a fine job of presenting the highlights of an article written by Elizabeth Fuller, librarian of the Westchester County Historical Society.

LEAD: While I agree with Mary Humphrey's article, ''Preserve the Preposition!'' [ Opinion Page, Nov. 1 ] , I would like to point out an omission in grammar. She states that ''our language is made up of seven parts of speech.''
LEAD: THE State Department of Environmental Protection is now charging polluters for the fish they kill with spills of chemicals or toxic materials.

LEAD: A prison guard, a chemical engineer, a realtor, the representative of the Dutch bulb industry in the United States, a computer expert and a consulting engineer - all accomplished jazz musicians after business hours - are members of a group playing together in a newly formed jazz band. The group, was organized by Norman Liss, who heads his own public relations firm in Hartsdale, and Peter Bard, a Westchester newspaper advertising executive.

LEAD: I thought I was the only such magazine junkie. I, too, have classics and fine books waiting to be read - someday. They wait on the end table beside my bed, but stacked on the floor is an even taller pile of magazines. I subscribe to 11 regularly and buy four more each month.

LEAD: TURN the clock back 25 years or thereabouts. The Dow Chemical Company is making napalm - jellied gasoline that kills in a particularly painful way - for use in Vietnam, and American students are chasing Dow recruiters off campus. Dow's reaction: part annoyance, part indifference.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 26 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: AMERICANS will spend nearly $3 billion this year on musical instruments and equipment, from million-dollar violins to 25-cent guitar picks. But in 1987, for the first time, more than half the money will be spent on electric and electronic instruments, as opposed to acoustic instruments.

LEAD: Lee Nicholson Martin, a journalist who covered some of the pivotal events of her era in the United States, Europe and Asia, died Wednesday of cancer at her home in Washington. She was 71 years old.

LEAD: An article on Nov. 1 about stock market risk incorrectly explained a trading strategy. As the value of stocks falls below the value of matching futures indexes, portfolio insurers sell stock index futures. This strategy can inadvertently lead to further stock declines, because it may create an opportunity for program traders to buy index futures and sell the corresponding stocks.
LEAD: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration has ordered a two-thirds reduction in the amount of formaldehyde that workers can be exposed to on the job.

LEAD: An unarmed man was arrested by uniformed Secret Service officers today after he scaled a White House fence and ran to near the foot of a stairway that leads to the West Wing where President Reagan's office is situated, the authorities said.

LEAD: I believe I understand Sam Toperoff's ugly feeling and its source. The key for me was his repeated use of the word ''umbilical.'' What could be more reminiscent of the fetal situation than his hard-hat dive, and what more evocative of primal fears of being left alone without a basic life support?

LEAD: Diane Elizabeth Arlington, the assistant director of the Institute for Health, Health Care Policy and Aging Research at Rutgers University, plans to be married Dec. 31 to Russell C. Leaf, an associate professor of psychology at Rutgers.

LEAD: WHEN Margaret Thatcher's advisers are asked about her international role, they modestly assert that she realizes the limitations of a ''second-rate power'' as a platform for world leadership. But whenever Mrs. Thatcher speaks for herself it is always in the voice of a woman who, in her heart of hearts, thinks of herself as the senior guardian of Western interests.

LEAD: Diane Elizabeth Arlington, the assistant director of the Institute for Health, Health Care Policy and Aging Research at Rutgers University, plans to be married Dec. 31 to Russell C. Leaf, an associate professor of psychology at Rutgers.

LEAD: The city of Philadelphia has pledged to put up more than $150,000 bail to free at least 300 inmates in an effort to ease prison overcrowding. But prosecutors and finance officials are challenging the plan.
LEAD: To the Editor: I found the articles on ''Europe's Other Half'' (Travel, Oct. 4) most interesting, but there are a few notes I should like to add, based on a recent trip (self-guided).
LEAD: A listing last Sunday in The World of New York, part 2 of The Times Magazine, about places to take children in New York City, misstated the phone number of Theaterworks/USA.
LEAD: A Danbury, Conn., probate judge who had been missing for four days was found dead in a hotel room in Washington Friday evening, the police there said yesterday.

LEAD: Mark A. Costantino, who has served as a Federal judge in the Eastern District of New York since 1971, will retire from regular active service on Nov. 30 and assume the status of a senior judge. In that capacity, he will continue to handle cases in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

LEAD: Martina Navratilova joking around before doubles match at Garden. Navratilova and Pam Shriver went on to defeat Claudia Kohde-Kilsch and Helena Sukova, 6-1, 6-1. (The New York Times/Ray Stubblebine)

LEAD: A BULKY gray mass, just discernible in the late afternoon light, lumbers through the dense elephant grass at the edge of the shallow river. Jag Dish, the mahout driving our elephant, whispers ''rhino.'' He thwacks the side of the elephant's head with a wooden stick to turn her toward the rhino, and the other three elephants in our group also approach, forming a broad arc.

LEAD: THE company's plans are ambitious and more than a little curious. There's the idea for a ''Nostalgicize'' exercise video, featuring young women performing aerobic routines to a 1940's beat. There's the Memory Lane Club of America, ''a basic service'' for collectors of old records and movies, to be specially marketed to retirement communities in Florida and other parts of the nation.

LEAD: I read your article, ''Baby Boom Hitting Nursery Schools'' [ Nov. 1 ] , with great interest. I would like to make one important correction. The article states that in the Prekindergarten Program of New Rochelle ''all 215 children fall below the income guidelines to qualify.'' This is inaccurate and was probably a misunderstanding; 10 percent of the 215 children do exceed the financial guidelines.

LEAD: $ Weeks This Last On Week Last List Fiction 1 1 5 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 2 4 3 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe.

LEAD: The widespread belief that Thomas Jefferson, the great theorist of American freedom, maintained an intimate 38-year relationship with one of his slave women, has been cast into doubt by new historical research.
LEAD: The plaster is discolored and crumbling and the seats are worn thin, but Sylvia Fine Kaye sees a brilliant future for the Hunter College Playhouse.

LEAD: IT was no grand design for Federal budget deficit reduction that was brought forth after four grueling weeks of top-level negotiations. It was, as some members of the team themselves dubbed it, a ''mouse.''

LEAD: Westfront 1918 Directed by G. W. Pabst. Nelson Entertainment-International Collection. 90 minutes. $29.95. You can't help thinking about ''All Quiet on the Western Front'' while watching ''Westfront 1918.'' Both are antiwar movies from the point of view of German troops in the World War I trenches; both were made in 1930, ''All Quiet'' in the United States, ''Westfront'' in Germany.

LEAD: A nearly full moon still hangs heavily over Los Angeles at dawn as Tommy Pinon, Bol Puth, Glen Pambuena and about 35 classmates gather at the bus stop on Temple Street, just opposite the Good Time Donuts shop, on the edge of downtown. The yellow bus picks them up and lumbers onto the Hollywood Freeway and over the hill for the half-hour ride into the San Fernando Valley to the Ulysses S.

LEAD: THE controversy at the Columbia University Business School is now big news. It stems from an offer of $100,000 made by Adjunct Prof. Asher B. Edelman to the students in his class who provide him with information that leads to a successful corporate takeover. The offer, which the Columbia administration asked him to withdraw, presents an opportunity for ethical rumination.
LEAD: Bobby Smith scored 17 minutes 5 seconds into the second period tonight and the Montreal Canadiens made the goal stand up for a 2-1 victory over the Devils.

LEAD: Mary Minton Eitel, the daughter of Mary Minton Cregor Eitel and Paul Theodore Eitel Jr. of Louisville, Ky., was married there yesterday to Leon Hilary Horne Jr., the son of Margot Scheffler Horne of Atlanta and Mr. Horne of New York. The Rev. Stewart M. Joy performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

LEAD: Syracuse University officials formally accepted an invitation to the Sugar Bowl today just five hours before its undefeated team staged a rousing comeback to complete the second perfect regular season in the school's 98-year football history.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: NEW YORK CITY is a treasure trove of ''X-marks,'' even though the term is, to put it mildly, not very well known. The reason for its lack of familiarity is that I have never used it since inventing it on a tour of Europe 25 years ago with a party of city planners.

LEAD: Holding elections in Haiti, after nearly 30 years of dictatorship, was expected to be a difficult task. But it has become even more difficult because of a feud between Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, the head of Haiti's provisional Government, and the nine-member Electoral Council that has been trying to organize the elections.

LEAD: A tape recording proves that officials at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base tried to cover up a radioactive spill at the base, Ohio's two Senators said today.
LEAD: Syrian soldiers patrolling West Beirut stormed dormitories at the American University of Beirut Thursday night, students said.
LEAD: Congress Street blossomed as this city's central, downtown business strip in the early 19th century, but since World War II much of it has fallen into decline.

LEAD: Coach Bob Knight pulled his Indiana players off the court with him after he drew his third technical foul and automatic ejection tonight, and the Hoosiers forfeited an exhibition basketball game with the touring Soviet national team.

LEAD: NOW that the legislative elections are over and the shape of the Senate and Assembly are set, lawmakers are talking about something that has been on their minds all year but not on their tongues, at least during the recent campaign: raising the tax on gasoline.

LEAD: THREE years after the Federal Government gave New York City 13 housing grants worth nearly $30 million, the city has spent less than $2 million of it and faces the possibility of losing almost half of what is left unless construction can start on several projects by Nov. 30, a prospect city officials consider unlikely.

LEAD: Melissa Duncan Lighthill and Elliston Perot Bissell 4th were married yesterday at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Sydney Wood-Cahusac performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A picture caption on the film page of the Arts and Leisure section today gives an incorrect title for a movie directed by Leonard Nimoy that is to open on Wednesday. It is ''Three Men and a Baby.''
LEAD: DUKE ELLINGTON By James Lincoln Collier. Illustrated. 340 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95.
LEAD: A tropical storm with 70-mile-an-hour winds slammed into the capital island of the Pacific archipelago of Truk early today, killing five people and destroying most of the buildings.

LEAD: THAT the stock market embodies turbulence, mayhem and unpredictability, no survivor of October 1987 can doubt. Some economists, borrowing the vocabulary of a new branch of science, now believe that it also represents chaos.
LEAD: WITH HIS LATEST PLAY, ''Lettice and Lovage,'' Peter Shaffer has happily rediscovered something he mislaid so long ago we'd quite forgotten he ever possessed it: a sense of humor.

LEAD: FOOD Center Drive in the Bronx could be renamed Alimentary Avenue or even De Gustibus Road but it would still be gentry-proof. LEAD: WHAT this country needs, says Senator Bill Bradley, is a good 5-cent candy bar, and to get one he has written legislation that would slash price supports for United States sugar production and allow more sugar to be imported.

LEAD: I thank Jesse Kornbluth for his gripping account of Michael Donald's tragic death and of his mother's commitment to justice. I lived in the South at the time and was outraged that a pack of social misfits like the Klan could get away with such treacherous acts in the 1980's.

LEAD: MUSICIANS TEND TO dislike being categorized and labeled; many resist it strenuously. How harmful can such pigeonholing be? Consider the cases of two composer-pianists, men of extraordinary talent and originality who were misperceived, dismissed as derivative early in their careers and lived out the remainder of their lives in frustrating obscurity.

LEAD: THE IGUANA By Anna Maria Ortese. Translated by Henry Martin. 198 pp. Kingston, N.Y.: McPherson & Company. $14.95.

LEAD: Television is kind to ''Gandhi,'' which CBS will show in two parts Wednesday and Thursday, beginning at 9 each night. If the physically grand scale of the film does not look squeezed or even much reduced on the video screen, it may be because we're used to seeing the sorts of spectacle we get here in television news programs.

LEAD: YELLOW roses everywhere - on gloves, hats, handbags and stoles - are just one of the lighthearted fashion accents supplied by Isabel Canovas for spring and summer. Other frippery includes yellow satin cummerbunds embroidered with black braid, black lace fans on hand-cut Bakelite frames and even fluffy yellow silk bows to clip on the fronts of shoes.
LEAD: The prospect that a quarter-million more Cubans may immigrate here by the mid-1990's has roiled emotions in a city still struggling to absorb earlier waves of refugees from that nation.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH trade with its customary partners is slackening under pressure from economic sanctions, South Africa has managed an overall gain in commerce so far this year, the Government reports. Experts here say that the country's recent 45 percent drop in exports to the United States, which was its largest trading partner, has been offset by trade with other nations, particularly in Asia.
LEAD: EFFICIENTLY run, well-attended meetings often seem to the officers of condominiums and cooperatives to be an impossible dream, much like an entire month free from complaints.
LEAD: They used to paint subway cars. Now they paint on canvases, and their works have sold for up to $200 each.

LEAD: ONE of the most convenient first courses to serve for Thanksgiving dinner is soup. Most soups lend themselves to advance preparation, if not several days beforehand at least early in the day. They can be reheated when dinner is ready to serve.
LEAD: The New Jersey Economic Policy Council has proposed a statewide tax on new construction to finance housing for low- and moderate-income families.

LEAD: THE ORCHESTRA OF THE EIGHT-eenth Century has been touring the Midwest by bus of late - pneumatic tires, diesel engines and state-of-the-art suspension systems bearing the weight of 200-year-old instruments, styles and sensibilities.
LEAD: Anyone keeping a list of drug-blighted careers these days would have to add that of 42-year-old James E. (Mike) Roark, the popular mayor of Charleston, W. Va.

LEAD: NORTH KOREA has lost faith in its ability to reunify Korea under Communist rule and is prepared to negotiate peace with South Korea and the United States following next month's presidential election in the South. This was my conclusion after 10 days of conversations in Pyongyang last month with a variety of North Korean leaders, including Prime Minister Li Gun Mo, Foreign Minister Kim Yong Nam and Hwang Chang Yop, the powerful secretary of the Workers (Communist) Party Central Committee responsible for foreign policy.
LEAD: PAST proposals for national service have languished in Congress, but the idea that young people could learn valuable lessons while serving their country seems irrepressible.
LEAD: A group of local historians and veterans has persuaded the state to preserve a tiny Lake Champlain island that was the scene of a significant battle in the War of 1812.
LEAD: Dartmouth College trustees have endorsed a call by the school's president to seek more female undergraduates, but they say the effort will not mean considering gender in admissions.

LEAD: AUGUST WILSON ENCORE August Wilson's new play, ''The Piano Lesson,'' opens at the Yale Repertory Theater, York and Chapel Streets in New Haven, this week. Mr. Wilson's ''Fences,'' which also had its premiere at Yale Rep, won a Pulitzer Prize and Tony Award after it was transferred to Broadway, where it is still running.

LEAD: WHEN the Arena Players Repertory Theater opened its Second Stage theater, it was as a space in which to produce more challenging drama than the lightweight comedies and mysteries offered in its Main Stage theater. Currently, however, Arena has reversed itself by offering the complex and innovative ''House of Blue Leaves'' by John Guare on the Main Stage, and ''Except for Susie Finkel'' by Joe Manchester on the Second

LEAD: The Transportation Department has ordered that all freight trains traveling in the Northeast rail corridor be equipped with automatic braking devices by July 1990. Amtrak passenger trains already have the equipment.
LEAD: A South Korean soldier was wounded today when North Korean troops opened fire inside the demilitarized zone, the South Korean Defense Ministry said.

LEAD: NEARLY 4,000 YEARS AGO, A COU-ple of business partners in Anatolia, (Turkey, in modern parlance) had a dispute in court. ''When I was in Kanesh, you went off to Durhumit,'' one said, ''and there you entered my guesthouse and took out two containers, sealed.'' In other words, according to Dr. Ira Spar, research Assyriologist at New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art, ''the guy stole a safe.

LEAD: Members of the United Automobile Workers in Illinois and four other states have voted to ratify a new three-year contract agreement with the Navistar International Transportation Corporation, officials said.

LEAD: A civilian leader of the Salvadoran rebels returned home today after seven years in exile and struck a conciliatory note, calling on his countrymen to work together ''to build a road to peace through dialogue.''

LEAD: Attitudes of Americans toward AIDS have shifted dramatically since last summer, marked by increased compassion for the victims of the disease, rising support for protecting them from being dismissed from their jobs and a growing opposition to requiring them to carry special identification cards, according to the latest Gallup
LEAD: Investigators said today that overheated bearings in an escalator probably ignited the fire in a London subway station in which 30 people died Wednesday evening.

LEAD: Former House Speaker Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill Jr. was moved from intensive care to a private room today at Brigham and Women's Hospital, where he is recuperating from bowel cancer surgery, said Kathleen O'Donnell, a hospital spokeswoman. She said the 74-year-old Mr. O'Neill was in good condition.

LEAD: IN A SMALL OFFICE IN the department of psychiatry at the State University of New York's Stony Brook, L.I., campus, an anxious man and a withdrawn woman face a blank television screen. Irene Carasiti, a registered nurse, slides a 22-minute tape into a video-cassette player. The man hunches forward; his wife remains apathetic.

LEAD: IN ''NUTS,'' BARBRA STREISAND PLAYS A WOMAN who curses frequently, exhibits violent mood swings and lashes out angrily at those she loves. This behavior is supposed to convince an audience that a judge might find her certifiably insane, but by some latter-day, urban standards, it's really all in a day's work.

LEAD: Emmanuel Le Roy Ladurie, who has been appointed the director of the Bibliotheque Nationale, France's national library, is one of the few European scholars whose name is known to American readers as well as historians. He is ranked as the foremost French historian of his generation and one of the two or three most influential historians in the world today.
