LEAD: Anyone keeping a list of drug-blighted careers these days would have to add that of 42-year-old James E. (Mike) Roark, the popular mayor of Charleston, W. Va.

LEAD: NORTH KOREA has lost faith in its ability to reunify Korea under Communist rule and is prepared to negotiate peace with South Korea and the United States following next month's presidential election in the South. This was my conclusion after 10 days of conversations in Pyongyang last month with a variety of North Korean leaders, including Prime Minister Li Gun Mo, Foreign Minister Kim Yong Nam and Hwang Chang Yop, the powerful secretary of the Workers (Communist) Party Central Committee responsible for foreign policy.
LEAD: PAST proposals for national service have languished in Congress, but the idea that young people could learn valuable lessons while serving their country seems irrepressible.
LEAD: A group of local historians and veterans has persuaded the state to preserve a tiny Lake Champlain island that was the scene of a significant battle in the War of 1812.
LEAD: Dartmouth College trustees have endorsed a call by the school's president to seek more female undergraduates, but they say the effort will not mean considering gender in admissions.

LEAD: AUGUST WILSON ENCORE August Wilson's new play, ''The Piano Lesson,'' opens at the Yale Repertory Theater, York and Chapel Streets in New Haven, this week. Mr. Wilson's ''Fences,'' which also had its premiere at Yale Rep, won a Pulitzer Prize and Tony Award after it was transferred to Broadway, where it is still running.

LEAD: MIXED BLESSINGS: Marriage Between Jews and Christians. By Paul Cowan with Rachel Cowan. (Doubleday, $18.95.) After 15 years of marriage, Rachel Cowan converted to Judaism, her husband's religion, and she is now studying to be a rabbi. Paul Cowan, a reporter for The Village Voice, is the author of ''An Orphan in History,'' an exploration of his Jewish identity.

LEAD: Eve Parish Chilton, the director of family program acquisitions for the Miramex Films Corporation, a distribution and production company in New York, and Harvey Weinstein, a co-chairman of Miramex, were married last evening at the Lotos Club in Manhattan. The Rev. Fred Baldwin, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Charles D.

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 GARDEN OF SHADOWS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The beginnings of the evil that beset the Dollanganger family in four previously published novels. 2 2 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon.
LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. dismissed about 100 employees late last week, a spokesman for the company said yesterday. The privately held securities firm has about 11,000 employees.

LEAD: The Stamford Transportation Center, a structure often ridiculed by Amtrak and Metro-North rail commuters as a monument to miscalculation, started service today, three years after its first projected opening date and still only partly completed.

LEAD: PITY the poor downhill skier's knee, so vulnerable to twisting and tearing. Here comes its owner, clad in the latest pants and parka and armored by the best technology in boots and bindings. He's plunging recklessly through the moguls, skiing on the ragged edge with too much speed and too little control.

LEAD: FOR THE LOVE OF MUSIC, a chamber music society directed by the violinist Richard Sortomme, gave four trios at Merkin Concert Hall yesterday afternoon. One was a classic - Schubert's expansive Op. 100, attacked with big-boned vigor by Mr. Sortomme, Semyon Fridman (cello) and John Klibonoff (piano).
LEAD: Just three years ago, Midway Airlines seemed on the verge of succumbing to the forces that have swallowed almost all the airlines that sprang up after the industry was deregulated in 1978.
LEAD: North Carolina's reign as the top team in women's college soccer continued today.

LEAD: Lynn Robin Friedrich, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Friedrich of Clifton, N.J., was married yesterday at Edgewood Country Club in River Vale, N.J., to Kenneth Edward Librot, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Irwin E. Librot of New City, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph Herman, assisted by Cantor William Lieberman, performed the ceremony.
LEAD: A picture caption Saturday about a speech in Washington by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel misidentified the man with Mr. Shamir. He is Avi Pazner, the Prime Minister's media adviser.

LEAD: Documents made available during a hearing on the Aug. 16 crash of a Northwest Airlines jetliner suggest that its sole survivor, 4-year-old Cecelia Cichan, was not saved by her mother, as had been believed.
LEAD: Four years ago, a 27-year-old named Sophie Mirman had a silly idea for a new business here: shops that sold only women's tights, stockings and socks.

LEAD: The Cetus Corporation, a biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif., has introduced an automated gene amplification system as part of its joint venture with the Perkin-Elmer Corporation. The system, which represents the first commercial introduction of Cetus-developed technology, relies on an enzyme to make as many as a million copies of a specific gene sequence, allowing the amplification of a DNA sequence in hours rather than the days or weeks typically required.
LEAD: Fitness

LEAD: The issue under debate here for three days was one of the central political questions of the age: What was the true meaning of Richard M. Nixon's Presidency and how will he be judged before the bar of history?

LEAD: The Federal Election Commission has lost internal documents that would shed light on why it dropped a case against Senator Bob Dole's 1980 Presidential campaign and Mr. Dole's wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole.
LEAD: Some Congressional leaders today called the proposed deficit-reduction package a starting point, while others said they were disappointed and would seek modifications.

LEAD: Victor J. Herwitz, a Manhattan lawyer for more than 50 years and former chief assistant Corporation Counsel of New York City, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital Center after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The Throgs Neck Bridge was closed to traffic last night between 9:31 and 11:40 after a man called the police and said 125 sticks of dynamite had been placed on the bridge and were set to explode, the authorities said.

LEAD: A rare 1926 concert version of Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue'' is among the works to be performed by the Harmonie Ensemble on Dec. 8 at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. The program, called ''Americans and Paris,'' also features Ravel's ''Bolero''; Poulenc's ''Aubade for Piano and 18 Instruments''; Ibert's ''Paris Suite'' and Milhaud's ''Creation of the World.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Political and Security Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Special Political Committee - 10 A.M. Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10 A.M. Legal Committee - 3 A.M.

LEAD: Major Brazilian exporters, alarmed by an American threat to impose punitive tariffs on their products, are quietly urging the Government to find ways of dealing with United States objections to this country's controversial computer policy.
LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

LEAD: A report in the Company News column of Business Day on Thursday, about Chrysler's 1988 model cars, misstated their price change from the previous year. Prices have been cut 1 percent, on average, on comparably equipped cars made in the United States.

LEAD: Bright with morning sunlight and adorned with photographs of a black leadership long past, the archives search room of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture bustled with the business of history over the weekend.

LEAD: Robin Ellen Platzer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Platzer of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Lawrence Judson, the son of Mrs. Morris Judson of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Judson. Rabbi Morris Goldberg officiated at the Harmonie Club in New York.
LEAD: The odyssey of the Cuban refugees who went on a rampage Saturday at a Federal detention center in Oakdale, La., began at a quiet fishing port near Havana seven years ago.

LEAD: One bane of a bicyclist's existence - the seat that begins to feel like a concrete slab 15 minutes into a ride - may not be worth complaining about anymore. A marriage of technology between the Spenco Medical Corporation and Avocet Inc., a producer of cycling components, has come up with a bike saddle that has thick gel at its core.

LEAD: JULIAN BREAM'S recital at the 92d Street Y Saturday evening found the famed guitarist in something less than his top form. Both fallibility of finger and a certain muted quality to the interpretations worked against appreciation of playing that was at best thoughtful, caring and expert.
LEAD: Vice President Bush says he would adopt a hands-on management style if elected President and would focus on a limited set of objectives including sharp reductions in Soviet conventional forces.

LEAD: A man was waiting to buy a plant at the counter of an Upper West Side store when another approached asking for a $20 bill in exchange for four fives. Yes, the plant buyer said, he did have a twenty, and handed it over.

LEAD: ALVIN LUCIER, who opened the Alternative Museum's music series Wednesday night, composes scores that combine true Minimalist austerity (devoid of the kinetic impetus of a Philip Glass or Steve Reich) with conceptual-art ingenuity and a fascination for acoustical experimentation. The results can range from the meditatively compelling to the downright alluring to the academically arid, and
LEAD: Steffi Graf serving to Gabriela Sabatini as she won in four sets yesterday at Madison Square Garden. SportsMonday, page C1. (NYT/Ruby Washington)
LEAD: QUESTION: There have been two Heisman Trophy winners from Yale, Larry Kelley in 1936 and Clint Frank in 1937. Which professional football teams did they play for?

LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 22, 1987: MONDAY American Express...Detroit Edison BellSouth Corp...Walt Disney Co Connecticut Nat Gas...NWA Inc Continental Ill Corp...San Diego Gas & Elec TUESDAY Angelica Corp...Interlake Corp BRE Properties...Kansas Gas & Elec Bank of Boston...Medtronic Inc Becton, Dickinson & Co...Merck & Co Brush Wellman...Morgan Keegan Inc Certain-teed Corp...J.C.
LEAD: Alan Pesky will leave Scali, McCabe, Sloves at the end of the year - the third of the five founding partners to do so.

LEAD: INCH for inch, measure for measure, there is, proportionately, more acting on stage at the small WPA Theater than in any other theater in New York - and most of it is being done by Elizabeth Ashley. The play is ''The Milk Train Doesn't Stop Here Anymore,'' and the stars are Ms. Ashley, Marian Seldes and Amanda Plummer.

LEAD: More than three centuries ago, La Rochelle's turreted city hall was a genuine fortress besieged by an army led by Cardinal Richelieu, the stern incarnation of the centralizing French state. Mayor Michel Crepeau today likes to show visitors the crease in a marble table top where in 1628 Admiral Jean
LEAD: An American Airlines pilot suffered a fatal heart attack while his jetliner was landing Saturday night, but the co-pilot brought the plane safely to a stop, the authorities said yesterday.

LEAD: Ayesha Madyun, a 19-year-old Washington woman, had been in labor two days when she arrived at D.C. General Hospital to give birth to her first child. Eighteen hours later, her labor had not progressed and the doctors decided that Mrs. Madyun needed an immediate Caesarean section: the baby's likelihood of developing a fatal infection was steadily rising.
LEAD: Auto Racing

LEAD: Paul Hardy, a Republican who campaigned as a reformer in the mold of Governor-elect Buddy Roemer, ousted Lieut. Gov. Bobby Freeman in the Louisiana runoff election Saturday, while the state's Attorney General, William Guste, won a fifth term.

LEAD: Bela Varkonyi was a much-played young composer in turn-of-the-century Hungary, but this early reputation seems to have been swallowed up by his move to and subsequent life in the United States. Even as exhaustive a reference as the New Grove Dictionary of Music makes no mention of him.
LEAD: The marriage of Karen Hilary Benson and Peter Norman Ruben took place yesterday at the Pierre Hotel in New York. Rabbi Joel Gore performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Charging that members of the Westchester County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children have abused their powers as peace officers, State Attorney General Robert Abrams is seeking a court order to dissolve the society.

LEAD: Dave Krieg passed for two touchdowns and ran for another, and Curt Warner had his second straight 100-yard rushing game today as the Seattle Seahawks routed San Diego, 34-3, ending the Chargers' eight-game winning streak.
LEAD: Near the shadows of the neon glare on lower Broadway in Manhattan, the will to survive drives men without homes and sometimes without hope to a dingy building on East Third Street.
LEAD: MARK DENDY choreographs as if he were devising kinetic comic strips. Some of his images are witty. Others are crude. Yet, for all his bumptiousness, he is a serious choreographer.
LEAD: SOME important Australian brewery officials made a stop in Times Square on Friday to light up a sign for Foster's.

LEAD: ABOUT the only nice thing to be said about the American Conference East is this: it's so bad, it's good. With the Indianapolis Colts losing to the New England Patriots yesterday, the Jets had an opportunity to take over sole possesion of first place. But when the Jets lost to the Buffalo Bills, 17-14, and the Miami Dolphins defeated the Dallas Cowboys last night, 20-14, a five-way tie at 5-5 was created.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A bunch of bouncing business.
LEAD: The Economy
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: LIKE the early-music movement as a whole, the Orchestra of the 18th Century is fast outgrowing its name. Frans Bruggen's Amsterdam-based, internationally assembled ensemble played a concert yesterday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall that marked the most significant advance thus far in this city of highly skilled, large-scaled playing of the standard repertory.

LEAD: Alois Brunner, the Nazi fugitive who has lived in Syria for the last 30 years was quoted earlier this month in The Chicago Sun-Times as saying he ''would do it again'' and that Jews ''deserved to die because they were the devil's agents and human garbage.''

LEAD: THE Second Stage has begun its ninth season with a 17-year-old play, which seems par for the course laid out in 1979 by its artistic directors, Robyn Goodman and Carole Rothman. Their mission was to give a second chance to works by major playwrights that were unsuccessful or little-noticed the first time out.
LEAD: Investors are expected to be unimpressed with a tentative agreement to trim the budget deficit by $76 billion over two years, Wall Street experts said yesterday.
LEAD: A newly formed electrical equipment company called Asea Brown Boveri has named Klaus E. Agthe president and chief executive for United States operations.
LEAD: The White House has refused to discuss the possibility of pardons in the Iran-contra affair, no matter how many ways reporters bring it up.

LEAD: JIMMY BEHR is not one to talk, but the fact is, he is running less and enjoying it more. Like so many other runners, Behr, a 40-year-old A.T.&T. supervisor from Staten Island, got caught up in the mileage mania of the 1970's and at one point was training twice a day. He ran - rather, consumed - over 100 miles a week.
LEAD: Seven poems by Emily Dickinson that have been set to music by six composers are to be sung by the soprano Dawn Upshaw on Dec. 2 at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.
LEAD: A woman and three children died early today in a fire that gutted a two-story apartment building.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The most persistent popular demand resounding in this capital, aside from the never-ending search for basic foodstuffs, is for the Government to make public the words of Boris N. Yeltsin, the outspoken politician who swept into control of the city two years ago only to fall from grace in a severe test of the
LEAD: Reserve and National Guard units across the country managed to reach almost 94 percent of their members in an emergency readiness test last month, the Pentagon said.
LEAD: In the converted barn here that for years was Jackson Pollock's studio, something resembling one of his famous drip paintings has been unexpectedly discovered - under some floorboards.
LEAD: When he climbed into the ring Saturday night at the Las Vegas Hilton outdoor stadium, Edwin Rosario had a conspicuous addition to his entourage.
LEAD: A high Angolan official says 3,000 South African soldiers remain in southern Angola after the fiercest fighting in a decade between Angolan troops and South African and guerrilla forces.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: President Jose Napoleon Duarte strongly criticized returning rebel civilian leaders today and demanded that they break their links with the military wing of the guerrilla front.

LEAD: A pair of penguins, Pete and Penny, making their skateless but sure- footed way across the ice at the Wollman Rink in Central Park yester day. The penguins, visiting from Sea World, are here for the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, which will be held on Thursday. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)
LEAD: Through a car window, a Lagos ''go slow,'' or traffic jam, offers a snapshot of the diminished fortunes of Nigeria, the giant of black Africa.

LEAD: Lawrence Taylor, injured hamstring notwithstanding, played today for the Giants - not a lot, but enough to help and inspire. But it was not enough to win the game, and the playoff hopes of the Super Bowl champions vanished.

LEAD: Gregory Muhlin, a research scientist at the New York State Psychiatric Institute at the Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan, died at the hospital Tuesday after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 42 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

LEAD: For months, there have been rumblings that President Reagan might pardon Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter and Robert C. McFarlane, key participants in the Iran-contra affair.
LEAD: The Government freed 985 political prisoners nationwide today as one of its moves to comply with a regional peace plan.
LEAD: Visitors pausing at President John F. Kennedy's grave in Arlington National Cemetery. Yesterday marked the 24th anniversary of his assassination as he rode in a motorcade in Dallas. (AP)

LEAD: A three-day conference on the Presidency of Richard Nixon was drawing to a close at Hofstra University when Roger Wilkins of the Institute for Policy Studies spoke up during a panel on the Nixon record in civil rights.
LEAD: A 66-year-old homeless man living under an oceanfront boardwalk on Staten Island died, apparently of exposure, in the frigid temperatures over the weekend, the police said.

LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former Cambodian head of state, plans to meet Prime Minister Hun Sen, the most powerful figure in the Vietnamese-backed Communist Government in Phnom Penh, around Dec. 10 in Paris in a new peace effort, according to Cambodian and other Asian diplomats.

LEAD: In an old mill town that makes lifetime heroes of its high school sports stars, Michael Considine was a quarterback on the football team, co-captain of the basketball team and captain of the baseball team.

LEAD: Lieut. Colonel Oliver L. North said during the Congressional hearings into the Iran-contra affair that he has fought in two American wars, Vietnam and Angola. During his examination by the Iran-contra committees, he proudly offered information about his service in Vietnam but never mentioned what he was doing in Angola.

LEAD: Five years after the introduction of sticks with aluminum shafts ushered in the era of high-tech hockey, wood is still king in the National Hockey League. Only about 80 players have adopted the aluminum sticks, but the number has been rising, for an obvious reason: several sharp-shooters claim that since switching to aluminum they are stick-handling better, shooting harder, and playing a more consistent game.

LEAD: She arrived on the junior tennis circuit in 1957, a 17-year-old from Sao Paulo, Brazil, who spoke no English and had only limited experience in competition. Although she had captured the Brazilian national title at age 14, Maria Bueno was young and her style seemed too unorthodox to threaten tennis's elite: Maureen Connelly, Doris Hart and and Althea

LEAD: PUBLICLY owned companies that manage mutual funds shared handsomely in the fund industry's swelling popularity during the 1980's. But they have been battered more severely than most stocks since the market reached record highs in late August.
LEAD: A stockbroker who suffered heavy losses on Wall Street last month apparently leaped to his death from the 32d-floor balcony of his Upper East Side apartment yesterday, the police said.

LEAD: PIANOPHILES were especially well represented in the audience that gathered for the Oslo Philharmonic concert at Carnegie Hall Friday evening: Andras Schiff, guest soloist for the Grieg Piano Concerto, has established a real following among the listeners who know and care most about the piano literature.
LEAD: Seventeen Cuban inmates escaped from a detention center early today by climbing through a steel roof grating, but all but three were recaptured within hours.
LEAD: No sooner had the high-stakes Skins Game become a golfing fixture than you could almost hear the wheels of copycat creativity grinding. If it works for golf, why shouldn't it work for tennis?

LEAD: Shove a $10 bill at a New York City subway token clerk and he's likely to shove back a Tenpak, a little plastic bag containing 10 tokens. The Transit Authority likes to promote this modest gesture toward efficiency. But riders participate at their peril.

LEAD: Chinese Olympic officials are well along in their plans for staging the 1990 Asian Games in Beijing, an event they expect to enhance their chance of winning a bid to become host for the Summer Olympic Games in 2000.

LEAD: The world economy is headed in the right direction. Galvanized by the stock market plunge, the Administration and Congress have begun to agree on cuts in the budget deficit. American and West German interest rates have fallen. Domestic demand in Japan had already turned up smartly.
LEAD: None of the 20 passengers in the last four rows of Continental Airlines' Flight 1713 died when the DC-9 crashed just after takeoff a week ago today, a survey shows.
LEAD: Dr. Jeffrey L. Bishop, a lecturer in astronomy at Columbia University, died Nov. 13 when a car struck him as he jogged near his home in Rockland County. He was 29 years old.

LEAD: Dance organizations moved into the technological age with varying degrees of enthusiasm. But there has been a growing sense that technology could be used to preserve the ephemeral art of dance, an awareness suggested in the Martha Graham Dance Company's recent bid for direct Federal subsidy of its archival programs.

LEAD: Does the stock market crash undermine the case for allowing commercial banks to compete in the securities business? No, say two financial heavyweights, William Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve. They conclude that the potential benefits of a careful liberalization far outweigh the risks to the stability of the banking system.
LEAD: Jay Schulberg, an Ogilvy & Mather 20-year man who quit last April as executive vice president, creative head, is joining Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

LEAD: The pressmen of The New York Times voted yesterday to ratify the tentative contract settlement negotiated earlier this month by management and their union, New York Printing Pressmen's Union Local 2. The president of the union, Lenny Higgins, said that the pressmen voted 216 to 44 to accept a 33 percent increase in wages over six years and a 10-year agreement on staffing levels.

LEAD: George Russell's music has had a pervasive influence in jazz circles since the 1940's, when compositions such as ''Cubano Be, Cubano Bop'' and ''A Bird in Igor's Yard'' pointed out intriguing parallels between Afro-Cuban rhythms, be-bop and Stravinsky. His sextets of the 60's, which included musicians such as Eric Dolphy, made some innovative and enduring records, and the news that Mr.

LEAD: The White House chief of staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., denied today that he formally asked Congressional leaders to allow the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to address a joint meeting of Congress next month.

LEAD: For perhaps 1,000 years, the windswept mesa here has drawn dreamers. First came the Indians, then the Spanish explorers, then 19th-century American miners, all drawn by what the Indians called ''the sky in the stone,'' the delicate turquoise mined here.

LEAD: A MAMMOTH civil lawsuit by shareholders against Ivan F. Boesky, the fallen Wall Street speculator, is expected to proceed expeditiously now that the United States Supreme Court has decided a securities case that had threatened to delay the Boesky matter.
LEAD: The South African Defense Force acknowledged today that 47 members of a black battalion with previous service in Angola were discharged last month but denied that there had been a mutiny.
LEAD: Susan I. Rosenholtz and Assemblyman Arthur J. Kremer were married last evening at the Plaza in New York. Rabbi Morris Friedman and Cantor Charles Ritter officiated.

LEAD: Hedda Nussbaum said yesterday that she was surrendering all rights to custody of the 17-month-old boy she and Joel B. Steinberg had raised as Mitchell Steinberg. She said the child's place was with his biological mother, Nicole Smigiel.

LEAD: An elderly Austrian arrested this month on a remote ranch in Argentina has emerged as one of the most brutal commandants of the Nazi labor camps, according to Austrian police files now made public.

LEAD: BEVERLY BLOSSOM is one of those rare solo performers who can indicate the most complex of situations and emotions with the simplest and most purely physical of moves and gestures. And ''Beverly Blossom, Again,'' a program seen on Saturday night at the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace, was the performer and choreographer at her best.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Hundreds of Greek Cypriot women bearing white banners stormed and scrambled across the line dividing their country today, scuffling with armed Turkish soldiers in protest against the division of the island.
LEAD: A homeless man panhandling for money stabbed at least five worshipers who tried to stop him from approaching a priest today during a mass.
LEAD: Camouflage Publishing, publisher of Spin magazine, of which Robert Guccione Jr. is president and chief executive, has welcomed David H. Horowitz, 58, as an investor and chairman.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 George Shultz received signs that Moscow wants to resolve the main differences remaining over a new missile treaty when the Soviet Foreign Minister, Edward A. Shevardnandze, meets him for two days of talks in Geneva. Page A1 El Salvador's President criticized returning rebel civilian leaders and demanded that they break their links with the military wing of the guerrilla front.
LEAD: Joe Montana threw for 304 yards and Jerry Rice caught three touchdown passes today to lead the San Francisco 49ers to a 24-10 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

LEAD: Most skiers are happy if they can ski every day during a week-long vacation or every day for a few weekends each season. Paul Schipper was not content with that. Every day that Sugarloaf/USA in Maine was open over the past six seasons, he has skied. On Saturday, a week into a seventh season, his streak reached 1,000 days.

LEAD: An article on Nov. 7 about organizations that prepare students for Scholastic Aptitude Tests misstated the policy of the Stanley H. Kaplan Educational Center. Students in the Kaplan preparatory course may retake the course free for up to a year regardless of their scores on the test.

LEAD: LIKE many ballets by George Balanchine, ''Divertimento from 'Le Baiser de la Fee' '' is named after its music. Yet it is a far from typical Balanchine ballet, as was vividly reaffirmed Friday night when Robert LaFosse made his debut in the work's only male role.

LEAD: The announcement Friday of a compromise plan on the Federal budget deficit removed one uncertainty from the credit markets, but many analysts said it was not enough to cause a quick, substantial decline in interest rates.

LEAD: The Mahler Fourth Symphony and the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto, which made up the Westfield Symphony Orchestra's program Saturday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, pursue different routes heavenward. Mahler's symphony takes roughly an hour wending its way toward a gentle fourth movement for soprano and orchestra that is a child's vision of paradise.
LEAD: Although most of the East's college football players took their helmets off for the last time this season on Saturday, there are playoffs and bowl games ahead for some.

LEAD: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation is expected to announce today that it will begin distributing some 20 different mutual funds, including products from Dreyfus, Federated, Franklin and Putnam, through 10 of its New York area branches.

LEAD: There was an occasional sign of frustration as Steffi Graf muttered to herself in German, swatted a ball or two in annoyance and all but abandoned attempts to coax her backhand slice over the net. For one of the few times during a remarkable year, the 18-year-old West German appeared vulnerable, and the prospect of an Agatha Christie ending to the tennis season filled the air at Madison Square

LEAD: The immigration agreement that set off the riot by Cuban inmates at a detention center in Louisiana reinstated an understanding between the two countries that was reached in December 1984. The State Department announced the reinstatement Friday.
LEAD: Earle Bruce has sued Ohio State and its president, Edward Jennings, because of the anguish his family felt after his dismissal as football coach, his attorney said today.

LEAD: The administration of President Raul Alfonsin has abandoned Argentina's decades-old policy of state domination of the oil industry and is appealing to private enterprise, both foreign and national, to help exploit the country's energy potential.
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he had received encouraging signs that the Soviet Union wanted to resolve the main differences remaining over a new missile treaty.

LEAD: THOUGH it hardly seems possible, Emanuel Ax, Isaac Stern and Yo-Yo Ma were making their New York debut as a trio Saturday evening in Carnegie Hall. They have played together elsewhere in this country as well as abroad, but they had not yet not done so here.

LEAD: A wild elephant trampled a school teacher riding a moped and sat beside the man's body until chased away by the police, the United News of India reported today. The elephant, which had strayed from a herd in Orissa State in eastern India, killed the teacher, Prabhakar Sahu, 45 years old, on a highway Saturday then squatted beside the body until it was forced back into the forest.

LEAD: The three conferences here on the Nixon Presidency produced a tantalizing moment when Jeb Stuart Magruder, the deputy director of Mr. Nixon's 1972 campaign, offered a clear explanation of why Nixon loyalists ordered the break-in at Democratic National Committee headquarters in the Watergate building in

LEAD: Two of the four defendants in the Howard Beach murder trial will not testify in their own behalf and a third is unlikely to, their lawyers say as they prepare to call their own witnesses in the two-and-a-half-month-old trial.

LEAD: Wisconsin insurance regulators have confirmed that they granted two insurance companies permission to market policies that limited or denied payments to state clients who have AIDS or AIDS-related illnesses.

LEAD: Many players were limping, and several faces were marked by cuts and bruises, souvenirs of connections with the opponents' sticks. But the Rangers, who had lately taken an emotional battering as well, flew home from Winnipeg without the hangdog demeanor they had worn for the last three weeks.
LEAD: American Home Products Corp. named John D. Feerick, dean of Ford-ham University's Law School, a direc-
LEAD: The rapid spread of foreign-owned assembly plants along the Mexican border will likely be sustained because of the latest plunge in the peso's value, industry officials here said.
LEAD: Iranian naval gunners fired on two Greek-registered vessels in the Persian Gulf over the weekend in apparent retaliation for Iraqi attacks on shipping bound for Iran.
LEAD: In the wake of last month's stock market plunge, world financial regulators have intensified their effort to change outdated national regulations to cope with an increasingly global market.

LEAD: OUT of television's often murky ''based on fact'' catalog comes ''Lena: My 100 Children,'' the movie on NBC at 9 tonight. Linda Lavin plays Lena Kuchler-Silberman, who after World War II dedicated herself to helping the surviving children of Holocaust victims in Poland. As might be expected, the story of the children is explored for maximum heart-tugging.
LEAD: The championships remain unsettled, but almost all of the champions will be back.

LEAD: For decades, Eastern Europeans who wanted reforms found the Soviet Union standing in the way. Now Moscow takes the lead and beckons, while Eastern Europe's leaders balk. Their economies are in crisis, their people dispirited. Most of the leaders are old or ailing and to them, the future looks uncertain and reform risky.

LEAD: A new survey of the single men and women in the city's shelter system conducted for the city by the New York State Psychiatric Institute, and based upon interviews with a cross section of shelter residents, depicts a deeply troubled population, in which most people may never be capable of living entirely on their own.

LEAD: After years of frantic scrambling for beds and blankets, New York City's system of shelters for the homeless has grown into a vast bureaucracy that city officials and critics alike say is becoming increasingly competent in providing at least the bare necessities to all who need it.

LEAD: Donald B. Reed is stepping into a competitive slot at the Nynex Corporation. The company has named him president of the Nynex Information Resources Company, which publishes white and yellow page directories.

LEAD: The Staten Island division might have been the toughest in the Public Schools Athletic League this football season. At one point or another, it qualified four of its six teams for the A League playoffs. But after last Saturday's P.S.A.L. quarterfinals, none remained.

LEAD: A political prisoner, pardoned by the Sandinista Government, receiving a certificate of liberty yesterday from an official of the Interior Ministry. Most of the prisoners had been accused of backing the contras. Page A6. (Agence France-Presse)

LEAD: In an unexpectedly decisive vote, Mexico's principal opposition party today chose a wealthy rancher with a reputation for aggressive oratory as its candidate for President in next July's general election here.

LEAD: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. will sell its History Book Club and two smaller clubs for $25 million to the Book-of-the-Month Club, a division of Time Inc., Harcourt's chairman, William Jovanovich, said Friday. The sale, which includes the Pre-School and Instructor book clubs, will be concluded Tuesday, he said.

LEAD: More than 1,000 Cuban inmates, outraged at the prospect of being deported under a new immigration agreement, took over a Federal detention center here Saturday night, seized about 30 hostages and set fire to most of the prison.

LEAD: When the airline industry was deregulated in 1978, the unfettered market was expected to give rise to scores of low-cost carriers that would create a bonanza for consumers, put the existing companies on the defensive and even run some of them out of business.

LEAD: Two years ago, in a Monday night game, Lawrence Taylor of the Giants hit the Washington Redskins' quarterback, Joe Theismann, with a clean but jarring tackle that broke Theismann's leg. The young, strong-armed Jay Schroeder came off the bench to lead the Redskins to a victory and to win the job as the starting quarterback.

LEAD: AM International Inc. said it had reached a four-year standstill agreement with Komuri Printing Machinery Co., which holds 6.7 percent of AM's common stock. Komori agreed to limit its ownership to less than 8 percent of AM's stock in the next six months and to less than 5 percent for the duration of the agreement.

LEAD: As Eric G. Larson announced his planned retirement as publisher of TV Guide last week, he also announced the promotion of William Deitch, a longtime magazine research specialist, to the position of general manager of TV Guide. By tradition at Triangle Publications, the job outranks publisher.

LEAD: IN the Talking Band's theatrical collage ''The Three Lives of Lucie Cabrol,'' the usually demure Tina Shepard plays the title role of a dwarflike French peasant woman whose family cruelly nicknames her ''the cocadrille,'' after a mythical animal born in a dungheap. Ms. Shepard strikingly transforms herself into a hunched, thick-skinned beast of burden who speaks in harsh, guttural cadences and survives through a combination of native shrewdness and a mystical attunement to the natural world.

LEAD: First-time travelers to Moscow or Leningrad are always struck by the banners. Huge letters, usually red, are strung across the road or hung from windows proclaiming love of party and country: ''Glory to the Communist Party!'' ''Our Policy, the Policy of Peace!'' But recent visitors found a new variation on the upper-floor windows of the unfinished United States Embassy office building.

LEAD: An appeal hearing sought by Peter Ferriola, the thoroughbred racing trainer, of a 120-day suspension imposed by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board began yesterday in the board's offices in Manhattan. LEAD: A major and previously unknown score by Franz Liszt is to be auctioned at Sotheby's in London on Friday. LEAD: Adele Miller, who with her late husband, Samuel, founded the Miller Advertising Agency in 1919, died last night of complications from Alzheimer's disease at Beth Israel Hospital. She was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Dozens of vehicles collided today in separate accidents on a fog-bound stretch of Interstate 215, and at least seven people were injured, a California Highway Patrol commander said. Estimates ranged from 30 to 40 vehicles involved in the crashes, said Capt. Ralph Limon. He said several accidents had occurred, some involving six to eight vehicles and another with as many as 15 to 20.

LEAD: The ghost of ''early music'' as a semi-amateur activity descended now and then at the sometimes fine concert in Merkin Concert Hall's ''On Original Instruments'' series Monday evening. In the last section of Schubert's ''Shepherd on the Rock,'' Malcolm Bilson hit a left handful of wrong notes on his replica of an 1815 Dulcken piano, Judith Nelson hit a tentative sounding high note and looked uncomfortable about it, and Lawrence McDonald flubbed the final flourish on his early 19th century clarinet.

LEAD: Tennis Becker Advances: Boris Becker defeated Claudio Pistolesi of Italy, 6-1, 6-2, in a second-round match yesterday at the $150,000 Young Masters tournament in Friedrichshafen, West Germany. LEAD: Allegheny International Inc. today estimated its net losses at $215 million for the third quarter and $285 million for the first nine months of 1987. The company also said it would pay no dividends for the sixth consecutive quarter.

LEAD: The commander of four New York City transit police officers suspected of making scores of false or improper arrests in the subways used a rating system to reward those who made the most arrests and issued the most summonses with the best assignments and work schedules.
LEAD: Questions appear on page 12..
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Jerry Carlson, conductor of the Gay Men's Chorus of Los Angeles, died of complications from AIDS on Monday at his home here. He was 31 years old.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The main course at holiday meals this season is costing less because of a surplus of turkeys.

LEAD: Soup is no longer served at the Community Soup Kitchen of New Haven. Ten years after they opened a modest once-a-week soup and sandwich program at the Salvation Army they are able to provide nutritious multi-course hot meals. ''Soup just isn't a hearty enough meal and now we have more to offer,'' explained David O'Sullivan, coordinator of the

LEAD: THE new Stamford Transportation Center made little impression on Eli Halpern last Monday. The Stamford resident, who regularly commutes to New York City on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, was unaware that the long-awaited and oft-troubled train station had finally started service.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 24 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: A GROUP of female friends, who happen to be therapists, were discussing Marilyn French's latest book, ''Beyond Power,'' at a cocktail party recently. When asked if I had read it, I had to confess that I hadn't, although I scored points for having read her two novels, ''The Women's Room'' and ''The Bleeding Heart.

LEAD: THERE WILL BE NO STEEL BARS. There will be a walk-through rain forest with birds flying freely overhead. There will be state-of-the-art artificial trees, designed by Jonquil LeMaster-Rock (above). There will be 200 species, including polar bears, penguins, puffins, muntjac, macaques and leaf-cutter ants.

LEAD: Mary Elizabeth Kirk, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elijah Thomas Kirk of Louisville, Ky., was married there yesterday to Nicholas Lieder Eastman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffery Eastman of Essex Fells and Bay Head, N.J., and Stratton Mountain, Vt. The Rev. David Searfoss performed the ceremony at the Calvin Presbyterian Church, assisted by Msgr.
LEAD: A picture caption on Oct. 18 about a bust on display at the Palais des Beaux-Arts in Brussels, misidentified the work. It is of Philip the Good, Duke of Burgundy.

LEAD: COLLECTING art requires a great deal of faith. One has to trust one's tastes, the art dealer and the market. But even with art prices soaring - a trend underscored earlier this month by the astronomical $53.9 million that Van Gogh's ''Irises'' brought at auction - faith can take you just so far. Increasingly, buying and selling is being regulated through legislation and case law, and consumers need to be aware of their rights to negotiate better deals.

LEAD: The hunting season makes serious eaters start thinking of game. In spite of easy, year-round availability, game is rarely found in home kitchens on Long Island. As a result, people who enjoy game dishes, eat them at restaurants.

LEAD: Betsy Rae Robbins, a health-program analyst with the Mayor's Office of Municipal Labor Relations, and Mark Robert Weiss, an associate at the New York law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, were married last evening at Congregation Beth El in Cherry Hill, N.J. Rabbis Howard Kahn and Isaac Furman and Cantor Jeffrey

LEAD: IN the two weeks since the arrest of Richard J. Angelo, the former Good Samaritan Hospital nurse charged with injecting a patient with a powerful muscle-paralyzing drug, more questions have been raised than resolved.

LEAD: RUTH SHEREFF, now 44 years old, bought stock on her own for the first time just two years ago. Her father, who had been managing her money until then, said that it would have been better had she lost money the first time out so she would learn caution and humility. Instead, she made a killing.
LEAD: Diamonds Still Dazzle

LEAD: WHEN John K. Kittredge retired as an insurance executive early this month, he and his wife, Betty, sold their home in Summit, N.J., and moved, not to Florida or Arizona, but to Chapel Hill, N.C., a town with which they had no ties.

LEAD: ROBERT C. MCCRAY STEERS HIS gray Chevrolet slowly around the common in Amherst, N.H., taking in favorite details: the swings in the yard of the brick schoolhouse, the steeple atop the Congregational Church, the white rail fence that hugs the town green. There's a Civil War monument, of course, and an old water trough and a flagpole.

LEAD: HOW to save the American musical theater? Kevin Connors thought he'd found a way. And when Roger Ludlowe High School in Fairfield, Conn., was closed last year, Mr. Connors knew he'd found the place.
LEAD: NOW 16 years old, Tucker is quite deaf, nearly blind and walks very slowly. But his owner, Elissa Zager, said recently that the family pet ''still has a sparkle in his eyes.''

LEAD: King Olav V of Norway says he is thrilled to be making his sixth visit to Minnesota, where one-sixth of the state's residents are of Norwegian descent. ''I have been enormously impressed by the unfailing interest in Norway here in this country,'' the King said at a dinner in his honor Friday night.

LEAD: EDWARD LOSS graduated near the top of his class in law school, was certified by the Illinois Supreme Court's Committee on Character and Fitness to become a lawyer and was waiting for a swearing-in date when the court barred his certification.

LEAD: FRANK LORENZO, CHAIRMAN OF THE TEXAS AIR CORPO-ration, personifies the grand social experiment called airline deregulation. Pioneer of the low fares that brought air travel within reach of millions of Americans, ruthless competitor and union-buster, he has since 1980 transformed a feisty regional carrier into the largest airline enterprise in the non-Communst world.

LEAD: ONE AFTERNOON NOT LONG ago, John Kander and Fred Ebb were attending a rehearsal at the tiny Vineyard Theater of a revised version of their first Broadway musical, ''Flora, the Red Menace.'' As Veanne Cox, who plays the title role, began singing ''It's a Quiet Thing,'' the composer and lyricist, who were sitting in different parts of the theater, each began to weep.

LEAD: E. F. Hutton is for sale. The stock market collapse last month and the likelihood of a downgrading in its credit rating were the final blows to a securities firm that has been struggling since it pleaded guilty two years ago to a check-kiting scheme that defrauded banks of millions of dollars. Last year, when most of Wall Street was awash in profits, Hutton had a loss of $90.3 million.
LEAD: A BEER company may ultimately have more clout than three major cities that are attempting to induce the football Cardinals to leave St. Louis.

LEAD: A father stopped by the foundry where he works on his way to Thanksgiving dinner and killed his two young sons by putting them in a large ladle and heating it, the authorities charged Friday.
LEAD: ''BY THE grace of God, I am here in this country,'' the young man said. ''By His grace, I am still alive. And by the same grace of God, I will return to carry on the fight.''

LEAD: ALL EVIDENCE to the contrary notwithstanding, everything has not been said and done about Abstract Expressionism and its derivatives. Bearing witness to this is a show of the works by the late Mario Garcia that comes to the Noyes Museum here courtesy of the Princeton Gallery of Fine Arts.

LEAD: To the Editor: Apropos your Practical Traveler ''Finding Lost Luggage'' (Travel, Sept. 27), I would like to share our experience with your readers. On Sept. 24 we checked in at the Eugene, Ore., airport bound for Kennedy International Airport by way of San Francisco. The cheerful, courteous United Airlines clerk agreed that the layover of half an hour might be too short if there were a delay at Eugene and rerouted us to Denver where the layover was a bit longer.

LEAD: NOT too many moons ago, a visitor had merely to step off the train or bus from Gatwick Airport at Victoria Station to find a W. H. Smith book-and-record shop with long-playing record treasures beyond imagining. Alas, the W. H. Smith store at Victoria contains no records these days. And the Our Price Records shop in the same station (now a subsidiary of W.

LEAD: FOR the first time, the presidents of eight Latin American nations are meeting without a United States presence to discuss solutions to their regional problems. The agenda for the conference, which is to conclude today, ranges from the conflicts in Central America to the region's foreign debt of nearly $400 billion.

LEAD: Scott Sutterfield was never afraid of his job as a guard at the Federal detention center in Oakdale, La., but he had a feeling that something unwelcome might happen when he went to work Nov. 21.
LEAD: Derek Schmidt kicked four field goals, and Dayne Williams scored twice on 1-yard runs today as Florida State rallied to beat Florida, 28-14, and end a six-game losing streak in the rivalry.
LEAD: To the Editor: Isn't it time the airlines did something about the carry-on luggage situation?
LEAD: STOCKS may have crashed, but if recession follows it is likely to come on little cat feet.

LEAD: THE thermometer acts like a yo-yo at this time of year. Its up-and-down readings should remind gardeners that more of the same lies ahead. To help plants survive, here are some reminders to get the garden ready.

LEAD: CHANGE is not merely in the air, it is here. Just look at what happened Oct. 4. Talk about a harbinger of worse things yet to come! I get depressed enough between November and April. I don't need a freak snowstorm in the first week of October to remind me that winter is on its way.

LEAD: Arthur Dennis was as surprised as anyone. He had just scored six of the eight touchdowns John Adams made in beating Midwood, 55-21, yesterday in a Public Schools Athletic League semifinal game in Ozone Park.
LEAD: At least 500 people were killed when giant waves churned up by Typhoon Nina smashed coastal towns and villages in southern Luzon, a provincial governor said today.

LEAD: At the Brick Presbyterian Church in Manhattan, Mary Gannon Moran, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Thomas Moran of Holland, Mich., was married yesterday to Madison Lewis Ford, a son of Mary Hope Lewis and F. Richards Ford 3d, both of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Heidi Hudnut-Beumler officiated.

LEAD: Prospective customers poring over items for sale yesterday in Shubert Alley, west of Broadway between 44th and 45th Streets. The market was sponsored by the cast of ''A Chorus Line'' and Actors' Equity, and the proceeds were donated to members of the union who have contracted AIDS. (NYT/Dith Pran)

LEAD: I HAVE never tallied the hours I spend driving on errands or playing chauffeur, but sometimes it seems that the car is an extension of my body and I am connected to the gas stations along Route 25A by a giant umbilical cord.

LEAD: It seems that the Mahopac Outlet Mall in Putnam County was jinxed from the start. Since it opened on Route 6 and Miller Road in 1973, three anchor stores in succession closed after the bankrupt chains of which they were a part went out of business. Those failures crippled smaller retailers there.
LEAD: CROWDED into a New York State hearing examiner's room on John Street one Friday afternoon this month were enough big guns to fight a major battle, even though only a skirmish was at hand.

LEAD: The Cole article seemed to assert that the state's official position on radon - all homes in the northern part of New Jersey should be tested within a year - is premature and ill-advised, and will result in an unnecessary expense to homeowners and windfall profits for companies that have jumped on the radon bandwagon.
LEAD: GOOD-BYE AND KEEP COLD By Jenny Davis. 210 pp. New York: Orchard Books/Franklin Watts. $12.95. (Ages 12 and up)

LEAD: Susan Elizabeth Tellier and Joseph James Perticone Jr., a son of Mary C. Perticone of Baltimore and the late Mr. Perticone, plan to marry Jan. 16, the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Tellier of Mamaroneck, N.Y., have announced.
LEAD: A MIND OF HER OWN The Life of Karen Horney. By Susan Quinn. Illustrated. 479 pp. New York: Summit Books. $22.95.

LEAD: AS the year 1987 winds down, millions of Americans are casting about for last-minute ways to minimize the tax burden that awaits them April 15. Although year-end opportunities for tax savings are not so plentiful now as they were prior to the Tax Reform Act of 1986, they do exist. For one thing, all tax benefits have not been abolished: Retirement savings plans, for example.are still available.

LEAD: Even in the horrific company of Nazi concentration camp commanders, Josef Schwammberger stood out as a bestial man, according to wartime Austrian police files that were recently made public. Mr. Schwammberger, now 75 years old, admitted shooting 35 Jews during questioning in 1945. He escaped from detention that year and later surfaced in Argentina, where he was arrested this month and now faces extradition to West

LEAD: FOR ME, FALL IS A TIME OF nostalgia. Cascading leaves and a nip in the air remind me of the impending holidays and the comfort of home. It is a season for moving indoors, crackling fires and celebration of robust fare. Tables laden with juicy roasted game birds, thick soups and stews laced with hearty winter vegetables reflect our need to stave off the cold.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH there has been an improvement in the spawning of striped bass in many of the rivers entering Chesapeake Bay, the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission announced earlier this fall that it would continue its current recommendation for a 33-inch minimum-length limit for migratory coastal stocks of the species.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Q. I have been advised that when I close my summer home for the winter, I should leave the heat on at a low setting of about 40 degrees to protect the wood paneling, built-ins and furniture. Do you think heating is necessary when the house is unoccupied?

LEAD: BRAD A. BALL couldn't get the melody out of his mind. For months during early 1986 he was haunted by ''Mack the Knife,'' written by Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht for ''The Threepenny Opera'' and a No. 1 hit for Bobby Darin in l959. What made the song stick was its irresistible connection to one of his biggest clients, the McDonald's Operators Association of Southern California - and, of course, to the Big Mac.

LEAD: AT 10:15 ON A SPARKLING AUTUMN morning, Gerard R. Roche - the Old Master, the High Priest, the Grand Acquisitor, the King of the Executive Headhunters - is seated at his desk on the 32d floor of the American Brands Building on Manhattan's Park Avenue, doing the thing he does better than anyone else.

LEAD: THE MAN IN FORMAL EVENING wear pauses to adjust one of his gold cuff links, and listens. From the balcony of his hotel he can hear drumming, muffled but insistent, borne by the breeze from somewhere beyond the perimeter of the new town's stark electric lights and flickering neon. ''Voodoo Warning is calling, down in Limbo,'' he croons softly to himself.

LEAD: UNLIKE THE HUGE EX-hibits of electronic home equipment staged each year in Chicago and Las Vegas, the much smaller Hi-Fi Show held last month in New York City was not just meant for the trade. It was open to anyone.

LEAD: Credit Report on a Tenant Question: I am trying to rent a one-family home. I plan to use a standard application form for prospective tenants. Aside from checking to see if people are employed, is there any way that I can get a report from a credit-reporting company to learn about the finances of people I might rent to?

LEAD: Touche Ross Video Tax Guide 1988 MasterVision. 75 minutes. $29.95. Similar to the one made by Touche Ross and MasterVision last year, this video guides individuals through a number of the intricate elements of present-day tax planning. The forward look this time is toward 1988, when additional changes stemming from the 1986 tax reform act become effective and new rules affecting taxpayers and their tax returns come into play.

LEAD: ''THE SLEEPING BEAUTY,'' A ballet on ice conceived for television, which will be shown next Sunday evening at 7 on Channel 13, banks on the current popularity of three key elements within the production: dance, skating and a renewed interest in fairy-tale themes. These are supposedly magic ingredients, but they do not automatically jell into a unified result.
LEAD: For years, the New York Hilton Hotel on Avenue of the Americas at 53d Street held on to a site it owned to the west of its parking garage in case it wanted to expand.

LEAD: In the wake of the stock market collapse of Oct. 19, and its fallout on the economy, investors are reassessing their financial and investment strategies. To help them do so, Fred R. Bleakley and Jan M. Rosen of The New York Times staff discussed these issues with two Wall Street professionals: Jonathan A.
LEAD: Cuban inmates late Saturday delivered a list of demands to officials at the Federal penitentiary here and said that they would release the 94 hostages they are holding if all demands are met.

LEAD: DURING the last eight years, the number of research reports presented at the annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience has more than doubled, exceeding 6,600 this year. In an attempt to keep up, more than 11,000 scientists and onlookers gathered for the 1987 convention, which was held in New Orleans this month.
LEAD: The brawny, but quick, outside linebackers have become such an intimidating power in the National Football League that even the slithery Freeman McNeil has been forced to change his style.

LEAD: Nearly 100 years ago the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences built a museum where children from the surrounding middle-class neighborhood of Crow Hill could ''stimulate their powers of observation and reflection.''

LEAD: THE kinds of investments that get the most publicity are often the least appropriate for the average investor, say the experts. Because they involve too much risk, have poor potential for return or require the time and attention that only the most sophisticated professionals can devote to them, these investments are best avoided by anyone whose primary attention is elsewhere, for instance, on a demanding job.

LEAD: BEHIND the esoteric acronyms and intricate statistics that dominate the Soviet-American negotiations on arms control, there stands a psychological equation, one so delicate that it seems strangely out of place amid the awesome power of mutual destruction held by the leaders in Washington and Moscow.

LEAD: WHATEVER its impact upon the public's psyche and pocketbook, the recent stock market collapse does not alter the basic argument for investing in mutual funds, provided individuals consider the funds' shortcomings as well as their advantages.
LEAD: POP-UP drains in bathroom basins may seem mysterious, but actually they are simple to repair. Knowing how they operate is useful.

LEAD: TRIM hedges, and if evergreen, store the clippings outdoors to use for making wreaths, door swags or table centerpieces. Clean out the tool shed. Go over catalogues and discard those no longer needed to make room for new ones due in January. Popular Flower
LEAD: Leaders of the flight attendants' union at American Airlines are asking members for authorization to call a strike before the busy holiday travel season.

LEAD: Susan Williams, a research analyst at the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif., and Daniel Schecter, a management consultant for the LEK Partnership in Los Angeles, were married yesterday at the Chapelgate Presbyterian Church in Ellicott City, Md. The Rev. Dr. Donald Kinloch performed the ceremony.

LEAD: IN case Tony Dorsett hasn't gotten the message, Tom Landry, the coach of the Dallas Cowboys, made it all but explicit last week. While he stopped short of saying the 33-year-old running back would be asked to retire after the season, Landry told The Dallas Times Herald that Herschel Walker represented the team's future.
LEAD: An 18-month-old girl was found alive Friday in a house with an infant and two adults who had apparently been dead for several weeks, the police said.

LEAD: The State Supreme Court has decided that Harry E. Claiborne, removed as a Federal district judge by the Senate through impeachment last year because of his conviction for income tax evasion, may practice law in Nevada.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Anatole Grunwald of New York and Vineyard Haven, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mr. Grunwald's daughter Lisa Grunwald to Stephen J. Adler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Adler of Baldwin, L.I. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: ''I'M DEVELOPING A NEW THEORY of 'Tamara,' '' says the 31-year-old Canadian playwright John Krizanc.

LEAD: The idea seemed seductively simple five years ago. The City of Rutland and neighboring towns would pool their garbage and burn it in a huge incinerator, producing electricity. The garbage, which had been threatening to overflow landfills, would be gone and the electricity would be cheap.
LEAD: FACING a gloomy fiscal picture, the Monmouth County community of Roosevelt held an Arts and Crafts Fair last Sunday to raise money for its First Aid Squad.
LEAD: SELECTED POEMS By Tony Harrison. 204 pp. New York: Random House. $15.95. SELECTED POEMS 1954 to 1982. By John Fuller. 175 pp. North Pomfret, Vt.: Secker & Warburg/David & Charles. $25.95.
LEAD: SQUANDERING EDEN Africa at the Edge. By Mort Rosenblum and Doug Williamson. Illustrated. 326 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.
LEAD: I would like to express my appreciation for the Nov. 8 articles on day care on Long Island and at our center, Clasp.
LEAD: WHAT investor would not be pleased to have the insider's edge, that boardroom's-eye view of corporate plans that would surely mean money in the market?
LEAD: What started as a proposal for the world's tallest building is turning into New York's most welcome coalition: Donald Trump, Mayor Koch and John Cardinal O'Connor.

LEAD: IT WAS THE MORNING RUSH HOUR IN SHEN-yang. A cloud of smog hung over the city of three million as the 41 members of the United States-Sino Securities Management Delegation boarded the bus at the Friendship Hotel. Our destination: a Chinese stock exchange.

LEAD: DURING the last eight years, the number of research reports presented at the annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience has more than doubled, exceeding 6,600 this year. In an attempt to keep up, more than 11,000 scientists and onlookers gathered for the 1987 convention, which was held in New Orleans this month.

LEAD: In a region of extremity and violence, Mubarak Awad is a curious political being. He is an Arab, born in Jerusalem, who tells his fellow Palestinians that nonviolent methods offer the best hope of ending Israel's 20-year occupation of the West Bank.
LEAD: President Reagan says that after leaving office he ''would like to start a movement'' to repeal the constitutional amendment that limits Presidents to two terms.

LEAD: Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Elizabeth Hoy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Hoy of Bethesda, Md., and Clyde Edwards Reetz, a son of Gay Edwards Reetz of Bronxville, N.Y., and John H. Reetz of Bradford, Pa. The Rev. Peter Beck performed the ceremony.

LEAD: NEW-AGE MUSIC IS OOZING TOWARD THE big time. Once found alongside seaweed and Tarot cards at an occasional macrobiotic outlet, new-age music has evolved from a shared secret to a trendy commodity. In the last year, two of its stars, the Swiss ''electroacoustic harpist'' Andreas Vollenweider and the Japanese synthesizer player Kitaro have played to full houses at Radio City Music Hall.

LEAD: REPRESENTATIVE Norman F. Lent of East Rockaway, the ranking Republican on the House Energy and Commerce Committee, is known in Washington as a man who can work with the opposition and shepherd complex commercial legislation through his panel.

LEAD: SOME consumers have recently received solicitations for ''affinity cards'' - bank credit cards offered in conjunction with a nonprofit charity or association. The sponsoring bank promises to help the organization every time the customer charges a purchase with the card.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: THE SELECTED LETTERS OF LIDIAN JACKSON EMERSON Edited by Delores Bird Carpenter. Illustrated. 343 pp. Columbia: University of Missouri Press. $42.
LEAD: THE phone call to my mother would not, I was sure, be the easiest I'd ever made. She was then in her early 80's, but enjoyed making people think of her as quite a bit younger.

LEAD: The Moscow authorities have begun to crack down on unofficial political groups in the aftermath of the Yeltsin affair, breaking up meetings and making some arrests, according to members of several groups.

LEAD: In a written rebuttal to the report of Mayor Koch's Commission on the Year 2000, the Manhattan Borough President, David N. Dinkins, said the commission had failed to recognize racism as a factor in the city's persistent problems of poverty, crime and homelessness.

LEAD: A New York woman named Joyce Brown recently achieved national notice for persuading a judge that the city had no right to hospitalize her, even though she lived on the streets. While the case inspired policy debate, it also distorted the problem of the homeless. Whatever one makes of their civil rights, few of the homeless enjoy life on the street.

LEAD: QUIETLY, with few people noticing apart from a handful of social researchers, the economic power of America's teen-age population is mushrooming, changing the nation's consumer tastes as well as its family life.

LEAD: THE TIGHTER I HELD HER, THE more she stiffened, arching her back and pummeling her heels into my midsection. And her continuous high-pitched shriek made my skull reverberate. It had been going on for nearly five hours. Seldom in my life had I felt so rejected by anyone. My 6-week-old daughter had colic.

LEAD: Prose Buds in Spring Too Part sermon, part celebration, nature writing is like taking one's prose style mountain climbing. This is Gretel Ehrlich observing spring in Wyoming. She is one of many writers in ''The Best American Essays 1987'' (Ticknor & Fields), edited by Gay Talese.

LEAD: All week long, the talk leading up to today's game between Miami and Notre Dame centered on the last meeting between the teams. Two years ago, Miami stomped the Irish by 51 points, and memories of that were supposed to fuel Notre Dame's bid for an upset.
LEAD: A military contractor and its president have agreed to plead guilty to charges of passing off used electrical connectors as new ones for military aircraft, a Federal prosecutor said Friday.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: At the Beth Israel Congregation in Vineland, N.J., Lynda Luby Eisenstat, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Eisenstat of Vineland, was married last evening to Mitchell Alan Dorf, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sheldon Dorf of Fox Point, Wis. Rabbi Murray Kohn and Cantor Miriam Frishman officiated. The bride is a sales representative in Atlanta for Vie de France, a bakery chain based in McLean, Va.
LEAD: The first of two aging Coast Guard cutters was scuttled Friday night to create an artificial reef for marine life and a new attraction for divers off the Florida Keys.

LEAD: Kristina Louise Dahl, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Robert Dahl of Manhasset, L.I., and Hancock, Mass., and Joseph Gerard Hylas, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hylas of New York, were married yesterday. Bishop Robert P. Varley performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset.

LEAD: ''THERE'S SOMETHING ABOUT A WAR'' goes the title of a song that was written for, but never used, in Stephen Sondheim's first musical as a Broadway composer, the 1962 ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum.'' There's something about a Stephen Sondheim musical that's something like a war - and, until the arrival of his latest and perhaps most tranquil show, ''Into the Woods,'' that war had threatened to rival the Thirty Years' War in duration.

LEAD: COVERT ACTION The Limits of Intervention in the Postwar World. By Gregory F. Treverton. 293 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95. THE PERFECT FAILURE Kennedy, Eisenhower, and the CIA at the Bay of Pigs. By Trumbull Higgins. 224 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $17.95.

LEAD: THE highway strip along Route 7 in Norwalk has never been a source of prime-time dining. With the arrival of Three Flags, that has changed. You might not know it from the exterior of the new brick building, which could easily suggest a fast-food eatery. The name rings bells that evoke a theme park more than a first-class restaurant.

LEAD: SOME people find Christian Lacroix's fashion designs overly theatrical. But that is precisely why Mikhail Baryshnikov, the artistic director of the American Ballet Theater, chose Mr. Lacroix to design costumes for a revival of Leonide Massine's ''Gaiete Parisienne,'' which will be on the bill for the company's season opening gala at the Metropolitan Opera House on

LEAD: Nastique scored a mild upset when she rallied from seventh in a field of 11 to win the 117th running of the Ladies Handicap by 8 1/2 lengths yesterday at Aqueduct. The race, which had a purse of $244,800 this year, is the country's oldest stakes race for fillies and mares.

LEAD: WHEN Joyce Brown was removed from a sidewalk in front of a hot-air vent on Second Avenue at 65th Street in Manhattan last month -and went to court to fight for release from the psychiatric ward to which she was taken - it was only the latest skirmish in an age-old battle for control of the urban landscape.

LEAD: TELEVISION AWAITS MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV; the Soviet leader arrives in Washington on Dec. 7, but already there are arguments. Soviet officials had suggested that Mr. Gorbachev make a 10 A.M. speech to a joint session of Congress. The time difference would have allowed him to appear live and in prime time in Moscow.

LEAD: Don McPherson led Syracuse to an undefeated season, thus ending a 24-year absence from a New Year's bowl date. Consider another aspect of McPherson's exemplary season. Back in 1961 Syracuse University's Ernie Davis became the first black man ever to receive the coveted trophy. Would it not be judicious and historically correct to award the Heisman to the first black quarterback from that same fine university?

LEAD: BARBARA and Joseph Suarez started life with very little money. Between that and some savings, they had a lump sum of $325,000.

LEAD: WOULD ANYONE ARGUE AGAINST THE proposition that the ear is the body's most important organ in the perception and evaluation of music? Not likely. Even the more presumptuous opera directors might concede, at least in principle, that there is more to music than meets the eye. But it is also true that seeing while listening can sometimes add a dimension to a problematical work and make a believer of a skeptic.

LEAD: LAST weekend I attended a conference of photography curators and archivists. They were not exactly a typical bunch of photo buffs even though many were carrying point-and-shoot cameras. But one of the most hotly contested topics of conversation involved a question that every photographer has to face at one time or another: how to decide which pictures to keep and which to throw out.

LEAD: THE death of a 5-month old baby in New Britain after he spent the night in a car with his homeless parents has focused attention once again on the plight of Connecticut's homeless and the fear that winter will bring more tragedy. Typically in winter, there is more attention focused on the homeless, a group whose number appears to be increasing as the state's stock of low-income housing and residential hotels diminishes.

Overall, he combined great running with great passing to lead Syracuse to an undefeated season.

LEAD: Basketball Tolentine Upsets Molloy: A standing-room only crowd of 1,200 squeezed into the gym at Archbishop Molloy High School in Queens last night to see the Stanners upset by St. Nicholas of Tolentine, 76-72, in the season opener for both teams. Tolentine, a school with an enrollment of 400, one-quarter the size of Molloy, outmuscled the Stanners with their bench strength.
