LEAD: LAST year, Americans gave $87.22 billion to charity, a 9.4 percent increase over 1985, according to the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel, which represents fund-raising advisers. For 1987, experts predict somewhat smaller increase in the wake of the October stock market collapse.

LEAD: THE San Diego Yacht Club has delayed until Wednesday any announcement of its plans for dealing with New Zealand's challenge for the America's Cup. Club officials are apparently trying to enlist the support of other potential United States syndicates in a unified stand against New Zealand.

LEAD: AS part of a general effort at urban renewal and civic image-building, the city of Galveston, Tex., commissioned seven architects to design arches for its 1986 Mardi Gras celebration , the first held in the city since 1946. Their widely varying results, shown in photographs, models and drawings, make up the amusing ''Arches for Galveston'' exhibition on view at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum through Jan.

LEAD: Rodney Beville's 92-yard touchdown run highlighted a 17-point third quarter that carried Emory & Henry to a 23-16 victory over Washington & Jefferson in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division III South Regional playoff final today.

LEAD: THE BERKUT. By Joseph Heywood. (Random House, $18.95.) Adolf Hitler killed himself in the spring of 1945 as the Red Army advanced on his bunker in Berlin. Or did he? Groan. Not another novel about how Hitler or one of his henchmen survived to sin another day. But don't despair. Joseph Heywood's second novel isn't your run-of-the-mill Nazi-hunting twaddle.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Deanna C. Maneker of Westport, Conn., and Morton M. Maneker of New York City of the engagement of their daughter Amy Jill Maneker to Dr. Brian Robert Herts, a son of Dorothy Herts of Roslyn, L.I., and Harry Herts of Scottsdale, Ariz. A March wedding is planned.
LEAD: Almost 20 years ago, New York City's hospitals and medical institutions helped create the world's largest regional blood supply organization.

LEAD: WITH 14 Federal and local agencies scrambling - sometimes competing with one another - to expose corruption, New York City's construction industry seemingly has a plethora of watchdogs. But top aides to Governor Cuomo now say the administration is poised to add two more units to clean up and regulate the diffuse mix of developers, contractors, suppliers and labor unions.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: GIVE a manager his choice and he'll pick a pitcher who can strike out batters over one who uses other means to secure outs. Results of pitchers' performances this past season support that choice.

LEAD: AS New York State nears the end of its colossal move of agencies from the World Trade Center, a former official is standing trial on bribery charges, while relocated employees are complaining of leaky pipes, frontier locations and excessive rents.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: AN extraordinary sight met my eyes one evening in late summer. My two cats were on the lawn facing something sitting between them. That ''something'' was black with white stripes. All three animals were frozen into immobility; the cats weren't taking their eyes off the skunk and the skunk wasn't certain just where to turn or what to do next.
LEAD: President Reagan asserted today that military intervention by the Soviet Union in other nations was ''a major impediment to improved U.S.-Soviet relations.''

LEAD: IN HER book ''The Biological Clock'' (Doubleday, New York, $18.95), Molly McKaughan of Montclair gives a new meaning to the term ''clock watchers,'' her phrase for most of the 5,000 women who replied to a 1985 survey on motherhood in Working Woman magazine.
LEAD: THE Stamford Fire Department is running a program to collect returnable bottles and cans and to cash them in for money to buy smoke detectors.

LEAD: SOMETHING has been added to the new shorter-length dresses for evening. Often, it is a long train of taffeta, shaped like a fishtail or an icicle. Sometimes, it is a cascade of ruffles made of netting.

LEAD: GEORGE WASHINGTON furnished the porch of his Mount Vernon home with 27 bow-back Windsor chairs. Thomas Jefferson is said to have sat swiveling in a Windsor as he drafted the Declaration of Independence. And Charles Eames told a reporter in the 1970's how much he admired this furniture: ''I have always hoped my chairs would be regarded as the

LEAD: A passer-by on West 18th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues might never imagine what hides behind the doors of the High School for the Humanities. On its second floor, enclosed within an old storage room, is Manhattan's only student-run zoo.

LEAD: Writers deserve star billing in a handful of films on the small screen this week. Harold Pinter's adaptation of ''The French Lieutenant's Woman'' (1981) - Saturday at 8 P.M. on Channel 11 - entwines John Fowles's story of a Victorian outcast with a modern tale of illicit love, not always successfully.

LEAD: IN ''A Little Visit With a Big Surprise'' [ Opinion Page, Oct. 25 ] , Herbert Hadad laments the apparent failure of a bond, built during a holiday encounter with some beautiful people, to survive separation.

LEAD: At Temple Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., Sari Lynn Kalomeer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kalomeer of Matawan, N.J., was married last evening to Gregory Seth Sholom, a son of Ronald Sholom of New York and Cornwall Bridge, Conn., and Susan Norwalk of Floral Park, Queens. Rabbi Ephraim Buchwald officiated.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: NO one goes to the Vallee du Giffre. In the Michelin Guide to the French Alps, it is mentioned only in passing, a place to get around or quickly through. There are no curiosities in its tiny villages, and its mountains - its jagged, hulking mountains - offer few gentle slopes for le ski moderne. It is one of those parts of the region known as the Haute-Savoie that time has left to the Savoyard peasants; and that, I was told more than once in Paris, where I was to get my train to the Alps, was reason enough to stay away.

LEAD: THE Palestinian guerrilla crossed the electrified Lebanon-Israel border fence on a moonless night last week, dangling from a motorized hang glider, passing the shimmering lights of the town of Qiryat Shemona, landing in a thorny field next to the Gibor Israeli army base. Within minutes, the guerrilla killed six

LEAD: The engagement of Kimberley Cordeaux Ozimek to Dr. Paul Peter Vessa Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vessa of Bergenfield, N.J., and Del Ray Beach, Fla., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Ozimek of Rye, N.Y.
LEAD: A picture caption on Nov. 1 with a guide to cruises misidentified a ship off Grand Cayman. It was the Holiday of the Carnival Cruise Lines, not the Norway of the Norwegian Caribbean Lines.

LEAD: Two gigantic building projects proposed for the West Side of Manhattan have prompted a groundswell of opposition so broad and deep that a number of urban experts and politicians say it has changed the way New Yorkers look at their skyline and feel about their government.

LEAD: THERE are more than 17 million men and women in the United States who spend endless hours during the day negotiating multimillion-dollar deals or managing sensitive operations or even performing life-and-death surgery so that on weekends and vacations they can perfect the art of trying to hit a dimpled, rubber-covered, solid- or composite-cored high-compression sphere weighing 1.62 ounces into a hole on the ground that is roughly four inches in diameter and impossible to see without the help of a small red flag.

LEAD: AS prison disturbances in Atlanta and Oakdale, La., lurched toward an uncertain ending last week, Washington policymakers were again confronting the consequences of America's fractious relationship with Cuba's Fidel Castro.

LEAD: When New York's highest court last week upheld two previous court rulings, it did not uphold smoking in public. It said that the State Public Health Council had gone too far in issuing new rules on public smoking. The council, said six of the seven judges on the Court of Appeals, had ''usurped'' legislative power.

LEAD: Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church in Wilton, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Lisa Benson Brinkman, the daughter of Richard Gene Brinkman of Wilton and Jensen Beach, Fla., and the late Audrey Benson Brinkman, to Michael Charles Jensen Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jensen of New York and Peekskill, N.Y.

LEAD: It was the Big Ten against the Pac-10, and the bodies were flying. But it wasn't the Rose Bowl. It was the semifinals of the 10th Great Alaska Shootout. Arizona beat Michigan, 79-64, today to advance to the title game.

LEAD: An article last Sunday about the belief that Thomas Jefferson maintained a long intimate relationship with one of his slave women misstated the history of Frances Trollope's book ''Domestic Manners of the Americans.'' It was published in 1832.

LEAD: Last season, the Giants played (and beat) the Redskins three times, and each team played each game as if it were for a championship. On Sunday, they will meet again before the usual sellout crowd at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in a game means little in the standing.

LEAD: To the Editor: In two articles on Salzburg and environs (Travel, July 5 and Aug. 16), Oscar Millard correctly described what the females wear as Dirndls. What the men wear he called flannel. The stuff is Loden. The only resemblance is that both are gray. PAUL SINGER Summit, N.J.

LEAD: DID Madame Bovary take arsenic to avoid doing dishes? While I was washing the previous night's dinner-party plates and platters, this question raced through my mind like turbulent waters through the Proustian floodgates of memory.
LEAD: Seventeen inmates at the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center in Manhattan have gone on a hunger strike to protest their internment.

LEAD: EAB Bank officials are having a contest to guess the exact number of lights on their 80 feet high Norway Spruce christmas tree. ( Hint: it was more than 20,000 last year.) If you can't count them from this photo, try it in person. The gala tree lighting ceremony takes place at the EAB Bank Plaza in Uniondale this Friday (Dec 4) starting at 4:30 p.m.
LEAD: ON JULY 4, 1986, Liberty State showcased to a national television audience. Millions of Americans saw a prime-time Boston Pops concert and fireworks show that highlighted Liberty Weekend.

LEAD: ''Starting Over: TV's Grant Tinker'' (by Diane K. Shah, Oct. 25) - give me a break. When you have Mr. Tinker's money and connections, you do not start over; you move on. KAY KAUFMAN Forest Hills, Queens
LEAD: BUYERS seeking a new home -whether a single-family house or a town-house-style unit - are increasingly likely to find that builders are offering modular construction.
LEAD: A money-changer sat in the shade of a tree overhanging the Rue Pavee, ordinarily one of the capital's busiest commercial strips, yesterday.

LEAD: Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $355,000 101 Burns Place 5-bedroom, 3-ath, 15-year-old frame raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room, deck, walk to stores; taxes $7,180. South Salem, N.Y. $352,000 Hoyt Street 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 16-year-old contemporary; cathedral ceiling, deck, greenhouse, lake rights; taxes $3,350.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IF you're wondering what to wear over poufed and flared evening dresses, the fashion designer Arnold Scaasi has the answer: Try a limousine. His approach for 30 years has been lavish, elegant evening dresses, shown each spring and fall in collections and custom-made for clients at his salon, Scaasi Couture on Fifth

LEAD: IVAN LENDL is doing everything he can to get Cindy Davenport to hit a tennis ball back across the net at the Tennis Club of Trumbull. But the 7-year-old Bridgeport girl, despite encouraging words of advice from the world's best tennis player, can barely get her racket on the ball, let alone hit it over the net.
LEAD: Cadets at the U.S. Coast Guard Academy in New London are learning how to steer a ship without having to set foot on one.

LEAD: With the Knicks at 1-7 and Gerald Wilkins not into the flow of Rick Pitino's motion offense, the coach made a change in his starting lineup. He replaced Wilkins at shooting guard with Trent Tucker, the better outside shooter.

LEAD: To the Editor: While it is no doubt possible to spend $100 for dinner for two at the places Mr. Millard mentioned, prospective visitors to Salzburg should not be discouraged by the prices quoted.

LEAD: THERE are Hungarians galore in 20th-century art - Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, Victor de Vasarely, Zoltan Kemeny and the photographers Brassai and Andre Kertesz are some that come immediately to mind. But famed though it is for its emigres, who also include Franz Liszt, Bela Bartok and several movie moguls, not to mention the Gabor sisters, Hungary itself hasn't had so much as a walk-on part in the

LEAD: To the Editor: S. Irene Virbila's article about the wonders of Bay Area bread (Travel, Nov. 1) could only bring a feeling of self-righteousness and I-told-you-so to those of us who always brought an empty suitcase to San Francisco in order to fill it with bread to bring back to New York.

LEAD: By drilling to the bottom of the ice sheet in the heart of Antarctica, Soviet and French scientists are determined to solve the riddle of the ice ages by acquiring a year-to-year record of climate for the last half-million years.

LEAD: The refusal of Government negotiators to allow rebellious Cuban inmates to meet with outside mediators appears to have become a stumbling block to the release of 26 hostages held at a Federal detention center here.

LEAD: THE McIntosh County Shouters, who gave their first New York concerts Friday and Saturday at Washington Square Church under the auspices of the World Music Institute, perform ring shouts, an archaic black music tradition that was long thought to be extinct. The ring shout, which was first described by visitors to plantations in the deep South as early as the 1840's, seems to have survived longest in isolated island communities off Georgia and South Carolina.
LEAD: TELEVISION audiences like color - so why not color the old, classic black-and-white movies, say the proponents of an electronic process known as colorization.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William F. Murdoch Jr. of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Patterson Murdoch to Dr. Henry Clinton Maguire 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Maguire Jr. of Merion Station, Pa. A January wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Tauno Schwelnus greeting children as he stood guard yesterday at Fifth Avenue and 58th Street.

LEAD: SOME day one of our advanced business schools will offer a graduate course in how to become a chief executive. It will probably attract armies of the brightest of the bright. But of course it will not work because in no office in the business universe is the crucible of experience more essential. Nor is experience itself the answer.

LEAD: Speculative disasters are an ancient curse. Even the Roman Forum most likely had its Black Fridays and Shattering Mondays. Now we have experienced our own panic, whose history cannot yet be written, but whose place in history can perhaps be tentatively assessed. A glimpse of the past may even help us peer into the future.
LEAD: Marcia Eve Neuhaus and David G. Speck were married last evening at the bridegroom's home in Alexandria, Va., by Rabbi Sheldon Ezring.

LEAD: For the first time in college football history, the Heisman Trophy should be awarded to an outstanding football team, not an individual. A team truly representative of amateur athetics with enough guts to get on the field with anybody -win or lose. . . Columbia University. MURRAY H. SALIT

LEAD: EARLY in the morning in an outrageously messy office at the New York headquarters of the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, the talk was about airplanes and money. To expand, the Memphis International Airport had to raise about $100 million. The five men sprawled in the sloppy office sipping from Styrofoam coffee cups were municipal bond specialists.
LEAD: THIS time of year, many companies are afflicted with the Peter Pan syndrome.

LEAD: Tim Foley's 42-yard field goal in overtime completed a comeback from an 18-point halftime deficit today as Georgia Southern, seeking its third consecutive national championship, edged Maine, 31-28, in the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I-AA playoffs.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article about Iceland in today's Travel section incorrectly gives the times of sunrise and sunset on the winter solstice, Dec. 21. The sun rises at 11:23 A.M. and sets at 3:34 P.M., resulting in about 20 hours of darkness.

LEAD: The article ''Northern Democrats Assess Gains in Election'' [ Nov. 15 ] reported on Patty Hotchkiss's victory over Ursula LaMotte in County Legislative District 2. It said some believe ''Mrs. Hotchkiss was greatly aided by a last-minute campaign by some who portrayed Mrs. LaMotte as an opponent of legalized abortion.
LEAD: Maine's rate of accidental deaths of children, nearly twice as high as in some other New England states, is prompting questions and some answers from the state's pediatricians.

LEAD: When the Reagan Revolution was in its formative stage in the late 70's, and its outriders were starry-eyed about cutting the monster called Big Government down to size, Cap Weinberger used to regale Reaganauts with the Legend of the Bureau of Indian Affairs.

LEAD: Lovers of the soprano voice, and more particularly the soprano voice as espoused by the younger American generation of singers, should be in clover this week. Three representatives of the breed - Carol Vaness, Leona Mitchall and Dawn Upshaw -will be giving recitals in a four-day span.

LEAD: ON this Sunday last year, we were 9-2 and coming off ''Fourth and Seventeen'' and the whole world could see we were headed for Pasadena. I didn't know one Giants' fan, however, who believed we would make it to Pasadena.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: BOLIVIA'S tourist attractions encompass a string of superlatives, starting with La Paz, at 11,909 feet the highest large city in the world.

LEAD: CANDLELIGHT CONCERTS Richard Kapp and his Philharmonia Virtuosi chamber orchestra will open the Candlelight Concerts of Larchmont series at 7:30 P.M. today in St. Augustine's Church, on Larchmont Avenue. The 13-year old ensemble has performed at Alice Tully and Avery Fisher Halls in Manhattan, the Kennedy Center in Washington, on tour throughout the Far East, and at the State University of New York at Purchase every year since the college's Performing Arts
LEAD: THE black-and-white film is grainy, but its impact is as powerful today as it was nearly 20 years ago.

LEAD: Thirty-five years ago, long before apartment ownership took hold in New York City, a small group of residential cooperatives in Queens formed a support group, the Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives.

LEAD: Donna E. Goldbach, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Goldbach of New York, was married in New York yesterday to Paul Stephen Appelgren, the son of Charles Appelgren of Montrose, Colo., and Irma Appelgren of Lakewood, Colo. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.
LEAD: LONG ISLAND duck farmers say they know when they and their ducks are not welcome.

LEAD: LEONARD A. LAUDER, president and chief executive officer of the Estee Lauder cosmetics empire, is barreling through a Bullock's department store in Southern California, an entourage of a dozen trying to keep pace. It is the sixth store he has visited today to critique the way his products are displayed.
LEAD: ARMED AND DANGEROUS The Rise of the Survivalist Right. By James Coates. 294 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $17.95.

LEAD: ACCORDING to a certain genre of romantic novel, there's a ''no better than she should be'' seductress simmering inside many a discreet black dress, and an adventurous swashbuckler lurking behind a lot of blue pin-stripe suits. Stick with these romances and inevitably passion flares, a volcano erupts.

LEAD: IT was nearly midnight when two young men, one carrying a piece of pipe, the other a length of lumber, marched down the middle of a deserted boulevard in the heart of the Haitian capital. They were members of one of the many neighborhood patrol groups that sprang up briefly last week in Port-au-Prince and other

LEAD: Lelia Erdice Pardee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Trevor Pardee of New York and Rio Dulce, Guatemala, was married yesterday to John Frederick Haller, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Boyd Haller of Carmel Valley, Calif. The Rev. Robert Jensen of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints performed a nondenominational ceremony at the home of David Bates, a cousin of the bride, and Mrs.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ALTHOUGH no President since Franklin Delano Roosevelt has been able to appoint more judges than Ronald Reagan, the Federal court system has not yet become the conservative bastion that he and his supporters had intended. It has not been for lack of trying. By the end of his term, Mr. Reagan will probably have named more than half of the nation's 743 Federal judges.

LEAD: EVER since the Oct. 19 stock market collapse, most analysts have been saying that the economy would slow down as a result, perhaps enough to send the nation stumbling into recession. They argue that consumers, who account for two-thirds of the gross national product, have lost both wealth and confidence and will pull in their horns accordingly.

LEAD: DURING his short visit to Washington next week, Mikhail S. Gorbachev plans to spend two hours with 60 American business leaders - a sign of the importance the Soviet leader attaches to an improved economic relationship with the United States.

LEAD: Embroiled in divorce proceedings, the dress manufacturer's wife was struggling to get what she considered to be her fair share of the assets accumulated over 12 years of marriage. Her husband claimed that his company's annual sales had dropped from $2 million to $800,000, but she suspected there was more there than met the eye - in the form of off-the-books cash sales.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Marion Gay Gordon, the daughter of Mrs. Carleton Walker Borden of Wilmington, Del., and Buck Hill Falls, Pa., and the late James Gay Gordon 3d, was married yesterday to Donald Cameron Lacy 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lacy Jr. of Richmond and Virginia Beach, Va. The Rev. Adam Lewis performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville,

LEAD: The Argentine Government has been thrust into crisis and confusion by the loss that President Raul Alfonsin's Radical Civic Union suffered in September by-elections, according to critics and supporters of the Government.

LEAD: ACROSS, by Peter Handke. Translated by Ralph Manheim. (Collier/Macmillan, $6.95.) The Austrian writer Peter Handke uses fiction to explore the ways in which we can escape from the labyrinths of language into subjective realms. His novel about Andreas Loser, an archeologist who literally gets away with murder, is ''one of the most arresting and expansive'' of his books, Lawrence Graver said in The Book Review last year.
LEAD: The Ward Melville Patriots upset the West Islip Lions, 27-14, yesterday to win the Suffolk County Conference I championship.

LEAD: It is gratifying to see that fashion designers are beginning to realize that furs and animal skins can be utilized in fashion without inflicting the cruelty that accompanies the use of genuine animal skins (Fashion: ''Imitation of Life,'' by Linda Wells, Nov. 1). The message is that real people wear fake furs.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: I enjoyed Paul Cohen's thoughtful article on the Mennonites. A considerable number of your readers are not attracted to yuppie-type articles about Wall Street, fashion or Madison Avenue. ADAM PENENBERG New York, N.Y.

LEAD: Govan A. Mbeki, a prominent leader of the outlawed African National Congress, talked of political hope and reconciliation in his first public speech since being freed from a South African prison early this month.

LEAD: Sarah Katherine Hofstadter, the daughter of Mrs. Theodore H. White of Bridgewater, Conn., and the late Richard Hofstadter, was married yesterday to Dov Wisner, a son of Tova Wisner of Haifa, Israel, and the late Moishe Wisner. Judge Stuart R. Pollak of the San Francisco Superior Court performed the ceremony at the bride's home in Oakland,
LEAD: Emile Zola's famed newspaper expose, ''J'accuse,'' which defended Capt. Alfred Dreyfus from charges of treason, has once again become a cause celebre - this time within the Zola family.

LEAD: To many people, windows are commonplace artifacts of urban life that require attention only when they get too dirty to see through. But to those sensitive to architectural values, windows are prime design features that must be maintained with care and replaced with even greater care only when the originals no longer serve.

LEAD: Enos Nkala, Zimbabwe's Minister of Home Affairs in charge of the country's police force, today viewed the macabre scene at Olive Tree Farm near here where 8 of 16 murdered missionaries were hacked to death Thursday.
LEAD: Today's television sitcoms are a far cry from what one used to think of as ''recreation,'' defined by Webster as ''refeshment of strength and spirits after work.''

LEAD: WITHIN THE EVER-WIDEN-ing stylistic spectrum of modern dance, the art of Erick Hawkins remains steadfast. Although his dances are charged with variety, their underlying esthetic and physical premise never alters. For Mr. Hawkins, whose company begins a six-day engagement at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, to dance is to move naturally, without strain, without tension and without artifice.

LEAD: DURING the last eight years, the number of research reports presented at the annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience has more than doubled, exceeding 6,600 this year. In an attempt to keep up, more than 11,000 scientists and onlookers gathered for the 1987 convention, which was held in New Orleans this month.

LEAD: More than 40 percent of American adults are concerned that they will contract AIDS, and fear of having the deadly disease is prompting many people to change their sexual behavior and take other precautions, the latest Gallup poll indicates.

LEAD: Cynthya Margaux Bletter, a daughter of Gladys Ketcher-Bletter of Great Neck and Westhampton Beach, L.I., and the late Sydney Bletter, was married last evening to Michael David Pallack, a son of Mati Pallack of Great Neck. Rabbi Robert S. Widom officiated aboard the yacht Paco Rabanne at the Water Club in New
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Government banned all reports on the political opposition or on anything deemed to be criticism of the authorities today, a day after President H. M. Ershad imposed a nationwide state of emergency.

LEAD: Against a backdrop of heightened urgency, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund opens its 76th annual appeal today on behalf of the hungry, the homeless and the underprivileged in the New York metropolitan region.

LEAD: South Shore lost its star tailback for almost half the game, and its star wide receiver in the final period. But the Vikings managed to battle back from a 26-12 deficit and defeat John F. Kennedy of the Bronx, 29-26, in an overtime shootout yesterday in a Public Schools Athletic League semifinal football playoff.

LEAD: At the Trinity College Chapel in Hartford, Mary Hunter Sloan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Sloan 3d of Farmington, Conn., was married yesterday to Mario A. Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Terrence B. Smith of New Milford, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Borden W. Painter Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: An inmate who tried to escape by crawling through a drainage culvert drowned after a night of heavy rain, officials said Friday. Jean Ulysses, 29 years old, formerly of Haiti, had pried loose a grate leading to the pipe Thursday night at Tomoka Correctional Institute, and heavy silt hampered Volusia County sheriff's divers who tried to rescue him, the authorities said.
LEAD: After months of showing the voters what a smart guy he is, Representative Jack F. Kemp is now trying to prove that he can be a tough guy as well.
LEAD: AN unmarried man in his early 30's gets a big promotion.
LEAD: CIGARETTES By Harry Mathews. 292 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $17.95.

LEAD: HOUSING COSTS: N.Y.-Northeast N.J. area* % change from % change from Oct. from Sept. from Oct. 86 Rents [1] 133.9 0.3 5.5 Homeowner's costs [1] 137.8 1.9 9.4 Fuel and utilities [2] 363.3 -3.8 0.1 *Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic.

LEAD: YOU'RE a smart person; do you really need a travel agent for your vacation trip? An agent is probably not going to save you a lot of money on an air trip, unless you are shy about calling a lot of airlines on 800 numbers and asking what the cheapest fare is to that place. But if you would rather do something other than this research, you probably need a travel agent.

LEAD: THE 7-year-old boy can not sleep tonight. His uniform is laid out beside his bed, and he keeps getting up to put on his blue and yellow cap, to finger the engraved buckle of his blue webbed belt, to gaze at the insignias decorating his brand-new blue shirt. My husband had bought the entire outfit, including the yellow kerchief and various metal buttons, for more money than he had paid for his own fall jacket.

LEAD: A man that authorities said had been impersonating a nurse at a Harlem hospital for three months has been arrested, setting off a review by the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation of the credentials of about 3,500 nurses registered with a referral agency, officials said yesterday.

LEAD: Twenty-one Brahman bulls escaped from a corral at the Mesquite Rodeo Arena Friday in a bull-riding lesson and swarmed across the Lyndon B. Johnson Freeway and lawns in this Dallas suburb. Motorists slammed on their brakes. Some took photographs. One bull made his way into a subdivision and was roped in front of a $500,000 home.

LEAD: Senator Paul Simon, seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination, said today that the Reagan Administration's farm policies had helped only the corporate farming industry. In a 90-minute stop here, the Illinois Senator told a crowd of about 100 people that farm programs should be redesigned to benefit the family farmers.
LEAD: One great athlete stands alone:Craig Heyward of the University of Pittsburgh. ALEXANDER N. COLONNA Amagansett, L.I.

LEAD: AT this time of year, mailboxes overflow with requests for charitable contributions. Before long, however, your mailman may be bringing you something more eye-catching than a letter - a videotape.

LEAD: Lakewood $84,000 1360 Lanes Mill Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; 2-car garage. W/W carpets, 2-car garage; taxes, $1,179. Livingston $205,000 37 Grand Terrace 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 47-year-old Tudor; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, full basement, den; taxes $2,543.

LEAD: Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court thought Federal agents were trying to plant marijuana at his ranch in the West and he thought a Pennsylvania mob was going to lynch him for his role in the Rosenberg spy case, according to a new book, ''The Douglas Letters.''

LEAD: THINKING IN PICTURES: The Making of the Movie ''Matewan.'' By John Sayles. (Houghton Mifflin, Cloth, $21.95; Paper, $9.95.) If you've ever wondered how some of the sillier dialogue gets into movies, John Sayles has a convincing explanation. Give a studio executive a script for a western, and there will come a time when, unable to visualize the stampeding buffalo herd, he will wonder, ''Couldn't one of the Indians say, 'Here come the buffalo'?

LEAD: The Trophy should go to one of the outstanding and most overlooked running backs of this season, Kenny Gamble of Colgate. This season he broke several school and Division I-AA yardage and scoring records. Even when compared with the better-known players from larger schools, Gamble has shown himself to be almost a one-man team.

LEAD: WE SHOULD be demanding more from our planners. Not necessarily longer hours at the meetings of the planning boards, but more in the sense that we look to them for the quality of life in the built environment.

LEAD: WHEN Eben Price became a father, he and his wife did what his parents had done for him 17 years earlier: They opened a savings account. ''After three and a half years of a marriage in which we'd never managed to maintain a savings account,'' said Mr. Price, a 32-year-old Dallas lawyer, ''we knew we'd never develop that kind of financial discipline any other way.

LEAD: A STEP IN TIME Having trouble perfecting your schottische, quadrille, turkey trot or galop? Not to worry. The Vintage Music & Dance Society of West Hartford will hone your skills in workshops from 10 A.M. to noon and from 1:30 to 4 P.M. Saturday, then give you an opportunity to show off at a grand ball from 8 P.M.

LEAD: When Li Peng was named Acting Prime Minister of China last week, some Western diplomats voiced concern not only with his plans for the future, but also with his schooling in the past. Mr. Li, who is assured of being named Prime Minister on a permanent basis at the National People's Congress next spring, is a 59-year-old Soviet-educated engineer who, in the eyes of some Westerners, has not enthusiastically supported the economic policies of China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, and might even have ''pro-Soviet'' leanings.
LEAD: To the Editor: We had a trouble-free trip to Italy this May and great pleasure and excitement until we arrived at the Troncetto, the artificial parking island for the trip to Venice.

LEAD: LAST month, Mayor Joseph J. Marinan Jr. of Meriden announced a $48 million plan to bring 19 downtown acres out of the doldrums. ''Those five square blocks are an untapped resource,'' Mayor Marinan said. ''They produce only $130,000 in property taxes - the same as two residential streets.''

LEAD: FEW tennis players think of calling their game ''lawn tennis,'' a name inappropriate except at Wimbledon and a few tradition-minded places, to distinguish it from the historic game of ''real tennis.''
LEAD: A 14-year-old boy was killed by the police in a shootout Friday after he chased his mother from his home, the police said.

LEAD: Jutting into the Pacific Ocean about 100 miles south of San Francisco, the Monterey Peninsula was among the first ports of call visited by Spanish seafarers who explored California in the 17th century. It still draws visitors from afar. Many come nowadays in search of a movie star who serves as mayor of one of its cities or to see the playful otters on exhibit at a three-year-old aquarium on Cannery

LEAD: Until last week, Richard L. Nahley was a pillar of this city's legal and political structure - a popular 51-year-old lawyer with a seemingly successful practice, a former corporation counsel and the city's Probate Court judge. He was active in raising money for charities and was an avid golfer and churchgoer.

LEAD: Sarah Gray Valentine, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Massie Valentine of Richmond and Virginia Beach, Va., was married last evening to Jesse Thompson Ellington 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellington Jr. of San Marino, Calif. The Rev. Frank F. Fagan performed the ceremony at St. James's Episcopal Church in Richmond.

LEAD: FRED GRATZON, FOUNDER AND CHAIR-man of The Great Midwestern Ice Cream Company in Fairfield, Iowa, doesn't follow politics closely. But he's hoping to turn a sweet profit on the battle for the Presidency. He has established the nation's first and only Presidential ice cream poll.

LEAD: Across the road from this town's dump is a fenced-off pond where marked walking trails lead to a public bathhouse with emergency medical facilities, and at the shoreline a sign reading ''No lifeguard on duty'' juts from greenish water.

LEAD: MRS. CARLA P. OF Houma, La., writes to ask, ''What is this Iowa carcass I keep hearing about politicians running in? A friend told me they have the world's biggest hogs up there in Iowa and every year they slaughter the biggest one they can find, clean out the carcass and make all the politicians run around in it to show they have real Iowa grit.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: POOR Bjorn Borg. When the former tennis champion moved back to Sweden a couple of years ago after a decade of tax-happy exile in Monte Carlo, he apparently had to leave most of his money behind. That, at least, is one conclusion suggested by some figures from the first income tax return Borg has filed in 11 years.
LEAD: ''Make no mistake. The Soviets are and will continue to be our adversaries, the adversaries indeed of all who believe in human liberty.'' - President Reagan [ 6:3. ]
LEAD: IN the heat of a bull or a bear market, when investors are experiencing the pleasure of profit or the pain of loss, it is hard to keep emotions out of decisions.
LEAD: TOM FREEMAN is a 22-year-old graduate student and left guard for Notre Dame. He wishes he could play four more years for Lou Holtz, the second-year coach.

LEAD: ON Christmas Eve at the San Juan pueblo in northern New Mexico, every family puts up a small pile of logs in front of their home. As the sky darkens over the pueblo, the wood is ignited into fires called luminarias. Dancers known as Matachines appear, in many-colored silk capes and streaming ribbons, led by a blanket-draped figure holding a cross.

LEAD: IT wasn't much more than a year ago that the final approval was granted, and the Philippines had itself a Winter Olympics team for the first time since 1972. Although there were dark moments in the campaign, like the time a government official was detained at the airport in Manila and forced to turn over important papers intended for the nation's Olympic
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Donna Rayner, a daughter of Alice Rayner and Ahmed Rayner Jr., both of Chicago, was married there last evening to Brandon Balthazar, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Don J. Balthazar of White Plains. The Rev. Michael Ivers performed the ceremony at St. Columbanus Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: The marriage of Debra Lynn Stein, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Stein of Allentown, Pa., and Scott Ira Rosen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Rosen of Wayne, N.J., took place last evening at Loews Glenpointe Hotel in Teaneck, N.J. Rabbi Moishe Cohen officiated.

LEAD: CHOREOGRAPHY OBSERVED. By Jack Anderson. (University of Iowa, $25.) In this anthology of criticism, the New York Times dance critic Jack Anderson concentrates on the one aspect of dance that fascinates him most - choreography. Choosing among his articles in The Times and other publications to form this collection, Mr.

LEAD: IN WILLIAM WEGMAN'S STUDIO in New York's Hudson Valley, the blond floors appear to be stenciled in an abstract floral pattern. In fact, after prolonged efforts to keep his dog out of the way of workmen during construction, Wegman took a different tack: he painted his dog's feet green and let her loose inside.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Passports Question: On the immigration forms of foreign countries, I have always written ''U.S.A.'' in stating where my passport was issued. Recently, on entering Thailand, I was asked to be specific. What is the proper way of answering this question? - D. W., White Plains Answer: The correct response is to name the city, the passport division of the United States Bureau of Consular Affairs says.
LEAD: The city's new law against aggressive panhandling has gone into effect, but the police say they did not have to use it the first day of the holiday shopping season.

LEAD: At St. Michael's Lutheran Church in New Canaan, Conn., Diane Webb Hunter, a jewelry designer, was married yesterday to Willard Clyde Mackey Jr., former chairman of McCann-Erickson Worldwide, an advertising agency in New York. The Rev. Elwood L. Stark performed the ceremony.
LEAD: By ALAN S. OSER
LEAD: TRUST YOUR HEART By Judy Collins. Illustrated. 275 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

LEAD: An article on Sept. 27 about Chicago misidentified the architect of Lake Point Tower. The architects were Schipporeit-Heinrich Associates, not Mies van der Rohe; George Schipporeit and John Heinrich, principals at the time of design, were students of Mies.
LEAD: The naming of Gordie Lockbaum, Holy Cross' great scholar and two-way star, will greatly enhance the Heisman Trophy.
LEAD: PRICKLY PEAR HILL was not supposed to be mentioned at a recent public meeting in Croton-on-Hudson, under ground rules set by the chairman. But every so often, the words slipped out.
LEAD: AT A SMALL Italian restaurant here, Allen W. McCracken fidgeted during a recent lunch and conceded he was somewhat nervous.

LEAD: Bridget Elizabeth Farrell, an associate at the New York law firm of Bower & Gardner, and F. David Campbell, a senior vice president of Key Bank of Central New York in Syracuse, plan to be married in May.
LEAD: Connecticut has found itself with about 7,000 new opera aficionados in recent weeks, and they are all between the ages of 5 and 12.
LEAD: Governor Cuomo of New York has withdrawn from a debate in Iowa and will be replaced by Representative Patricia Schroeder, a Colorado Democrat.

LEAD: TO say that the Germans invented Christmas undoubtedly taxes the imagination - and patience - of historians beyond the tolerable, even if many trimmings of the event, including its celebration around the winter solstice, have undeniable pagan Teutonic elements. But even skeptics will acknowledge that, in all likelihood, Christmas markets had their origins somewhere between the Rhine and the Oder, the North Sea and the Alps.

LEAD: OUR firm recently conducted an investigation into the issue of unfunded liabilities associated with retirement medical benefits. Among 40 major corporations studied, most cited liabilities ranging from $25 million to $1.5 billion. So far, these liabilities remain a closely guarded secret, but the situation is rapidly changing.

LEAD: LINCOLN CENTER'S Great Performers series took a leap into the 20th century Friday night when the Kronos Quartet played the first in its three-concert series at Alice Tully Hall. Like most Kronos concerts, the program featured premieres and recent compositions (the oldest, Bill Evans's ''Waltz for Debby,'' dated back to 1956).

LEAD: WHITE LIGHT. By Patricia Volk. (Atheneum, $18.95.) This inventive if flawed first novel is half comic strip, half yuppie spiritual crisis. When 35-year-old May Graves, an art director at a magazine for teen-agers, makes an ill-received comment at a meeting, trouble begins. A month away from New York City is what she needs, and soon May is in a hotel in the Adirondacks trying desperately to return to a simpler state.

LEAD: Elise Michelle Udolf, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Udolf of West Hartford, Conn., was married there last evening to Michael Douglas Leopold, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Leopold of North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Harold Silver officiated at Temple Beth Israel.

LEAD: A special Government inspection of Eastern Air Lines in June found that the airline's practices on postponing aircraft repairs was a ''misuse'' of Federal policy and that pressures on Eastern's crews posed a potential safety hazard, according to a report.
LEAD: There is no book of sexual manners in the office, because sex simply doesn't belong in the office. - 'Letitia Baldriges's Complete Guide to Executive Manners'

LEAD: The Soviet Union's eight-year intervention in Afghanistan is at a crucial moment, Western diplomats here and in Moscow say, with Moscow increasingly desperate to find a way to pull out its 115,000 troops when the Afghan regime is losing ground to the Islamic rebels.
LEAD: LANDIS VALLEY CHRISTMAS

LEAD: Elizabeth Bussiere, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Bussiere of East Setauket, L.I., was married yesterday to Sung-il Choi, the son of Shin-jae Kim of Reston, Va., and In-kyu Choi. The Rev. Stephen Eddington performed the ceremony at the Unitarian-Universalist Fellowship Hall in Stony Brook, L.I.
LEAD: A daughter of former New Jersey Gov. William T. Cahill was found dead in her apartment here after drowning in a bathtub, the woman's family and law-enforcement authorities said Friday.

LEAD: Credits were reversed on two cartoons in The Week in Review last Sunday. One, showing President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua sitting on a shipment from Moscow, was drawn by Steven Turtil of the Charleston (W. Va.) Daily Mail. The other, showing a contra leader as a puppet on President Reagan's foot, was by Rainer Hachfeld of the Hamburger Rundschau in West

LEAD: IN 1895, the seafaring residents of City Island were promised a new school building and bridge to the mainland if they would leave Westchester County and join New York City. With 900 ballots cast, the city beat the county by only two votes.

LEAD: THERE ARE SEVERAL MO-ments in Hugh Whitemore's ''Breaking the Code'' when Derek Jacobi fulfills our conventional expectations of a major actor. He expresses pain, anger, grief, desolation and, once or twice, a curious mix of them all, making one's eyes pop at the authenticity of his emotions and the potency of his performance.
LEAD: A jury has ruled in favor of the state in the sex discrimination case brought by Nancy Graff, a former acting editor of the magazine Vermont Life.

LEAD: Jayson Williams, a sophomore reserve forward, scored all of his game-high 22 points in the second half yesterday to lead St. John's to an easy 105-60 victory over Harvard in the opening round of the 13th annual Joe Lapchick Tournament at Alumni Hall. In the championship game today, the Redmen will face Loyola Marymount, which defeated Tennessee

LEAD: King Lear. Pygmalion. The Old Testament. Greek tragedies. If you substitute the nouns and verbs, you could write the family business owner's story. . . . His problems are the problems of humanity, and the business funds and fuels them. It's a family passion play, with the business founder center stage, usually alone.

LEAD: TURKEY'S 22 million voters are going to the polls today in their first civilian-supervised general elections since the military relinquished its hold over NATO's easternmost member in 1983. The outcome, however, is less of an issue than how the election will affect the country's long and flawed campaign for membership in a Western community of nations that are inspired, in

LEAD: THE roseate tern, which nests in the Stewart B. McKinney National Wildlife Refuge off southwest Connecticut, has been declared an endangered species by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, effective Dec. 2.

LEAD: I felt the warm rush of support from a kindred spirit as I read Daniel Meier's essay ''One Man's Kids'' (About Men, Nov. 1), about his life as a first-grade teacher. A newly minted clinical psychologist, I recently chose among several job offers, settling on a child-care agency run largely by women.

LEAD: THE dough that is the basis of the Tuscan crostata, a shallow one-crust pie usually topped with fruit or homemade fruit jam, is to an Italian what pate a foncer fine is to a French pastry chef, a classic sweetened crust for a tart. Any Italian knows know to make pasta, mixing eggs into a mound of flour, but only the most able cooks can create the flaky, butter-laden base that is the truth of a celestial crostata.
LEAD: For the first time in his seven years with the Giants, Lawrence Taylor will miss a regular-season or playoff game for which he was on the roster.
LEAD: ''This is more fallout from the crash.'' - eter Cohen, chairman of Shearson Lehman, potential bidder for E. F. Hutton

LEAD: A few years ago, thanks to a fund-raising campaign, that included bumper stickers reading ''Hot to Trot,'' the Hartford Mounted Police was established. A 10-horse stable was built, the horses were donated, and, before long, a police officer astride a horse became a familiar sight in city parks.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: WHILE many Wall Street professionals were looking for ever-greater rewards in a bull market that was defying economic gravity earlier this year, Lawrence A. Krause, one of the nation's leading financial planners and head of his own firm in San Francisco, was busily writing ''Sleep-Tight Money,'' (Simon &

LEAD: The Orchestra of St. Peter by the Sea, whose founder and maestro, the Rev. Alfonse Stephenson, is the former conductor of the musical ''A Chorus Line,'' will return to its home at St. Peter's Church in Point Pleasant Beach for a Christmas concert Saturday.

LEAD: THE mail-order catalogues have been examined, the local shops resplendent with Christmas displays explored, and you've still not found the definitive gifts for those very special people on your Christmas list. It's obviously time for a fresh approach.
LEAD: IN COMMEMORATION of the 50th anniversary of the composer's death, the Paper Mill Playhouse is having its own George Gershwin celebration, presenting the breezy pastiche ''My One and Only.''

LEAD: CIRCLES OF DECEIT. By Nina Bawden. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) The British novelist Nina Bawden's latest work is aptly named, since most of its characters are deceiving someone, not infrequently themselves. The unnamed narrator, a painter, has even elevated the practice to an art. He makes finely detailed copies of important works by the masters - always for legitimate purposes - and uses the income to finance his smaller output of originals.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:
LEAD: The Border War THERE'S a mini-border war going on between Smithtown and Huntington, and since the United Nations is otherwise engaged, the towns are taking their dispute to Suffolk County.

LEAD: SINCE it was signed in August, the Central America peace treaty has prompted tentative political steps which, if followed up, could alter the way Central American states treat their internecine and ideological quarrels.

LEAD: WE'RE BEING OVERRUN. THEY'RE COM-ing from Paris, London, Rome, Hollywood, New York, Seattle, Hoboken and Palermo -from Zimbabwe, Mexico, China, Zaire, Japan, Sweden, Canada, Israel, plus points in between, as well as out of the woodwork. Some arrive preceded by dignified, majestic pronouncements as to their Importance.

LEAD: IN TODAY'S BOOK-stores and libraries, you can get hold of just about any kind of dictionary, from the 12-volume-plus-supplements Oxford English to dictionaries of foreign languages and back-and-forth dictionaries (English-Swahili, Francais-Esquimau, etc.) to dictionaries of slang, of computerese, of dirty words and even of multilingual insults.

LEAD: THE celebration of the New Year is usually here today and gone tomorrow, except in Scotland, where the joys of the season and the pleasures of the flask linger a full two days. Scots allow Jan. 2 as well as Jan. 1 for a double measure of oblivion, and count their blessings twice over. Not till Jan.

LEAD: A system of no-bid contracts for emergency towing on limited-access highways in New York City has been allowed to remain in place despite a New York City Comptroller's audit in 1981 that showed it had engendered widespread fraud, a Bronx grand jury asserted yesterday.

LEAD: Dick Schultz, the executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, said today that he felt relief when a Federal judge in Washington denied a request by Howard University to delay the start of the Division I-AA playoffs.
LEAD: A laundry owner who offered to clean used coats and distribute them to the poor said Friday he was overwhelmed by the response.

LEAD: THE REAGAN ADMINIS-tration's tolerant attitude toward increasing size and concentration in American business finds considerable favor with a select group of business people. They generally approve of the recent wave of corporate mergers, and the Government's less-than-aggressive enforcement of antitrust laws.

LEAD: LATE IN THE FALL OF 1973, A 6-FOOT, 4-INCH BRITON named Gordon White marched into the Pierre hotel in Manhattan, took over a one-bedroom suite on the 37th floor and set about building an empire.

LEAD: The hostages spent months chained to a wall, told to keep silent in the solitude of their dark, windowless rooms. They were treated, one of them said, ''like an animal, like a dog,'' often not able to get a drink, to wash, to go to the bathroom. They saw only masked gunmen.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: I read with astonishment that Senator Dole whispered to me, during a House-Senate conference, that I should ignore his pronouncements on austerity and press for expansion of Medicaid coverage of prenatal care. No such conversation took place.
LEAD: THE HEALTH OF NATIONS True Causes of Sickness and Well-Being. By Leonard A. Sagan. 233 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.
LEAD: FOR more than a century, this city's mill complex, perched downtown on the Squamscott River, churned out millions of yards of cotton fabric and formed the backbone of the local economy.

LEAD: THE CENTRAL FIGURE OF ''Repentance'' is Varlam the dictator - the mayor of a Georgian city who looks vaguely like Mussolini but also has some of Hitler's madness and Stalin's cunning and something, too, of the Georgians' own Lavrenti P. Beria, Stalin's murderous secret police chief with his glittering pince-nez.

LEAD: Crossroads Africa Dec. 2 - Since its founding in 1957, Operation Crossroads Africa has sent more than 8,000 young Americans to rural African and Caribbean communities to work on development projects in medicine, agriculture, education and construction. And over the past 23 years, more than 3,200 young African political leaders and professionals have visited schools and other institutions in the United States.

LEAD: THE rout on Wall Street has reversed last summer's bond slump. ''We think it's win-win for bonds now,'' said Robert J. Barbera, senior vice president and chief economist for E. F. Hutton & Company.

LEAD: THE TWILIGHT OF THE PRESIDENCY: From Johnson to Reagan. By George E. Reedy. (NAL, $17.95.) When George E. Reedy, who had been President Johnson's longtime press secretary and special assistant, first published this book in 1970, it was fairly hailed as a distinguished and thoughtful - and sometimes frightening - essay on government.

LEAD: James T. McShane, a former F.B.I. agent who helped in the Federal investigations into the conduct of Hamilton Jordan, the former Presidential aide, and Raymond J. Donovan, the former Secretary of Labor, died Friday at the Hospital of Saint Raphael in New Haven after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived in Madison,

LEAD: ALL that afternoon, as I followed Robert Pucciariello through the labyrinthine aisles of his Book Emporium in Sea Cliff, I was reminded of my son Frederick the Younger. Fred does not sell books. He is a cabinetmaker and master carpenter; he works with his hands and his head. But so does Mr. Pucciariello.

LEAD: I HAD just finished interviewing Henry Roth, the author of ''Call It Sleep,'' when as if by some dramatic design, a large, flat package was delivered to his New York hotel room. It was an advance copy of Mr. Roth's first book in 53 years, ''Shifting Landscape,'' a complete collection of his shorter writings along with many excerpts from letters and interviews, lovingly assembled by his gifted Italian translator, Mario

LEAD: In his Oct. 18 Opinion Page article, ''Bad Advice About the Problems of Radon,'' Prof. Leonard A. Cole [ of Rutgers-Newark ] criticized the state's Department of Environmental Protection for its adoption of the 4-picocurie/liter of air standard for radon remediation.

LEAD: The grave site, complete with a number of family members and a little of the history of New York City, stands in disrepair squarely in the middle of Van Cortlandt Park. The iron fences are collapsing, the monuments are badly twisted, the name Van Cortlandt is barely legible amid the weeds.
LEAD: Maria Stieglitz suggests painting our old houses in bright San Francisco colors [ ''Why Victorian Drab? Try Tangerine Gables!'' Opinion Page, Nov. 1 ] . It might be a good idea.
LEAD: THE THIRTIETH YEAR By Ingeborg Bachmann. Translated by Michael Bullock. 181 pp. New York: Holmes & Meier. $19.95.

LEAD: ''KORCHNOI is the only grandmaster in the world from whom I can still learn a lot, especially about the middle game,'' said the Dutch grandmaster Jan Timman after the Interpolis International Tournament in Tilburg, the Netherlands.

LEAD: The Gospel According to Al Green Produced and directed by Robert Mugge. 1984. Magnum Entertainment 94 minutes. $29.95. From the opening ballad (''I Love You With All My Heart'') to the rafter-raising sermon and gospel hymn (''The Lord Will Make a Way Somehow''), Al Green carries this marvelous film along with his voice and his smile.

LEAD: MUCH WAS EXPECTED OF the Louis XIV state bedchamber that has just been inaugurated, together with its adjoining entrance gallery, at the Metropolitan Museum. Thanks to Pierpont Morgan, Louis Untermeyer and other collectors of an earlier generation, the Met had some majestic Louis XIV pieces. For years, Mr.

LEAD: Eight reactors that helped put the punch in the United States arsenal of nuclear weapons sit silent along the Columbia River today as Federal officials ponder a report that suggests what could be done with them.

LEAD: WHEN KEVIN ROCHE'S 1 United Nations Plaza, the hotel and office tower at the corner of First Avenue and 44th Street, was finished in 1976, the most notable thing about it was the extent to which the tower's shimmering glass-and-metal form broke rank with everything around it. The building is an exquisite minimalist sculpture; its abstract form has nothing to do with any of the buildings near it, except for the allusions its blue-green glass makes to the United Nations Secretariat building across First Avenue.
LEAD: FOR many of Wilton's town employees, it's a nice place to serve, but they can't afford to live there.

LEAD: An Air Force Titan 34D, the nation's most powerful unmanned rocket, roared into space tonight with a secret military satellite that a civilian expert said would provide instant warning of an enemy missile attack on the United States.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Bona of Boonton Township, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Dawn Elaine Bona to Robert A. Rizzo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Amedeo A. Rizzo of Broomall, Pa.

LEAD: IF the thought of job security was ever far from the mind of Jimmy Johnson, the University of Miami head football coach, it was brought back with a shiver last week with the news out of Columbus, Ohio.
LEAD: THE FIREBRAND By Marion Zimmer Bradley. 608 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

LEAD: A bipartisan group of legislators, fearful of the consequences of mounting economic problems on the fragile democracy of the Philippines, called on President Reagan today to put together the equivalent of a Marshall Plan to channel $1 billion more a year to that country over the next five years.

LEAD: Gift Mart at Temple Features 35 Vendors The Larchmont Temple Gift Mart is next weekend - opening Saturday at 7 P.M. and closing at 10 P.M. and reopening next Sunday, when the hours are 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. The price range is $5 to $600, and 35 vendors are participating this year. Gift certificates are available.
LEAD: Winter will bring another season of anxiety to those who live within breathing distance of a chemical plant that has drawn wide attention.

LEAD: RINGER. By Marshall Terry. (Corona/ Texas Monthly, $16.95.) ''Ringer'' is a self-conscious retelling of the biblical story of the prodigal son, with characters who never rise from their flat landscape. An elderly widow, Eliza MacDuff Ringer, has been transplanted from a small Texas town to an apartment in Dallas so she can be close to her one responsible son, Bill.

LEAD: STEAL THIS URINE TEST: Fighting Drug Hysteria in America. By Abbie Hoffman with Jonathan Silvers. (Penguin, Paper, $5.95.) Drug abuse is a serious national problem, but part of that problem is public and governmental misunderstanding and over-reaction: that is the important theme of ''Steal This Urine Test,'' and it's one that the book documents thoroughly.
LEAD: AS befits the inventor of the most successful noise-reduction system in the recording business, Ray M. Dolby speaks with a soft voice.
LEAD: THE problem of choosing a first course at a small dinner is easily solved by pasta.
LEAD: Vernon Maxwell promised to lead his Florida teammates to a championship if they reached the semifinals of the preseason National Invitation Tournament, and last night, he made good on his word.

LEAD: Despite steps taken by the Turkish Government to stop human rights abuses, violations of citizens' liberties still continue, according to a 1987 report issued last week by the Helsinki Watch Committee.
LEAD: The Women's Professional Billiard Association was pleased with Roger Starr's article on women's pocket billiards and Jean Balukas (''The Best Woman in the Hall,'' Oct. 18).

LEAD: In one Brooklyn neighborhood, what might have been a day of joy for its Haitians yesterday was instead a time of sadness, somber reflection and desperate but largely futile attempts to reach relatives back in Haiti by telephone.

LEAD: There was a moment of silence. Stunned silence. ''I think that's the first time in my life I've heard him shut up,'' Jack Nicklaus said. ''He was speechless. For once, he was at a loss for words.'' But the silence didn't last. Lee Trevino - who watched in something like disbelief today as his 6-iron shot trickled into the cup for a hole-in-one - began bounding about the 17th tee, hopping into the air, waving his cap.

LEAD: A bomb exploded Saturday outside a laboratory where nuclear weapons are designed, blowing out dozens of windows, and a man saying he belonged to a group called the Nuclear Liberation Front today claimed responsibility for the blast.
LEAD: Federated Department Stores Inc. has named John B. Utsey chairman and chief executive of one of its major department store chains, the Houston-based Foley's.

LEAD: THERE is more to the physical-fitness craze than muscle tone and target heart rate. At no other time of year is this more apparent than during the holiday season, a period when life as we know it turns into a frenzied shopping spree. No longer will a necktie do when it could have been a pair of running shoes.
LEAD: ''I always live in the present, and so it seems that my life is always the same and that my age is always the same.''

LEAD: Henry A. Walker Jr. was chief executive officer of Amfac Inc. from 1967 to 1982, a tenure he now calls long enough. But last week, following the abrupt dismissal of Ronald R. Sloan as president and chief executive officer, Mr. Walker resumed those titles and duties in addition to his role as chairman.

LEAD: They will not win an election anytime soon. But in their first week home from exile, El Salvador's two top civilian rebel leaders appear to have already had an impact on political thinking here that outweighs their potential showing at the polls.

LEAD: Jury selection begins Monday for the trial of Nicodemo Scarfo, the reputed head of organized crime in Philadelphia and southern New Jersey, on charges of masterminding a multimillion-dollar drug ring. Selection of the 12 jurors and four alternates is expected to take most of this week. They will be sequestered in a hotel until the trial is over, which the authorities hope will come before Christmas.
LEAD: Choo San Goh, the ballet choreographer and associate artistic director of the Washington Ballet, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 39 years old.
LEAD: The first snow of winter was falling, fat wet flakes in the headlamps of the construction trucks. The distant cruise missile base, floodlit and overhung with cranes, glowed in the dusk.

LEAD: Haiti's first attempt in 30 years at a presidential election was abruptly called off by election officials today after a frenzy of attacks on voting stations, churches and radio stations in which more than two dozen people were killed.

LEAD: St. John's University survived a scare today to win the 13th annual Joe Lapchick Memorial tournament at Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens. The Redmen, who have never lost a game in the history of the tournament, held off a late rally by Loyola Marymount University to win, 88-85.

LEAD: Six months have passed and Sean Nelson can still hear the gunfire. The 17-year old football player was walking home from his girlfriend's house on a Friday night in May when six shots rang out. One of the bullets hit him in the back. By the time he was taken to a hospital, Nelson realized he was lucky to be alive, but he had another dread - that he would never play football again.

LEAD: * Chicago Milwaukee Corp., Chicago, said it had extended its self-tender offer and withdrawal rights for any and all of its outstanding $5 prior preferred stock at $55 a share until midnight Tuesday.
LEAD: IN a market grown increasingly hostile toward the stocks of giant aerospace companies, the General Dynamics Corporation and the Boeing Company are selling at their lowest prices in three years.

LEAD: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said yesterday that he had been asked to consider running as a favorite-son candidate in the New York Democratic primary in April. If he decides to do run, he said, it would be to help keep the 1988 Democratic Presidential race open until the convention in July.

LEAD: The New York City Human Resources Administration has become mired in bureaucracy and should be broken into smaller, localized units with more accountability, the State Commissioner of Social Services said in a television program aired yesterday.
LEAD: Mary Beth Whitehead, the surrogate mother in the landmark Baby M custody case, has married the father of a child she expects to give birth to in the spring.
LEAD: A 17-month-old girl survived for two to three weeks apparently by eating potato chips and drinking water from a toilet while her parents and infant sister lay dead nearby, the authorities say.

LEAD: Throughout his eight-day ordeal as a hostage, Scott Sutterfield was more afraid of what was happening outside the Federal detention center in Oakdale, La., than he was of what was happening inside.

LEAD: Helped by weather conducive to shopping in New York, California and other places, sales rose considerably from a year earlier during the weekend that traditionally begins the holiday shopping season, some major retail chains reported.

LEAD: While goblins and ghouls roamed this tiny borough over the Halloween weekend, 19-year-old Christopher Fabiani and three friends left a beer-drinking party, piled into a pickup truck and started to cruise the twisting back roads.
LEAD: * John Kelleter has joined Caravetta Allen Kimbrough, Miami, part of the Omnicom Group, as senior vice president, director of marketing.
LEAD: Were it not for his red ties, Henry S. Kanegsberg could easily disappear in a crowd. Even his employer, the National Broadcasting Company, describes him as ''a wallflower.''

LEAD: From Bob Froese's vantage point, all that could be seen were raised sticks, sticks pointing his way, usually a menacing sign at Madison Square Garden but in this case an indication that he had just made hockey history.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A few years ago, Harold Ballard, owner of the Toronto Maple Leafs, outraged many Canadians when he passed the word that a female reporter would be welcome in the team's locker room if she joined the hockey players in removing her clothes. Nobody could be sure that the 84-year-old Ballard, who has made a career of cantankerousness, was joking.

LEAD: The stock market may still be down in the dumps, but those who expected a downturn in business activity so far have been proved wrong. According to the National Association of Purchasing Management, the economy continued to grow in November, but at a slightly slower pace than was reported the previous month.

LEAD: FROM the moment Judy Collins stepped onto the stage of Carnegie Hall Friday evening and opened with an a cappella rendition of ''Amazing Grace,'' it was apparent that the singer's 25th anniversary concert in New York would be markedly different in tone from her annual post-Thanksgiving concerts.

LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Farm Prices... Oct. Tuesday Construction Spending... Oct. Leading Indicators... Oct. Wednesday New-Home Sales... Oct. Thursday Factory Orders...
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Bruce Murray of Clemson, proving he possesses the characteristics of an efficient striker, found the right time to get free inside the opposing penalty area as the Tigers scored a 3-2 victory today that eliminated Rutgers from the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament.

LEAD: Most European officials want Washington to stablize the dollar and Bonn to keep stimulating its economy whether or not those things happen within the framework of a formal meeting of the world's industrial leaders. Japan, for the moment, seems to be off the hook.

LEAD: A system of no-bid contracts for emergency towing on limited-access allowed to continue despite a 1981 City Comptroller's audit that showed it had engendered widespread fraud, a Bronx grand jury has asserted.

LEAD: Clyde Drexler and Steve Johnson scored 28 points each tonight, leading the Portland Trail Blazers to their fifth consecutive victory, a 125-104 decision over the Nets. It was the fifth straight loss for New Jersey.

LEAD: H. R. Haldeman shrugged. ''To this day I still don't know why that was done,'' Richard M. Nixon's former chief of staff told a questioner at Hofstra University the other day. ''And I don't know anybody who does. Why they would hit the National Headquarters is beyond me, because nobody in that place knows anything anyway.
LEAD: Last Call
LEAD: TREMONT: The driver of a gypsy cab was shot and killed in the Bronx Saturday night in an apparent robbery attempt, the police said.
LEAD: The sun, small and red as a copper penny on a hot stove lid, rose this morning over a gently sloping hillside where a giant American farm breakfast was spread.

LEAD: Babe Herman, the popular Brooklyn Dodger star of the 1920's and early 1930's, died Friday at the age of 84. Mr. Herman died of complications from pneumonia and a series of strokes, his son, Charles Robert Herman of Miami, Fla., said.

LEAD: STEPHEN PAULUS, the young American composer, wrote ''So Hallow'd Is the Time'' for the Greenwich Choral Society eight years ago. The Connecticut singers - by the look and sound of them, a group of about 100 amateurs - brought this music to the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Saturday night. It is described as a Christmas cantata.
LEAD: Before last month's stock market plunge, Spain's economy was zipping along in Europe's fast lane.

LEAD: This week's calendar of new debt issues is relatively light and headed by today's regular weekly Treasury auctions of new three- and six-month bills. While the slate of new corporate and tax-exempt issues appears light, underwriters said that if market conditions improve and interest rates decline, issuers might bring existing shelf-registered issues to market.

LEAD: Here is the text of the agreement signed today, ending the eight-day uprising at the Federal Detention Center here. The agreement was typed on the stationery of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d. Upon the release of all remaining officers being held on the compound at F.D.C. Oakdale, the following agreement will immediately be enforced.

LEAD: Lee Rich believes in MGM/UA, even if many of his own employees are skeptical.

LEAD: John J. Murphy, president, chief executive and chairman of Dresser Industries, has underscored his company's focus on the energy industry with the announcement that Dresser plans to acquire the N. W. Kellogg Company.

LEAD: State Department officials who are facing a possible cutback of $60 million and the possible loss of some 1,200 jobs in a budget-cutting effort were annoyed to discover a slow but sizable leak of money over the years in a corner of the room used by correspondents who cover the department.

LEAD: Search teams pulled five bodies from the Indian Ocean today in the area where a South African Airways jet crashed with 159 people aboard.

LEAD: Two Connecticut men, a groom and his best man, were killed early today along with the bride and eight other people when a fire erupted toward the end of their wedding party in a luxury hotel on the resort island of Margarita.
LEAD: The New Orlean Saints assured themselves of the first winning season in their 21-year-history today, beating the Pittsburgh Steelers, 20-16.

LEAD: Most of the people who worship at St. Luke's Church in the South Bronx have very little money to spare. But yesterday, as they filed out after the service, they were asked to give to a group that is even poorer than they are - the homeless.

LEAD: Sidney Flax was wounded in a dive bombing attack while serving with the U.S. Army in Naples in World War II. He recovered, returned home, married, raised a family and worked in a bank until he suffered a stroke two years ago. His right arm and side are paralyzed; his right leg had to be amputated.

LEAD: Well, why not?

LEAD: Labor negotiations in two industries - milk distribution and private refuse carting - were scheduled today in an effort to avert strikes tonight that would halt the delivery of milk and the collection of all commercial garbage in New York City and many suburban areas.

LEAD: HAD there been snow for tracking, had the deer that walked past my son, Steve, been a buck instead of a doe, had the season on black bear not been closed, had moose been legal game, the six of us who recently journeyed to the northeastern tip of New Hampshire for two and one-half days of hunting could have come back with more than a box of leftover groceries.

LEAD: Floyd Smith, a railroad clerk with the New York Transit Authority and a sergeant in the Marine Corps Reserve, did not take kindly to a joke that Alexander M. Haig Jr. made about on the campaign trail recently at the Marines' expense.
LEAD: SOUTH JAMAICA: Two men working in a Queens grocery store were injured Saturday night when an incendiary device exploded in the shop, the police said.
LEAD: When the stock market collapsed last month, Vadim Krys's portfolio declined by about 30 percent from a high of $14,000.

LEAD: Until this year no foreign player had ever won a major American team title, but that barrier was broken four months ago at the American Contract Bridge League's summer nationals in Baltimore. And the successful player, Jaggy Shivdasani of Bombay, India, was on track to repeat the success when the final day's play began at the fall nationals here today.

LEAD: Orders for American-made machine tools surged 46.2 percent in October from the previous month, to $267.3 million, according to a report scheduled to be released today by the industry's trade association.
LEAD: * Long Island Rail Road to Christopher Thomas Associates, Garden City, L.I.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Donald Hodel, the Secretary of the Interior, and Ross Swimmer, the Assistant Secretary for Indian Affairs, touch a responsive chord when they call for a new relationship between the Government and Native Americans that is based on Indian ''self-determination.'' Such a relationship is a desirable goal, but also a distant one.
LEAD: The dollar fell to a record low today on the Tokyo foreign exchange market. Stock prices also declined.

LEAD: A month after the Senate's defeat of Judge Robert H. Bork, life has yet to return to normal for many of the conservative Southern Democrats who voted against President Reagan's Supreme Court nominee.

LEAD: On Dec. 30 CCA Industries of East Rutherford, N.J. - already the national marketer of such brands as Nutra Nail, Pro Perm and Hair Off -will go onto two of the three commercial television networks to advertise Eat 'n Lose, another contribution to a diet-conscious nation.

LEAD: At the northern end of Central Park, where the landscape is rocky and wild, Charles Heuer and his daughter glided freely across the Lasker Memorial Skating Rink yesterday afternoon, sharing the ice with a dozen neighborhood cognoscente.

LEAD: Martha C. Kurshan, an associate at the New York law firm of Shea & Gould, and Carl Stine, a second-year student at the Fordham University School of Law, were married yesterday at the bride's home in Manhattan. Rabbi Jacob Reiner officiated.
LEAD: The last time Columbia won an Ivy League basketball championship was in the 1967-68 season. Since then, Penn and Princeton have dominated the league, while Columbia's fortunes have sagged.

LEAD: Despite a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign appealing both to national pride and to private gain, British private investors have apparently shown only limited interest in the shares of Eurotunnel, the British-French consortium that plans to build a tunnel beneath the English Channel.

LEAD: It's been three decades since the Dodgers decamped for Los Angeles, and since then, it seems, Brooklyn's beloved Bums have become more beloved than they ever could have been when they were breaking the borough's heart with depressing regularity.

LEAD: Candles were burning Saturday evening in Zion Evangelical Church, and bunches of flowers were tied to a metal fence outside. Young men and women were holding a protest vigil, while uniformed policemen patrolled outside and secret policemen mingled with the onlookers.

LEAD: In what negotiators interpreted as a good-faith gesture, Cuban inmates controlling the Federal penitentiary here released four hostages early today. The action surprised Federal officials and led them to hope for a break in negotiations.
LEAD: When a veteran railroad worker was hit by a locomotive while trying to stop a runaway car, his death prompted not only a Federal investigation but also a strike over safety issues.

LEAD: After 15 years of decline, the profitability of American business - measured as a return on investments - is rising again, and the future health of the economy is riding on whether the turnaround can be sustained.

LEAD: PETER H. ENGEL's American Consulting Corporation announced a small acquisition last week. It's only the beginning. The former Procter & Gamble, Philip Morris and Colgate-Palmolive marketing executive has had big growth plans for his eight-year-old company, especially since it went public last August.

LEAD: THE revival of ''Alexander's Feast'' at the 92d Street Y Saturday evening afforded a welcome opportunity to hear one of Handel's freshest and most inventive works, and so was a welcome event even if the performance did not quite take wing in the way one had hoped.
