LEAD: The presidents of eight Latin American countries ended a four-day conference today by calling for a sweeping overhaul of the Organization of American States and demanding a ceiling on repayment of their foreign debt.
LEAD: From their grim expressions and animated, sometimes caustic, reactions to critical lapses and controversial line calls, one might have thought Ivan Lendl and Pat Cash were playing in the past.
LEAD: Joe Montana threw four touchdown passes, three to Jerry Rice and one to Dwight Clark, as the San Francisco 49ers cruised to a 38-24 victory over the Cleveland Browns tonight.

LEAD: A man was killed yesterday morning in an apparent robbery attempt at his grocery store in the Bronx, the police said. The man, who was identified as Hector Borrayo, 38 years old, of 5360 Broadway in Manhattan, was shot once in the head around 8:30 A.M. at the Metro-One-Superette at 2070 Clinton Avenue in the Tremont section of the Bronx, said Sgt.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: FOR the Giants, it was an opportunity to defend their honor as Super Bowl champions. In this strike-snarled National Football League season, the Giants were all but out of the playoffs. But if they could win, they would remind the Redskins and themselves of what might have been had there been no strike.
LEAD: Jim Carson's power-play goal just 40 seconds into the third period earned the Los Angeles Kings a 2-2 tie with the Devils tonight.
LEAD: FATHERS AND CHILDREN. By C. L. Sulzberger. 304 pages. Arbor House. $19.95.

LEAD: Many of the Cuban inmates in the Federal penitentiary here are unsophisticated rural people who have been hardened by years in prisons for infractions as minor as disagreeing with the Government of Fidel Castro while in Cuba or failing to pay traffic tickets in the United States, according to those who know them.
LEAD: For the first time in seven years, Turks voted today in national elections free of military supervision, a poll depicted as reinforcing the revival of democracy.

LEAD: France allowed an Iranian sought for questioning in terrorist bombings to leave the country today, a step in restoring relations between Paris and Teheran after their bassies and diplomats have been under police siege for nearly six months.

LEAD: THE New York Youth Symphony began its Carnegie Hall concert Sunday afternoon with ''American Slick,'' a work by the young composer William Doerrfeld, who said in a program note that he ''set out with one thing in mind . . . to make the orchestra boogie.'' That he does, in loud-louder-loudest terms that leave this observer inclined to wait and hear what other arrows Mr.

LEAD: At Congregation Kehilath Jeshuran in New York, Marla Frances Wald, the daughter of Eve Wald of New York and the late Dr. Philip M. Wald, was married yesterday to Dr. Oren J. Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Cohen of Washington. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein officiated.

LEAD: THE thoughtfulness of Carol Vaness's recital at Alice Tully Hall yesterday afternoon began with her choice of music. There were such tender little Rossini masterpieces as ''La Promessa'' and ''L'Invito''; then four Strauss lieder of solid substance followed by three elegant desserts by Tosti. Nowhere in French song is despair so eloquent or nostalgia so touching as in Chausson's ''Temps des Lilas'' and ''Colibri.
LEAD: The death of Harold Washington has ushered in the next chapter in the evolution of urban black political power, what the late Mayor called simply, ''The Movement.''
LEAD: South Korean Jet Vanishes
LEAD: Americans, reassured by the financial markets' steadier performance during November, have not changed their minds about the economy, according to a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll.
LEAD: Jascha Heifetz, the violinist, has been at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center here for several weeks with an undisclosed illness, a hospital spokesman said.

LEAD: IT was good to be in Leimen, West Germany, Boris Becker said, where he could sample his mother's cooking and spend time with friends he rarely sees. The past three years have been like a trip to Oz, as Becker was swept off his feet in a whirlwind of events that were often beyond his control. Clicking his heels, returning home on occasion, gives him a chance to catch his breath and reflect on a relatively brief but tumultuous tennis career.

LEAD: Nikolai I. Bukharin's widow has asked Mikhail S. Gorbachev for the political rehabilitation of her husband, who was executed in 1938 after he was ousted from the Kremlin hierarchy by Stalin, a journal appearing today reported.

LEAD: Skiing Tomba Wins Again: Alberto Tomba of Italy won his second consecutive World Cup ski race in three days yesterday with a victory in the giant slalom at Sestriere, Italy. Tomba, 20 years old, won the special slalom Friday.
LEAD: It has been a hard several years for Mozambique, the southern African nation beset by drought, famine, a tattered economy and a persistent insurgent movement.

LEAD: The president of the New York City Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr., called yesterday on the Governor and the State Legislature to enact legislation that would ''provide a context for sweeping reform of the city's school system.''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Invoking Islam, but interrupted by Islamic guerrilla rockets, Afghanistan's Communist leader, Najibullah, introduced a new constitution today in an effort to legitimize his shaky Soviet-backed regime.

LEAD: One of the first gifts to the 76th appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which formally opened yesterday, came from Lisa Sheiman of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

LEAD: * Aaron Rents Inc., Atlanta, a renter and seller of furniture, named M. Lee Hulsebus president and chief operating officer, succeeding R. Charles Loudermilk Sr., who has been elected a director and continues as chairman and chief executive.
LEAD: An avalanche roared into an Andean valley near Santiago today, burying a workers' camp and a picnic area. The Government television said up to 60 people were missing and feared dead.
LEAD: THE steady trend of law firms growing larger appears to have stalled, as partnerships have recently experienced a series of dissolutions and collapsed deals.

LEAD: The Media-Advertising Partnership for a Drug-Free America, advertising's biggest voluntary effort since the bond drives of World War II, has announced thet Lynn C. Mapes, recently retired Reader's Digest executive, has joined the organization as a volunteer to serve in the important job of media director.
LEAD: A South Korean airliner with 115 people on board disappeared as it flew near Burma from the Middle East Sunday.

LEAD: Co-op City, the huge, integrated apartment complex in the northeast Bronx, is about to begin a marketing campaign - even though it has a waiting list of several months for an apartment. The objective is to persuade more white people to live there.
LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY
LEAD: As if it wasn't enough that Mikhail S. Gorbachev has elbowed past Ronald Reagan in popularity polls, his glasnost is now crowding America off the T-shirts.

LEAD: As the South Shore football coach, Marty Senall, prepares his team for Saturday's Public Schools Athletic League Division A championship game against John Adams, a couple of big questions remain. How's Arthur Davis? And how's Marc Senall?
LEAD: ''There is a consensus on two things. One is that the debt has to be paid, and the other is that the debt cannot be paid.''

LEAD: One of my first Gulag cell mates was a professional swindler. After a career of enterprising scams, Leonid had exhausted his opportunities for ''work'' in the Soviet Union. As he served his sentence, he was studying English with the hope of living in the United States.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that work on the final language of the treaty on medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles has been ''going on in a good way, and there isn't any particular problem about that I know of.''

LEAD: The Moscow Ballet closed its two-month American debut tour tonight with a first-rate performance at the War Memorial Auditorium here. Founded in 1979 as a local touring ensemble by Irina Tikhomirnova, a former Bolshoi ballerina, the Soviet company is now directed by Vyacheslav Gordeyev, a leading dancer with the Bolshoi.

LEAD: An Air Force Titan 34D, the nation's most powerful unmanned rocket, roared into space Saturday night with a secret military satellite that a civilian expert said would provide instant warning of an enemy missile attack on the United States.

LEAD: A New York City police detective who is a security officer for Governor Cuomo has defended actions he took in the first hours of an investigation of the robbery and assault of the Governor's father-in-law, Charles Raffa, three years ago.
LEAD: The bond market is expected to come under renewed downward pressure this week, largely because of the weakening dollar and soaring prices of basic commodities and precious metals.

LEAD: Auxiliary Bishop Agustin A. Roman, who was flown to Oakdale, La., this weekend to make a videotaped appeal to Cuban inmates holding 26 hostages at a Federal detention center, is a man who has never forgotten his humble roots, according to those who know him well.

LEAD: Deborah L. Kozupsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Kozupsky of Spring Valley, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark D. Lazarus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Lazarus of Rye Brook, N.Y. Cantor David Rosenswieg officiated at Le Chateau in South Salem, N.Y.

LEAD: About 100 Haitians lined up to vote at a small school near the downtown area of the capital this morning, and, according to witnesses, were set upon by a mob of 50 to 100 men believed to be remnants of the Tontons Macoute, the old bodyguard of the deposed dictator, Jean-Claude Duvalier.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The marriage of Barbara Anne Perry to Dr. Jean-Marie Bind took place yesterday at Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn. Cantor Mark Lipson officiated.

LEAD: Senior executives of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., like those at other major Wall Street firms, often engage in spirited debates about strategy. Recently, Drexel's officials have been arguing about an issue generally not considered to be controversial: its image advertising.

LEAD: While outnumbered by Soviet forces, NATO has sufficent conventional strength to make a Soviet attack highly unlikely, according to a classified ''net assessment'' of opposing strengths and weaknesses prepared by the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
LEAD: A controversial proposal to tax vegetable oils and fats, which is opposed by Europe's trading partners, will be submitted to the European Community summit meeting this week.

LEAD: AMONG the hardiest of perennials, ''The Secret Garden'' is back - tonight at 9 on Channel 2 - with its story of a bratty little orphan girl who undergoes magical transformation in a gloomy Yorkshire manor called Misselthwaite. Published in 1911, the story was written by Frances Hodgson Burnett, an amateur gardener who specialized in minor literary classics, including ''Little Lord Fauntleroy.
LEAD: Buffalo limited Miami to 229 yards - just 23 on the ground - and stopped Dan Marino's streak of 30 straight games with at least one touchdown pass as the Bills beat the Dolphins today, 27-0.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. called Local 1199 of the hospital workers' union ''the conscience of the labor movement.''

LEAD: In the worst outbreak of violence yet in this country's presidential campaign, the ruling party candidate, Roh Tae Woo, dodged rocks, sticks and tear gas canisters today as he faced crowds aflame with bitter memories of the harsh Government suppression of a 1980 uprising here.

LEAD: Present tests for the AIDS virus antibody are highly accurate. Yet if applied to the population at large, they could falsely brand nine people infected for every true case identified. The President's AIDS commission had better be sure it understands this treacherous paradox if it intends to recommend the widespread testing favored by some

LEAD: When Samuel Nansi needed $35,000 to open his Joie de Vivre Bar here, he did not bother with banks. Instead he turned to the tontines, an informal credit system rooted in African tradition. Without signing a paper or filling out a form, Mr. Nansi emerged from his monthly tontine meeting with $35,000 in cash.

LEAD: The conviction of Robert Melias on a rape charge in a Bristol court two weeks ago appeared routine, except that vital evidence came from a technique called ''genetic fingerprinting,'' which is acclaimed as the biggest advance in the science of crime detection in a century.

LEAD: Poland's Communist Government appeared ready today to announce that the public had approved a program of severe economic belt-tightening, after the nation's first referendum in more than 40 years.

LEAD: All Democratic Presidential candidates, in varying degree, are supporting the arms control treaty Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev are about to sign. All Republican candidates except Vice President Bush are opposing the treaty, or reserving judgment.

LEAD: United States factory sales of electronic equipment, components and related products during the first nine months of the year increased 6.7 percent over the corresponding period last year, an industry association said Friday. Sales for the 1987 period totaled $165.5 billion, compared with last year's nine-month record sales of $155.2 billion, according to figures released this week by the Electronic Industries Association here.
LEAD: Cuban inmates today released 26 hostages they had held for eight days in the Federal detention center here.
LEAD: Among the arresting sights in ''Into the Woods,'' the fairy-tale musical by Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine, is the wolf's eerie grin as he pursues Little Red Ridinghood.

LEAD: The smaller scheme is generating the larger debate as the New York City Planning Commission reviews proposals for a 36-story tower on the East River and a pair of 46-foot-high shafts on the Hudson.
LEAD: An influential conservative group is issuing a major new manifesto this week that chastises some in the movement as lacking compassion toward the needy.

LEAD: The competition to buy E. F. Hutton & Company, which continued through the weekend, is being complicated by the amount of capital the brokerage house has tied up in its new Manhattan headquarters building, according to several Wall Street professionals close to the bidding.
LEAD: QUESTION: After his first five years in the major leagues, how does Darryl Strawberry compare with Mickey Mantle and Willie Mays regarding home runs and runs batted in?

LEAD: Texas and Tulane are included and Colorado and Wake Forest are excluded. With the last options for college football's bowl games closed over the weekend, the 18-match lineup has the usual mix of deserving and undeserving teams.
LEAD: Clarence E. Unterberg, an investment banker, died Saturday at his home in Tinton Falls, N.J. He was 86 years old.

LEAD: PHIL ESPOSITO, a man who admits he is in a hurry but contends he does not feel rushed, has found himself under the burden of a skewed timetable ever since he assumed control of the Rangers last year in midsummer.
LEAD: BRONX: Two subway work trains collided yesterday in the Bronx during a test of their propulsion systems.
LEAD: The United States announced tonight that it had suspended virtually all military assistance and some economic aid to Haiti after violence there caused the cancellation of elections.

LEAD: Robert Hunter School is ''bursting at the seams,'' said James Gamble, its principal. In six years, enrollment has grown to 631 from 485, and when more children come next year there will be no room to add classes. Some teachers will have as many as 30 pupils.
LEAD: THE New York City Ballet presented audiences with a generous sampling of varied works from its repertory at weekend performances at the New York State Theater.

LEAD: William McKechnie, right, the head of the Transit Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, speaking at the union's office at 299 Broadway. With him was Barry W. Agulnick, counsel to the union. Mr. McKechnie called on Charles J. Hynes, the special prosecutor, to investigate charges that some transit police officers made false or improper arrests.

LEAD: At the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., Shari Rita Schonfeld, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Schonfeld of Brooklyn, and David Gary Cherna, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Cherna of Livingston, N.J., were married yesterday. Rabbi Dr. Manfred Fulda officiated.

LEAD: A United Airlines Boeing 767 carrying 116 people went into a dive to avoid a collision with a small plane, passing within 100 feet of the smaller craft, according to a report received by the Federal Aviation Administration.

LEAD: The United States has developed a new negotiating approach on conventional arms that would require Soviet-bloc nations to reduce the number of their tanks and artillery pieces to levels of that of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization - a cut of more than 50 percent.

LEAD: The guest list for the official Soviet delegation to the summit is not yet final, but one person the Russians will send is Anatoly F. Dobrynin, according to an official at the State Department.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders met today for the first time in four months and agreed to try to avoid convening a special session of the Legislature this year. LEAD: President Reagan outlined hard-line bargaining positions today on a broad range of issues that he and Mikhail S. Gorbachev will discuss during their summit conference next week, as he and other senior officials tried to play down expectations of what the talks might produce.

LEAD: Dick Crum resigned yesterday as football coach at the University of North Carolina, which finished this season with a 5-6 record. A statement was released jointly by Crum, Chancellor Christopher Fordham and Athletic Director John Swofford.

LEAD: The Gallup Poll reveals that twice as many Americans have a ''favorable opinion'' of Mikhail Gorbachev as have an unfavorable view of him. That is a stunning tribute to the skill of Soviet propaganda and dismaying evidence of the power of American wishful thinking.

LEAD: Clint Hurdle, one of the most highly rated rookies in baseball 10 years ago, ended his career as a player yesterday and began a new one as a manager in the Mets' farm system.

LEAD: After Bo Jackson's team-record rushing performance and three touchdowns led the Los Angeles Raiders to a 37-14 victory over the Seattle Seahawks Monday night, the running back said that he had not given any thought to giving up his baseball career with the Kansas City Royals.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IF I were to catalogue the foods that best lend themselves to hasty cooking or cooking within 60 minutes, scallops - whether sea scallops or bay scallops - would rank high. If they are overcooked, however, they tend to dry out or become chewy. In prolonged cooking, they also tend to lose their moist succulence and even their sweetness.

LEAD: For Darryl Dawkins, the last two months have been harrowing. LEAD: When Lou Wacker arrived at Emory & Henry College in 1982 to coach the football team, he said his goal was a national championship for the Division III school. The statement sounded foolhardy, considering that the school's reputation had been made in the classroom, not on the field. Before Wacker arrived at Emory & Henry, the Wasps had had just one winning season in the previous 13.
LEAD: The chairman of a State Senate committee apologized today to Governor Cuomo, condemning ''false rumors'' that he said had been spread about Mr. Cuomo by a top staff member of the committee.
LEAD: Construction spending fell five-tenths of 1 percent in October, the first decline since March, the Commerce Department reported today.
LEAD: BASEBALL

LEAD: I HATE parent-teacher conferences. I love the teacher. I love the school. I even kind of love the little chairs you have to sit in, that set your knees to knocking against your sternum. I always bring a bribe: a bagel with butter and a cup of coffee. It's unnecessary. My elder child is the kind of kid about whom the teacher says everything you've waited all your life to hear: imaginative, generous, social, the proverbial ''pleasure to have in class.

LEAD: Jules Haimovitz, one of a group of managers who attempted a leveraged buyout of Viacom International Inc., yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of Aaron Spelling Productions Inc. in Los Angeles.

LEAD: It's back to the bench for Doug Williams, the Washington Redskins quarterback, and he's a bit miffed about it. Williams was the starter until he missed Sunday's game against the Giants due to a back injury. The job now belongs to Jay Schroeder, who rallied Washington from 16 points behind to a 23-19 victory.

LEAD: WHILE other market seers were too stunned to make predictions after stocks collapsed in late October, Barton Biggs shamelessly forecast a rally of at least 400 points for the Dow industrial average. He followed that up with bullish comments in Barron's in November that the imminent rally could take the
LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

LEAD: Chicago's City Council, in an emotional special session in chambers surrounded by chanting protesters, appeared late Tuesday night about to elect Eugene Sawyer, a black Alderman, as Acting Mayor. However, opposition to his selection set off a round of wrangling that continued into the early morning hours today.

LEAD: The 11-week-old labor dispute between the Detroit Symphony Orchestra and its musicians worsened today as negotiations for a new contract broke down and the symphony canceled its Christmas concerts.
LEAD: Stephen Zoll, an architecture writer and editor, died Nov. 24 of injuries suffered in an automobile accident near Cambridge, England. He was 55 years old.

LEAD: Proceeds from the 1988 United States Women's Open golf tournament will be donated to the Maryland Special Olympics, Ricki Baker, the tournament's executive director, said today at a news conference at the Baltimore Country Club, which will be the site of the event July 18-24.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Bill Parcells has told his Giants that despite rumors to the contrary, he will return next year as coach. He said the same thing during his weekly radio show for WNEW-AM.
LEAD: This fall the relentless pounding of the ocean had so badly eroded parts of Gilgo Beach that waves broke within 20 feet of the Ocean Parkway.
LEAD: A Galveston insurance heir was convicted today of defrauding his family's charitable foundation of nearly $1.5 million and faces up to 85 years in prison.
LEAD: Dominique Wilkins scored 22 points and Tree Rollins added 20 tonight to offset a 22-point season debut by Boston's Kevin McHale and lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 120-106 victory over the Celtics.

LEAD: If a former close aide to the rightist Salvadoran political leader Roberto d'Aubuisson ever comes to trial, a key piece of evidence could be a notebook that appears to show the inner workings of rightist death squads, according to American and Salvadoran officials.

LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has delayed approval of new stock-index futures contracts until it can complete its investigation into the Oct. 19 market collapse, commission officials said today.
LEAD: The Nordic Investment Bank is offering $200 million of 9 1/2 percent notes, due in 1994, at a price of 99.80 to yield about 9.54 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

LEAD: Jerome Robbins, absent from Broadway since 1964, plans to return next fall with a retrospective of his theater choreography that would include dances from the period between ''On the Town,'' in 1944, and ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' which opened two decades later and was his last work for the commercial stage.

LEAD: A masked man walked into the Upper East Side office of a Manhattan gynecologist yesterday afternoon, stabbed the doctor and his wife, who works as his receptionist, and then fled, the police said.

LEAD: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board today supported the creation of an umbrella agency to more closely coordinate policy among the major Government bodies that regulate financial institutions.

LEAD: The Federal Government has seized five Florida properties worth $20 million as part of a campaign to confiscate investments made with profits from drug trafficking, estimated to exceed $300 million in Florida.

LEAD: Repeated high-level warnings failed to deter Michael K. Deaver from contacting certain former White House associates and venturing broad hints that he could use their help as a private lobbyist, according to testimony today at his perjury trial.

LEAD: THE trouble with hiring a bunch of high-spirited, independent-minded chefs and putting them in the same room is that they may not do exactly what they were hired to do. Since they are unlikely to take a product they are being paid to promote as seriously as the people paying them do, they tend to kid around.

LEAD: Lillias Dulles Hinshaw, a Presbyterian minister and the daughter of the late Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, died after a long illness Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: ''No I don't resent his popu-larity or anything else. Good Lord, I co-starred with Errol Flynn once.'' - President Reagan, on Mikhail S. Gorbachev [ A10:2. ]
LEAD: Toni Taylor, a writer and teacher, died of a stroke Nov. 22 at her home in Rutland, Vt. She was 87 years old.

LEAD: The committee of general creditors of Texaco Inc. yesterday approved an interim settlement proposal in the oil company's three-year battle with the Pennzoil Company, but it declined to disclose its terms until a crucial showdown in bankruptcy court today.
LEAD: Dragged down by the diving stock market, the Government index designed to predict the economy declined by two-tenths of 1 percent in October, the Commerce Department reported today.

LEAD: The Soviet leader who will arrive next week in Washington will be less a stranger to Americans than any of his predecessors. Just days before his summit visit, Mikhail Gorbachev was there for all to read in his new book, ''Perestroika,'' and for all to see in an interview on American television. The reviews were quick and varied: canned and candid, belligerent and believable, inspirational and manipulative.
LEAD: DEAR DIARY:

LEAD: Investigators for the Government of India filed criminal charges today against the Union Carbide Corporation; Warren M. Anderson, its former chairman, and eight Indians stemming from the 1984 gas leak at a Carbide subsidiary's plant in Bhopal, India.

LEAD: A hostage was released tonight by Cuban inmates controlling the Federal penitentiary here amid uncertainty about why the 36-year-old correction officer was chosen and what obstacles remained to settling the eight-day prison uprising.

LEAD: Supporters of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., who espouses theories of political conspiracy, have succeeded in placing an anti-AIDS referendum on the state ballot next June, California officials report.

LEAD: He is called the Ox. The nickname for Afghanistan's Soviet-sponsored leader, Najibullah, refers not only to his bulky physique, but also to his stubborn, driving power and his approach to obstacles in his path.

LEAD: Two former agents of the United States Customs Service were sentenced today to 120 years in prison in the 1982 death of a Dominican currency courier who was robbed of nearly $700,000 in cash and checks.
LEAD: The negotiations to sell E. F. Hutton & Company stretched well into the evening yesterday without a clear winner and with a possibility that the firm would not announce its buyer until Monday.

LEAD: Senate tax writers began piecing together a $9 billion package of tax increases today as top White House officials lobbied Republican senators to support the deficit-reduction agreement reached last month between the Administration and leaders of Congress.

LEAD: Short-term interest rates were little changed yesterday while Treasury bond yields rose slightly as traders kept one eye on fluctuations in the stock market and waited for more economic data to give a clearer picture of interest rate trends.

LEAD: The Federal Government spends $3.4 billion a year on guaranteed loans for college students, but $1.6 billion of that, or nearly half, helps no one pay for books and tuition. It goes to cover the cost of defaulted loans.

LEAD: The Soviet Union and third-world countries have joined Western nations at the General Assembly to defeat a move by Syria that many countries contended would confer legitimacy on international terrorism.
LEAD: ''GOD THE REVELLER'' is one of Erick Hawkins's most beautiful dance works, typical in its clarity but unusually threaded throughout with a sly wit. It runs through every image.
LEAD: For all the differences between Mikhail Gorbachev and Ronald Reagan, the Gorbachev interview on NBC Monday night demonstrated a striking similarity.

LEAD: From Los Angeles to Tel Aviv, Paris to Johannesburg, Brad Gilbert's road to the Nabisco Masters was an eight-week odyssey that ended in Itaparica, Brazil, last week, on a hard court baked by temperatures exceeding 100 degrees.

LEAD: A chart in Business Day on Nov. 24 about third-quarter bank performance included incorrect figures provided by the First Bank System of Minneapolis and First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles for their common equity ratios. The equity ratio for First Bank System should have been 4.64 percent, placing it third in the rankings behind J.
LEAD: WHO'S the boss? That's easy; it's Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

LEAD: A United Airlines Boeing 767 carrying 116 people went into a dive Sunday to avoid a collision with a small plane, passing within 100 feet of the smaller craft, according to a report received by the Federal Aviation Administration.

LEAD: The dollar rallied from Monday's record lows in active interbank trading yesterday, helped by support from Asian and European central banks and by rumors that West Germany is about to cut its key interest rate.
LEAD: FYODOR DOSTOYEVSKY. A Writer's Life. By Geir Kjetsaa. Translated from the Norwegian by Siri Hustvedt and David McDuff. 437 pages. Elisabeth Sifton Viking. $24.95.

LEAD: Jay Edwards, a 6-foot-4-inch freshman guard, scored 7 consecutive points and had 12 of his team's final 16 as Indiana defeated Notre Dame, 76-59, tonight.
LEAD: The Senate has been called the world's most exclusive club. Now comes word that it is much more like the locker room of a sports team.
LEAD: When Evander Holyfield beat Dwight Muhammad Qawi for the World Boxing Association junior heavyweight (a k a cruiserweight) title in July 1986, he was a busy man.

LEAD: To curb overzealousness in its internal security agency, the Canadian Government has ordered it to disband a countersubversion branch that until recently maintained files on 30,000 people, including some in labor and antiwar groups that have broad public backing.
LEAD: The Dance Theater of Harlem will perform in the Soviet Union in a four-week tour that begins May 13 at the Palace of Congresses in Moscow.

LEAD: Concerned that political violence could re-emerge as a threat to the Irish republic, Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey presided uneasily today over two initiatives against the Irish Republican Army.

LEAD: Pan American World Airways yesterday struck an 11th-hour deal with its pilots that could undermine a yearlong attempt by some of the airline's unions to find a buyer for the carrier and replace its current management.
LEAD: IN the middle of the holidays, one can grow tired of going out, tired of all that heavy food.

LEAD: George (Punch) Imlach, who guided the Toronto Maple Leafs during their glory years in the National Hockey League and then built the expansion Buffalo Sabres into a contending team, died today after suffering his third major heart attack. He was 69 years old.

LEAD: SISTER FRANCES A. CARR is the kitchen deaconess, or head cook, of the little Shaker community of Sabbathday Lake near Poland Spring, Me., about 30 miles northwest of Portland. She is one of the handful of remaining members of the sect, whose adherents once numbered in the thousands. LEAD: The Southland Corporation's on-again, off-again attempts to become a private company were on again yesterday as its investment bankers came up with a new plan to finance the $5.1 billion deal.

LEAD: The Senate Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations approved a $12.2 billion foreign aid bill today that includes a ban on the Reagan Administration's plans to sell Stinger anti-aircraft missiles to Bahrain.

LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration awarded contracts yesterday to four companies to begin building the nation's first permanent outpost in space, an undertaking that would cost at least $14 billion and would be the last manned space program of this century for the United States.
LEAD: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov played routinely to an uneventful draw in the 18th game of their world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, on Monday.

LEAD: In tough bargaining for next week's summit meeting, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has already had to make one concession to President Reagan - the state dinner at the White House Tuesday will be black tie, not business dress as the Russians requested.
LEAD: Assets of the nation's mutual funds plunged $53.2 billion in October, the month of the stock market's spectacular dive, to $774.1 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

LEAD: IN the 1940's and 1950's Hempstead served as the downtown for many of the new Long Island communities then emerging throughout Nassau County, but it began to slip into decline as the county evolved into a highly prosperous suburban area.
LEAD: Two months after a major radiation accident shocked this Brazilian city, the threat of contamination, like an intangible plague, still reaches deep into the psyche of its inhabitants.

LEAD: An investigation by the Department of Health and Human Services has cleared officials of the Gay Men's Health Crisis of accusations that the Manhattan-based group used Federal money to produce sexually explicit educational comic books.
LEAD: The personal trusts of Lamar and Nelson Bunker Hunt filed for protection from creditors today under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
LEAD: ON Monday Pepperidge Farm, many a tummy's favorite, will introduce into Northern California eight (count 'em, eight) new frozen, single-serving desserts.
LEAD: Paul L. Field and David W. Pardonner, who started a cable television company from scratch just eight years ago, are selling it and four associated partnerships for $225 million.
LEAD: MEDICAL historians trace the idea of fighting cancer tumors with heat to Hippocrates, who successfully treated his fellow Greeks in baths of hot sand 24 centuries ago.

LEAD: Richard N. Perle, a former Pentagon official whose hard-line views are expected to be influential in the Senate debate over ratification of the new missile treaty, sharply criticized some of the treaty's verification provisions today.

LEAD: The Onset Corporation has begun a friendly $8.75-a-share offer for the Decision Industries Corporation, which it said would cost $92 million, but a second company said that it would pay more for the computer concern based in Horsham, Pa.
LEAD: IN the French language, a pecher is a peach tree and a peche is a sin. To these nearly sound-alike words add mignon, meaning cute, and the result is both a pun and the name of a new liqueur.

LEAD: Senior Democratic leaders, increasingly dismayed and frustrated by the performance of their party's six contenders for President, have started meeting privately to discuss ways of getting other candidates into the race.
LEAD: The United States sharply criticized France today for making what one official said was a deal with Iran to obtain the release of French hostages in Lebanon.

LEAD: NO one has ever accused Rudolf Firkusny of being a frivolous performer, nor were they likely to do so after his extraordinarily demanding program at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening. LEAD: Reagan Administration officials today described the Afghan Government's proposal to have Soviet troops withdraw over a period of 12 months as inadequate.

LEAD: Picasso's ''Souvenir of Havre,'' an oval Cubist work depicting a bottle of rum, a glass, seashells, an anchor, ropes and a piece of fake wood, was auctioned at Sotheby's in London last night for $7.6 million, a record at auction for a painting by the artist.

LEAD: While it barely qualifies, having had its premiere merely a month after V-E Day, Britten's ''Peter Grimes'' stands as one of the few postwar operas to establish for itself an undisputed place in the standard repertory. This morality play about a violent social outcast remains today a gripping piece of musical theater, particularly when realized in a production of the sort presented this evening by the Opera Company of Philadelphia, here in the Academy of Music.

LEAD: For London's wine crowd the week began Monday with a tasting at the Groucho (''I wouldn't want to belong to any club that would accept me as a member'') Club in Soho. It ended Friday at the opening of Sir Terence Conran's long-awaited oyster and wine bar, Bibendum, in South Kensington. It was a busy five days, but then, this is a vibrant wine city.

LEAD: A day after Mikhail S. Gorbachev's appearance on American television, the White House arranged yesterday for an unusual four-way session between President Reagan and the anchors from ABC, NBC, CBS and the Cable News Network.

LEAD: Guy Morriss, the New England Patriots' center whose 215 games are the most of any active National Football League player, was placed on injured reserve yesterday with a fractured right hand. Morriss, a 15-year veteran, was hurt in the fourth quarter of last Sunday's 34-31 overtime loss to the Philadelphia Eagles.

LEAD: The Koch administration has for the first time begun withholding rent payments from an uncooperative welfare hotel in an effort to force it to correct dangerous health and safety code violations, city officials said yesterday.

LEAD: James Baldwin, whose passionate, intensely personal essays in the 1950's and 60's on racial discrimination in America made him an eloquent voice of the civil-rights movement, died of stomach cancer early yesterday at his home in St. Paul de Vence in southern France. He was 63 years old.

LEAD: Six weeks after the stock market crash wiped out half a trillion dollars of the nation's wealth, those who work in the multibillion-dollar sports industry are in broad agreement that the immediate impact on athletes and athletics was limited, that the short-range fallout has been negligible and that even in the face of a possible recession the long-term outlook remains bright.
LEAD: Award-Winning Books

LEAD: The former head of New York's state militia will be the star prosecution witness at the first criminal trial in New York resulting from the sprawling investigations into the Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx military contractor, lawyers in the case said yesterday.

LEAD: A Federal judge Monday revoked bail for a son-in-law of former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo who was accused of continuing to take bets four months after his conviction on Federal bookmaking charges. The convict, Joseph Mastronardo Jr., 35 years old, of Huntingdon Valley, was convicted in July of running a multimillion-dollar gambling operation that stretched from New York to Florida.

LEAD: IVAN LENDL and Pat Cash were playing for the richest single prize in tennis history. It was the final of the initial Stakes Match, seen on ABC-TV Sunday afternoon, and at one point, one of the announcers, Cliff Drysdale or Arthur Ashe, said, ''If Cash gets much further behind, he might be left with nothing but a handshake.

LEAD: American publications may not have much of an appetite for such news out of the Soviet Union as ''Volunteers Harvest Uzbekistan Cotton by Hand'' or ''Substandard Auto Services Plague Khabarovsk,'' but Soviet television's version of arms control talks in Geneva or a new flare-up in the Persian Gulf could be a different story - at least the owners of Worldview Inc.

LEAD: The Brooklyn District Attorney has asserted that a New York City judge ordered the complainant in a sexual misconduct trial to get on the floor on her hands and knees, as the defendant and others watched, to demonstrate her position when she was attacked.

LEAD: WHEN you close your eyes and think of Christmas, do you see snow-covered cottages decorated with gumdrops, cinnamon candies and candy canes?

LEAD: In the days before the Reagan-Gorbachev meeting, a reporter from Washington finds a surprisingly hopeful mood in Western Europe about East-West relations. It's not just anticipation of the first limited agreement to reduce the superpowers' nuclear arsenals. One even hears thoughtful speculation about the beginning of the end of the cold war.

LEAD: Presidencies, like people, go through a natural aging process. And with 14 months left in office, the two-term Reagan Administration has clearly passed through middle age and is approaching retirement.

LEAD: Claiming control of more than half of Nicaragua, contra leaders today announced their cease-fire plan, which calls for a 41-day break in hostilities beginning next week and simultaneous talks on political issues.

LEAD: Julius K. Nyerere, the former Tanzanian President, said today that apartheid would leave a social and economic legacy that would last long beyond the transfer of political power to South Africa's black majority.
LEAD: The Union Leader, New Hampshire's influential statewide newspaper, today endorsed Pete du Pont, the former Governor of Delaware, as ''our choice for President.''
LEAD: Washingtonians have a way of dealing with invitations to parties they know will be either a crush of warm bodies or a crashing bore.
LEAD: France's secret dealings with Iran to obtain the freedom of French hostages have upset the British Government and drawn fierce criticism from the British press.

LEAD: The combatants in New York City's bitter tabloid newspaper war - The Daily News, The New York Post and New York Newsday - appear to be on the threshold of a final melee that could determine the city's newspaper landscape for many years to come.

LEAD: Generals don't start wars, politicians do. That is the message of a campaign commercial being broadcast in New Hampshire by Alexander M. Haig Jr., a retired four-star Army general now a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination.

LEAD: Larry Davis, who is being tried for the murder of four suspected drug dealers, told the trial judge yesterday that his throat had been slashed by a fellow inmate at the Bronx House of Detention Monday while three officers from the Department of Correction watched and ''did nothing.''

LEAD: The uprisings at two Federal prisons have focused attention on a dimension of the Cuban refugee exodus generally overlooked among the countless successes achieved by Cubans settling in Miami over the last three decades: the struggle of the black Cuban to share that success.

LEAD: A prime-time Soviet broadcast of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's interview on NBC News rolled along untouched for 55 minutes tonight, until the subject of Raisa Gorbachev came up - and with it, by implication, the ticklish question of her role in her husband's grand designs for Soviet society.

LEAD: In Joanell Meringolo's sixth-grade class, students have aliases such as Claudius and Sempronia and a lingering Halloween pumpkin is called Aeneas. When a draft slams the door shut, it is the ghost of Julius Caesar that has just stalked by.

LEAD: THE technology of home toasters has not changed fundamentally in 40 years. Their function is simple and limited. Of course, that hasn't stopped American manufacturers from fiddling with size, shape, color and special features to create diversity, real or imaginary, among brands - just as shoppers are led to believe that there is a difference among the half-dozen brands of canned peas on the market.

LEAD: FREDERICK WISEMAN, the lawyer turned film maker, made his first feature in 1967, the tough, harrowing, litigation-plagued ''Titicut Follies,'' about life in the State Prison for the Criminally Insane at Bridgewater, Mass. It seems he's scarcely taken a day off since. In the last 20 years he's made 18 highly personal documentaries, most of them about institutions (hospitals, the police, the Army, meatpacking, among other subjects) that shape and define American life.
LEAD: Ron Guidry, who spent an agonizing offseason last winter as a free agent, faces a different problem this winter. He will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his left shoulder next week.

LEAD: Helped by a fistfight between K.G.B. and C.I.A. agents, Victor A. Vaguine, a Soviet nuclear physicist, defected with his wife and two children to the United States 16 years ago in Switzerland.

LEAD: John Hapgood, a pen-and-ink artist, has donated two of his scratchboard drawings to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which opened its 76th annual drive Sunday.

LEAD: One dark night a long time ago in Provincetown, Mass., hearing sounds of desperation in the water that lapped our rental house, I waded in and retrieved a fully clothed female person, age about 18.

LEAD: They line the shelves of bookstores, an array of interchangeable titles: ''College Guide,'' ''Selective Guide to Colleges,'' ''Comparative Guide to American Colleges,'' ''Insider's Guide to the Colleges,'' and so on. That is the first clue that selecting the right college guide can be just as daunting as selecting the right college.

LEAD: ONE of the the quirks of commercial television is that truly provocative and sensitive subjects get shunted to distant corners of the schedule. Take, for example, periodic specials aimed specifically at young audiences. This afternoon's ABC ''Afterschool Special,'' at 4 P.M., tackles the thorny issue of this nation's constitutionally decreed separation of church and state.

LEAD: Part of a crowd of about 5,000 that gathered, with some scuffling, outside City Hall in Chicago last night as the City Council tried to choose a successor to Harold Washington. Page A20. (AP)

LEAD: The Supreme Court today handed industrialists what appeared to be a partial victory over environmental groups in a complex decision limiting the ability of citizens to sue polluters for past violations of the Federal Clean Water Act.

LEAD: PEACH may be the most popular fruit to flavor wines and spirits these days, but now that winter is approaching it is a pleasure to turn to the seductively rich taste of pear.

LEAD: Facing pressure at home and abroad to do something about their sluggish economy, West Germany's Finance and Economics Ministers agreed today on a plan to encourage capital spending, Government officials said.

LEAD: The Royal Bank of Canada, the largest bank in the country, announced yesterday a complex plan to acquire 75 percent of Dominion Securities Ltd., Canada's largest full-service securities firm. The deal is worth $385 million (Canadian), or $294 million in United States currency.

LEAD: An Israeli soldier was slightly wounded early today when two unidentified gunmen opened fire on an Israeli Army patrol after having cut a hole in the Egyptian-Israeli border fence, an Israeli Army spokesman said.
LEAD: An editorial on Nov. 28 gave the wrong date for Riverside Church's ''Messiah'' sing. It is Dec. 13.

LEAD: Black & Decker is recalling about 500,000 weed trimmers because of the potential for electric shock, the Consumer Product Safety Commission says. Involved are Model 82209, Type 1 and 2, and Model 82210 Type 1 and 2, 9-and 10-inch bump-feed trimmers, the agency said Monday. The wiring in some of them may be improperly located, allowing the handle tube to cut it, and lead to an electric shock hazard.

LEAD: Several members of the civilian Electoral Council disbanded by the Government after an abortive presidential election refused today to accept the Government action, heightening the conflict over Haiti's future.

LEAD: LIKE the apparently mismatched pair in ''Burn This,'' the people in the three one-act plays by Lanford Wilson that opened last night at the Sanford Meisner Theater are on edge. The reconciliations made as the lights go down tend to be soft, but Mr. Wilson's steady humor and his smart dialogue offer pleasures along the way.
LEAD: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it might reduce the Primerica Corporation's senior long-term debt to a speculative BB rating from BBB currently.

LEAD: DR. RICHARD B. SYKES, who heads the research arm of Britain's big pharmaceutical maker, Glaxo Holdings P.L.C., says that trying to develop a major new drug is like betting on race horses, with one notable difference.
LEAD: An admitted killer testified yesterday that he and two defendants had helped carry out the dramatic prison escape of Joanne Chesimard, a Black Liberation Army leader, in 1979.

LEAD: MARIANNE FAITHFULL confessed to nervousness Monday at the Bottom Line, in the second of three nights in her first live show since 1983. But a remarkable band, Ms. Faithfull's singular voice and, perhaps, the tension of facing an audience again combined for one of the strongest performances in recent memory - complex, adult emotions conveyed with artful directness.

LEAD: CONSUMERS who look for seasonal caviar bargains are in for a disappointment this year, and those who indulge in this delicacy for the holidays may be shocked at prices posted by retailers across the country.

LEAD: The Colonial League, the six-team organization that just finished its second season with a flush of success, is delighted to serve as a model for intercollegiate football. LEAD: Some people wouldn't think twice about refusing garlic for the sake of a heavy date. True garlic lovers don't avoid garlic for the sake of human contact; instead, they limit their human contacts to other garlic lovers.

LEAD: The milk deliverers' union, angry because management refused to continue contract talks through the night, struck at 12:01 A.M. today, halting all deliveries to New York City, Long Island and most of Westchester County, union officials said.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: * Robert Jaczko, creative director, has been promoted to senior vice president at Doremus & Co., Boston.
LEAD: The latest round of buyer incentives is likely to do even less to stimulate the auto industry than the last round, which ended just two months ago, analysts and industry sources say.

LEAD: Production of vacherin Mont d'Or, a soft-ripened cheese prized by connoisseurs, has been halted by the Swiss Government. The cheese has been linked to outbreaks of listeriosis, a sometimes fatal bacterial infection, in the western part of Switzerland.

LEAD: NASA announced today that its long-delayed mission to Jupiter would be launched in 1989, and would include an audacious rerouting of the spacecraft to use the gravitational force of Venus and Earth to fling the craft like a stone in a slingshot toward Jupiter.
LEAD: The Census Bureau says whites are twice as likely as blacks to complete college, although there is a far smaller gap between the races in finishing high school.

LEAD: THE holiday vacation period can be challenging for parents facing nearly two weeks' worth of plaintive cries of ''What'll I do?'' from restless youngsters. It can be especially trying if one or both parents must keep to working schedules.
LEAD: The Sony Corporation of America said yesterday that it planned to increase prices of its consumer and professional products, effective Jan. 4, to offset the decline in the United States dollar.

LEAD: According to the dictionary, a pant is ''any of a series of rapid, heavy breaths'' or ''a throb, as of the heart'' or ''a puff, as from an engine.'' But not at a big Fifth Avenue department store. There, or so an advertisement proclaims, a pant is a ''must-have for this year's directional winter wardrobe.

LEAD: ''Sherlock's Last Case,'' a mystery thriller by Charles Marowitz, is to close after the matinee performance on Sunday at the Nederlander Theater, 208 West 41st Street. Directed by A. J. Antoon and co-starring Frank Langella and Donal Donnelly, the play will have run for 13 previews and 124 performances.

LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former Cambodian leader, met today with Prime Minister Hun Sen of the Vietnamese-backed Cambodian Government in a first tentative effort to negotiate an end to the guerrilla war in their country.

LEAD: Presidential candidates used to emerge from the smoke-filled room, chosen by shrewd old pols. Now they emerge from trials by fire, electronic fire, chosen by the public. NBC's two-hour program Tuesday night carried on-screen screening to a new level by including each candidate of both parties. In principle, it's part of a welcome, historic shift to primary election campaigns.
LEAD: President Reagan will appear on the major commercial television networks Thursday night in an interview to be conducted by the network anchors.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration charged the Soviet Union today with a new technical violation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. The American move was welcomed by Senate conservatives who have been concerned that the Administration has not been firm enough in dealing with Moscow.
LEAD: Pierre Jean Baptiste came to a small Brooklyn storefront Tuesday morning hoping for news about his mother and brother, who were chased from the polls in a Haitian town Sunday morning.

LEAD: The heated question of aid to Pakistan will soon hit the floor of the House of Representatives. The vote will be close, for principle seems to vie with principle - helping Pakistan for itself and for its help to the Afghan rebels versus trying to pressure Pakistan to stop building nuclear weapons.
LEAD: Simon Weber, a writer and editor at The Jewish Daily Forward for nearly 50 years, died Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 77 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

LEAD: The chairman of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Douglas D. Danforth, embarked on a new career yesterday. He was named chairman and chief executive of the Pittsburgh Pirates baseball club.

LEAD: Twenty-seven people received minor injuries last night when two private buses collided at 41st Street and 11th Avenue. The police said the accident occurred at 6:20 P.M. when a Trailways bus returning to its garage at 525 11th Avenue collided with a Delaware-bound tour bus. The Trailways bus was traveling west on 41st Street, and the tour bus, owned by Gregg's Bus Service of Yorklyn, Del., was southbound on 11th Avenue en route to the Lincoln Tunnel.

LEAD: IT was probably only a matter of time before some Fifth Avenue Christmas windows succumbed to decorator fever. The windows in question, ho ho ho, are at Gucci, at Fifth Avenue and 54th Street.

LEAD: The West German Government today announced its plan to bolster the nation's economy by offering low-rate loans to local authorities and small businesses. But signs were mixed on whether the Bundesbank would follow with a cut in its main lending rate.
LEAD: An investigator has concluded that a supervisor dismissed from the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant near here had slept on duty numerous times.
LEAD: The National Football League Players Association has filed a motion in Federal court in Minneapolis that would remove the major restraint to free agency when this season ends.

LEAD: A Thanksgiving outing that became an icy ordeal ended today when two hikers were found three days after they were scheduled to return from the San Gabriel Mountains. The hikers, Stephen Thomas Parker, 31 years old, of La Verne, and Kip Brook Pennington, 24, of Upland, were found by rescue teams and flown out by helicopter.

The only noticeable departure from convention was a small outburst of didactic works that reached its nadir in a line of books called ''Disney's Classic Value Stories,'' with the title ''Walt Disney's Dumbo and the Magic Feather: A Tale About Confidence.

LEAD: Both the median price of a new house and the number of new houses sold fell sharply in October, the Commerce Department reported yesterday, evidence that the collapse of the stock market six weeks ago is beginning to affect other segments of the economy.

LEAD: A team of British and American astronomers has discovered two celestial objects much farther away from Earth than any previously known. The discovery of the two quasars, one 12 billion light years away, reinforces a growing belief that the outer limits of the observable universe have yet to be glimpsed.

LEAD: The last Gimbels store will close by Jan. 31 because it has lost its lease at a suburban Pittsburgh mall, store officials said today. The Gimbels chain was anchored by the Herald Square store in New York City. The 36 stores were sold individually by their corporate parent, Batus Inc.

LEAD: A threatened strike by milk deliverymen and processing plant workers in New York City and surrounding counties was averted yesterday when a state mediator persuaded both sides to accept a cooling-off period of up to 10 days.

LEAD: Phil Esposito was furious when the Boston Bruins traded him to the Rangers 12 years ago, but he has since forgiven them, and he has consented to watch his former jersey, No. 7, raised to the Boston Garden rafters tonight as tribute to his eight seasons of service there.

LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus widened to $5.52 billion in the first 11 months of the year from $2.93 billion a year earlier, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported today. Officials said that Korean exports during the period rose 34.3 percent, to $41.91 billion, while imports rose 28.7 percent, to $36.39 billion.

LEAD: WHEN the question is asked, Paul Coffey looks away momentarily, ruminatively rubbing the jaw his trademark beard once occupied. When he finally turns back, there is softness in his dark eyes. There are no tears. ''My seven years in Edmonton were fantastic,'' Coffey said in response to a query regarding regrets about the defenseman's recent transfer from the Oilers to the Penguins.
LEAD: A Federal-state agreement on greater environmental protection of the Chesapeake Bay does not go far enough, 16 environmental organizations said today.

LEAD: Salomon Brothers Inc. disclosed that it might sell its stake in Alleco Inc., formerly the Allegheny Beverage Corporation, because of a disagreement with Alleco over terms of the $18.5 million in senior subordinated debentures controlled by the New York investment firm. Alleco shareholders approved a transaction today in which a management group agreed to acquire Alleco's food service business, the Service America Corporation, for $345 million in cash and the assumption of the debentures.

LEAD: Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. called today for a special session of the West Virginia Legislature to deal with an economic crisis that has left the state unable to pay some of its bills. It has also left the state's leadership deeply divided politically.

LEAD: Testimony ended yesterday in the three-month-old Howard Beach murder trial, and the judge said he expected jury deliberations to begin next Wednesday, after closing arguments Monday and Tuesday.

LEAD: A school district has the right to ban male students from wearing earrings while attending classes, a Federal district judge has ruled. The judge, Paul E. Plunkett, released an opinion Tuesday denying a request for a temporary injunction against the Bremen Community High School District by attorneys for 17-year-old Darryl Olesen of Midlothian, who contended that the ban violated his constitutional rights.
LEAD: WHEN a foreign-based advertising agency opens a branch in New York, it can't really be too hopeful of attracting local clients, what with the great selection of American agencies available.

He was a little more than 3 years old, and he was throwing a tantrum in the checkout line of the supermarket.

LEAD: The on-time performances of the 14 major United States airlines improved slightly in October, according to records released today by the Department of Transportation. The improvement apparently reflected both better service and more realistic scheduling by the airlines.

LEAD: The tepee jokes elicit only strained smiles from most residents here on the Mashantucket Pequot Indian Reservation. Tribe members hear them often from tourists and out-of-towners. They say it's a common misconception.

LEAD: Declaring that it wanted to make its profitable trading operation even more profitable, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said yesterday that it was acquiring a New York Stock Exchange specialist firm.

LEAD: Horse Racing Migliore Wins Again: Richard Migliore rode his fourth winner in five mounts yesterday when he guided Fine Timing to a front-running 5 1/2-length victory in the $33,000 allowance feature for fillies and mares at Aqueduct. Fine Timing, a 3-year-old daughter of Well Decorated and Rhythmic Lady, covered the six furlongs in 1:11 2/5 as racing shifted to the winterized inner-dirt track.

LEAD: THERE was a wonderful opening shot; it looked like the bass section of the Mormon Tabernacle Choir. Twelve men in dark suits (save one, Bob Dole, who chose light blue) seemed ready to burst into song. In a way, they did; the television format demanded riffs and recitatives. Tom Brokaw had it right: ''It's not easy running for President of the United States.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged a foreign investment firm and three British investors with violating Federal securities laws by manipulating the price of Bancroft Convertible Fund Inc. stock in the days before they made a tender offer for Bancroft last year.

LEAD: Not all of Washington will be rolling out the red carpet for Mr. Gorbachev's arrival on Monday. LEAD: Time magazine, which recently introduced a Max Plan on advertising sales and greatly upset its competitors, has now announced that it will not increase its ad rates next year, the first year it has not raised them since 1963. And that is certain to upset its rivals even more.

LEAD: In a new blow to the prestige of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, a judicial inquiry reported today that a former senior aide had violated guidelines on conflict of interest on at least 14 occasions by mixing private and public business.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A serious battle is building here on arms control agreements with Moscow, but it won't really be about what appears on the surface.

LEAD: Tonight at Carnegie Hall, New York will have one of its infrequent opportunities to assess Ottorino Respighi (1879-1936) as a composer of opera, a sphere in which his relative obscurity is a matter of some irony.

LEAD: The nation's non-farm businesses increased their efficiency in producing goods and services by 3.6 percent from July through September, the best improvement since the first quarter of 1986, the Labor Department said today.
LEAD: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will perform works by Debussy, Mozart, Caplet and Faure at 8 tonight, 3 P.M. tomorrow and 5 P.M. Sunday. Tickets are $18. Information: 874-6770.

LEAD: Noble & Associates of Springfield, Mo., has acquired the Don Tennant Company in Chicago and has merged it into its Noble & Associates agency there to form Noble Tennant, a shop with $25 million in billings. Robert B. Noble, founder and chairman of the parent company, will be president and chief executive in Chicago.

LEAD: The administrative judge for the New York City criminal courts, beginning an inquiry into allegations that a judge humiliated the complainant in a sexual misconduct trial, examined the record of the trial yesterday.

LEAD: Ray Bourque may have surrendered his No. 7 to Phil Esposito tonight and watched it be retired to Boston Garden's rafters without him, but collectively the Bruins were not in so giving a mood. Their seven-minute rally at the game's end brought them a 4-3 victory against Esposito's dejected Rangers.

LEAD: New tests on the urine of a 73-year-old hospital patient revealed no signs of the paralyzing drug that a 25-year-old nurse is accused of injecting into him, the Suffolk County District Attorney's office said today. The nurse, Richard J. Angelo, is suspected of killing at least 10 people.

LEAD: The offices and a warehouse of a man who has been Santa Claus for many underpriviledged children were looted of about $500 in merchandise Wednesday. ''I think anybody would have to be pretty bad off to steal from the poor,'' said Dorcas Drake, whose annual toy drive serves 50,000 children. Mr. Drake, a retired justice of the peace, has served as Santa Claus for 30 years.
LEAD: ''I think as long as you've got a chance to strive for peace, you strive for peace.'' - President Reagan [ A16:6. ]

LEAD: Robert A. Schmetterer, who left the worldwide chief executive's job at the HCM agency determined to start his own place, has settled for partnership status and the presidency at Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey. Asking for a name on the door as well would have been asking too much.
LEAD: * New York City Transportation Department to Gleckler & Co., for an advertising campaign to warn young people against drunken driving.

LEAD: Georgia O'Keeffe's ''Black Hollyhock With Blue Larkspur,'' from about 1930, was sold yesterday at Sotheby's for $1.9 million. It was the highest price ever paid at auction for a painting by the artist, in a record sale of American art at Sotheby's.
LEAD: Judge Robert H. Bork said tonight that the Senate appeared to misunderstand its role in the confirmation of Supreme Court nominees, and he blamed politics for his rejection.

LEAD: The Vons Companies said it had agreed to buy 172 grocery stores from Safeway Stores Inc. in a cash and stock deal valued at about $408.2 million. Vons, based in El Monte, Calif., operates 193 stores in Southern California that generated $3 billion in sales last year. The Safeway stores that Vons intends to buy had sales of $1.6 billion last year and would extend Vons's reach into Central

LEAD: A former Army medical instructor was sentenced to five months in the stockade and was given a dishonorable discharge Wednesday for having sexual relations with three female soldiers without telling them he carried the AIDS virus.

LEAD: Standard Register, the Dayton, Ohio, maker of business forms and systems, has decided to move its advertising to the Martin Agency in Richmond. The business-to-business account is in the $1 million to $2 million range. For the last 25 years, the advertising was handled by Griswold, a Cleveland-based Ross Roy subsidiary.

LEAD: The Food Notes column in The Living Section on Wednesday omitted the publisher of ''Cook Quick.'' It is Oxmoor House.

LEAD: If huge crowds and supporter fervor were enough, Kim Dae Jung would win South Korea's presidential election hands down.

LEAD: The Santa Fe Railway, continuing a cost-cutting drive begun last year, said it would consolidate its operating divisions and repair yards by 1990. The move will result in the immediate layoff of 170 workers and is expected to result in further layoffs.

LEAD: The Union Pacific Corporation said it holds 16.4 percent of the Beard Company and may seek control of the Oklahoma City-based oil and gas concern. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Union Pacific said it might acquire Beard to obtain the company's 28 percent stake in USPCI Inc.

LEAD: ON Nov. 15, 1979, Margaret Thatcher publicly named Anthony Blunt as the ''fourth man'' in a notorious spy ring that included Guy Burgess, Kim Philby and Donald Maclean, all three of whom had defected to the Soviet Union in 1951. Actually, Blunt had been confronted 15 years earlier by M.I.5, the British security agency, about his longtime role as a Soviet agent.

LEAD: TAKING the true story of William Walker, the American adventurer who once ruled as the self-declared president of Nicaragua (1856-57), the director Alex Cox and the writer Rudy Wurlitzer have made ''Walker,'' a hip, cool, political satire that's almost as lunatic as the title character.

LEAD: As a tour guide, I rate zero. It is my perception of myself that I know nobody, never go out, have a bad case of agoraphobia, cannot recognize even the most famous buildings and like to believe I am invisible, even when crossing the road. I have no brilliant ideas for people from out of town. Nor has any one of them ever been so foolish as to expect me to have any.
LEAD: Eleven former all-America football players and two coaches will be inducted into the National Football Foundation's College Hall of Fame Tuesday at the organization's annual awards dinner.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan yesterday affirmed the conviction of a Pakistani arms dealer who said he had sold arms to Iran under the secret authorization of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North.

LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk met again today with Prime Minister Hun Sen of the Vietnamese-backed Cambodian Government and said Hanoi pledged to pull its occupation troops from the country next year if the two could reach an agreement to settle their differences.
LEAD: The National Education Association, which played a major role in the 1980 and 1984 races for the Democratic nomination, today decided against an early endorsement in the 1988 campaign.

LEAD: Jacques Travers, an instructor of French at Brooklyn College and founder of a Roman Catholic house for the homeless, died of cancer of the esophagus Nov. 23 in Elbeuf, France. He was 62 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

LEAD: ORCHESTRATING a night on the town, such as dinner and a show, is much like directing a play. The script may be solid, the casting superb, the set inspiring - but if your timing is off, the whole effort collapses like a leaky balloon.

LEAD: The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today to bar the sale of Stinger anti-aircraft missiles to any nation in the Persian Gulf for the next year, a move that would block a planned sale to Bahrain.

LEAD: A large section of prostate gland removed from former Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. showed no signs of cancer, a hospital spokeswoman said today. Surgeons at Brigham and Women's Hospital removed 90 percent of the enlarged prostate of the former Speaker of the House of Representatives on Monday and tests were performed on tissue samples.

LEAD: President Reagan, strongly defending the arms control treaty he expects to sign with the Soviet Union at the summit meeting next week, said today that conservative critics did not understand what the treaty would accomplish and had accepted the idea ''that war is inevitable.''

LEAD: ''A Hero's Journey: The World of Joseph Campbell'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. These are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 22. The film opens today at the Eighth Street Playhouse.

LEAD: Matilda Cuomo, wife of the Governor, shaking hands with President Francesco Cossigna of Italy yesterday in Rome. At left was John Guode, president of the Christopher Columbus Quincentenary Jubilee Commission. Theyt were attending a reception for members of the commission, which is in Rome to plan for the celebrations marking the 500th anniversary of the discovery of the New World.

LEAD: For the first time since the Nicaraguan civil conflict began nearly six years ago, officials of the Sandinista Government held peace talks today with a delegation representing United States-backed guerrillas.

LEAD: A 35-year-old Bronx man was indicted yesterday in connection with what prosecutors called a scheme to resell at least 1,000 handguns he had ordered legally by mail as a federally licensed dealer.
LEAD: A list of college guidebooks on the Education page on Wednesday omitted three books in some editions.

LEAD: Chris Spielman, the Ohio State All-America linebacker and a finalist for the Lombardi Award in 1986, won that 40-pound granite trophy last night as the nation's outstanding collegiate lineman of 1987, but the victory was bittersweet.

LEAD: In the last few years, residents of the Upper West Side have become accustomed to seeing many of the neighborhood's old town houses restored to their original 19th-century and early 20th-century elegance. That is what seems to have happened to two adjoining buildings at 103 and 105 West 89th Street near the corner of Columbus Avenue.

LEAD: A restaurant writer's urban sextant always points to special dining spots, so when I play tour guide with friends who visit for the holidays, our wanderings seldom stray far from the shores of gastronomy. Sure, I may start the day with a stroll up festive Fifth Avenue, hanging a right at 57th Street, then along the gilded commercial stretch on Madison Avenue in the 60's and 70's, where the only way to avoid insolvency is to have your credit cards stitched to your pocket lining.
LEAD: The Heisman Trophy used to be a nonstop, first-class ticket to the National Football League for running backs.
LEAD: The House today overwhelmingly rejected an industry-backed drive to take the tough issues of air pollution and acid rain off Congress's agenda until at least 1989.

LEAD: With the Senate Judiciary Committee's hearing on the nomination of Judge Anthony M. Kennedy barely a week away, most of the liberal groups that were in the forefront of the successful effort to keep Judge Robert H. Bork off the Supreme Court are maintaining a wary silence.
LEAD: The Yale Music Spectrum will perform works by Mozart and Beethoven tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street). Tickets are $9. Information: 362-8719.
LEAD: The Comptroller of the Currency in Washington today opened the door for nationally chartered banks in Texas to cross county lines to open branches.

LEAD: South Korea's rapidly growing electronics industry has become the country's second business sector to exceed $10 billion in annual exports, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported today. Ministry officials said that exports of Korean electronic products since January reached $10.02 billion on Wednesday and were expected to climb to $11 billion by year-end.

LEAD: A high-ranking New York state police officer, responsible for investigating allegations of corruption and misconduct in the force, was charged yesterday with extortion and conspiracy in a scheme to sell false Vermont birth certificates to people seeking American passports.

LEAD: The Government ordered an investigation yesterday into an incident earlier in the week in which a Delta Air Lines jet taxied onto a runway at Los Angeles International Airport as a United Airlines jumbo jet was taking off from the runway.

LEAD: Goldome, the Buffalo-based savings bank, said it had raised its stake in the Leslie Fay Companies to 21.1 percent, from 17.8 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Goldome continued to say that it had acquired the shares of the New York-based apparel concern for investment purposes only.

LEAD: There is little or no evidence that unconventional learning techniques will help the Army produce better soldiers, a National Research Council committee said today. But the panel said some methods deserved further study.
LEAD: State health officials have begun formal disciplinary action against the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in the death Feb. 22 of Andy Warhol.

LEAD: An actor and two musicians from the current Brooklyn production of ''The Mahabharata'' will perform ''Interrogations, or Koan, the Words of the Zen Masters'' at the French Institute-Alliance Francaise (22 East 60th Street) tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. and Monday at 6 P.M.

LEAD: ATLANTA, Friday, Dec. 3 - Following are the eight points of the agreement signed early this morning between the negotiators for the Government and the detainees. It was read to reporters by by Gary Leshaw, an attorney for the Atlanta Legal Aid Society, who was present during the negotiations.
LEAD: A Vietnamese tribunal sentenced 17 people to prison today on charges of trying to stage a guerrilla invasion with American and Thai backing.

LEAD: The Ronald Reagan Library may soon become a reality, but not everyone can understand why it's being built in this bedroom community where shopping malls, housing developments and ''valley speak'' abound.

LEAD: Giving to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has become a holiday tradition for many people. The 76th annual appeal opened last Sunday and will continue through February, Elizabeth L. Weiler, who is 82 years old, says proudly that she has contributed to the fund ''ever since the day it started, and I never missed a year.

LEAD: Efforts to negotiate a cease-fire between Iran and Iraq appeared near collapse today after officials said Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar had made no progress in talks with a senior Iranian official.

LEAD: John Ziegler, the president of the National Hockey League, said yesterday that no specific agreements had been reached to permit Soviet teams to play in the league. Ziegler met with Soviet hockey officials in Moscow this week. According to a report earlier this week in The Toronto Globe and Mail, a tentative agreement had been reached to allow four Soviet teams to play in the N.H.L.

LEAD: Ballet Hispanico and Lee Brunner, the liturgical dancer, will perform with the choir of Trinity Church on Sunday at 3 P.M. at the church, 74 Trinity Place. The performance is a benefit for God's Love We Deliver, an organization that provides hot meals for homebound AIDS patients. Tickets are $10; $100 for the performance and a reception.

LEAD: N.B.A. Hawks 102, Bullets 94: Kevin Willis scored 23 points and Cliff Levingston had 21 to lead visiting Atlanta to a victory over Washington last night. Levingston, starting in place of the injured Dominique Wilkins, had 13 points in the first half, during which the Hawks opened a 45-30 lead.

LEAD: People pour into New York in December, and some of those who fill the sidewalks to overflowing and drive the cars that clog the streets are going to be friends of yours. When they come to town, they will ask you what to do. Here and on page C6, eight Times critics offer suggestions on what to show visitors in this holiday season, as the city's energy begins to mount to its crescendo.

LEAD: WHEN the antiquated London stock market finally cast off tradition and plugged into the deregulated frenzy of modern Wall Street in 1986, the phenomenon was heralded as the Big Bang. In ''Serious Money,'' a ferocious new satire about the financial wheeler-dealers born in the ensuing boom, Caryl Churchill takes the term literally.

LEAD: The first person picked up and confined under a New York City program to hospitalize mentally ill street people against their will made an impassioned plea for her freedom last night and pledged not to return to a life on the streets.

LEAD: A strong reservations today about efforts by the army-dominated Government to speed through a reorganization of the disbanded electoral council and hold new elections by early February.

LEAD: An investment group led by the wealthy Texas investor Robert M. Bass has received Federal antitrust clearance to raise its stake in the Bell & Howell Company to 25 percent, from 16.2 percent.
