LEAD: Workers on Wall Street are learning that a bonus is exactly what the word implies: a payment or reward in addition to salary that is by no means guaranteed.

LEAD: The United States may drop its demand that an overall limit be placed on warheads on Soviet land-based missiles as part of a larger compromise on reducing long-range nuclear arms, senior Administration officials said today.
LEAD: Increased demand in the transportation sector helped lift factory orders 1.1 percent in October despite the shock from the stock market plunge, the Government said today.

LEAD: THE skill with which ''Repentance'' has been made is sure to be eclipsed in importance by the very fact that it was made at all. The level of political self-criticism to be found in this Soviet film is so high, and the satire so scathing, that ''Repentance'' has been greeted as a phenomenon at home.

LEAD: ''THE TROUBLE WITH SPIES'' has the manner of an overage tadpole that knows it will never be a frog. It's dour and gloomy, though it's supposed to be lighthearted. Somewhere along the line, a turn was missed.

LEAD: A high-ranking New York City corrections officer denied yesterday that he or any of his colleagues at the Bronx House of Detention had ever willfully allowed another inmate to attack Larry Davis, a 21-year-old murder defendant.

LEAD: The illusions end on Damon Street, all of them: liberal, Reaganite, black solidarity, beneficent government, the innocence of man. Here are the Henry Horner Homes, 19 10-story buildings, red brick outside and cinder block inside, erected with Federal public housing money and managed by the Chicago Housing Authority.

LEAD: The 19th game of the world championship chess match ended in a draw yesterday in Seville, Spain, after determined efforts by the 36-year-old challenger, Anatoly Karpov, failed to budge the 24-year-old titleholder, Gary Kasparov.
LEAD: A Tampa police officer who was disciplined in the Dwight Gooden case last year has been dismissed because of repeated violations, Tampa police officials have said.

LEAD: In the face of a strong attack from President Jose Napoleon Duarte, who has charged them with complicity in political assassinations, Salvadoran rightists are urgently seeking help from their traditional ally - the army.

LEAD: An aide to Justice Minister Nabih Berri today denied a statement by a terrorist suspect in the United States that Mr. Berri ordered a 1985 plane hijacking.

LEAD: An article on Monday about parishioners' efforts at St. Luke's Church in the South Bronx to help homeless people described a church shelter program incorrectly. The Partnership for the Homeless, a private multidenominational coalition, provides food and operating assistance. New York City government provides beds, linen and transportation.
LEAD: The East Wing is in a swivet over Raisa Gorbachev - again.
LEAD: Kraft Inc., said yesterday that it planned to sell its Duracell Inc. battery division in order to focus more heavily on its core food businesses.
LEAD: One person was killed and two others were seriously injured in a fire that swept through a three-story house in Queens late last night, the authorities said.

LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association will set up a $9 million scholarship fund for athletes who did not graduate but decided later to return to school, according to Dick Schultz, the executive director of the N.C.A.A.

LEAD: George Steinbrenner, once the prime pursuer of star free agents, passed up the chance to sign Jack Morris a year ago, but the Yankees' owner may have different thoughts about another free-agent pitcher this year.

LEAD: In an unusual, concerted effort to stabilize the dollar and promote economic growth, West Germany's central bank cut its most important lending rate today, and hours later six other European central banks cut their rates.

LEAD: The road to Shearson Lehman Brothers' acquisition of the E. F. Hutton Group was surprisingly risky, according to a number of people close to the marathon negotiations. Some senior Hutton officials feared at one point that, if no bidder succeeded, the firm could face a possible exodus of employees, according to the sources.
LEAD: Up to 31 railroad cars overturned near here, and a leak of a chemical from a derailed tanker prompted the evacuation of 900 residents, officials said today. No injuries were reported.
LEAD: Rebellious Cuban prisoners ended an 11-day uprising at the Federal penitentiary here early this morning and began freeing their 89 hostages.

LEAD: In the dangerous world of the decoy police officer -in which officers, seeking to attract muggers, disguise themselves as helpless old ladies or derelicts sleeping in the subway - there have been heroes and heroines. And there have also been casualties.

LEAD: The New York Legislature was in a punitive mood, and responding to public outrage over a few brutal subway crimes committed by teen-agers barely old enough to be in high school, when it passed a law subjecting those as young as 13 years old to prosecution as adults.

LEAD: Ben W. Lewis, Avery professor emeritus of economics at Oberlin College, died Tuesday of a heart attack in Cleveland. Professor Lewis, an economist in the Roosevelt Administration, was 87 years old.

LEAD: Minutes after she arrived home from work today, Zel Benton bundled up her three children and they all climbed into the family van. On the 15-minute drive to the Federal prison where her husband, Charles, was being held hostage for the 11th day, she wondered if this was the day she had been waiting for.
LEAD: Representative Richard A. Gephardt has called for legislation forcing businesses to offer health insurance to their employees, ''just as they must now provide a minimum wage.''

LEAD: As Mikhail S. Gorbachev prepares for his first visit to Washington next week, his vision of America seems out of sync with the views of an increasing number of his countrymen.
LEAD: A measure that would allow artists to share in the increased prices of their works every time they were resold was endorsed today by artists as an appropriate reward for their contributions.
LEAD: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation was the volume leader on the New York Stock Exchange today with more than 44 million shares traded, one of the busiest days ever for a single stock.

LEAD: The John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard Univesity announced today that the Central Intelligence Agency had provided $400,000 for a three-year program of research and training on intelligence assessment and policy.

LEAD: Surely, the residents of Lake Wobegon, Minn. (alt. 1,418, pop. 942) still head home each day at the 6 P.M. sounding of the town fire alarm for heaping plates of tuna hotdish with cream of mushroom soup.

LEAD: A puzzle ran through the recent controversies over President Reagan's first two candidates for the Supreme Court vacancy. Robert Bork, whose fight lasted four months, and Douglas Ginsburg, who withdrew a few days after being chosen, are judges on the prestigious United States Court of Appeals in Washington, only one step below.
LEAD: The Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, apparently concerned about how the summit is going to play in Siberia, wants a little help from his hosts.

LEAD: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, said yesterday that he would take charge of the investigation into suspected false arrests by officers of the New York City Transit Police Department.

LEAD: The number of states mandating education about AIDS in the public schools has tripled in the last six months, with 17 states and the District of Columbia now requiring such instruction, the National Association of State Boards of Education said today.
LEAD: Carlyle E. Maw, a former chief legal adviser and Under Secretary of State in the State Department, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 84 years old.

LEAD: The flight engineers union has reached a contract agreement with Pan American World Airways, giving the company concessions of $24.8 million for each of the three years of the contract, the union said yesterday.
LEAD: Sales of American-made cars and light trucks rose 9.9 percent in the last 10 days of November, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

LEAD: That Army versus Navy ranks as an event rather than just another football game is more evident than ever this year. Tomorrow's meeting at Veterans Stadium in Philadelphia has been sold out for a month, although the game matches teams that between them have won only 6 times in 20 opportunities.
LEAD: If someone sat behind a player and recorded the length of time he took to play each card, a graph of the results would provide a good indication of his level of ability.

LEAD: For years, executives at Wall Street's big retail brokerages have worked at creating a financial powerhouse that can create imaginative deals with one hand and market them far and wide with the other.
LEAD: New York City transit police officers defended their force yesterday amid growing charges that fellow officers had made dubious arrests on subway trains and platforms in recent years.

LEAD: Katherine Ruth Erskine, a freelance writer, and Dale Aubrey Jenkins, an executive vice president of the Urban Group, a New York real-estate development company, were married last evening at the Beekman Tower in New York by Judge Elaine Slobod of the Family Court of Orange County.

LEAD: Alexander M. Haig Jr. declared yesterday that the Soviet Union was willing to negotiate a reduction in nuclear arms because it was ''in trouble economically, technologically, ideologically and demographically.''

LEAD: Interest rates on commitments for fixed-rate and adjustable mortgages fell between early October and early November, the first drop since August, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday, The drop in mortgage rates mirrored the drop in interest rates in general after October's stock market collapse.
LEAD: Secre-tary General Javier Perez de Cuellar appealed today formore than $85 mil-lion in emergency aid to save 250,000 families facing starvation, poverty and disease in Lebanon.
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has impressed the American public, winning twice as many favorable opinions as negative ones, and has persuaded a solid majority that he is opening up the Soviet system.

LEAD: The Museum of Modern Art and some 200 of its curatorial and administrative employees reached agreement on a new three-year contract this week.

LEAD: Jay Kriegel, a longtime associate of CBS Inc.'s chief executive, Laurence A. Tisch, has been named senior vice president in charge of external relations and governmental affairs. LEAD: Can it be mere coincidence? That is the question here.

LEAD: Under the auspices of Women for a Meaningful Summit, a group of political women will converge in the capital this weekend for a host of activities.

LEAD: WEST GERMANY's Government and its central bank, the Bundesbank, are at last moving to stimulate the national economy. But the question remains whether the actions proposed are too little, too late and too grudging to restore confidence that international cooperation can restore stability to exchange rates and prevent a deterioration of the world economy.

LEAD: President Reagan, backing away from his own previous statements on what he called ''the Iran-contra so-called affair,'' said today that it was not a scandal, ''and never at any time did we view this as trading weapons for hostages.''
LEAD: Show your visitors you don't have to be Broadway bound or in bondage to a bank to enjoy a New York musical.

LEAD: The Strategic Air Command has suspended low-level flights for the new B-1 bomber, limiting the training of crews for their main mission of low-level bombing, according to officers at the command's headquarters in Omaha.

LEAD: A music critic's guests should expect long, late, peripatetic evenings. While the sun's up, they're on their own - although they should savor the sonic smorgasbord that is New York, from the white-noise barrage of the subways to the polyphony of languages and accents everywhere.
LEAD: Two neo-Nazis were each sentenced today to 150 years in prison for their roles in the slaying of a Denver radio host. They will be ineligible for parole for at least 50 years.
LEAD: The Senate Finance Committee today unanimously approved a $9 billion package of tax increases that would affect mainly businesses and higher-income Americans, but in relatively limited ways.
LEAD: * Working Woman magazine will increase its circulation rate base by 5.9 percent, to 900,000, and its rates by more than 11 percent, beginning with the March issue.
LEAD: Apparently, nothing works like home ice for the Devils. They returned to Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight after a long trip and defeated the St. Louis Blues, 4-2.

LEAD: Fred Lebow, the race director of the New York Marathon, announced yesterday that six runners in the race this year had been disqualified for cheating. Last year, 25 disqualifications were made, including one in which the men's second-place finisher, Antoni Niemczak of Poland, tested positive for use of steroids.

LEAD: The American political right has never found an arms control treaty it liked. Now it is marshaling forces for a Senate fight over the treaty eliminating Euromissiles that Mikhail Gorbachev and President Reagan plan to sign Tuesday.

LEAD: IT goes without saying that ''Student Confidential'' is bad, for it arrives by way of Troma Inc., the small company that has turned badness into an art form. Still, there are standards for everything, and this isn't the kind of bad film that's any fun.
LEAD: Nearly six weeks after it began presenting evidence, the prosecution rested its case today in the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver, the former White House deputy chief of staff.

LEAD: The House of Representatives approved a $587 billion spending bill for 1988 today that requires $7.6 billion in cuts agreed to in the deficit-reducing plan reached last month by Congress and the White House.

LEAD: David S. Ruder, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, today became the only head of a major financial regulatory agency to withhold support from efforts in Congress to repeal the Glass-Steagall Act.

LEAD: The hardy Asian tiger mosquito, an aggressive biter and a carrier of disease, has spread to 17 states since arriving in Houston aboard used tire casings two years ago, prompting new Federal inspections of used tire imports, health officials said today.
LEAD: Nascar stock-car drivers will be involved in a drug-testing program in 1988, according to an announcement yesterday by Bill France Jr., the organization's president.

LEAD: Richard Goode will give another in-stallment in his continuing perform-ances of the complete Beethoven piano sonatas Sunday at 3 P.M. at the 92d Street Y (at Lexington Avenue). Tickets are $12.50. Information: 996-1100.

LEAD: WHEN I spent a winter seven years ago in the ancient university city of Salamanca, Spain, I passed many evenings in a cluttered and boisterous little taverna called Covechuela. My affection for this place had little to do with the food, which was satisfying but hardly memorable. What attracted me were the warmth and ebullience of the place and the puckish owner, whose nightly performance included picking up coins left as tips, flipping them ceiling high, then catching them in his shirt pocket.

LEAD: He isn't a boy wonder any more, flashing the smile that earned the affection of the fans at Wimbledon in 1985 when he won the biggest tournament of all on the strength of a game called serve and swagger. Tennis has become more like a job than a game for Boris Becker, and like everyone else in the work force, there are some days when he would prefer to stay in bed.

LEAD: Todd Alexander scored 20 of his 24 points in the second half tonight to help Southern Methodist upset Florida, 82-76.
LEAD: The chairman of the Democratic National Committee is urging his party to write a short 1988 platform instead of a long one filled with promises to special interest groups.
LEAD: Everything is coming up Russian these days in Washington.
LEAD: Juan Alberto Melgar Castro, a general who served four years as Honduras's chief of state, died of a heart attack Wednesday. He was 52 years old.

LEAD: Everyone loves to make jokes about the stupendous history of corruption in Hudson County. Say what you want, people here know how to welcome home a politician from prison.

LEAD: Seventeen years after passage of the Clean Air Act, 80 million Americans still live with unhealthy amounts of smog and ozone. LEAD: THIRTEEN centuries have elapsed since the Islamic invasion of North Africa obliterated ancient Carthage. But reminders of the striking blend of artistic genius and institutional cruelty that characterized the Carthaginians have survived, and a new exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History brings both the beauty and the horror of Carthage into sharp focus.

LEAD: ''THE MAGIC OF KATHERINE DUNHAM'' is exactly that. One salutes the vision of Alvin Ailey for undertaking and realizing as major a project as this fantastically staged full-evening program of sassy, colorful and vibrant revivals by America's most famous black dance pioneer.
LEAD: New York City officials said yesterday that they were close to an agreement with NBC on a plan to keep the network from leaving its headquarters in Rockefeller Center.

LEAD: The coordinated cuts in European interest rates today could dissuade the markets from pushing the dollar down for a while. Beyond that, the cuts fulfill a major condition that the Reagan Administration had set for doing more on its own to stabilize the dollar.

LEAD: If you still have any doubts, misconceptions or illusions about what Mikhail Gorbachev wants and plans for the Soviet Union, don't blame him. He has laid it out as clearly as anybody has the right to expect.

LEAD: Construction shortcuts contributed to the bridge collapse on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway that killed 10 people last April, New York State's final report on the disaster stated today. The report confirmed earlier findings that erosion around the base of one of the bridge's piers had led to the collapse.
LEAD: The Buffalo Bills' shutout of the Miami Dolphins and Dan Marino last Sunday has little meaning for the Jets in their rehearsals this week, said Bud Carson, the Jets' defensive coordinator.

LEAD: Using pulses of light lasting only one-millionth of one-billionth of a second, scientists at the California Institute of Technology have invented an instrument to detect the subtle sequences of events that occur in some ultra-fast chemical reactions.

LEAD: Like every other great city, New York yields up its most picturesque moments slowly. An odd corner; a patch of beauty where you don't expect it; a certain slant of light. . . . But I think people should be left to find out such things for themselves.
LEAD: President Reagan, who has not given a formal endorsement to Vice President Bush's campaign for the White House, today gave him a firm political pat on the back.

LEAD: SOME of the most touching images now on view in New York are in a small format and a small place (the Kevorkian Gallery in the Islamic section of the Metropolitan Museum of Art). Initiated by a royal personage who was roughly the contemporary of Shakespeare and Caravaggio, they were admired and collected by people as various as Rembrandt, the Empress Maria Theresa of Austria and William Morris, the English poet, painter and all-purpose designer.

LEAD: The Emerson String Quartet will perform works by Mendelssohn and Beethoven tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Tickets are $14. Information: 570-3949.

LEAD: Wendy Lee Gramm, one of the Reagan Administration's most vigorous deregulators, has been selected to head the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the White House announced yesterday.

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 411 money market mutual funds decreased $237.2 million, to $261.85 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. LEAD: Bad hands won out over bad shooting tonight as the Phoenix Suns gained a 120-114 victory over the Knicks at Veterans Memorial Coliseum.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, whose campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination has been built around an appeal to the mainstream of American politics, has asked the nation's leading Socialist organization not to endorse his candidacy at their convention this weekend.

LEAD: The thing to do in New York at Christmas is to walk, anywhere in Manhattan where you can see the lights. This is the truly extraordinary thing about the city now - the way in which the energy of New York becomes, suddenly, frozen in millions of tiny points of perfect light. The light of Christmas in New York is different from the light of any other time, or of any other place; it is more precise, more delicate, at once overpowering in its sweep and gentle in the way it touches the eye.

LEAD: A Miami man described by Federal officials as the largest arms dealer in the United States was indicted Wednesday on charges that he conspired to smuggle 103 combat helicopters armed with wire-guided TOW missiles to Iraq.

LEAD: FORTY years ago, Norma, Lal and Mike Waterson would spend their evenings in their parlor in Yorkshire, England, singing along with their grandmother - reprising ballads, hunting songs, hymns and carols that their grandmother probably sang with her parents. One family member would take up the tune; the rest would join in, and if the melody reached too high or too low, they'd choose a harmony note instead.
LEAD: The bruised and battered Nets, losers of 7 consecutive games by a total of 111 points and in need of help at several positions, yesterday signed Johnny Moore, a free-agent guard.

LEAD: IN the history of the postwar avant-garde, the name Black Mountain College crops up repeatedly, framed in the golden glow of legend. The list of artists and writers who as students and teachers entered into the school's short, experimental existence is studded with impressive names. Founded in 1933 in the hills outside Asheville, N.C., by a group of disenchanted faculty members from Rollins College in Florida, Black Mountain placed the arts and, in its first years, especially the visual arts, at the center of its curriculum.

LEAD: Overturned cars lay in a heap after train derailed Wednesday near Charleston. About 900 people within a one-mile radius had to leave their homes because a chemical, acetic anhydride, a combustible corrosive, was leaking from an tanker car. No injuries were reported. (AP)

LEAD: From more than six dozen books initially considered, the editors of The Book Review have chosen 16 for this, the 20th list of best books of the year. LEAD: One of Yale University's brightest lights apparently had some rather dark thoughts as a young man. Paul de Man, who was Yale's Sterling Professor of Humanities at the time of his death in 1983, wrote for an anti-Semitic, pro-Nazi newspaper in Belgium during World War II, a Belgian researcher has discovered.
LEAD: ''Why Wed?'' I've not yet skimmed the article, but your cover picture says it all. Who is going to help this guy up off the floor, come, say, his 60th birthday? SALLY T. PETITE Bronxville, N.Y.

LEAD: THE SMALL OFFICE IS CROWDED: 9 OR 10 women wait for their names to be called. After signing in, I stand by the desk and wait like the rest. The silence is communal - not uneasy. ''What stage of your cycle are you at?'' I ask a woman about 35 - my age. Under other conditions this question would have prompted her to move away from me shaking her head, certain I was one of the many odd characters a large metropolitan city regularly serves up.

LEAD: OVER the last few years, liberals and conservatives have forged a remarkable consensus on the need to help low-income families move from welfare rolls to payrolls, from dependency to productive labor. But the consensus is sometimes hard to discern in the bitter partisan wrangling over details of the complex welfare bills now before

LEAD: THE mass filling the picture is one of those Southwestern mesas that look like fossilized architecture. A reproduction of a 1978 black-and-white photograph by Michael Smith, it could be an Abstract Expressionist image, and, in a way, owes its existence to that movement in art. ''Toroweap, Arizona,'' as it's called, is one of the 67 landscapes by 56 photographers that make up ''Views and Visions,'' the present attraction at the Carlson Gallery at the University of Bridgeport.

LEAD: Transcontinental airplane trips provide ''wonderful work time'' for running the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, according to Michael S. Dukakis, the only sitting Governor in the Presidential race.
LEAD: The nation's community colleges are locked in a bitter dispute with an agency that accredits business schools over the issue of transferring credits from the two-year colleges.
LEAD: Thirty black owners and operators of McDonald's fast-food franchises across the country have contributed $22,500 to the Democratic Presidential campaign of the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

LEAD: To the Editor: We read the letters concerning the accommodations at the Fattoria La Loggia in Tuscany and must take exception to their general negative tenor. As one of the letter writers also did, we (six adults) arrived at the Fattoria La Loggia on July 25 for a one-week stay.
LEAD: Together, President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, have fundamentally altered the way foreign policy issues will be framed in the 1988 Presidential campaign.

LEAD: AFTER WOODY ALLEN WATCHED the first version of ''September,'' his new film opening Dec. 18, he went out and filmed it all over again - rethought, rewritten and, because time, tide and actors wait for no man, substantially recast.

LEAD: Trip Gabriel writes of men's ambivalence about marriage as though it were something new. The icon of American culture is the lonesome cowboy, epitomized by Shane. These single men do the heroic deeds that married men cannot. How could any man be a product of this culture and not be ambivalent about marriage?

LEAD: THE FIRST TIME I HEARD THE WORD ''glasnost'' from a Soviet official was last October, on a flight from Reykjavik to New York after the Reagan-Gorbachev summit meeting. Together with other Soviet emigres, I had gone to Iceland to protest human rights violations in Russia. On the flight back, I found myself seated near Yuri Dubinin, the Soviet Ambassador to the United States, a veteran diplomat who had never seen a live dissident so close.

LEAD: A SURVEY of holiday offerings in craft shops indicates concentrations here and there on single items such as chairs, teapots or kaleidoscopes, but otherwise broad selections of work in all media.

LEAD: FILES for smoothing and shaping metal and wood are useful and inexpensive additions to any do-it-yourselfer's tool kit. However, files are categorized by an obscure terminology that can make choosing one perplexing.
LEAD: RARE ARTHUR MILLER

LEAD: THERE is no reason in principle to object to hybrid openings, but the elements really have to go together. One of the best known is the Gruenfeld Defense, which, in essence, is a Queen's Gambit combined with a fianchetto of the black KB.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: No, ''The Color Purple'' which has its cable premiere this week, didn't win a Pulitzer Prize. That accolade went in 1983 to the Alice Walker novel that formed the basis for the 1985 movie directed by Steven Spielberg. Nor did ''The Color Purple'' - to be shown on WHT Sunday at 8 P.M. and Friday at 9 and on HBO on Saturday at 8 P.M.

LEAD: Rose Mary Denman, who was suspended from her duties as a minister in the United Methodist Church when she acknowledged she was a lesbian, has been accepted as a minister in the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship.

LEAD: POLITICIANS habitually have problems squaring high moral principles with reality - most painfully when they have to deal with fellow citizens who have been kidnaped by terrorists. In an age dominated by the televised image, the hostage becomes compellingly human in his helplessness, generating pressure for action.

LEAD: Carolyn Wendell Wheller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry S. Wheller Jr. of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills, N.J., to Peter Joseph Deluca, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pete C. Deluca of Trinidad, Colo. The Rev. David B. Earnest officiated.

LEAD: IN RICHARD STRAUSS'S OPERA ''Die Frau ohne Schatten,'' a mythical emperor turns slowly to stone because his wife can't bear children, a symbol (in Hugo von Hofmannsthal's brilliant, if now rather sexist, libretto) of her inability to love. Looking at the current state of rock-and-roll, one wonders if something similar isn't happening.

LEAD: New York farmers received a record net income of $598 million in 1986, up 33 percent from the year before, and the highest profit ever reported in the nearly 50 years that records have been kept, according to agricultural statistics issued this week here and in Washington.

LEAD: MICHAEL BLUM, a 31-year-old New York-born pianist who has studied at the Juilliard School, began his recital on Thursday evening in Merkin Concert Hall with his best work - four of Mendelssohn's ''Songs Without Words'' shaped in limpid, supple phrases and colored by a soft, shimmery tone.

LEAD: Susan Rachel Webber, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Banice M. Webber of Providence, R.I., was married there last evening to James Gregory Gatto, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Gatto of Brooklyn. Rabbi Leslie Gutterman officiated at Temple Beth-El.
LEAD: Holmes is too old to fight with his wife, let alone Mike Tyson. This will be a horrible fight. The winner of this fight will be the promoter! ROBERT MAYE The Bronx
LEAD: THE view up and down the broad numbered avenues of New York's Upper East Side is changing, and not everyone in the old neighborhood approves.
LEAD: OF all the challenges in marriage, starting a business together surely ranks as one of the trickiest. All the stresses entrepreneurs face, like the absence of a regular paycheck, are doubled.

LEAD: THE Reagan Administration is supporting the Salvadoran Government in its effort to prosecute rightist political leader Roberto d'Aubuisson, whom President Jose Napoleon Duarte has accused of being involved in the murder of the Roman Catholic Archbishop here in 1980.

LEAD: THE STORY OF THE DAL-kon Shield is a story of loss and suffering and bitterness and pain. It is a story of individual heartbreak and corporate defeat. And it is a story that points up the difference between science and law.

LEAD: WHY mount a stage adaptation of a screen classic that owed its nightmare quality to startling backdrops, ominous lighting and crafty camera angles? Susan Mosakowski's 50-minute version of ''The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari,'' the 1919 spooker about the malevolent hypnotist and the somnambulist he sends forth from his coffin to murder townsfolk, affords no satisfying explanation.
LEAD: The city's firefighters union threatened to run advertisements aimed at scaring tourists away until the city said it planned to hire 38 additional firefighters.
LEAD: THE HOUSE DEMOCRATIC BILL Training.

LEAD: The heirs of elderly Wisconsin residents who needed county welfare money in the Great Depression for a 90-cent electric bill or a $1.50 pair of shoes may get a surprise after their relatives die.

LEAD: THE dog got sick in the living room. My husband and son were rushing to catch an early train. But it was a holiday for me. I would clean up, I told them, not knowing exactly where to begin. ''Have a good day,'' my son said, averting his glance from the mess. ''You must be kidding!'' I cried. ''Well, have a better day,'' he offered.

LEAD: The engagement of Mary Elizabeth Horan, a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at George Washington University, and Robert Forrest Lutz, the vice president in charge of the Los Angeles institutional equity office for Prudential-Bache Securities, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John William Horan of Fairfield, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be.
LEAD: THE capitalist world last week continued to present a bewildering split-level scene.

LEAD: THE MORE EXPENSIVE THE antique, the faster its sale. Such has been the supply-and-demand rule of home furnishings in recent years. Indeed, the lust for a set of graceful Regency chairs, a beautifully inlaid cabinet or a breakfront crafted by an 18th-century furniture maker became as much a status symbol as a silver Porsche or a gold-faced Rolex watch.

LEAD: My old interlocutor Georgi Arbatov, shunted aside as Head Flack by Valentin Falin (the Ethnic Bomber) and his Novosti aide, Gennadi Gerasimov (my look-alike), probably has some summit questions on his mind that I am free to answer.

LEAD: The story goes that when Eleanor Blair was about to give birth to her sixth child, her husband dropped her off at the hospital in Cornwall, N.Y., and proceeded to the skating meet where another of their children was competing.

LEAD: The Soviet Union's highest-ranking judge urged better legal defense for citizens, less government interference in the judicial process and shorter pretrial detention periods, in an interview published today.

LEAD: Julia Barnett Just and Michael Milsner Azerrad plan to be married May 21, the parents of the bride-to-be, Ward Swift Just of Paris and Vineyard Haven, Mass., and Mrs. Robert Turrell Bower of Washington and Quogue, L.I., have announced. Mr. Azerrad is the son of Joel Azerrad of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and Ruth Mils ner of San

LEAD: In the same issue, a review of ''And the Band Played On: Politics, People, and the AIDS Epidemic,'' by Randy Shilts, misidentified the C.D.C., which since 1980 has been known as the Centers for Disease Control.

LEAD: REVIVALS THAT DRASTICALLY ALTER THINK-ing about a composer and his work are not common, but they do happen. The most famous such event in musical history took place in 1829, when a 20-year-old named Felix Mendelssohn brought the ''St. Matthew Passion'' out of obscurity by conducting the first performance since Bach's death 79 years earlier.

LEAD: Maura Rafferty, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael G. Rafferty Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Christopher H. Craig, the son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Clifford Craig of Cincinnati, plan to marry in July, the parents of the future bride have announced.

LEAD: BEFORE the Tax Reform Act of 1986, many high-bracket investors bought tax shelters. They could use the losses from these deals to offset earned income, or income from such traditional investments as stocks and bonds. But the new law imposed tough restrictions on shelters, and did so retroactively.

LEAD: A BOAT OFF THE COAST By Stephen Dobyns. 260 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

LEAD: At the chapel of St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I., Carmen Knoepffler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alberto Knoepffler of Madrid, was married yesterday to Peter Kellogg Ingerman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Ingerman of Northport, L.I. The Rev. Charles A. Ribaudo performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Holmes, in need of neither money nor adulation, will be allowed to place his future health on the table and roll the dice. Does not the real sickness lie in those who would encourage and permit this obscenity as well as those who would, out of morbid curiosity, observe it? LAWRENCE W. YOUNG

LEAD: Gov. Bill Clements sharply criticized the Texas Supreme Court Friday, saying its failure to hear an appeal on a $10.3 billion judgment against Texaco had eroded business confidence in the state.

LEAD: To the Editor: After reading the letters about Fattoria La Loggia, I wish to relate our experience. We were more fortunate than those who visited in June. We arrived on Sept. 26 and were housed in a fairly comfortable apartment on the grounds of La Loggia, but we could see that the place in no way resembled Mary Davis Suro's description.
LEAD: THE Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater was in top form on Friday night at the City Center Theater when it gave this season's first performances of three works from its repertory.
LEAD: Hong Sook Ja, the first woman to run for the South Korean presidency, dropped out of the race today and threw her support to an opposition leader, Kim Young Sam.

LEAD: FROM Suffield to Guilford, from Greenwich to Putnam, new condominiums and commercial developments are cropping up, along Main Streets and tucked away in suburban and rural corners. Now, one of the newest developments is taking on quite a different - and older - look.

LEAD: The voice reigns in South African popular music. Voices join in ringing harmonies, overlap in syncopations, swoop into falsetto or glide through melodies; the clicks that are part of the Zulu language turn into percussion. This week offers two chances to hear South African vocalizing - one from a choir that has won superstardom in South
LEAD: Q. The walls in my living room are covered with dark wood panels, and I want to paint them a light color. What should I do to paint these walls without damaging the wood?

LEAD: The Frank Sinatra and Liza Minnelli concert that was scheduled for Friday night at the Brendan Byrne Arena at the Meadowlands in New Jersey was canceled and rescheduled for 8 o'clock tonight. The Friday concert was canceled because the music for Mr. Sinatra's orchestra was lost in transit from Los Angeles.
LEAD: VICTOR BORGE Borge Productions 120 minutes. $49.95. 1-800-666-8742.

LEAD: THE Council on Compulsive Gambling of New Jersey has reported that 53 percent of callers to its ''hot line'' (800) GAMBLER had problems with casino gambling and that the average gambler was a 34-year-old married male with two children.
LEAD: Seventeen months ago, Glenn Smith was a person with AIDS who needed a home, and Madge Lewis was a person with a home who wanted to help.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Stuart Teitz of Denver have announced the engagement of their daughter Rebecca Eve Teitz to James Curtis Ackerman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton S. Ackerman of Oradell, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: I was reading Trip Gabriel's article alone in the kitchen, while my husband (of 29 years) was in the adjacent TV room, watching his sixth hour of football. I wonder why those bachelors who were interviewed believe they must relinquish their cherished adolescence the moment they say ''I do.'' Any of them in need of reassurance is welcome to spend a Sunday at our house from now until the Super Bowl.

LEAD: Much was made of the willingness, or lack thereof, of men to commit to marriage. But to what would they be committing? Marriage in the 1980's is not the stable, lifelong institution it once was. SIMON SPIVACK, M.D. Worcester, Mass.
LEAD: This list of paperbacks is a selection from the New & Noteworthy column since the December 1986 Christmas issue. It includes novels, stories, biography, memoirs, history, essays and science.

LEAD: THE magnolia was getting ready to bloom back in my Philadelphia garden and I was questioning my sanity. Why was I was trekking into subarctic conditions to spend a week skiing in the highest and most remote private guest ranch in the Wyoming Rockies? I and my intrepid party of seven knew we would be cut off from civilization, deep-frozen, virtually snowbound.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH she has been working in the area just six weeks, Pearl Dowell has become accustomed to the cars coming and going near the Southfield Village complex in Stamford. She is also aware of why they come: to buy drugs.

LEAD: Britain's best-known architecture critic, Prince Charles, has touched off a spirited public debate about modern buildings and royal privilege with a stinging attack this week on property development.
LEAD: There is an exception to every rule, and yesterday, tennis fans at Madison Square Garden discovered that sometimes a match can be over before it is over.
LEAD: Four parents have sued three liquor distillers, three beer breweries and a wine cooler company, saying their children's birth defects stem from the mothers' drinking while pregnant.

LEAD: THE letter to the Long Island editor on Nov. 15 by John M. Geraghty Jr., referring to the article I wrote, ''The Population Bomb Is Still Ticking'' [ Opinion Page, Oct. 25 ] , calls for this response, as he raises every issue dear to the hearts of those who feel threatened by the mildest suggestion of population control.

LEAD: At Christmastime every story deserves a happy ending. If only the Three Sisters had moved to Moscow and gone dancing with the Brothers Karamazov. What if Ahab married Hester Prynne and gave up the seafaring life? When The Book Review asked a number of writers what literary endings they would change, heroines were saved from death and despair, underdogs turned into heroes.
LEAD: Roberta E. Zlokower, a teacher, and Robert J. Wolpert, a corporate lawyer, were married last evening at the Parker Meridien in New York by Rabbi Chaim Etrog.

LEAD: COOKBOOKS tend to cluster. Several along similar themes are published each season, either reflecting current tastes or predicting a trend. This year the cooking of countries bordering the Mediterranean seems to dominate the lists. The current passion for olive oil, vegetables and pasta, not only for flavor but for health, may be a factor.
LEAD: YOU would like to have a travel agent help you plan a good vacation. Or, conversely, you would like to get a better travel agent than the one you have. What are criteria for selection?

LEAD: THE ''not in my backyard syndrome'' has been recently felt by a group of Terryville and Port Jefferson Station residents, whose neighborhood is the proposed location for a crisis nursery - for infants and small children at risk of being abused by their parents.
LEAD: LYME DISEASE is not being treated in the press and by part of the medical profession as the severe affliction it can be.

LEAD: An international conference marking the 75th anniversary of Africa's oldest national liberation movement, the outlawed African National Congress of South Africa, concluded here Friday with worldwide pledges of solidarity but little optimism that the end of apartheid was at hand.
LEAD: The Federal Government should not support efforts to allow homosexuals to adopt children, a Presidential advisory group says.

LEAD: If the zoning rules do not permit a taller building, the answer must be to dig deeper for space, and that is what the owners of the old St. Marks Theater building have done at Second Avenue and St. Marks Place in Manhattan.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Swibold of North Canton, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Katharine Margaret Swibold, to Jordan David Becker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth B. Becker of New City, N.Y.

LEAD: An article from San Salvador on Nov. 5 about steps by Central American governments to comply with a regional peace agreement discussed the release of political prisoners in Nicaragua. The issue was also described in a chart on Nov. 7 and an article in The Week in Review on Nov. 8.
LEAD: Felix Haurowitz, a distinguished professor emeritus of chemistry at Indiana University who made several key discoveries relating to hemoglobin in blood, died Wednesday. He was 91 years old.
LEAD: The underground link between France and England is about to become a reality (Works in Progress: ''The Big Dig,'' Nov. 8).
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 17 food establishments cited for violating the health code.
LEAD: THE city's public schools are in crisis. The number of dropouts is alarming, but the authorities don't even know what the actual numbers are.

LEAD: WHEN a screaming group of white teen-agers confronted three black men in Howard Beach, Queens, last December, it was the start of one of the most racially charged episodes in New York City in years. But the murder trial that began Sept. 8, now nearing its end, does more than document the troubled state of race relations in the nation's largest city.
LEAD: The money was blowing in the wind as part of a bank robber's booty sailed off into a stiff breeze, only to be grabbed by eager bystanders and even more eager police officers.

LEAD: Tim Brown, the flashy Notre Dame flanker and kick-return specialist, won the 1987 Heisman Trophy as the nation's outstanding college football player yesterday, eclipsing his chief rival, Don McPherson, the quarterback who led Syracuse to its first undefeated regular season in 28 years.

LEAD: ON the surface, dance by Pooh Kaye often appears anarchistic or even slyly animalistic. But Ms. Kaye has the trained eye of an artist and much of her work, though it spills out across the stage with the teeming impulse of life itself, is extremely controlled and self-aware. And art and artlessness exerted quite a contrary pull in dances performed by Ms.

LEAD: I read with mixed emotions Patricia Allaire's ''Mountain Hikes, Now'' [ Topics, Opinion Page, Nov. 1 ] . This was an account of how she and her son hiked Crane Mountain near her Adirondack cabin.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Reginald F. Pierce Jr. of Etna, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Steinkamp Pierce to Winslow Drury Beguelin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dayton Beguelin of Locust, N.J.
LEAD: Several New Jersey communities that have long been embarrassed by having state prisons named after them were given something this week that they have long wanted - anonymity.

LEAD: The Nature Conservancy, a nonprofit environmental protection group, plans to acquire and protect about 6,700 acres of marshes, bogs, forests, and other ecologically significant land along the Connecticut River in four states.

LEAD: IT'S deja vu time; a new Chinese restaurant, Peking Dynasty, has opened on Merrick Road in Wantagh. This restaurant, like other recent Chinese arrivals, is in the mold, with the standard color scheme of pink, rose, plum, burgundy, mauve and gray. In bygone days, Chinese restaurants were red and gold and sported dragons and lanterns.

LEAD: THE Walter Camp Football Foundation yesterday named Dick MacPherson, who guided Syracuse to an 11-0 record, as the coach of the year. . . . The Detroit Tigers traded Dan Petry, who had a 9-7 record last season, to the California Angels for Gary Pettis, an outfielder who hit .208. . . . LaMarr Hoyt, the pitcher seeking to return to the major leagues with the Chicago White Sox, must answer Federal charges alleging he violated probation by testing positive for cocaine use, according to a report in The San Diego Union.

LEAD: THE 1919 GERMAN FILM CLASSIC ''The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari'' has been a favorite of Film 101 courses for a variety of reasons. Although its validity as a harbinger of the moral climate that permitted Hitler's rise to power has been debated, its significance for the cinema as a bold stylistic departure into a realm of fantasy and expression has remained indisputable.

LEAD: LEONARD J. BRUCKMAN is the head of the air quality unit of the State Department of Environmental Protection. His department has been responding in recent weeks to Federal criticism of the ozone level in the state, which exceeds the 0.12 parts per million standard set in the 1970's.
LEAD: ''THIS baby just wasn't meant to be,'' a friend told me, by way of comfort, when the pregnancy dragged to its horrible four-and-a-half-month conclusion.
LEAD: One season later, in separate high-intensity games before the second largest regular-season college basketball crowd ever, the lives of David Rivers and Keith Smart took different turns today.

LEAD: Kudos to Louis Auchincloss for celebrating the brilliant but rarely read William Gaddis in his article ''Recognizing Gaddis'' (Nov. 15). I would like to add further praise by pointing out the enormous influence that Gaddis's 1955 novel ''The Recognitions'' had on the ''black-humor'' and fabulist-oriented writers of the 1960's, specifically Thomas Pynchon.

LEAD: Yearlong celebrations of King Bhumibol Adulyadej's 60th birthday culminated in Thailand today with Buddhist rites, colorful processions and a claim of a world record for voluntary vasectomies. A spokesman for the Population and Community Development Association said 1,214 men were vasectomized free of charge in an annual event held on the King's birthday.
LEAD: Larry Holmes is not too old to fight. He is too old to win, especially against a man of the caliber of Mike Tyson. OWEN P. ROBINSON Madison, N.J.

LEAD: DEFORE exploring the strange history of the diagramed deal, let us consider it as a play-or-defend challenge. If a spade is led against four hearts, would you choose to play or defend? Would your answer be different if one of West's small clubs was traded for one of East's small spades?

LEAD: IN one country, plans are afoot to close unprofitable steel mills and eliminate thousands of jobs. In another, a Government-decreed belt-tightening drove thousands of workers into the streets, where they ransacked a city hall. In a third, voters rejected an economic austerity program.

LEAD: Holiday time often brings out creative talents. With each year, the traditions become more firmly rooted and the family looks forward to to a display of seasonaltrimmings. The three designs shown here are easy to duplicate and are made from live plant materials. Two of them are based on influences from Victorian England and are enriched by embellishments from this country.
LEAD: The leaders of the 12-nation European Community failed tonight to agree on a major overhaul of the organization's finances to ease its transition to a frontier-free trading bloc by 1992.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Daniel J. Linhart of Winter Park, Fla., and Dr. Robert S. Kennedy of Cambridge, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Carole Lesley Kennedy to William Peter Shea, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Shea of Glen Head, L.I.

LEAD: O.T.N.M. (Over-Thirty-Never-Married) may soon become the favored code in singles ads, thanks to the exposure given this group by Trip Gabriel in his article ''Why Wed? The Ambivalent American Bachelor'' (Nov. 15).

LEAD: Larry Holmes, at 38 years of age, is not too old to fight. Like most older athletes, he can compensate for that lost step, that slower trigger in his reflexes. Put him in with most of the heavyweights of today and he'll have his way. However, he is too old - and worse yet, has been inactive too long - to fight a young ogre like Mike Tyson.

LEAD: The stenographer who recorded the proceedings of a sexual misconduct trial has told an investigating judge that she did not see the trial judge humiliate the complainant by ordering her down on her hands and knees to re-enact an assault, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

LEAD: AT least one thing's right with this wicked old world. ''The Nutcracker'' has returned to the New York State Theater. On Thursday night the New York City Ballet danced this season's first performance of Tchaikovsky's eternally popular holiday ballet. Once again, George Balanchine's choreography conjured up a realm of enchantment.

LEAD: The South African Government has indicated that it may further restrict Govan A. Mbeki, the African National Congress veteran released from prison last month. The move dampened hopes that his jailed colleague, Nelson R. Mandela, the organization's best-known leader, might also be freed soon.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Franklin Kezer of Shrewsbury, N.J., and Bailey Island, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ann Bradley Kezer to Stephen Samuel Lazarus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Lazarus of Cincinnati.

LEAD: A high-stakes money pyramid called the airplane game involving hundreds of players here has crashed under the weight of criminal indictments. Seven players face criminal charges and 33 others are under court order to stop playing the game, Attorney General James Shannon said Tuesday.

LEAD: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants insists he is concerned only with the four games remaining in this losing season, starting with the 1 P.M. game today against the Philadelphia Eagles in Giants Stadium. He says he does not want to think about next year until this year is past.

LEAD: The largest commercial nuclear power plant in the United States was dedicated Friday by Energy Secretary John S. Herrington. Construction began in 1976 on the three-unit, 3,810-megawatt plant, and commercial generation began in January 1986. When the third unit comes on line next year, only the Paluel nuclear power plant in France and a plant near Leningrad in the Soviet Union will be capable of generating more power.

It might have received no more attention from us than any other shrub or tree, except that the old man always asked about it.

LEAD: COMMERCIAL TELEVISION ENTERTAINMENT is tumbling into a Vulgarity Sweepstakes. Today's viewers will find language and situations on their weekly series that would never have got past the ''program practices'' guards just five years ago. One major reason for the change is the expanding presence of cable television, where more permissive rules about content allow operators to carry uncensored theatrical-release films and stand-up comedy acts that revel in aggressive coarseness.

LEAD: The second summit meeting between President Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev ends in icy collapse without any agreement, not even on a date for the next summit. LEAD: Commentators on the marriage patterns of baby boomers persistently return to the single, comfortingly familiar assertion (revamped for the 1980's) that women want marriage, men avoid it. In fact, however, the rueful and somewhat bewildered discourse on this subject cuts across gender lines. Single women and men of this generation are saying remarkably similar things about the absence of marriage in their lives.

LEAD: Shearson bought Hutton for $962 million in a deal that will, by some measures, create the securities industry's largest firm. For example, the combined sales forces will number 12,300, about 800 more than at Merrill Lynch, the industry leader. LEAD: Attempting to put the ''crash'' in perspective, Paul Volcker states that ''the market went up 30 percent this year and it's gone back down 30 percent, to where it was at the beginning of the year.'' Unfortunately, as millions of investors will attest, a 30 percent gain followed by a 30 percent loss doesn't bring you back to where you started.

LEAD: IN THE BLITHELY, DANGEROUSLY NONCONFORM-ist household in which Bill Forsyth's superb new ''Housekeeping'' unfolds, maintaining order may be a matter of sweeping the floating debris into closets while the flood waters surge knee-high. Or it might mean letting Darwinism prevail among the houseplants.

LEAD: For 70 years, the poor, the hungry, the homeless, the troubled, the abandoned and the sick have come to the agencies and offices of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York looking for assistance. We have responded by offering food, shelter, clothing, medical care and services to meet immediate and long-term needs of individuals and families unable to cope on their own with the crisis of survival in the urban setting.

He has conducted ''Tristan'' many times, including performances in London at Covent Garden and in Berlin with the Berlin

LEAD: SAVE for the purist who insists on skiing the 16 miles, most wintertime visitors to Mount Assiniboine Lodge in the Canadian Rockies are whisked in by helicopter, as we were. The 15-minute ride from the muddy Mount Shark Heliport above Bryant Creek and over Assiniboine Pass was exhilarating. Suddenly there was a new world below with white snow interspersed with dark patches of larch, spruce and fir.
LEAD: SO many French restaurants, charcuteries and patisseries have opened in Greenwich in recent years that the town seems to be turning into a gustatory department of France.

LEAD: OUTSIDE THE LEC-ture hall, sunshine falls in dusty beams through the trees. It is a scene suffused with tradition, a mixture that is two parts dry leaves to one part poetry. Students lounge on the steps, books propped before them, just as Princeton students have sat on the same steps, reading the same books, for generations.
LEAD: AS Christmas approaches, bringing visions of warm, crackling fireplaces, the state's lumberjacks and landscapers are reporting a scarcity of firewood, the first, many say, in their memories.

LEAD: Rising to the Occasion In the presence of magnificence - in this case sunlight on a ruin - we sometimes become magnificent too. This is from ''A Glastonbury Romance'' by John Cowper Powys (Overlook).

Oberdorfer of the Federal District Court in Washington performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: ONE of the paradoxical things about art book publishing is that within a book that is almost too heavy to lift, let alone to carry, a slender pamphlet of exceptional distinction may be hiding. Equally well, what looks at first sight like a routine enlargement of an exhibition catalogue that dates back to 1976 may turn out to be full of new facts and new insights and in every way an indispensable addition to knowledge.

LEAD: WIM VANDEKEYBUS, MICH-ele-Anne de Mey, Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker -all are experimental Belgian choreographers and dancers. All work from both the gut and the brain, and they affect us, accordingly, in the same areas. Their pieces provoke and disturb.

LEAD: BEFORE getting down to serious business with an avant-garde interpretation of ''King Lear,'' which is coming up after the New Year, the George Street Playhouse here is indulging in a bit of folderol called ''Nunsense.''
LEAD: WHEN their aged parents became too feeble to care for themselves, the Inuit set them adrift on ice floes. In modern America, many such parents are banished to nursing homes.
LEAD: Wagner achieved the biggest football victory in its history today as it eliminated Emory & Henry, 20-15, in a National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III semifinal.

LEAD: The Charter of the Olympic Games states clearly that ''the use of the [ Olympic ] emblem for advertising alcoholic beverages is strictly prohibited.'' LEAD: To the Editor: My traveling companion and I enjoyed the article on Bateman's, Rudyard Kipling's home (Travel, Aug. 23). Having seen the house and gardens, we must say the article is very accurate. We especially enjoyed the motor car in the adjacent building. Kipling was somewhat of a hot-rodder with his auto, and we could just picture him whizzing down the narrow country lanes we had driven to get to the house.

LEAD: Andrew A. Rooney's Guest Observer column ''Running on Empty'' (Nov. 8) was amusing and instructive. Thanks. You do not mention my greatx grandfather, President Zachary Taylor, 1849-50. He did not attend the Whig Convention. The announcement of his nomination arrived ''postage due''; he refused it.

LEAD: THREE WEEKENDS AGO, IN A large rambling house high up in the Hollywood Hills, a party of three sat before a model theater. Built to a scale of 1 to 12, it mimicked exactly the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles, complete with proscenium, flies and a keyboard for the lights. The house was the home of David Hockney - painter, draftsman, printmaker, photographer and stage designer - and the party of three had driven up from Santa Monica for a run-through in miniature of a new production of Wagner's ''Tristan and Isolde,'' which has its premiere this evening at the Dorothy Chandler
LEAD: A Dummy Bomb In Pennsylvania

LEAD: A summit meeting that is more than cosmetic can take place only when each superpower -and its political leader - has a strong interest in seeking accommodation with the other. That is why Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev are meeting in Washington, and why each can confidently expect to gain something important.
LEAD: When the Citizens Union was founded in 1897, its members called for honest and efficient city government, improved rapid transit, better schools and ''lavatories adequate to public needs.''

LEAD: What a strange time for Otis Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Services, to float his new Social Security balloon. Just days ago, Congressional and White House negotiators gave up trying to cap automatic cost-of-living increases in Social Security benefits. That's one reason the deficit-reduction package that Congress will struggle with this week is a mouse, or worse.

LEAD: It may be impossible to convince Christians who are ''fundamentalists'' that taking everything in the Bible literally can lead to very un-Christian results, but this is certainly the case insofar as following the instruction to ''go forth and multiply'' is concerned today.

LEAD: The comedian Joan Rivers has filed a $50 million libel suit against a writer and Conde Nast, publisher of Gentlemen's Quarterly magazine, over an article saying she had complained that her husband, who later died, was driving her crazy.

LEAD: Donna Ellen Coufos, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George M. Azzariti of Alpine, N.J., was married yesterday to Christos J. Thomas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Thomas of Yonkers. The Rev. Robert Stephanopolis performed the ceremony at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral in New York.

LEAD: CHRISTMAS was a lot easier on parents before toys came along. When children played with wooden spoons or pots, their parents not only didn't have to spend any money but, more important, didn't have to make any choices. (They also didn't have to squirm around under couches and beneath dish washers, days later, rooting for mislaid pieces from the Erector set.) By the late 1800's, the toy business was in full swing.

LEAD: WHEN visiting Americans tour a Russian factory, farm, school or hospital, they are sure to be politely interrogated about how it stacks up against a comparable facility in the United States. After this questioning, they may be startled to hear their host declare, contradicting the immediate evidence and the apparent rules of glasnost, ''Yes, we have all that, too.
LEAD: As she has done on the first Saturday in December for the last seven years, Mary O'Dea left her home in Taunton, Mass., before sunrise and boarded a chartered bus bound for New York.

LEAD: TO SAY THAT WE ARE IN THE midst of a Gershwin boom is like saying that an American-food fad is in progress: It's not as though ''The Man I Love'' and jambalaya have been out of favor all these years; it's just that the big guns among writers and practitioners are now turning their very conspicuous attention to what always were highly esteemed - and worthy - items.

LEAD: When Mario Saleiro, a young Brazilian architect, was offered a job in Portugal this year, he jumped at the chance. ''I hope to return here one day,'' he explained while packing, ''but everything has become so difficult.''
LEAD: THE terror that swept Haiti last week was the latest reminder of the difficulty American policymakers face in trying to work their will, no matter how benevolent, on other nations.

LEAD: Michael Kory, a former radio and phonograph manufacturing executive and later a member of the American Stock Exchange, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 60 years old. Mr. Kory held various executive posts in the 1950's and 1960's for the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation, rising to vice president for sales and president for distribution.

LEAD: Airport Codes Question: For a research project, I would like to know who regulates the coding system for baggage ticketing at airports. If Kennedy Airport in New York is JFK, why should Key West be EYW? Where can I get information? - I. P. A., Brooklyn Answer: Those three-letter codes used for labeling airline passengers' baggage are determined by the International Air Transport Association, the trade organization of most of the world's airlines.

LEAD: Andrew Rooney's proposal for a Presidential candidate who doesn't want the job is a welcome idea, if not exactly a new one. As Plato wrote in Book VII of ''The Republic'': ''The truth is that the State in which the rulers are most reluctant to govern is always the best and most quietly governed, and the State in which they are most eager, the worst.

LEAD: A GLIMPSE of the whirling dervishes of Turkey was virtually obligatory for generations of Western travelers making the Grand Tour of the Orient. Indeed, few sensations better epitomized the romantic appeal of the East than the enigmatic ritual of the dervishes, whose name means ''those who have chosen the road of suffering.

LEAD: IN THE early to mid-70's, residents of New York and other cities were flooded with invitations to free dinners, courtesy of the Amrep Corporation. Those who went were treated to something else as well: a high-pressure sales pitch about the natural beauty and investment potential of land in Rio Rancho Estates, a sprawling new subdivision that Amrep was developing 15 miles northwest of Albuquerque, N.M.
LEAD: The Cambridge City Council is to vote Monday on a proposal to censure the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for evicting about 25 homeless people from a vacant lot owned by the university.

LEAD: JOHN WANAMAKER, one of America's legendary merchants, boasted in 1878 that the three-acre ground floor of his new store in Philadelphia was ''the largest space in the world devoted to retail selling on a single floor.''
LEAD: Mary and James Lizzio met at 14 and married at 24, and for a time, they lived a modest life of simple verities: work, family, church and an occasional summer clambake.

LEAD: The Rev. Bruce Ritter has stepped on a toe or two practicing what he calls ''muscular Christianity,'' but his enemies have a tendency to forgive him. LEAD: Thomas E. Powell Jr. of Burlington, N.C., the founder of two biological supply companies, died Thursday at Alamance County Hospital, after a three-month illness. He was 88 years old. Dr. Powell, who was born in Warrenton, N.C., and had a doctorate in biology, founded the Carolina Biological Supply Company in 1927 and headed its operation from 1936 until his death.

LEAD: Broadcast Nostalgia Dec. 7 - They are names from the golden era of radio broadcasting, the 1930's, 40's and 50's: Lon Clark (''Nick Carter, Master Detective''), Fran Carlon (''Big Town'') and others from the Mercury Theater, including Margo Lane. They will be part of the Big Broadcast, an evening of nostalgia, at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, starting at 7.

LEAD: HISTORY not only repeats itself, but as I head into my 92d year, I am beginning to suffer from acute deja vu. I have seen Halley's comet twice, lived through two World Wars, and experienced two stock market crashes, one in October 1929, the other October 1987. The two crashes had much in common. The advice given by the experts in 1929 is very much like that being given now.

LEAD: The engagement of Elizabeth Ann Masket to Jonathan Sommer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Sommer Jr. of Somers, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David C. Masket of the Riverdale section of the Bronx. The couple plan to marry in March.

LEAD: I find it appalling that men who can risk the ups and downs of Wall Street, climbing Mount Everest and racing in the Grand Prix are ''scared'' of taking on the greatest challenge that life has to offer - the ability to commit to caring about another human being.

LEAD: BY early afternoon, some of the stores on Shop Street, Galway's aptly named main commercial thoroughfare, are starting to close their doors. Bumper to bumper, long lines of cars thread their way along Shop and the other narrow streets that lead out of town. The buskers, strolling street musicians, have put aside their fiddles and tin whistles; they, too, are leaving.

LEAD: LAST call to plant bulbs; if the ground is dry, water after planting to spur root growth, then mulch. Use a calibrated spreader to lime or feed lawns, or both. Finish putting up windbreaks for conifers and other evergreens that need protection from strong gusts. Guy wire young fruit trees and saplings.

LEAD: THESE should be glory days for America's industrial exporters. Their products bristle with state-of-the-art technology. They are lean and hungry after responding to an onslaught of foreign competition during the early 1980's. And most are using the pricing advantage created by the dollar's steep decline against major industrial nations to regain old markets or establish new ones.

LEAD: AMONG THE MOST FAMOUS series of jazz recordings ever made is certainly that overseen by Milt Gabler in the late 1930's and the 40's and 50's, a series that has not lacked for reissues over the years. Most recently, Book-of-the-Month Records issued a four-LP set (two cassettes or three CD's) and a few years ago CBS issued a clutch of some of the most famous cuts in a series of LP's.

LEAD: AT 13, I desperately wanted to be what I then thought was called an adventuress. It took years to discover the true landscape of that word, with its night-prowling denizens and emotional quicksand. And further years to understand that I didn't mean adventurer either, but some compound poet-naturalist-explorer whose snares were sentences and whose darts were tipped with the curare of wonder.

LEAD: To the Editor: You recently advised your readers how to save their film from being exposed at airport X-ray machines (Practical Traveler, Sept. 6).

LEAD: TO A CRITIC OF THE EXCESSES of development that have plagued most American downtowns, San Francisco would appear to be the promised land. Here, the planners and the voters, not the real-estate developers, hold the power. The process of getting approval to put up a high-rise office building in the downtown business district here is so complex it must make the hardiest developer yearn for the simplicities of doing business in New York.

LEAD: PEOPLE CONVINCED that there can't be too much of a good thing prefer their music nonstop, and technology has caught up with them at last. It isn't just that the playing time of records has increased steadily over the years, growing from 4 1/2 minutes a side in the days of 78-rpm disks to about 30 minutes in the LP era and reaching an uninterrupted 70 minutes or thereabouts on CD's.

LEAD: ERICK HAWKINS choreographed ''Black Lake'' in 1969 but for some reason this translucent ceremonial suite has not been danced since 1978. On Friday night it was revived again at the Joyce Theater, 19th Street and Eighth Avenue, as part of the Erick Hawkins Dance Company season ending tonight.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: AFTER ALL THE HOOPLA, THIS IS A winter of discontent with trendy food. No matter the months past, filled, as they were, with purple potatoes and white eggplants, goat cheese and grazing, a salad called mesclun and a fish called skate, South-western cafes, French bistros, Italian trattorias and restaurants as elaborately designed as M-G-M stage sets.
LEAD: The problem, says one letter, is that a car is like a spouse. And the one you live with has to fill different and often contradictory needs.

LEAD: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Christmas issue of December 1986. It only suggests high points in the main fields of reader interest, and it does not include the titles chosen by the editors of The Book Review as the Best Books of the Year. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings.

LEAD: ON THE BLOCK If practice makes perfect, then the students in Hofstra's art appraisal program should be on their way to perfection after today, when they get a chance to put theory to practical use in a Christmas auction. For a handling fee of $3, people who have been cleaning out their attics or bric-a-brac shelves can bring art and artifacts - prints, paintings, glass, furniture, silver and the like - to Monroe Lecture Hall on the Hempstead campus between 10 A.M.
LEAD: LAWMAKERS and lobbyists are still uncertain about the fate of dozens of New Jersey programs that face the ax as Congress tries to reduce the Federal deficit.
LEAD: South Africa announced today that it had begun withdrawing troops from southern Angola, where they had been aiding pro-Western rebels in a civil war against Government forces backed by Cubans.

LEAD: At Temple Emanu-El in New York Leann Frank, the daughter of Meyer Werthan Frank of Atlanta and the late Claire Marx Frank, was married last evening to Dr. Edward Hollander, the son of Florence Hollander of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Samuel Hollander. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated. The bride is president of Comfort Shopping Inc., a corporate premium and gift concern in New York.

LEAD: TEAMS that did not win, some that didn't even contend, watched the Minnesota Twins win the World Series after making one key trade last winter - the acquisition of Jeff Reardon as their No. 1 relief pitcher. The nonwinners saw the San Francisco Giants make some midseason and late-season trades and win a division title after having lost 100 games two years earlier.

LEAD: SEVENTEEN Sing Sing inmates, convicted of everything from murder to drug trafficking, recently played musical chairs, made up new names for themselves and talked about the temptation to violence.
LEAD: AT FIRST GLANCE, IT IS hard to understand why the French film industry is so worried.
