I have followed their campaigns as closely as the next voter and have two years experience as a police reporter. Here then are three good reasons why each should be

LEAD: ''LA FIAMMA,'' the most successful of Ottorino Respighi's operas, came to New York Friday night -apparently for the first time - in a Carnegie Hall concert performance by the Collegiate Chorale under Robert Bass. It is a tale of witchcraft and forbidden love set in Byzantine Ravenna, orchestrated with the lush resourcefulness we expect from the author of ''The Pines of Rome.

LEAD: From the mainland point of view, politics in Puerto Rico tend to get a little scrambled because there are both Democrats and Republicans in each of the two principal island parties: the Popular Democratic Party, which favors continued commonwealth status for Puerto Rico, and the National Progressive Party, which is pressing for statehood.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: With thousands of Americans pouring into Washington for a demonstration Sunday on behalf of Soviet Jewry, the stage is set for human rights to become a prominent and contentious issue in the summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

LEAD: The Strategic Air Command is assessing which nuclear weapons could fill the gap in European defenses expected to be opened when intermediate-range missiles are removed under the coming arms agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union.

LEAD: Women would be required to notify sexual partners before having abortions under a bill approved by the Pennsylvania Legislature, and girls under the age of 18 would need parental consent or a court order to allow the procedure.

LEAD: The Tall Men Starring Clark Gable, Robert Ryan, Jane Russell. Directed by Raoul Walsh. 1955. Playhouse Video. 122 minutes. $59.98. For a tale that pits Clark Gable against Robert Ryan, ''The Tall Men'' makes a mighty mild movie. The weather is heavier than the plot of this Western, which takes place mostly on a big cattle drive from Texas to Montana - 5,000 head herded by a batch of Mexican hombres from ethnic casting plus a tribe of Sioux to be shot down along the way.

LEAD: NANCY GRAVES is rummaging through her things in the makeshift studio she keeps in a corner of the Tallix Foundry in Beacon, N.Y. The place looks like the treasure trove of a budget-minded King Midas. Scattered on shelves and dumped in boxes are hundreds of everyday objects cast in bronze: bronze milk crates, pleated lampshades, sunflowers, rigatoni, even bronze rippled potato chips.

LEAD: THEMES on French postal issues run the gamut from art to wrestling. The latest in the Artists' series offers ''Precambrien,'' a painting by Camille Bryen. This stamp is from a set that includes some of France's most attractive issues. Earlier this year, the work of Bram Van Velde was featured.

LEAD: THE COINCIDENCE THAT LARGE surveys of the art of Frank Stella and Julian Schnabel are taking up a lot of prime exhibition space in New York City at the moment has an air of perfect timing about it. The exhibitions, Stella's at the Museum of Modern Art, Schnabel's at the Whitney, are both by the enfants terribles of their respective artistic generations, and come toward the end of a tumultuous decade in art.

LEAD: LINDA RONSTADT ONCE LAMENTED half-jokingly that she sang like a German and thought like a Mexican and wished it were the other way around. Listening to her beautiful, long-awaited album of Mexican mariachi music, ''Canciones de Mi Padre'' (Asylum 9 60765-1; all three formats), however, one hears no conflict between music and concept.

LEAD: HE sits at his desk, his back to the audience. As he speaks, the voice, coarse, down-reaching and reverberative, is instantly recognizable. A radio announcer once said, ''It is the lowest voice in show business; so low that when he speaks, he unties your shoelaces.''
LEAD: Although New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will feel the sting of Federal budget cuts, most legislators from the region believe cuts are needed for the sake of the general economy.
LEAD: Concerts in memory of two widely admired jazz musicians who died during the past year - Woody Herman and Dick Wellstood - will be presented this week.

LEAD: Alissa Bick Ehrenkranz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel S. Ehrenkranz of New York and North Salem, N.Y., was married last evening to Peter Douglas Morris, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sherwin M. Morris of Rochester. Rabbi Joel Goor officiated at the Regency.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: THE decades-long battle between municipal officials and landlords over enforcement of health and safety code rules has taken a bizarre turn: The landlords are taking the city to court.

LEAD: 'CHRISTMAS CAROL' TOUR Three touring companies of ''A Christmas Carol,'' a production that originated in Omaha, Neb., in 1976, are going across the country this year. The East Coast contingent will stop at the Jorgensen Auditorium of the University of Connecticut in Storrs for an 8 P.M. performance on Friday.

LEAD: PUBLIC television's ''Masterpiece Theater'' ventures into predictable territory tonight - on Channel 13 at 9 P.M. - with Jane Austen's ''Northanger Abbey.'' Here, in a one-part, 90-minute adaptation, is still another excuse for a British period piece, exquisitely costumed and expertly acted. But fans of the series are likely to be perplexed by this particular adaptation.

LEAD: At St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York, Janet Sue Coffman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. G. Coffman of Panama City, Fla., was married yesterday to Michael Evans Hoover, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Hoover of North Canton, Ohio. The Rev. John G. B. Andrew performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A PLAY WITH PUPPETS James Merrill, who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1977 for ''Divine Comedies,'' a collection of poetry, will bring his one-act play with puppets, ''The Image Maker,'' to Seton Hall University in South Orange tomorrow evening.

LEAD: AMERICAN MEN ARE AN IMPRES-sionable lot. When they dress, they try on roles in much the same way they slip on loafers. To those who would scoff at that notion, Clifford Grodd, president of Paul Stuart, the Manhattan clothier, replies, ''Men tend to model themselves, sartorially, on public figures they respect.

LEAD: In everyday life a gift is usually a fairly straightforward thing. In fiction, however, it is almost inevitably symbolic and it often has unexpected consequences. The gift may please, or it may rebound on the giver. It may also expose one or both parties, may express aggression as well as affection.

LEAD: I must say I find all this negativism concerning the advertising business these days quite extraordinary. Every time I read an article about the megamergers, etc., I read the lines ''A lot of the fun has gone out of the business.'' The irony is that the quote usually comes from those who have become wealthy (thanks to the advertising business) and have sold out in one way or another.
LEAD: There is a joke circulating among singles in New York City: ''How does the single woman get rid of roaches? She asks them for a commitment.''

LEAD: Prime Minister Zbigniew Messner addressing the Polish parliament yesterday. He announced that the steep price rises for basic foodstuffs planned for next year will instead be implemented over three years. At rear, in dark glasses, was President Wojciech Jaruzelski. Page 19. (AP)

LEAD: EVEN people familiar with the name finnan haddie often have only the vaguest idea of what it is. Some people think it's a fish in a cream sauce, others wonder whether it is actually made with fins.

LEAD: THE RAPID ESCALATION of prices paid at auction in the 1980's for Frank Lloyd Wright's furniture and architectural fittings has spurred increased activity in the marketplace for his designs and has intensified debate over the fate of furnishings removed from his houses.

LEAD: Most deer run away. Jeff Humphreys says his eight-point buck was carried away. Mr. Humphreys, of Ligonier, Pa., told the police that someone stole his freshly killed deer from the back of his pickup truck Tuesday night as the truck was parked at an inn. ''He had shot himself a nice eight-point,'' said Jim Steel, a state trooper, ''and he was at a watering hole for a beer and to talk about his deer, and he came out to find the deer was taken.

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $4.95.) Nightmarish experiences befall a woman appointed Ambassador to Rumania. 2 5 GARDEN OF SHADOWS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The beginnings of the evil that beset the Dollanganger family in four previously published novels.

LEAD: BUSINESS TRAVEL OFTEN takes us to unsought destinations. One recent evening, three men and I, related only by the fact that we had worked together on a business deal, found ourselves at large in Houston after a late dinner. Maybe it was the heat and humidity, maybe it was the myth of Texan rambunctiousness, but we decided it was too early to go back to our hotels.

LEAD: THE recent construction of a 100-foot microwave tranmission tower by the Long Island Rail Road has taken the community of Woodbury by surprise, causing anger and concern in residents who said they had no knowledge of its planning or execution.

LEAD: Three leading Haitian presidential candidates today joined three major trade unions and another candidate in calling for a general strike beginning Monday to protest the suspension of national elections last Sunday amid a crescendo of violence. One candidate urged the military-dominated Government to resign.

LEAD: THE opera ''Nixon in China'' received its world premiere in October by the Houston Grand Opera. At that time it was much written about, and the range of opinion was extreme. Conservatives denounced or dismissed it tooth and claw. Progressives hailed it, sometimes extravagantly. Modernists were confused; most of them dote on Peter Sellars, the director, but dislike Minimalism, the stylistic school from which the composer, John

LEAD: Unfortunately, especially among heavyweights, those who fought one fight too many are numerous. Joe Louis, arguably the best ever, being slaughtered in the eighth round by a young Rocky Marciano, most closely parallels Larry Holmes's current sad journey and its probable sad ending. LARRY WOLFSON
LEAD: ABOARD U.S.S. HENRY M. JACKSON, in Puget Sound - The sound of the klaxon was grating, but the chief of the watch was crisp: ''Dive, dive.''

LEAD: In their distinctive school uniforms, the boys and girls traversing the streets of Baltimore's Cherry Hill neighborhood are indistinguishable from the millions of students in private and parochial schools throughout the country.

LEAD: AMERICAN culture bears the burdens of tradition lightly if at all. It is both our joy and our calamity and a source of constant confusion. Perhaps it is this kind of rootlessness and free-floating liberty that creates such bewildering events as Friday night's ''Fledermaus'' at the Metropolitan Opera.

LEAD: While Soviet-American trade has never been large in volume - it will total only about $2 billion in 1987 - it has been controversial and highly political. In the early 1970's, during the era of detente, American companies began to move into the Soviet Union in a big way. In 1971, Mack Truck designed and built a large part of the Soviet Union's $1.4 billion Kama River truck manufacturing plant.

LEAD: ''THERE is a very lonely feeling, because it's like losing something of your own,'' said Inez Woodbury of the First and Summerfield United Methodist Church, of which she has been a member for 45 years.
LEAD: CAPE MAY COUNTY currently suffers from a case of environmental gridlock involving sewage sludge, a byproduct of waste-water purification.
LEAD: THREE years ago, David Dorfman was a road-equipment purchasing agent. Now the 54-year-old Mine Hill resident practices the art of manuscript illumination.

LEAD: The New York of two very different periods will live again on the walls of the PaineWebber art gallery, at 1285 Avenue of the Americas, beginning Thursday when it opens an exhibit of photographs taken during the first decades of the century by the the architectural firm of McKim, Mead & White and during the Depression by photographers working for the Works Progress Administration.

LEAD: A great deal of scientific evidence suggests that the normal central nervous system is significantly less functional at 40 than it is at 20. This dysfunction is perhaps most evident in an area with great implications for a boxer's well being, hand-eye speed and coordination. Holmes, after an amateur career, 50 professional fights, and countless rounds of sparring, does not possess a normal central nervous system.

LEAD: AFTER a week of tough talk, conciliatory platitudes and other pre-summit maneuvers, Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev now stand on the verge of what could be one of the most serious and constructive dialogues that Soviet and American leaders have had in many years.

LEAD: SPRING 1988 MAY WELL BE ONE of the sexiest seasons in recent times. Now that the collections for next season have been presented in Milan, Paris and New York, it is clear that most of the design community has become obsessed with promoting overt seductiveness. In general, skirts are not only short, they are skintight.

LEAD: Chiat/Day headquarters in Los Angeles has won a major new product assignment from Sunbeam Appliances of Downers Grove, Ill. The talk is of an introductory ad budget of anywhere from $12 million to $20 million, more than Sunbeam's total budget for all other products.

LEAD: FIRST came aerobic dancing, with rooms full of people energetically bouncing up and down, kicking and cavorting like gazelles. The music was loud and disco-fast, and the true believers were every bit as committed, even as fanatic, as the daily runner.

LEAD: All the trappings of George Winston's solo piano concert Wednesday at Avery Fisher Hall suggested humility. Proceeds from lobby sales of Mr. Winston's recordings were donated to the Food for Survival Food Bank in the Bronx; program notes gave discographical data on albums by Mr. Winston's influences.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article from Atlanta in some copies on Wednesday about the release of a hostage by Cuban inmates at the Federal penitentiary misstated the date of an agreement between Cuba and the United States on the deportation of some 2,500 Cubans from this country. It was Nov. 20.

LEAD: From the visitors' gallery of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, this nation's leading stock market seems to work like any other. Young men dash around the big bright room, frantically signaling their trades and nervously scanning the rows of computer screens flashing prices.

LEAD: Mark Shepherd Jr., chairman of Texas Instruments Inc. and a leading figure in the electronics industry, said last week that he would retire in April after 40 years with the company. Mr. Shepherd, who will keep his seat on the board, will be 65 years old in January.

LEAD: Carl W. Priesing, former president of Wahl Eversharp Inc., manufacturers of pens and pencils, died of natural causes Monday at the home of his son, John, in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 89 years old and lived in Southbury, Conn.

LEAD: At this time of year, the east wind lopes across Greenham Common Air Base and bites like a wolf. The women in the Peace Camps stick close to their fires, brewing tea in blackened kettles, warming their anger at predictions that their movement will wither away once President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev sign a treaty banning medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles.

LEAD: Leaders of the outlawed Solidarity labor union, contending that Poland's Communist leaders ''failed to gain a public mandate to govern'' in the national referendum last Sunday, appealed to union members today to step up activities both openly and underground.

LEAD: There are no Broadway openings scheduled until the Jan. 26 premiere of ''The Phantom of the Opera'' at the Majestic Theater. But producers and theater owners have been competing feverishly during the past few weeks for the rights to a number of musicals, plays and comedies that promise one of the busiest spring seasons in years.

LEAD: The Watersons, an English a cappella folk group that helped spearhead the 60's British folk revival, perform in a style that is about as bare-boned as ensemble folk singing could be. The Yorkshire-based family group, made up of Norma, Lal and Mike Waterson, along with Martin Carthy (a Waterson by marriage), made a rare New York appearance at the Triplex Theater on Friday night.
LEAD: It wasn't pretty. In fact, it was rather ugly. As Carl Banks, the Giants' outside linebacker, put it, ''It was the kind of game that didn't seem to want to end.''

LEAD: People here seemed surprised when not just one but two candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination showed up Saturday night for a campaign forum sponsored by the Johnson County Democratic Party.

LEAD: The killing of one Irishman by another is such a routine part of this province's strife that it is unusual when the loss of innocent life causes people to stop and actually wonder whether the long, coarse weave of vendetta and grievance might be altered.

LEAD: After the removal of the controversial general manager of Amarillo's newspapers by the owner during a boycott effort, the papers have apparently struck an uneasy peace with T. Boone Pickens and other critics from the local Texas business community.

LEAD: When I was a boy, I sometimes visited a house in upstate New York that was just across a fence from an old, overgrown, hillside cemetery. This graveyard was a beautiful place, shady on hot days, and I used to love playing there. Cemeteries are often intriguing to children, I think. They are sometimes our first brush with the mystery of death, and also with the power of memory.

LEAD: Seven suspected Kurdish guerrillas and two Turkish soldiers were killed in separate clashes today in this township near the Syrian border, the semi-official Anatolia news agency reported.

LEAD: To win a world-class race, every yachtsman needs a fast boat first and a shrewd lawyer second. LEAD: Yevgeny I. Tolstikov, a Soviet explorer who led several pioneering expeditions to the Antarctic, died Friday, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported today. He was 74 years old.

LEAD: Only two lawyers in this century have argued 100 cases before the Supreme Court. Tomorrow they will be joined by a third when Lawrence G. Wallace, a deputy solicitor general, defends a Federal tax law.

LEAD: Thousands of disabled people - some young, others frail and elderly - cannot navigate subways and buses. Many feel imprisoned in their own homes. They find it difficult, sometimes even impossible, to get to medical appointments and senior citizen centers, or to visit friends or relatives. Meanwhile, disabled people with jobs pay private ambulette companies up to $200 a week to get to and from work.

Howard Padwee of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., to David Rawley Scofield, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John B. Scofield of Indianapolis. The Rev. Joseph H. Gilmore performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A VERITABLE fortune is spent on scouting these days. Each season, coaches and scouts from National Basketball Association teams travel the country, evaluating college players and viewing hours of videotaped college games.

LEAD: Joan Sandra Bodenheimer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Bodenheimer of River Edge, N.J., was married yesterday to Ted William Borowsky, a son of Irvin John Borowsky and Beverly Borowsky, both of Philadelphia. Rabbi Robert L. Lehman performed the ceremony at the Stony Hill Inn in Hackensack, N.J.
LEAD: The summit meeting in Washington could be the most important in the history of the global political competition between the United States and the Soviet Union.

LEAD: It was still dark this morning when 39 sleepy New Yorkers boarded a bus bound for the capital, bringing blankets and newspapers and bags of lunch. LEAD: YEFIM BRONFMAN is an unusually talented young pianist who seems to have trapped himself in a confining world. The heavy Romantic virtuoso repertory that dominated his evening at the 92d Street Y on Saturday certainly confirmed many of his virtues, but one also had the feeling it concealed others.
LEAD: The Republican Presidential candidate Pat Robertson won 83 percent of a straw poll vote at the state party conference and party leaders today made a decision that could help him even more.

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has announced several major domestic policy initiatives. Here are some of the programs and the progress so far in putting them into effect. Financing industry: Beginning Jan. 1, about 60 percent of Soviet factories will be required to pay their own way, the biggest step so far in decentralization of economic controls.
LEAD: The Government said today that it did not expect much to come of this week's summit meeting between President Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

LEAD: Nancy Reagan's breast cancer surgery in October prompted a national surge of interest in mammography, the procedure for detecting such cancers long before they can be felt. But when such cases fade from the news, demand for the procedure recedes. Only 11 percent of American women undergo mammography on a regular basis.

LEAD: The leaders of the 12 Western European nations who gathered here Friday for two days of deliberations were very much aware that they were doing so on the eve of a momentous summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

LEAD: While the Reagan Administration has looked to the Haitian Army to oversee the country's transition to civilian rule, United States intelligence knows little about the politics of the men who run the army.

LEAD: On the eve of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's arrival in the United States, about 200,000 marchers streamed down Constitution Avenue to Capitol Hill today to send the message that Jewish emigration and human rights should figure prominently in the Soviet leader's meeting this week with President Reagan.

LEAD: The San Diego Yacht Club's agreement last week to meet New Zealand in a closed match for the America's Cup in 1988 has created a major upheaval among other challengers. Some are taking sides in the controversy, but many appear to be reaching for middle ground. Most are hoping for compromise.

LEAD: There is more to a well-worn putter than the personal attachment to a golf club with years of winning matches under its heel. It is often a club with a hardened grip, fashioned that way with the same hands applying a similar intensity, game after game. A golfer is more sensitive to the feel of the putter than to any other club.
LEAD: FEWER of the best and brightest students have been applying to law schools, forcing many schools to be less selective, a recent study has concluded.

LEAD: Political infighting and adverse market conditions have ended a period of relative stability for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, presenting the danger that the oil price crash of 1986 is on the verge of repeating itself.

LEAD: John Elway, rebounding from a poor first half, threw two second-half touchdown passes today, and Mark Haynes scored a fourth-quarter touchdown on an interception return as the Denver Broncos overcame a 17-3 deficit to defeat the New England Patriots, 31-20.

LEAD: As the United States and the Soviet Union prepare for summit talks on a new treaty to reduce long-range arms, a debate is intensifying over whether the American proposal would increase or decrease the vulnerability of the U.S. nuclear forces.

LEAD: Joe Montana completed his first 17 passes, giving him a league-record 22 straight over two games, and he also passed for two touchdowns and ran for another today as the San Francisco 49ers defeated the Green Bay Packers, 23-12.

LEAD: A swarm of plainclothesmen scattered a small demonstration today by people denied permission to leave the Soviet Union, tearing their placards and roughing up Western television journalists trying to film the event.

LEAD: The recent presentation on national television of a university student confessing to taking part in the kidnapping of an army officer set off a flurry of charges of violation of judicial procedures and mistreatment of the prisoner.
LEAD: A 38-year-old firefighter died early yesterday after suffering a heart attack while working on the roof of a burning building in Brooklyn, the authorities said.

LEAD: When New York City officials began to hospitalize mentally ill street people against their will, they believed that they would be able to move many of the patients out of the wards and into the community.

LEAD: On the road, nothing comes easily for the Devils, certainly not victories. So while the scoreboard read 1-1, one might forgive them the indulgence of relishing it as something of a moral victory.
LEAD: The Corroon & Black Corporation, a big insurance brokerage, has named Richard M. Miller chief executive. Robert F. Corroon, 65, and the son of a founder, has relinquished the position.

LEAD: All Army personnel on active duty will be tested for exposure to the AIDS virus at least once every two years. The Army thus becomes the first military service to establish a formal policy for periodic retesting of servicemen for the deadly virus.
LEAD: Wall Streeters may not have much to laugh about these days, but they did have some light moments at the four-day annual convention of brokers that ended here today.

LEAD: KIRSTEN FLAGSTAD died 25 years ago today, and the anniversary raises memories. All of us have done dumb things in our lives, and one of the dumbest I ever did was to miss the Metropolitan Opera debut of Kirsten Flagstad. It was a Saturday matinee performance on Feb. 2, 1935. In those Depression days I was the complete Wagnerite and missed no performance of importance.
LEAD: Despite the shrinking dollar and economic uncertainties, there has been an outpouring of generosity in response to the 76th annual appeal for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Kaufman of New York and the late Miriam Daniels Kaufman, took place yesterday at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Rabbi Irving J. Block, assisted by Cantor Herman

LEAD: President Reagan intends to nominate T. S. Ary to be director of the Bureau of Mines, the White House has announced. Mr. Ary, president of the Kerr-McGee Corporation's Minerals Exploration Division, will succeed Robert Carlton Horton if confirmed by the Senate to the Interior Department post.
LEAD: Today's regular weekly auctions of three-month and six-month Treasury bills are the only Government securities auctions scheduled this week.
LEAD: Marcus Broadnax, the guard who was supposed to provide St. John's with outside shooting this season, may leave the university, possibly as soon as the end of the month.

LEAD: Passengers panicked when an engine fell off their twin-engine USAir jetliner more than 4,000 above New Jersey, and what worried them most was the landing, a passenger said today.
LEAD: The Capitol Steps, a singing group that specializes in political satire, has just released its Christmas album: ''Ronald the Red-Faced Reagan.''
LEAD: Dayton's first black police chief will step down Monday with a payment of at least $100,000, amid charges that he is the victim of racism.

LEAD: At the end of last season, Robert DeCormier stepped down after 17 years as head of the New York Choral Society. John Daly Goodwin, the group's associate conductor, replaced him, and on Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall took the podium for the first time in his new post.

LEAD: The South African Government's efforts to draw conservative black leaders into negotiations for a political settlement appear to have suffered a serious setback amid signs of an imminent security crackdown.

LEAD: Roughly a decade ago, the results of New York City's last revision of its charter went into effect, decentralizing many services and giving 59 community boards the responsibility of overseeing the city's performance on behalf of local residents.
LEAD: Winning breeds an uncanny confidence, even amid inexplicable adversity.
LEAD: LaMarr Hoyt, the former San Diego Padres pitcher, was arrested Saturday at his apartment here and charged with possession with intent to distribute cocaine and marijuana, authorities said.

LEAD: Melodrama now refers to overheated theatricality, but the word's original meaning is more specific and quite different, describing the combination of music and dramatic reading. In its version of Andre Caplet's ''Masque de la Mort Rouge,'' the Chamber Music Society has satisfied both definitions. Saturday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, Irene Worth narrated Poe's tale from one side of the stage.
LEAD: Dashiell L. Madeira, a retired Navy rear admiral, died Nov. 29 at his home in Virginia Beach, Va. He was 90 years old.

LEAD: Fraud in the Federal Government's major welfare program for mothers and children could be costing $1 billion a year, according to a report by the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services.
LEAD: Morton Baran has joined the Martin Agency, Richmond, as senior vice president and director of broadcast production.

LEAD: After Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan sign their arms control treaty Tuesday, the focus here will shift to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and its patrician chairman, Claiborne Pell.
LEAD: Can a salami sandwich help the Dolphins when the defense doesn't?

LEAD: A Federal court ruling on Thursday barring the seven regional telephone companies from the design or manufacture of telecommunications products could become a major obstacle to their plans to develop proprietary technologies.
LEAD: Iranian gunboats raided two tankers today, setting one ablaze and killing at least one crewman on the other.

LEAD: The Yankees today lost Ron Hassey, the left-handed-hitting catcher they thought they had secured, but they intensified their effort to obtain a left-handed-hitting outfielder. General Manager Lou Piniella acknowledged that he had talked to the Cincinnati Reds about Dave Parker and said he would meet with them again Monday.
LEAD: Charlotte Thorndike North, a writer and artist, died of cancer Friday at her home in Montclair, N.J. She was 74 years old.
LEAD: IN this, his silver anniversary season as a head coach, Don Shula shakes his head trying to figure out why this year is different from all the others.

LEAD: Leslie Beth Galton, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Barry Galton of Wayne, N.J., was married yesterday to Scott David Goldberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Goldberg, also of Wayne. Rabbi Joseph Brodie officiated at the Pierre in New York.

LEAD: Many books acquired by one publisher have wound up at completely different houses, including one now on its way to bookstores - ''The Binghams of Louisville'' by David Chandler. Signed up initially by Macmillan, then canceled last July after some of its facts were challenged, it is to be published by Crown Publishers on Dec.
LEAD: Before Francois Duvalier nominated his son to succeed him as President, legend has it that he passed on his secret for controlling this disparate country.
LEAD: At Saturday morning's weigh-in, Dwight Muhammad Qawi was snarling.

LEAD: Mike Murphy was dismissed today as the coach of the Los Angeles Kings.

LEAD: Judges ruled today that Foreign Minister Shimon Peres and Abba Eban, a member of Parliament, must testify at the trial of Mordechai Vanunu, a former nuclear technician accused of espionage, the defense said. Mr. Peres was Prime Minister when Mr. Vanunu told The Sunday Times of London in the fall of 1986 that Israel manufactured nuclear weapons at a secret installation.

LEAD: One thousand jobs and nearly $2 billion are expected to flow to the Houston area because of the space station contract announced by the space agency last week. But beyond those gains, it is the symbolism of the announcement that pleases city leaders.
LEAD: If Mikhail Gorbachev wants to change minds and make friends in his summit talks this week, a sure place to start is Afghanistan.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Losing baseball games and being away from home were two experiences that were foreign to Willie Banks in high school. But the 18-year-old right-hander received an education in both while struggling through a summer of discontent with the Elizabethton (Tenn.) Twins in the Class A Appalachian League.

LEAD: A woman who worked with Mother Teresa in helping the poor, an Asian-born medical student who spoke little English when he immigrated in 1971 and a West Point cadet honored for his poetry are among the 32 Americans who were named yesterday as winners of Rhodes Scholarships for study at Oxford University in

LEAD: Golf Woosnam Wins Record Golf Prize: Ian Woosnam of Wales won the biggest prize in golf history yesterday, clinching the winner-take-all Million Dollar Challenge at Sun City, Bophuthatswana. He shot an eagle 2 on the 17th hole en route to a four-under-par 68. Woosnam scored a four-stroke victory over his fellow Briton, Nick Faldo, finishing at 274, 14 under par, tying the tournament record.
LEAD: The New Orleans Saints, helped by Bobby Hebert's two touchdown passes, qualified for the playoffs for the first time with a 44-34 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers today.
LEAD: The first advertising for Claridge's Fine Food & Confections will start in the New York market in the third week in December, concentrating on radio ads.
LEAD: Don W. Wilson, standing in front of the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution in the rotunda of the National Archives, was sworn in Friday as Archivist of the United States.

LEAD: NO matter what Lawrence Taylor has done when he hasn't had his Giants helmet on, it's time that even the perfectionists who question his life style realize that as a football player, maybe no one has ever displayed a purer spirit in the pursuit of an opposing quarterback.

LEAD: Couples who lived together before marrying have nearly an 80 percent higher divorce rate than those who did not and they seem to have less regard for the institution, according to a study of Swedish women by the National Bureau of Economic Research here.

LEAD: IN June 1969, Ethel and James Lee were officially allowed, after a six-year struggle, to adopt a child they had been bringing up. The case was significant because the Lees are blind. Tonight at 9 on Channel 4, the Lees are brought to prime-time television by way of a ''based on fact'' movie called ''Eye on the Sparrow.

LEAD: At St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York, Suzanne Kathleen Leonard, a daughter of Dr. Barbara M. Marlowe of Brooklyn and the Rev. Richard D. Leonard of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Karl-Walter Sykora, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Sykora of Bonn. The Rev. John Clermont performed the ceremony.
LEAD: A 32-year-old Long Beach, L.I., man was stabbed to death in his house early today, the police said.

LEAD: Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev, the Soviet leader who makes his first visit to the United States Monday, is a product - even, it sometimes seems, a prisoner - of the system he is trying to change.
LEAD: The presence of the actress Bette Davis at the White House this evening gave President Reagan another opportunity to repeat one of his favorite lines.

LEAD: At Temple Israel in Memphis, Barbara Dee Weiss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold M. Weiss of Memphis, was married yesterday to Henry William Kimmel, the son of Arnold Kimmel of New York and Lakeville, Conn., and the late Lois Kimmel. Rabbi Harry K. Danziger and Rabbi Jordan M. Parr, the bride's brother-in-law, officiated.
LEAD: Peter Lorenz, a conservative politician who was kidnapped by leftist extremists in 1975, died today of a heart attack at his home here, a Government spokesman reported. He was 64.

LEAD: AFTER the October rout in stock prices, many investors turned to electric utilities in search of a safe haven. ''Most utility issues offer high yields and superior price stability, which appeal to investors in a bear market,'' the Value Line Investment Survey noted.

LEAD: It has taken longer to build than Grand Central Terminal - five years versus three - but the new Stamford train station is now open. It is not completely finished even now, but after innumerable delays, cost overruns and construction problems so serious that they required the complete rebuilding of certain sections, no one is likely to worry too much that there is still no escalator on one side of the tracks or a tunnel beneath them.

LEAD: Lower interest rates in Europe were of no help in the Treasury bond market last week, as yields fluctuated around 9 1/8 percent in light trading amid widespread confusion about the direction of the economy.
LEAD: As Mikhail S. Gorbachev prepares to bring his message of goodwill and openness to official Washington this week, the Soviet Chamber of Commerce is selling it to the American public.
LEAD: The broadest measure of Japan's trade surplus fell 21 percent in October from its level of a year earlier, shrunken by the effect of the strong yen, the Finance Ministry said Friday.
LEAD: A week after Haiti's disastrous attempt at holding its first presidential election in 30 years, lines are being drawn for a new phase of political battle.
LEAD: ''There is really only one fundamental issue on the agenda - freedom. Whatever glasnost is, it is not freedom.''- Senator Bob Dole, at human rights rallybefore the summit meeting. [ A20:1. ]

LEAD: Long considered an important nationalist symbol, Petrobras, Brazil's huge state oil monopoly, has decided to expand and diversify its operations abroad to help distance itself from Brazilian economic troubles.
LEAD: The Dallas Cowboys drew their smallest crowd ever for a game at Texas Stadium yesterday as small turnouts marked some games in the National Football League's 12th weekend of play.

LEAD: The United States' chances to win medals at the Calgary Olympics in Alpine skiing were slim enough before Tamara McKinney broke an ankle while training last month, three weeks before the start of the World Cup season in Sestriere, Italy.

LEAD: For three months, in the public spotlight, prosecution and defense lawyers in the Howard Beach murder trial have been clashing in a Queens courtroom over the guilt or innocence of four white teen-agers charged with murder or manslaughter in the death of a black man.

LEAD: Andre Nichols, a Brooklyn man who fatally shot a Roman Catholic priest last year but was acquitted of murder in the shooting, was arrested at a Fort Greene housing project Saturday night after he attempted to rob a woman at gunpoint, the housing police said last night.
LEAD: The United States, often accused of interfering in this country's affairs, has tried to persuade South Koreans that it is neutral in next week's presidential election.

LEAD: Two Navajo tribal police officers have been found dead in a burned-out vehicle on a reservation near the Utah-Arizona border, prompting a murder investigation by Federal and local agencies , authorities said.

LEAD: If Joseph Baum's fantasy is fulfilled, lovely ladies in long gowns will step onto the maitre d'hotel's terrace, pause for a modest moment, place a hand on the burnished brass handrail with its lead-crystal balusters, and then, on the arm of an escort, flow down the stairs.

LEAD: ''FLORA, the Red Menace,'' the 1965 John Kander-Fred Ebb musical, whose brief stay on Broadway is remembered mainly for the presence of Liza Minnelli, opened last week at the Vineyard Theater, with a few new Kander-Ebb songs and a new book by David Thompson. In its present incarnation, the show catches enough of the 1930's (''Mister, just give me a job'' is the refrain) to make one wish it had mined that rich vein more deeply and allowed its appealing central characters more of a chance to break out of musical comedy convention.

LEAD: The United States has urged both Israel and Syria to exercise restraint in the wake of an attack Nov. 25 by a Palestinian guerrilla on an Israeli army base, a State Department official said today.

LEAD: A brass quartet entertaining visitors yesterday to a street fair on Madison Avenue. LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mayor Tom Bradley signed a law Friday banning the sale and manufacturer of realistic-looking toy guns. The measure goes into effect later this month.

LEAD: The Scott Paper Company has agreed to pay the Federal Government fines totaling $475,000 to settle charges that it deliberately violated Federal health and safety regulations at its paper mill in Winslow, Me.
LEAD: It was raining when Peter Bosselmann walked a visitor through Central Park and the Upper West Side the other day to measure Manhattan's disappearing sunlight.
LEAD: Neil Underberg, one of the founders of the Finley, Kumble law firm that is now in the process of dissolution, has become the latest of its partners to join another firm.
LEAD: Arthur John Stringer Jr., an advertising agency copy supervisor, died of cancer Nov. 20 at his home in Mountain Lakes, N.J. He was 60 years old.
LEAD: William S. Rukeyser, a former editor of Fortune and Money magazines, is joining Whittle Communications, a magazine publisher based in Knoxville, Tenn., as editor in chief.

LEAD: With the Dow Jones industrial average near its low of Oct. 19, the mood among professional investors shifted last week from nervousness to outright pessimism. The hopelessness is now pervasive and most investors can find few reasons to buy stocks, Wall Street traders and money managers said.

LEAD: The Mets admitted today that they had a Ray Knight-type problem in their negotiations with Lee Mazzilli, but Mazzilli's agent blamed the Player Relations Committee for the snag that could end the player's second term with the club.
LEAD: AMIL GARGANO, chairman of Ally & Gargano, has decided not to talk to corporate suitors any more. It just leads to a lot of problems, he says.
LEAD: Robin E. Rosenberg and Bruce K. Segall were married yesterday at the Bayside Jewish Center in Queens. Rabbi Myron Fenster, assisted by Cantor Bernard Dienstag, performed the ceremony.

BORIS ARONSON (1900-1980) was an artist who, having chosen set design as his metier, enjoyed the boon of early recognition both in his native Kiev and in New York City. Luckily for him (though he is unlikely to have thought so at the time), this recognition fell short of that premature elevation to fame and fortune that has tainted the lives of so many other young artists in our era.

LEAD: WITH all the talk in recent weeks of ''Heisman hype'' and controversy over who votes and how, it was reassuring on Saturday to watch Tim Brown's selection as the 1987 winner. Reassuring, that is, because the announcement, like much else in college sports, has become Big Business.

LEAD: Dr. Richard W. Lyman, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, is leaving the philanthropy and returning to Stanford University to head a new Institute of International Studies.

LEAD: This is a village of 700 buildings. One of them, depending on the observer, is either an eyesore, a dilapidated commercial artifact of the 1930's, or an architectural gem, a compact well-preserved example of the modern style.

LEAD: John Cardinal Krol, a onetime meatcutter who became one of the most influential prelates of the Roman Catholic Church, announced today that he would retire Feb. 11 as Archbishop of Philadelphia .

LEAD: The Museum of American Folk Art, currently without a home, would move into what is now a gloomy, lifeless mall across from the Lincoln Center, under a negotiated cease-fire in a 15-year zoning battle.

LEAD: Amidst the summit hoopla, some less exalted Muscovites now prepare another gathering, humbler but earth-shaking in its own way: an unofficial human rights conference to begin tomorrow. That a group of former political prisoners could contemplate such a seminar in Moscow says much about how times have changed.

LEAD: ''THIS is a Dish Towel Club,'' the copied letter begins. ''Send a dish towel to the person listed as No. 1 below, copy this letter and send it to six of your friends.'' Then the good news: ''You should receive 36 dish towels.''

LEAD: Dealers hurriedly marked down prices of Treasury securities late yesterday after a late surge in the stock market, then they marked them back up after underwriters of the four-part, $1.5 billion Southland Corporation offering reported the deal as ''done.''

LEAD: If you put nine of the world's leading bridge administrators on a luxury yacht with something to celebrate, the result may be a somewhat bibulous bridge game. It happened in October on the Southern Breeze, which was anchored off Ocho Rios, Jamaica, during the world team championships.

LEAD: American cattle producers who have been battling to persuade the Japanese to import more American beef will descend on Capitol Hill next week with 300 pounds of prime beef to be served at a luncheon for Japanese officials.

LEAD: E. F. Hutton Group Inc. disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it would pay its financial advisers - Salomon Brothers Inc. and the Blackstone Group -$3.35 million each if the brokerage's $960 million merger with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. was completed.
LEAD: Either Rick Pitino is a supreme motivator or the Washington Bullets have serious problems.

LEAD: The National Hockey League Board of Governors agreed yesterday to bend its waiver rules to make some players available to the American and Canadian Olympic teams for the Winter Games in February in Calgary, Alberta. John Ziegler, the league's president, said the Canadian-based teams have been asked to submit a list of five or six players who would be available to Team Canada.

LEAD: The chief executive of NBC said yesterday that, despite nearly $100 million in tax breaks from the city and state, the television network would have saved tens of millions of dollars a year if it had moved to New Jersey.
LEAD: In baseball, when is a strike a strike?
LEAD: With fervent calls for a new era of peaceful understanding, President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev today signed the first treaty reducing the size of their nations' nuclear arsenals.

LEAD: NEIL SIMON'S strange 1970 play, ''The Gingerbread Lady,'' seems to strain mightily to fly into pieces, and part of the fascination of seeing it lies in watching director and cast struggle to hold it together. The challenge of keeping it coherent, in fact, must be one reason it continues to appeal to producers.

LEAD: An investment group led by Blasius Industries, a rubber and metal company based in Erie, Pa., has proposed an extensive restructuring of the Atlas Corporation, a gold exploration and development concern based in Princeton, N.J..

LEAD: Defying widespread predictions, the economy has held up well since the stock market collapsed in mid-October and an imminent recession appears quite unlikely, private and Government analysts maintain.
LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge said today that a committee of Texaco Inc. shareholders must approve any settlement proposed by the company's creditors and the Pennzoil Company.
LEAD: Gary Vitti, the Los Angeles Laker trainer, worked on James Worthy's painful left knee for almost 45 minutes in an attempt to get him ready for tonight's game at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

LEAD: Mathias Rust, the 19-year-old West German serving a four-year sentence here as a result of his border-hopping solo flight to the Kremlin wall, has been denied a pardon, a Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

Lambert of Manhattan, for the results of a home study of prospective parents, conducted by a legally blind worker. The worker recommended against adoption by prospective parents who were later found to have abused the child they were seeking to adopt.

LEAD: James Baldwin, a son of Harlem whose words and perceptions influenced the lives of millions around the world, was eulogized yesterday as a literary giant and as a loving spirit whose unflinching honesty was informed by a delicate and yet durable tenderness.
LEAD: New York State's 13 medical colleges said yesterday that any faculty member, hospital resident or medical student who refuses to treat an AIDS patient would be dismissed.

LEAD: An American production of Caryl Churchill's ''Serious Money,'' a comedy set in the financial markets of London and New York, is to open Jan. 18 at the Royale Theater on Broadway. The production will mark Miss Churchill's Broadway debut.

LEAD: An article from Washington yesterday about the makeup of missile crews included an incorrect figure from the Strategic Air Command for the number of women serving in nuclear missile control centers. The number is 42, not 120.

LEAD: If the official Soviet caricature of America used to be Rambo, this week it is Mister Rogers.

LEAD: An article on Nov. 14 about a dispute between New York City firefighters and police officers gave an incorrect address for the New York City Fire Museum. It is at 278 Spring Street in Manhattan.

LEAD: President and Mrs. Reagan invited a cross-section of America - 126 stars of business, science, sports, politics and the arts - to the White House state dinner this evening in honor of Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa.
LEAD: Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov fought to a thorny draw Monday in the 21st game of their world chess championship match in Seville, Spain. The score now stands at 10 1/2 points each.

LEAD: AMERICAN Jews have generally celebrated Hanukkah, or the Feast of Lights, as a minor holiday, particularly in culinary terms. Little thought is given to ceremonial foods other than the ubiquitous potato pancake, or latke, and a few sweet pastrylike desserts, all fried in oil.

LEAD: Six months ago, American intelligence officials were convinced their worst nightmare had come true: Marine guards had let Soviet agents into the Moscow Embassy and presumably given them access to some of the most closely guarded secrets of the United States Government.

LEAD: BAKING may be the most alluring kitchen activity for children. The Tolvid vaccine, developed by Upjohn, is produced by Diamond Scientific. Pseudo-rabies is a contagious virus that affects about 6.4 million, or 8 percent, of the nation's 80 million hogs.

LEAD: A small new basketball league, or a new basketball small league, or both, or neither, held its first draft, big or small, yesterday morning at the Sheraton Centre.
LEAD: The Economy
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: YOU can, without a doubt, have too many ties. You can even have too many books, records, scarves, gloves and all the other perennials of the gift-giving season. Food, though, is another matter. You might be given the wrong food: chocolate when you can't bear the sight of it; mustard when you have two dozen jars; Julia Child's opus when you haven't mastered tuna fish sandwiches.

LEAD: The New York City Correction Commissioner, Richard J. Koehler, yesterday ordered Larry Davis, accused of murdering four men, to be isolated and guarded in his cell in the Bronx House of Detention by a special unit from Rikers Island.

LEAD: Those hawks now mobilizing to block Senate ratification of the treaty eliminating intermediate-range nuclear missiles threaten to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory, both for their own side in the defense-policy debate and for America's position against its adversary.

LEAD: A BREAKFAST auction last week at the Four Seasons called ''Great Cooks Salute Thirteen'' gave new meaning to the term culinary artist. Included in the Channel 13 benefit were paintings, drawings, decoupages, photographs, pottery, a multidimensional sculptured collage, sculpture in terra cotta, bronze and clay, and even a diorama of lobsters.

LEAD: Burt Sugarman, the television and film producer who is the chairman of Giant Group Ltd., disclosed today that he had been questioned in September by the Securities and Exchange Commission's staff in connection with Giant's purchase of the TRE Corporation's common stock and an offering of Giant debt securities last year.

Marriott Hotel across town dogged a bewildered young woman whose status as the only black reporter in the Soviet press corps was making her an instant celebrity.
LEAD: ''For everyone, and above all for our two great powers, the treaty whose text is on this table offers a big chance, at last, to get onto the road leading away from the threat of catastrophe.''

LEAD: A coroner opened an inquest today into the death, apparently by suicide, of an Oxford University theologian suspected of having written an attack on the Archbishop of Canterbury that created an uproar in the Church of England.

LEAD: Richard Mercier of the Customs Service with items that were among jewelry and carvings valued at $6.3 million found hidden in a shipping container at Port Newark. In Long Lee, a Taiwanese businessman, was indicted for trying to evade $421,818 in customs duty. According to officials, Mr. Lee planned to emigrate from Taiwan and bring his jewelry business with him.
LEAD: In this city that divides bitterly over almost every topic, from baseball to politics, one subject engenders rare unity: the awful state of public education.
LEAD: A car-bombing this evening at Manila International Airport added to the worries of Philippine officials as they prepare for a regional summit meeting next week.
LEAD: The Reagan Administration's top experts on drug law enforcement and the prevention of drug abuse told a Congressional panel today they had made limited progress in the war against drugs.

LEAD: Even for this city, which long ago mislaid its sense of wonder, this was a thrilling day, bathed in a glow of satisfaction at what has been achieved and of optimism about what may lie just ahead.
LEAD: A recent harangue in this space denouncing three lies put forward by Mikhail Gorbachev in his NBC interview has drawn a revealing response from Georgi Arbatov, the Kremlin's Americanologist.

LEAD: Dr. Sarah Kestenbaum, a professor of social work at Hebrew University in Jerusalem and a legislative assistant to Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat, died of cancer Saturday at the Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem. She was 57 years old and lived in Jerusalem and Washington.

LEAD: Marcus Broadnax, a sophomore reserve guard at St. John's, said yesterday that he would leave the university after this semester, which ends Dec. 23. ''I'm through practicing,'' he said. ''Next semester I'll be in another school. I spoke with Coach Carnesecca and he said that he understood.'' Broadnax, who averaged 38.9 points a game in his senior year at Fort Walton Beach (Fla.) High School, said he had been misled during the recruiting process by Coach Lou Carnesecca and his assistants, Ron Rutledge and Brian Mahoney.
LEAD: Senator Paul Simon of Illinois promises an administration of good deeds. He spins the vision of a nurturing Government.
LEAD: IT is 6 P.M. on the tarmac of National Airport in Washington, and a passenger on the Eastern Airlines shuttle realizes that he has neglected to make an urgent phone call.
LEAD: An American pilot was shot down over Nicaragua on Sunday while ''clearly engaged in enemy activity against our country,'' the Nicaraguan Defense Minister said today.

LEAD: When 27 police officers tried to arrest Larry Davis a year ago in connection with the murder of four drug dealers, the resulting shootout attracted national attention. LEAD: Morrill Cody, a former deputy director of the United States Information Agency, died Nov. 23 at the Manor Care nursing home in Wheaton, Md., after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange is investigating the performance of Spear, Leeds & Kellogg and M. J. Meehan & Company, specialists that make the markets in the stock of J. P. Morgan & Company and Gould Inc. respectively, people in the industry said yesterday.

LEAD: Coach Tom Landry of the Dallas Cowboys was surprised to receive heavy criticism from Bum Bright, the team's principal owner, after a 21-10 loss to the Atlanta Falcons Sunday. Aware that the Cowboys (5-7) were perilously near elimination from playoff contention, Landry said yesterday that he intended to coach the Cowboys until 1989.

LEAD: The Senate Appropriations Committee today approved a wide-ranging $606 billion appropriation bill for the 1988 fiscal year, including $7.6 billion of the spending cuts required by the budget compromise between Congress and the White House.

LEAD: The fiscal news from New York's City Hall lately has come with typical speed and classic urgency, with the kind of drama Mayor Koch invests in most matters that swirl about him. It has also come with seeming contradictions - mixed messages that tend to confuse an already murky economic picture.

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev summoned some of the nation's leading cultural, intellectual and political leaders to the Soviet Embassy this afternoon, turned on the television lights, and delivered a two-hour sales pitch for his vision of a new world order.
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation, which has packaged the remnants of the American Motors Corporation as a new Jeep/Eagle division, will begin selling new auto models this month.
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: Sting, Peter Gabriel and other internationally known musicians are planning a six-week world tour beginning next August to support Amnesty International, the human-rights organization, and its campaign to renew support for the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The dates and itinerary have not been set, but the prospective tour, called Human Rights Now, is to include Eastern European and third-world countries.
LEAD: General Assembly ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE- 10 A.M.

LEAD: The text of the treaty signed today by President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev spells out how hundreds of American and Soviet inspectors will insure that 2,611 American and Soviet missiles are smashed, exploded, crushed, burned or launched to be destroyed.

LEAD: TELEVISION was cheery yesterday. Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev both spoke from the East Room of the White House. Their wives sat side by side. Then Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev spoke again, this time in front of a pretty fireplace in the State Dining Room. ''There's the great Gorbachev smile,'' Dan Rather said accurately; the mood was almost festive.

LEAD: FOR more than 10 years, developers in New Jersey have pushed steadily westward from New York to offer cheaper alternatives to Manhattan's high-cost office space and to accommodate the growth of Jersey-based companies. So far, however, few have ventured beyond Morris and Somerset Counties.

LEAD: Donald L. Dotson , chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, is resigning, and Administration sources say President Reagan is expected to name one of two current members of the board to succeed him.
LEAD: Dr. David Mann, a psychotherapist and former professor of psychiatry at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 61 years old.
LEAD: Musical Odyssey
LEAD: Juan Chanax nods proudly toward the shiny soccer trophies on display throughout his family's modest apartment: symbols of his life as an immigrant, and now of the passing of a way of life.
LEAD: Ron Hextall became the first National Hockey League goaltender to shoot and score a goal as the Philadelphia Flyers downed the Boston Bruins, 5-2, tonight.

LEAD: An agreement emerging at the summit would cut Soviet and American long-range nuclear weapons by half. But is that - as opposed to the treaty signed yesterday banning Euromissiles - good? Will it actually reduce the risks of war? Many experts argue that the strategic arms agreement actually would make U.S.
LEAD: Edward Staley, former chairman of the W. T. Grant Company, died of cardiac arrest Friday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 84 years old.

LEAD: The recent discovery of oxygen-rich bubbles that had apparently been preserved in amber since the time of the dinosaurs has drawn its first major challenge. Two researchers in California say that their amber samples show no oxygen at all.
LEAD: This year, the Russians are working on openness. Next year they may get around to organization.
LEAD: The judge who on Monday invalidated the sale of the New York Coliseum site on Columbus Circle ruled that the city had illegally made the full purchase price contingent on a zoning variance.

LEAD: At Park West High School, a forbidding concrete structure in the heart of Hell's Kitchen, students have assaulted and robbed each other, stealing jewelry, coats and radios, since the start of the school year. Violence erupts over even such trifling items as train passes.

LEAD: HAROLD LEVINE and Robert H. Schmidt, the disparate pair that have been running Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver since it began with $1.5 million in billings in 1972, have now completed a sort-of second-generation management transition.

J. Quinnell in which the Roman Catholic Archbishop figures as a character.

LEAD: The Euromissile treaty signed Tuesday is hailed as the first to eliminate an entire class of nuclear weapons. Perhaps of greater significance, the treaty includes verification provisions of unprecedented sweep and detail. Properly managed, these could soften the core of mistrust that has so dominated arms control and U.S.-Soviet relations.
LEAD: The estate of Andy Warhol is expected to sue New York Hospital soon over the death of the 58-year-old Pop artist at the hospital last February.

LEAD: In composing ''Lulu,'' Alban Berg made a fascinating attempt to reconcile chaos and order under one operatic roof, setting a harrowing tale of moral anarchy to a 12-tone score that is rigorously organized down to the smallest staging detail. Most productions of the work, some of them highly acclaimed, have ignored or played down Berg's intricately interlocking scheme of music and stage action.

LEAD: Until five years ago, the wooded hillsides and sloping fields west of Old Clinton Road were full of white-tailed deer and hunters this time of year. The deer still abound. But the hunters have been pushed elsewhere, squeezed out by $200,000 and $300,000 houses in two new developments, Rolling Hills and Cherry Hill.

LEAD: After a sluggish start, sales for the Christmas shopping season's first 10 days picked up in many stores, according to telephone interviews with nationwide and local retailers that cater to consumers with a broad spectrum of incomes.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a report in the Business People column of Business Day yesterday incorrectly characterized remarks made by Robert Galvin, chairman of Motorola Inc.

LEAD: A navy plane carrying Peru's top soccer team crashed into the ocean off a Lima beach Tuesday night, and only one of the 43 people aboard was known to have survived, the navy said today.

LEAD: The Soviet Union has fewer operational medium-range missiles than previous American Government estimates have stated, according to a confidential annex to the new missile treaty.
LEAD: House members asserted today that the Reagan Administration had failed to keep a three-year-old pledge to tighten control over the handling and disposing of polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's.

LEAD: Ten films will be shown during the annual Recent Films From West Germany series, beginning today at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. LEAD: A senior State Department official warned tonight against efforts to subvert next week's presidential elections in South Korea.

LEAD: Michael K. Deaver's defense lawyers were told today that they could not argue before the jury that the former Presidential aide's memory was impaired by alcoholism when he was questioned about his lobbying business.

LEAD: East European governments erupted in a chorus of applause today for the Soviet-American arms treaty. They praised it as a victory for Moscow's advocacy of change and willingness to compromise and expressed some hesitant admission of President Reagan's role.
LEAD: Citing concerns about Colorado's image, Gov. Roy Romer today proposed a $5 million bailout for thousands of depositors in 15 industrial banks where deposits are frozen.

LEAD: Funeral procession for John Toomey, a 38-year-old firefighter, at Sackett and Hoyt Streets in Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn after Mass yesterday at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. Mr. Toomey died last Sunday after suffering a heart attack while battling a blaze on the roof of a building in Brooklyn.

LEAD: After all the grief over first bringing American medium-range missiles into Europe - and then over removing them - Germans greeted the disarmament treaty today with a mix of relief and anxiety over what comes next.

LEAD: A host of miniature comets so small that they have eluded detection are probably swarming through the inner solar system and their bombardment over several billion years could account for many of the craters on the Moon, Earth, Mercury and Mars, space scientists reported yesterday.

LEAD: A New Jersey bank demanded yesterday that the Public Service Company of New Hampshire immediately repay a $425 million debenture issue that is due in 2004, because the utility had defaulted on a $37 million interest payment that was due Oct. 15. The effect on the company, which is already on the brink of bankruptcy, is not clear.

LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has banned Cleveland State's basketball team from postseason play for two years because of violations in the 1983-84 season. LEAD: Bond prices rose modestly in light trading yesterday, as investors and traders continued to wait on the sidelines until there are enough economic data to clarify the welter of year-end economic forecasts now being published.

LEAD: Mr. Coffee came under new management in July as a result of a leveraged buyout and then decided to get an ad agency to replace its in-house facility.

LEAD: Bill Goodstein, the agent for Dave Righetti, said tonight that the relief pitcher had received an offer from a Japanese team that would make him the ''highest-paid athlete in team sports history.'' Goodstein declined to disclose the offer or the team, but a friend of Righetti said the offer was for slightly more than $8 million for two years.

LEAD: SITTING the other night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's production of ''Nixon in China,'' I found myself hoping that Richard M. Nixon would overcome whatever reservations he may have and go to see it. Before one had seen the opera, one could understand his doubts. He had every reason to fear that he would be made to look foolish, or that his attendance might become a silly celebrity event, full of reporters and flashbulbs and television cameras.

LEAD: ''Taxi!'' the middle-aged black woman on Central Park West shouted into the night. ''Taxi!'' she repeated three times. Finally, one stopped. But just as the woman opened the door, the cabby spotted another fare down the block and sped off . . . to pick up a man dressed like a gorilla.

LEAD: Peter Fleming, the longtime doubles partner of John McEnroe, will soon be taking on a new assignment. Early next year, he will become McEnroe's manager in an attempt to help the volatile left-hander regain the No. 1 position in international men's singles rankings. Speaking in London yesterday at the Masters Doubles championships, Fleming said his aim was to remove ''negative aspects'' of McEnroe's game, which should enable him to challenge Ivan Lendl for the top ranking.

LEAD: THE Maria Benitez Spanish Dance Company presented a compelling program on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue. But there was one moment that stood out. It came with a farruca performed by Eduardo Montero. Choreographed by Jose Luis Ayuste to traditional music, the solo gave Mr. Montero, a guest artist with the company, a chance to let loose with steely, lacy fusillades of foot beats of such exquisitely precise timing and dynamic range that one watched breathlessly.
LEAD: The Senate Labor Committee today unanimously approved the nomination of Ann Dore McLaughlin to be Secretary of Labor. The panel voted to send the nomination to the Senate floor with no debate.

LEAD: LIKE plaster particles and tarpaulins, contractor-bashing has become an integral part of home-improvement jobs and apartment renovations, occurring at regular intervals between felling the first wall and signing the last check.

LEAD: Five people were wounded today, one of them seriously, when a bomb exploded at the Athens Chamber of Commerce and Industry as the chamber was crowded with members taking part in board elections, the police said.

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, speaking as much to his own people as to his American audience, tonight depicted his talks with President Reagan as precisely the kind of success he had promised his first visit to the United States would produce.
LEAD: James Dobson, who appeared with President Reagan in ''Hellcats of the Navy,'' died of a heart attack on Sunday. He was 67 years old.

Banner, made from a shop apron, was reminiscent of those hung in the strike of 1936-37 by the United Automobile Workers. More than 3,000 workers faced layoffs when the plant ceased operations.

LEAD: A memorandum of understanding to the Soviet-American agreement on medium- and shorter-range weapons pinpointing basing, production and support sites for the arms was released yesterday. Missile production installations in Magna, Utah, and Votkinsk, U.S.S.R., are open to 13-year inspections. All other sites listed here are open to one type of inspection or another, with the exception of all remaining missile production installations and all research and development launch sites.

LEAD: WHIMSY rides high at the Circle Repertory Company with the opening last night of Timothy Mason's ''Only You,'' a short evening of small talk. Ostensibly this comedy concerns the compartmentalization of prospective young lovers, each of whom never seems to know when he has found a rightful romantic partner.

LEAD: After disproving scouting reports that said he was too small and too slow to become a competent college football player, Paul McGowan of Florida State University capped his collegiate career yesterday by winning the 1987 Butkus Award as the nation's best collegiate linebacker. McGowan, who totaled four first-place votes and 25 points from a panel of 11 sportswriters and broadcasters, won by a point over Chris Spielman of Ohio State, who had five first-place votes.
LEAD: FOR obvious reasons, darts is not a contact sport. But in one significant way, darts resembles that American schoolyard in-your-face contact sport of basketball: winners stay on.
LEAD: Scores of black constables revolted against their white commander today, tried to run him down and fought a gun battle with a riot squad that chased them, the authorities said.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article from Washington on Wednesday about Senator Paul Simon's candidacy for President gave an erroneous date for an article he wrote for Harper's Magazine. It appeared in 1964.
LEAD: CRIME AND MYSTERY. The 100 Best Books. By H. R. F. Keating. 219 pages.
LEAD: Slam Stewart, a distinguished jazz bassist celebrated for singing along with his solos, died of congestive heart failure Wednesday at his home in Binghamton, N.Y. He was 73 years old.
LEAD: The nation's deficit in foreign trade leaped to a record $17.6 billion in October as Christmas goods and other imports rose more than five times as much as exports, the Government said today.

LEAD: A FESTIVE spot in midtown for a self-indulgent snack is Petrossian, the caviar and champagne palace on Seventh Avenue at 58th Street. The menu has been greatly expanded to offer a wide range of refined finger foods that can be tasted in the plush Art Deco dining room or at the marble-topped bar. Options include tasty little roulades of smoked sturgeon with wild mushrooms, truffled foie gras en croute, smoked salmon wrapped around avocado and Russian salmon roe, and fillets of smoked eel encasing shiitake mushrooms (all $12 each).

LEAD: Mayor Koch has chosen the city's Criminal Justice Coordinator, Kevin Frawley, to be Commissioner of Investigation, the chief mayoral watchdog over corruption and other abuses by city employees, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

LEAD: Henry Threadgill's ''Run Silent, Run Deep, Run Loud, Run High'' - a work for 28 musicians and singers -is to receive its world premiere tonight and tomorrow at 8 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in the Fort Greene section (718) 636-4100). Tickets are $15 to $20.
LEAD: The Legislature voted early today to repeal the state's tax on advertising and professional services, and Gov. Bob Martinez indicated he would sign the bill Friday.
LEAD: King Carl XVI Gustaf handed the Nobel Prize in Literature today to the poet Joseph Brodsky and gave seven other laureates their awards for economics, physics, medicine and chemistry.

LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar told the Security Council today that its authority was being undermined by Iran's refusal to accept its cease-fire call and indicated he felt it was time to impose an arms embargo.

LEAD: Eurotunnel shares sank 29 percent today, the first day they were traded, underscoring the risky nature of investing in the Anglo-French consortium that is building a rail tunnel under the English Channel.

LEAD: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev concluded their three-day summit conference today with what they described as significant progress toward a treaty limiting strategic weapons. But they failed to conclude major new agreements on Afghanistan or the other key issues that still divide them.

LEAD: The decisions on whether to send Cuban detainees back to Cuba will be taken away from the immigration authorities and entrusted to a special panel of the Justice Department, Reagan Administration officials said today.

LEAD: During three years as a marketing representative for I.B.M., Stu Jackson learned much about product presentation and consumer relations. Those lessons served him well last night in another, very different, capacity.

LEAD: The Bear Stearns Companies has filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan against the brokerage house of Jardine Strategic Holdings Inc. of Hong Kong for withdrawing from an agreement to acquire a stake in the company.

LEAD: Ronald O. LEAD: TWO plays newly adapted for television explore, in very different ways and contexts, the subject of survival. The South African ''Asinamali,'' on Channel 13's ''Great Performances'' tonight at 9, describes the brutality of living under the oppressive policy of apartheid. ''Foxfire,'' a Hallmark Hall of Fame presentation on CBS Sunday at 9 P.M., deals with the unavoidable pressures of simply growing old.

LEAD: The House approved Thursday an $11.5 billion foreign aid bill despite warnings from Republicans that President Reagan would veto the measure because it contains new restrictions on his Central American policy.
LEAD: Ending Wall Street's three-day rally, stock prices fell sharply late yesterday after a seesaw session that reflected unexpectedly bad news on the trade front.

LEAD: In 17th century France, there lived an unusual woman, Ninon de Lenclos. She was the most famous of courtesans, lover, friend, adviser and companion of the great and near-great: monarchs, statesmen, authors, philosophers, generals. Her lawyer, Francois Arouet, was a former peasant who served her with diligence, and she was quite taken with the lawyer's precocious 10-year-old son.

LEAD: The start of Bob MacKinnon's second term in six years as the Nets' interim coach was marked by a first half in which fewer plays were called from the bench, the substitution pattern had longer playing time, and the emphasis was on better ball movement and passing.

LEAD: SOME performance artists, like Eric Bogosian and Ann Magnuson, delight in caricaturing an entire spectrum of American types. Others, like Michael Smith, concentrate their energies on the refinement of a single symbolic character.

LEAD: The New York bridge scene lost one of its great veterans when Herman Horowitz of Rego Park, Queens, died in August just short of his 90th birthday. Only two weeks earlier he was the big winner in a six-hour rubber bridge session that would have tested many a younger man.

LEAD: The dollar plummeted yesterday to its lowest levels since the 1940's amid heavy trading, as dealers sold the currency in the wake of the unexpectedly bad report on the nation's trade deficit in October.
LEAD: Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive American financier, was identified today as a co-conspirator in the trial of Carlos Lehder Rivas, the reputed leader of a Colombian cocaine-smuggling network.

LEAD: Former House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. was released today from Brigham & Women's Hospital here after a nearly monthlong stay in which he underwent surgery for rectal cancer and had an enlarged prostate removed. A hospital spokeswoman said Mr. O'Neill, who marked his 75th birthday Wednesday, left the hospital accompanied by his wife, Mildred, for their home in Harwichport on Cape Cod.

LEAD: The Western Union Corporation closed the polls on a thrice-delayed shareholder vote on a vital part of the telecommunications concern's restructuring plan. A shareholder meeting for balloting also was adjourned for the corporation's chief subsidiary, the Western Union Telegraph Company. A spokesman said the shareholder meeting would be reconvened on Monday to announce the results of the balloting.

LEAD: The Senate early this morning approved a $26 billion deficit-reducing package, including $9 billion in tax increases, that is needed to carry out a major part of the budget compromise reached between Congress and the White House last month.

LEAD: Joseph Clark, a high school principal here who has won national acclaim as a disciplinarian, has been ordered to reinstate 50 students he had ejected because they were disciplinary problems and were not doing their school work.

LEAD: A wind-swept fire raced through a suburb of Rangoon, killing a five-year-old boy and leaving 2,500 people homeless, it was reported today. A primary school was among the 180 buildings and shanties destroyed in the two-hour blaze Wednesday, which started in a kitchen.

LEAD: Bond prices were battered yesterday as the dollar plunged to new lows in the wake of the record $17.6 billion trade deficit reported for October. The losses were most pronounced among the longer-term Treasury maturities as institutions struggled to sell bonds to uninterested buyers.
