LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union were able to end the summit meeting on a positive note not only because they had made some real progress but also because they sidestepped their central disagreement on the issue of testing space-based defensive weapons.

LEAD: What are you doing for New Year's? If you play football in the American Conference, don't make plans. For no one knows, with only three games remaining in the regular season, just who is going into the playoffs.

LEAD: Frederic V. Grunfeld, an author and journalist whose biography of the French sculptor Auguste Rodin was published last month, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Barcelona, Spain. He was 58 years old and lived near Deya, Majorca.

LEAD: Israeli troops shot and killed a West Bank resident and wounded at least 15 other Palestinians today as violent unrest continued for the second day and spread throughout the occupied territories.

LEAD: Dr. Hugh Roberts Williams, director of the Talbot County Mental Health Clinic in Easton, Md., from 1977 to 1985 and the in-patient psychiatrist at Franklin Square Hospital in Baltimore from 1985 until early this year, died Wednesday of prostatic cancer at his home in Royal Oak, Md. He was 65 years old.
LEAD: Dr. Louis Gray, a retired physician from New York City, died Wednesday at the National Orthopaedic Hospital in Arlington, Va. He was 98 years old and lived in Rockville, Md.

LEAD: Nearly a year after the death of a black man in Howard Beach, Queens, sparked one of the most bitter racial controversies in New York City in years, a jury began yesterday to deliberate the fate of four white teen-agers charged with murder or manslaughter in his death.

LEAD: THE annual ''Emerging Sculptors'' show at the Sculpture Center was organized by Marian Griffiths, the center's director, and bears her stamp. LEAD: The Kansas City Royals, and not the Yankees, got Floyd Bannister tonight when the Chicago White Sox sent Bannister to the Royals for four young pitchers. The trade ended a months-long scramble for the left-handed pitcher.

LEAD: The Long Island Philharmonic, under its music director, Christopher Keene, is to perform works by Martinu, Dello Joio and Tchaikovsky tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at Hauppauge High School in Hauppauge, L.I., and Sunday at 7:30 P.M. in the Tilles Center for the Performing Arts in Greenvale, L.I. Jerome Carrington will be the cello soloist.

LEAD: The cellist Yo-Yo Ma will discuss such issues as the Asianization of American music and the appeal of Western music in Asia tonight at 7 at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street. He is to speak along with the society's president, Robert B. Oxnam. Tickets are $10. Information: 517-8508.

LEAD: Anthony Griffin could scarcely have guessed that an argument with a cab driver here last month would end with Mr. Griffin dead in the parking lot of a police station, victim of a police bullet in the forehead. Much less could he have known that this would become a landmark in the troubled history of one of Quebec's forgotten minorities.
LEAD: Park Eung Soo, distraught over the potentially ruinous split in South Korea's political opposition, killed himself last weekend to express his unhappiness.

LEAD: A United Nations envoy has opened negotiations with the exiled King of Afghanistan and guerrilla leaders on a transitional government to take power if the Soviet Union withdraws its forces, diplomats and officials say.
LEAD: Giving to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has become a tradition closely linked to the holiday season, according to many donors.
LEAD: Elizabeth Harper Landon Gurlitz, a magazine editor for four decades, died last Friday at the Mediplex Home in Westport, Conn., where she had lived several years. She was 96 years old.

LEAD: The newly restored Rainbow Room is the subject of a series of tours and events on Sunday sponsored by the Municipal Arts Society. Tours begin at 11:30 A.M. and run through 2 P.M. with a buffet lunch throughout.
LEAD: A picture caption on Wednesday about CBS News film of a Soviet missile carrier misidentified its cargo. CBS later reported that it was not an SS-20 missile, only a canister used for one.

LEAD: The third Reagan-Gorbachev summit conference brought no major breakthroughs beyond the treaty banning medium-range missiles. But neither was there a breakdown as at Reykjavik, and hopes have been raised for more far-reaching agreements next year.

LEAD: LaMarr Hoyt, the American League Cy Young Award winner in 1983 when he pitched for the Chicago White Sox, yesterday denied an allegation in United States District Court in San Diego that he had violated terms of Federal probation by testing positive for cocaine use. LEAD: Ever illuminated, New York becomes even more incandescently lustrous in the weeks before Christmas as holiday lights flicker on, building tops are bathed in red-and-green spotlights and even familiar street lamps acquire a cool, wintry glow. From the malls of Park Avenue to the poinsettia-encircled ''trees from different lands'' at the New York Botanical Garden, evergreens of every description are already festooned with millions of lights.

LEAD: Bad news on the October trade deficit came right in the middle of the Washington summit conference. Even as President Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev explored arms control, there it was -stark confirmation that the Soviet Union is not the only superpower with economic problems. America's economy is also out of kilter, and the experts aren't sure how to fix it.

LEAD: The Empire Brass, conducted by Joseph Giunta, will perform works by Handel, Gabrieli, Rossini, Purcell, Prokofiev, Gershwin and others tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Carnegie Hall. Tickets are $14 to $25. Information: 247-7800.

LEAD: American Brands Inc. said it had agreed to sell its Pinkerton's Inc. security services unit to CPP Security Service Inc. of Van Nuys, Calif. Terms were not disclosed. Pinkerton's is the nation's oldest provider of security services. American Brands, based in Old Greenwich, Conn., had announced in October that it planned to divest the company as part of its strategy of concentrating on its core businesses: tobacco, distilled spirits, financial services and office products.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times. Mr. Gorbachev's remarks were translated by an official Soviet interpreter. OPENING STATEMENT

LEAD: Metropolitan Opera audiences who know Peter Hall only as the director of two famously lackluster productions, ''Macbeth'' and ''Carmen,'' must have a seriously distorted view of his talents. As often happens, the right man was hired for the wrong jobs. The prolific Englishman's work is more justly represented by his stagings of Mozart operas, particularly for the Glyndebourne Festival, of which he has been artistic director since 1984.

LEAD: What H. W. Fowler did for everybody, Bryan A. Garner, a 29-year-old associate at a Dallas law firm, set out to do for lawyers. The result, published this month by the Oxford University Press, is ''A Dictionary of Modern Legal Usage.''
LEAD: Seven weeks ago, in the Giants' first game after the National Football League players' strike, Stephen Baker made a play he could not forget. He wishes he could forget it.
LEAD: Tom G. Kessinger, a scholar on South Asia who heads the Ford Foundation's office in New Delhi, has been named president of Haverford (Pa.) College.

LEAD: Altamont and Allan Burke alternately expressed defiance and contrition today over the evidence that their brother David had fired shots aboard an airliner that led to its crash and the deaths of all aboard.

LEAD: One team has evidently undergone a formal regrouping. The other, also adrift at the bottom of the National Hockey League pack, continues to speak of a need for consistency, for positive breaks and attitudes, and for the players to get acquainted so that familiarity can breed something useful, like a winning streak.

LEAD: The Shadow Trend is apparent coast to coast, from San Francisco to New York: a newly energized movement that opposes big buildings in cities because they cast shadows, threaten views, crowd facilities and offend somebody's taste. But the virtuous opponents rarely explain how, without big new buildings, cities can end housing shortages, expand job opportunities and collect tax revenues.

LEAD: France has packed 14 Iranians and 3 Turks onto an airplane bound for Gabon in West Africa. An additional eight Iranians and a Turk are under house arrest. All were accused of harming French interests by plotting against the Khomeini regime. Oh no, says Paris, this isn't appeasement and has nothing to do with other efforts to placate Iran and gain the release of two French hostages held in Lebanon.
LEAD: Mayor Koch named Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the Deputy Borough President of Manhattan, to be Commissioner of Financial Services yesterday.

LEAD: In 1961, if Samuel R. Pierce Jr., then a partner at Battle, Fowler, Stokes & Kheel, had wanted to have lunch with another black who was a partner at a prominent New York City law firm, he would have had to dine alone.
LEAD: Donald Jackson, editor of the six-volume ''Papers of George Washington'' and other historical documents, died of cancer of the prostate Wednesday in Colorado Springs, Colo. He was 68 years old.

LEAD: The Chants Elysee Opera and Concert Ensemble will present a staged performance of Debussy's cantata ''L'Enfant Prodigue'' at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. Francisco Aybar, a pianist, is to give a recital of works by Schumann, Liszt and Albeniz on Sunday at 3:30 P.M.

LEAD: After every Presidential debate there is a scramble to declare the winners and losers. Did Gov. Michael S. Dukakis look Presidential on NBC last week, or merely subdued and tired? Did Alexander M. Haig Jr. inflict serious damage to Vice President Bush, or merely nip him around the ankles?

LEAD: In what Government officials are treating as a political assassination, unidentified gunmen killed a leading member of El Salvador's official Human Rights Office last night, officials said.

LEAD: Mayor Koch speaking with his sister, Pat Thaler, as Gail and Harold Koch, the mayor's sister-in-law and brother, listened during birthday party celebration last night at the Grand Hyatt Hotel. LEAD: The board of directors of the Pan Am Corporation has major reservations about some of the terms proposed by Jay A. Pritzker for the takeover of Pan American World Airways that will have to be resolved before he can gain control, a source close to the board said yesterday.

LEAD: British Airways raised its bid for all of British Caledonian Airways to more than $360 million today in a fierce battle with the Scandinavian Airlines System, which Wednesday night offered $200 million for 26 percent of British Caledonian.

LEAD: The Primate of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America is leading an effort to ease hostility between Greece and Turkey.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The U.S. trade deficit jumped to a record $17.6 billion in October as Christmas goods and other imports rose more than five times as much as exports. The result was far worse than analysts had expected and caused turmoil in the financial markets. The dollar fell to record lows against the yen and the mark, bond prices rose steeply and stocks fell.

LEAD: Plans to lease a 13-acre Times Square plot for the construction of four large office towers should be blocked until allegations of improprieties by the project's principal developer are fully investigated, speakers told a public hearing yesterday.

LEAD: A director of the Pennzoil Company said yesterday that the company ''had been making progress'' in talks with representatives of Texaco Inc.'s creditors and shareholders about a possible plan of reorganization for Texaco. Any such plan would include a settlement proposal between Pennzoil and Texaco in their legal dispute, which will be four years old next month.
LEAD: After years of losses throughout the Farm Credit System from depressed land values, a Federal land bank declared itself insolvent today, the first ever to do so.

LEAD: A picture caption in The Home Section yesterday about home improvement in Greenwich Village apartment misidentified two people. The man seated in the center was William F. Miller, a general contractor; the other man was Tom Brashares, a Manhattan architect.
LEAD: Have you ever seen a Soviet motorcade go backward?

LEAD: N.H.L. Bruins 4, Kings 3: A freak goal by Lyndon Byers in the second period broke a 2-2 tie last night as Boston collected its fourth victory in its last five games. Bobby Carpenter and Paul Fenton gave visiting Los Angeles a 2-1 lead in the first period, but the Kings couldn't hold it and were defeated for the sixth time in the past six games.

LEAD: After three months of trying to woo, cajole, persuade and perhaps even provoke the jury in the Howard Beach murder trial, each lawyer is now pinning his hopes on certain key jurors as he tensely awaits the verdict.

LEAD: The man who swallowed poison and died before he could be questioned about the disappearance of a South Korean airliner was probably a former North Korean diplomat, Japanese officials said today.
LEAD: The interior of the Biltmore Theater in Manhattan, which recently received landmark designation, was damaged by fire early yesterday in a blaze that officials say was deliberately set.

LEAD: A Congressional subcommittee charged today that politically motivated officials at the Office of Management and Budget improperly pressured health experts into adopting a regulation easing food labeling requirements and ''undercut the credibility'' of the Food and Drug Administration.

LEAD: Within Chile's increasingly heated electoral climate, the role of foreign governments, politicians and organizations has become a point of contention between President Augusto Pinochet and his opponents.

LEAD: New observations by radio telescopes strongly support the theory that stars form from collapsing gas clouds and indicate for the first time that the process is spawning dozens of stars at once, scientists reported yesterday.

LEAD: The education summit meeting called yesterday by Governor Cuomo marks an important first step toward reform of New York City's troubled school system. But as education and political leaders seek consensus on issues of school system governance, students at Manhattan's Park West High School face a more basic problem: personal safety.

LEAD: The New York State Thruway Authority, which has been plagued recently by a bridge collapse that took 10 lives and by scandals that claimed its two top executives, is now facing serious cash problems that make a toll increase of up to 30 percent likely this spring, according to its chairman, William C.

LEAD: A former airline passenger agent angry at his dismissal wrote his former supervisor a threatening note on an air-sickness bag shortly before the airliner carrying them crashed in central California on Monday, Federal agents said yesterday.

LEAD: It was there on the table in the Soviet press room all through the summit talks, a neat pile of copies of a document prepared in Moscow for American journalists covering the great event. Nobody paid attention to it, what with all the important meetings and statements and interviews.

LEAD: A housing expert working under a Federal judge's orders has identified nine privately owned sites here that he says could be used to build the public housing required under a desegregation order.
LEAD: Michael Fay, the New Zealand banker who has challenged the San Diego Yacht Club for the America's Cup next summer, may not be the only challenger.

LEAD: Despite the heavy snows of early October that damaged hundreds of thousands of trees in the Hudson Valley, cultivated Christmas trees weathered the storm in good shape and are now ready for harvest.

LEAD: Except for the red berets and metal-studded belts of the Guardian Angels, the people fighting could have been involved in just another street-corner brawl in Chelsea. Such fights have become common there since the crack epidemic began, residents say.

LEAD: The House agreed today to extend the life of its Iran-contra investigating committee into next year to provide for an orderly disposition of classified documents and continued access to the papers for those involved in follow-up inquiries.

LEAD: The International Olympic Committee's executive board in Lausanne, Switzerland, gave final approval yesterday for competition in the next year's Olympic Games to 18 athletes, including Ingemar Stenmark and Marc Girardelli, skiing stars, and Naim Suleymangolu, a weight lifter.

LEAD: The Italian magistrates investigating the Vatican bank scandal remain determined to prosecute an American Archbishop despite a court ruling in July that declared him beyond their juridiction, judicial officials say.
LEAD: The Democratic Presidential candidates raised the possibility of higher taxes to reduce the nation's budget deficit last night in their first joint appearance before a New York audience.

LEAD: Thousands of passengers stampeded onto a fog-delayed ferry in Shanghai today, and 11 people were killed and 76 injured in the crush, the official New China News Agency said. The stampede occurred as thousands of people pushed forward when the vessel docked after a delay of several hours.
LEAD: With income tax rates dropping on Jan. 1, taxpayers can benefit by finding ways to defer income until next year.

LEAD: The Yankees, who have tried and failed all week to get a left-handed-hitting outfielder in a trade, appeared to be close today to securing one on the free-agent market. The agent for Mike Davis said there was a strong chance Davis would soon reach agreement with the Yankees.

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 410 money market mutual funds increased $522.6 million, to $262.41 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 111 institutional funds decreased $361.1 million, to $73.20 billion. Assets of the 206 general-purpose funds increased $294 million, to $79.89 billion.

LEAD: OLIVER STONE'S ''Wall Street'' is a gentrified ''Everyman,'' an upscale morality tale to entertain achievers who don't want to lose touch with their moral centers, but still have it all.

LEAD: The GTE Corporation announced yesterday that James L. Johnson had been elected to succeed Theodore F. Brophy as chairman and chief executive when Mr. Brophy retires at age 65 in April after 30 years at the telecommunications company.
LEAD: The two major victories this season for Dayton, Wagner's opponent for the Division III national championship, were over Ithaca College and Augustana of Illinois.
LEAD: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries suspended deliberations today to allow mediation of the sharply divergent views of Iran and Iraq on production policies.

Mr. Feltsman is replacing Rudolf Serkin, who canceled his recital because of illness. Tickets are $22.50 and $25. Information: (516) 922-0061.

LEAD: The prosecutor told the jury at the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver today that Mr. Deaver's exploitation of his 20-year friendship with Ronald and Nancy Reagan to enhance his lobbying business may have ''broken their hearts.''

LEAD: The Federal Reserve and 11 foreign central banks announced a preliminary agreement today to increase the required capital base of banks, seeking to create a bigger cash cushion in the world banking system.
LEAD: About 5,000 New York employees are expected to lose their jobs when E. F. Hutton & Company merges with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. next month, executives of the two companies said here today.

LEAD: Japan's trade surplus shrank in November for the seventh month in a row, falling 36 percent from a year earlier as the stronger yen continued to affect the country's imports and exports, the Government said today. LEAD: Glasnost has entered the international vocabulary as a catchword for a general liberalization of Soviet society. But in the Soviet Union itself, glasnost is a term whose meaning and practice are matters of intense debate.

LEAD: Armour Pharmaceutical is recalling 208 lots of a blood clotting agent distributed for hemophilia patients because of the possibility it could contain the AIDS virus, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

LEAD: The 22d game of the world chess championship between the titleholder, Gary Kasparov, and his challenger, Anatoly Karpov, was agreed drawn today after just 19 moves. The score is tied, 11 to 11, with just two games remaining.

LEAD: The complainant in a sexual-misconduct trial retracted her accusation yesterday that a judge had humiliated her by ordering her on her hands and knees to re-enact a rape. She said the Brooklyn District Attorney's office had coerced her into making the false accusation, according to her lawyer.
LEAD: In its deliberations over the bill to reduce the Federal deficit, the Senate dropped two measures concerning television and radio broadcasting.

LEAD: Barbarity has returned to the treatment of sick prisoners, thanks to a prison guards' lawsuit and a timid judge. Chaining such prisoners to their hospital beds is not just cruel; it's superfluous. But the guards insist that this is a matter of collective bargaining, not humanity. They will have a hard time making that case; meanwhile, why do the courts insist on putting back the chains?
LEAD: The Senate today unanimously approved President Reagan's nomination of Ann Dore McLaughlin, a former Under Secretary of the Interior, to be Secretary of Labor.

LEAD: The Philadelphia 76ers, already weakened in the frontcourt by injuries to Tim McCormick, a 7-foot center, and Roy Hinson, a 6-9 forward, suffered another setback yesterday. LEAD: ''The Wild Pair,'' which sneaked into the Criterion and other theaters yesterday, is about an F.B.I. man (white) and a big cop (black) who join together to bring down a big drug pusher (black) and a sadistic ex-Marine colonel (white) who is on a private mission to save America from lesser races. The good guys are played by Bubba Smith and Beau Bridges, who also directed.

LEAD: A couple have settled a lawsuit against an anti-abortion group that took them to court because they withheld extraordinary life support from their newborn baby, their lawyer says.

LEAD: Should electricity users be allowed to charge a hefty portion of their bills to the U.S. Treasury? A little-noticed provision in the House-passed deficit reduction bill would make such shuffles more difficult by limiting use of tax-exempt bonds to finance utility buyouts. By going along, Senate conferees would strike a blow for fiscal responsibility.

LEAD: Consumer prices rose 7.9 percent in November, bringing inflation for the first 11 months of 1987 to a record 125.8 percent, the central bank has announced. November's rate was down from October's 8.3 percent rise, according to figures released by the Bank of Mexico. Private analysts have predicted that inflation for the year could go as high as 140 percent, well above the previous annual record of 105.7 percent, reached in 1986.

LEAD: The recent revelation that Transit Police officers made scores of illegal arrests for alleged sex abuse and other crimes in 1983 and 1984 is only the beginning of what promises to be a long and sorry story. It is fast becoming clear that the ill-advised practice of measuring police productivity by arrest quotas is responsible for a far more extensive pattern of false arrests and for undermining the credibility of an entire police agency.
LEAD: An important committee of the General Assembly voted overwhelmingly today to condemn a Congressional attempt to close the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer mission here.
LEAD: For the last four years, the Oerlemans family has been picking up pennies, nickels and dimes as well as foreign coins from the streets of New York City, and this week they gave it all back.
LEAD: Dr. Sidney Yudin, a New York City psychologist, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 66 years old.

LEAD: Since the birthdays of George Washington and Abraham Lincoln are national holidays, at least for this year let's look at today as a holiday, too. John Jay, probably the most unheralded of the Founding Fathers, was born 242 years ago.

LEAD: All American workers will soon be able to obtain estimates of their Social Security benefits and how much their families would receive if they die or become disable, the head of the $200 billion pension and disability program said Thursday.

LEAD: An article on Wednesday about the funeral of the author James Baldwin misstated the frequency of funerals held in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Manhattan. Funerals are held there regularly.

Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, acknowledged general support for the Olympic movement, the aide said, he would not promise that a team from his country would attend the Summer Games next September in Seoul, South Korea.

LEAD: Several mischievous amendments are waiting as the House gets ready to vote next week on reauthorization of the Endangered Species Act, one of the most effective environmental laws ever enacted. The most troubling, offered by Solomon Ortiz of Texas, would delay new regulations requiring shrimp fishermen to use excluder devices that permit sea turtles to escape their nets.
LEAD: The Sports of The Times column yesterday and its picture caption misidentified the former women's world darts champion. She is Sandy Reitan.

LEAD: LIKE other stock market investors, the 40 million mutual fund shareholders learned several important lessons from the record plunge on Oct. 19. Indeed, they were awakened to some of the realities of the investment world.

LEAD: Leonard Slatkin of the St. Louis Symphony is conducting the New York Philharmonic for three weeks this month. LEAD: N.H.L. Gretzky Passes Esposito: Wayne Gretzky reached another scoring plateau, and Grant Fuhr stood out in goal in leading the Oilers to a 2-1 triumph last night over the Vancouver Canucks at Edmonton. Gretzky moved into sole possession of third place on the league's career scoring list with 1,591 points.

LEAD: David Frishberg, the Los Angeles-based songwriter and performer, is a consummate craftsman of pop-jazz songs whose lyrics have the cutting precision of the best light verse. In the refinement of his language, he is equaled only by Stephen Sondheim among contemporary American songwriters. But instead of theater songs, he writes jazz tunes filtered through the climate of Hollywood movie music.
LEAD: Ralph Nading Hill, a well-known writer and preservationist, died Thursday of a stroke at the Medical Center Hospital of Vermont, in Burlington. He was 70 years old.

LEAD: Walter Anderson, an investigator in the office of the Queens District Attorney for 25 years, died Wednesday at the Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Lloyd Harbor, L.I.

LEAD: County Natwest Ltd. announced today that it would acquire Wood Mackenzie & Company, an Edinburgh-based brokerage house, in the most significant consolidation move in the British securities industry since the worldwide stock market plunge in October.
LEAD: Pope John Paul II cleared the way today for the beatification of the Rev. Junipero Serra, the founder of nine Spanish missions in California.
LEAD: Vice President Bush resumed his pursuit of the Republican Presidential nomination today with some help from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration established a new process today to decide whether Cubans held in American prisons should be sent back to Cuba, but lawyers for the inmates said the procedures were inadequate.

LEAD: Public television's ''Mystery!'', packaged by WGBH of Boston and underwritten by Mobil, is on a nifty winning streak these days. Having just finished a splendid trio of Dorothy L. Sayers adaptations, with Edward Petherbridge as Lord Peter Wimsey, the series is now returning to Agatha Christie's Miss Marple stories, once again starring Joan Hickson as the venerable but dogged sleuth.

LEAD: Thomson McKinnon Securities announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Carolina Securities Corporation, a Raleigh, N.C., brokerage house. No purchase price was disclosed.
LEAD: The duo of Ronnie Mathews, pianist, and Ray Drummond, bassist, perform tonight at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440). Music begins at 9:45 P.M.; there is no cover charge or minimum.

LEAD: A judge ignored pleas for leniency by defense lawyers and Federal prosecutors today and sentenced a former state legislator to eight years in prison for his role in a $20 million swindle of a union pension fund.
LEAD: For the second time, a Federal appeals court today invalidated a rule of the Federal Communications Commission that required cable television companies to carry all local stations.

LEAD: Because the world can be a scary place, many people go forth armed - not with Uzis, Mac-10's or Berettas but with an understanding of body language. Now Dr. Paul Ekman, an expert in the muscles of emotional expression, has added a new weapon. He and his colleagues, Wallace Friesen and Maureen O'Sullivan, have found a sure way to detect the crocodile smile.

LEAD: In a surprise move, E. F. Hutton & Company announced at a staff meeting yesterday that it would begin to lay off its employees on Tuesday and that those dismissed would be expected to leave the day they receive notice, according to several people who attended the meeting.

LEAD: ''THE blatant sexism of Ira Berkow's column on Chris Evert - 'Too Much in Love?' - left me sputtering, 'What! I don't believe this!' ''

LEAD: The United States will continue to protect its maritime industry, and Canada its publishing and film industries, under an agreement aimed at eliminating most restrictions on their bilateral trade by the year 2000.

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev stopped here today on his way home from the Washington summit meeting and was given a triumphal welcome by other Warsaw Pact leaders and thousands of East Berliners who cheered him along the motorcade route.

LEAD: Chris Mullin was suspended for last night's game by the Golden State Warriors, a day after he missed a practice for the second time this season. Mullin failed to show up for practice on Thursday and was barred from practice and the game against the Atlanta Hawks. Coach George Karl, who met with team officials Thursday night to discuss the situation, said the starting guard would be fined.
LEAD: A fire destroyed four stores on the boardwalk in Wildwood, N.J., last night and caused heavy damage to other businesses.

LEAD: This city, designated several years ago as the most livable in the United States, had for five years been as hospitable to Billy Smith as could be imagined. But tonight, he got a sense of how quickly the old neighborhood had changed.

LEAD: An independent blood test on Joyce Brown, the first street person involuntarily hospitalized under a new Koch administration program, found that she was not suffering from a medical ailment suggested by city doctors. Her lawyers immediately renewed their pleas for her release.

LEAD: The Soviet flag flew high at the Reagan White House. Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, pressed the flesh on Connecticut Avenue and beguiled members of Congress. And both he and President Reagan pronounced their summit meeting a solid success. Whether or not that assessment seems justified after close examination of their labors, it surely succeeded in the largest sense.

LEAD: The first settlement between bondholders and some of the utilities participating in the Washington Public Power Supply System nuclear plants has been reached in New York.
LEAD: The baseball market was rocked today by two deals that involved 13 players and four teams, including the Yankees and the Mets, who had never before made a trade involving a major-league player.

LEAD: Mary Schmidt Campbell, New York's new Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, appointed Charmaine Jefferson as her deputy yesterday. Ms. Jefferson is the 33-year-old general manager of the Dance Theater of Harlem and a former government official.
LEAD: The crossword puzzle clues yesterday omitted an entry for 33 down. It should have been Wag.

LEAD: Mary Overlie performs infrequently in New York. The three solos she presented on Thursday at the Kitchen made that fact seem even sadder, given the grandeur and refinement of the dances and performing.

LEAD: The jailed wife of convicted spy Jonathan Jay Pollard today was transferred from a prison hospital in Kentucky to one affiliated with the Mayo Clinic for treatment of a digestive disorder, Government officials and family members said. A Justice Department official said Anne Henderson Pollard, who was given a five-year term in March after pleading guilty to charges related to her husband's sale of state secrets to Israel, was checked into Methodist Hospital in Rochester, Minn.
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration told Americans today to avoid eating mussels, oysters and clams from the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Canada.

LEAD: With only a few hours left before the scheduled end of the summit meeting, American and Soviet officials were still wrangling at the White House over how to overcome their differences on how strictly a 1972 treaty limits the ''Star Wars'' missile defense program.

LEAD: Treasury bond prices continued to decline yesterday in what dealers termed one of the slowest trading days of the year. Most of the losses were unrealized, however, because they consisted more of dealer price-cutting than actual sales. Despite price cuts of up to three-quarters of a point on the longest maturity, buyers were rare, dealers said.

LEAD: Alain Chevrier, Devils' goalie, blocking shot in first period last night at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Flames went on to win, 5-1. Page 57. (The New York Times/Angel Franco)
LEAD: THE newest hotel in New Haven was actually built in 1847. Developed by Michael Franford of Woodbridge, the Inn at Chapel West began life as a large, Federal-style two-family house.

LEAD: HUNGER is an urgent problem in the cities and rural areas of the state, according to the Rev. Robert Betts, the director of the Connecticut Food Bank in New Haven. Mr. Betts, an ordained Episcopal priest and a social worker, struggles daily with the problem of hunger.

LEAD: The trade deficit jumped to a record $17.6 billion in October, with imports rising by 12.3 percent while exports edged up only 3 percent. The gap was much worse than had been predicted by the experts, most of whom were expecting it to be no worse than $15 billion. October is a big month for importing Christmas goods, but there were signs that the report could not be dismissed as a seasonal quirk.

LEAD: Nicodemo (Little Nicky) Scarfo, who law-enforcement authorities say is the boss of organized crime in Pennsylvania and New Jersey, and four other men were acquitted of Federal drug conspiracy charges today.

LEAD: Gail English Loflin, a daughter of John J. Loflin of Rye, N.Y., and the late Bonnie Loflin, and Steven Alexander Wolff, the son of Joan M. Wolff of Port Chester, N.Y., and Joel C. Wolff of New York, plan to marry in June.
LEAD: Mookie's batting and fielding are excellent, and his mere presence offers continuity in a business where managements change players as often as most people change shirts.

LEAD: IT WOULD BE THE BIGGEST, costliest, most provocative biomedical research project in history, and the United States must embark on it immediately. That was how Walter Gilbert, Nobel Prize-winning biology professor at Harvard University, heard the genome project described at scientific meetings all through 1985 and 1986.

LEAD: Eleven months before the 1988 Congressional elections, more than 100 officials of political action committees gathered recently at Democratic Party headquarters to hear suggestions on how to spend their money.

LEAD: A TRULY capitalist country is one that can afford not one but several annual collections of ''best'' short stories. While short story collections used to be notoriously poor sellers, they are proliferating - which means either that the market for them has improved, or that American literature has, in some improbable way, transcended the question of sales.

LEAD: Television's Christmas traditions may not be very old, but they are strictly observed. When it comes to holiday movies, no viewer will be surprised to learn, for example, that Sunday night Frank Capra's heart-warmer, ''It's a Wonderful Life'' (1946), is offered on Channel 9 at 6 P.M. James Stewart, Donna Reed and Lionel Barrymore do the string-tugging.

LEAD: Israeli soldiers shot and wounded at least five residents of the occupied Gaza Strip today, as shopkeepers throughout the West Bank shuttered their stores to protest the violence that has left six Palestinians dead in four days.

LEAD: JUST last spring, New York City was, as its political leaders were delighted to report, wealthy. It was rolling in money that was going to buy all sorts of things that politicians like to give to the people who elect them: More police officers, more teachers, better schools, cleaner streets.
LEAD: Even the weather conspires against the battered nation of Cambodia, which is already short of money, expertise, labor, reliable statistics and communications with the outside world.

LEAD: Day and Night for All Ages Rainbow Restoration Dec. 13 - After two years of refurbishing, the two-story complex atop the RCA Building at Rockefeller Center will reopen to the public Dec. 29. But first, three preliminary events will introduce guests to the restored glitter of one of the premier nightspots in the city.

LEAD: Thousands of convictions for drunken driving in Pennsylvania are now in question because of faulty breath analyzers that led to arrest for the innocent and release for the guilty, a state official says.

Kennedy of Winchester, Mass. The future bride, who graduated magna cum laude from Tufts University, is a candidate for a master's degree in communications and international relations at Boston University.

LEAD: The city is drawing up plans to move several black families early next year into public housing projects in South Boston, the predominantly white community that exploded in the 1970's when students were bused to integrate the city's schools.

LEAD: Hedrick Smith of Chevy Chase, Md., and Ann B. Smith of Arlington, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laurel Ann Smith to William Kirk Doggett 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Doggett Jr. of Wellesley Hills, Mass.

LEAD: The slim young prince arrived in a silver carriage, wearing a scarlet and gold tunic draped with pearls, diamonds and rubies. The princess emerged from an immense fairy tale palace that shimmered with strands of white lights.
LEAD: THE park has been our refuge for the last three seasons. From the earliest days of tolerable spring through the warm autumn, my son and I have visited our sanctuary religiously.

LEAD: To the Editor: I found the article on the Weissensee Cemetery in East Berlin (Travel, Nov. 8) of great interest. My grandparents are buried in this cemetery and I have visited there four times in the last 15 years.

LEAD: SOME houses on a tree-lined street in Katonah have had a hard life. First, in about 1895, they were lifted from their foundations and hauled a mile south on horse-drawn rollers. Then, after sitting there for a peaceful half century they were rattled and shaken for years by truck traffic.
LEAD: A PRIVATE terrace is a special amenity for an apartment dweller squeezed into a high-rise building. It is the closest thing to having a backyard, and those who have them guard them jealously.

LEAD: It is a crucial time for the Jets, and the man who is attempting to lead them against the New England Patriots today is the stolid Ken O'Brien, the quarterback with the cannon arm and a turtle's feet.

LEAD: IN the early 1970's, officials in this Chicago suburb closed their two main shopping streets to traffic, planted trees and grass and flowers where there had been concrete, and turned the whole area into a landscaped pedestrian mall. The hope was to revitalize a fading downtown, and lure back shoppers and retailers from those other malls, the large regional shopping centers that had stolen them away.

LEAD: I enjoy turning first to the last page of The New York Times Magazine to see what you have decided to feature in Works in Progress. The photographs are invariably interesting, and sometimes evocative (''Gearing Up for the Holidays,'' Nov. 15).
LEAD: A LESSON in the art of drinking Champagne is neatly provided in a single picture by the French Ambassador to the United States, Emmanuel de Margerie; his wife, Helene, and Mayor Koch.

LEAD: CONDOMINIUM developers are turning to clearance sales, low down payments and other marketing techniques to help sell an overload of new condominium apartments in Manhattan. But sales activity has grown sluggish as the financial trauma on Wall Street intensifies a traditional winter downturn.

LEAD: JOE PATERNO was honored last night at the Waldorf-Astoria as the 80th recipient of the Pennsylvania Society's Gold Medal for Distinguished Achievement. The society donated $25,000 in the Penn State coach's name to the university's Joe Paterno Library Endowment Fund. Paterno donated $150,000 to launch the fund in May 1986.

LEAD: Defense Minister Humberto Ortega Saavedra said today that Nicaragua plans to more than double its military forces over the next seven years and increase the number of warplanes and other weapons over fear of a United States invasion.

LEAD: Kathryn Mary Brown and Alexander Penn Hill Wyrough, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Wyrough of Upper Marlboro, Md., plan to marry in June, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John S. Brown of Princeton, N.J., have announced.

LEAD: After four days of futile talks, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries failed today to reach an agreement to end the rampant discounts and runaway oil production that are undercutting the cartel.

LEAD: After all those years with all those injuries, everything seemed to turn round for Phil Simms. In 1984, he passed for 4,044 yards, a Giant record. LEAD: The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, which saw its proposal to build a $185 million baseball stadium turned down by voters last month, suffered a second setback this week when its request for $60 million in state money was denied.

LEAD: IF YOU are still scratching your head about what to give your executive spouse or Wall Street friend for the holidays, and want to buy something with a financial theme, here are some suggestions. There is even an idea or two for the budding 5-year-old investment banker in the family.

LEAD: STONY BROOK'S Country House is much like a big Christmas tree now, awash with light and beckoning to all who see it. The large white Colonial is arresting at any time of year, but during the holiday season it's especially dazzling.

LEAD: MY grandson has a Jewish mother and a Catholic father. This is not unusual. There is hardly a family today in which someone hasn't married outside the faith. What is unusual is that my grandson, now 5 years old, is making me aware of my religion.

LEAD: ONE would almost think that America's moralizing politics had beached up on France's worldly shores. The fall season had been taken up with a scrappy tennis match in which the right served up a financial or personal scandal at the left only to have the left slam one back; the right won in, let's say, three sets.
LEAD: IN Turkey where it flourished in the 15th century, marbled paper making was known as ebru, or the art of the clouds.

LEAD: N.B.A. Nuggets 131, 76ers 121: Jay Vincent scored a season-high 33 points as the Denver Nuggets built a 19-point lead and then held off the 76ers yesterday in Philadelphia. After trailing by 87-68 early in the third quarter, the 76ers closed the deficit to 120-116 with 2 minutes 9 seconds to play when Gerald Henderson tapped in a missed free throw.

LEAD: Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois got a bargain of sorts yesterday by spending a mere $330,000 - less than half of what he'd planned - to buy Frank Lloyd Wright furniture and architectural drawings at auction.

LEAD: Yes, the Mets should keep Mookie Wilson. We fans are asked to be loyal to teams even though management charges a lot for a game, sells expensive concessions, builds ever bigger impersonal stadiums and bombards us with clacky music and commercials. Then, on top of that, the owners blithely trade players we enjoy - Hubie Brooks, Kevin Mitchell, Jeff Reardon, Ray Knight, Jesse Orosco, Rafael Santana.

LEAD: IT is one of the world's great urban parks, rivalling the Bois de Boulogne in Paris, the Imperial Gardens in Tokyo and Central Park in New York. But for the 20 million residents of Mexico City, the Bosque de Chapultepec is more than just a vast verdant expanse in the heart of the city. LEAD: ONE could say that in ''Laughing Stock,'' Romulus Linney is getting at the essence of writing and pondering the purpose of life. But that would make Mr. Linney's work sound pompous, and it isn't. It's a treat and a tonic.
LEAD: A lighted cross atop a Christmas tree in the town of Hyde Park should be removed because it is ''a symbol of the Christian beliefs of the community,'' a Federal magistrate has ruled.

LEAD: A strong earthquake with a preliminary reading of 5.6 on the Richter scale occurred in the Pacific Ocean off central Japan today, the Hong Kong observatory reported. The observatory said the quake hit at 12:56 P.M. and its epicenter was about 340 miles south of Tokyo in an area where several small islands are located.

LEAD: GOLD CUP RACERS Baby Bootlegger, a fully restored 30-foot powerboat that won the Gold Cup Races in 1924 and 1925 will be on display at Mystic Seaport until April 10 in an exhibition titled ''A Gentlemanly Pursuit: Gold Cup Racing in the 1920's.''

LEAD: I have just read Albert F. Cafiero's article regarding improving rail service rather than widening our congested highways. [ ''Why Widening Congested Highways Is the Wrong Route to Follow,'' Nov. 15 ] .
